Quote:
On the street,
methamphetamine has
a range of nicknames
including "speed",
"pure", "P" "burn"
"goey", "crank",
"meth", "crystal",
"ice" and "Ya Ba".
It can be a powder,
a crystal 'rock'
like form, or a
pill.The nickname
"P" is unique to New
Zealand.

Authorities have
seized $95 million
worth of crystal
methamphetamine -
nearly enough to
supply one million
people with
individual hits of
the drug P.

"I've just got out
of Mt Eden jail and
75 percent of the
people in my yard
there were in there
for P or P-related
offences."... What
Dave and his
jailmates want is
Pure (P for short),
which is the street
name for pure uncut
methamphetamine.

"I understand it
commonly happens in
Rotorua. I haven't
seen a dog on P, but
I've heard about it
from drug squad
police at
conferences." Though
there was no
suggestion the
Manaia dogs were on
P, an armed
policewoman was on
hand as they were
cornered and loaded
into a dog van.

Cooking up the
methamphetamine drug
P in an illegal
laboratory of
volatile chemicals
is like putting your
head in a can of
petrol, police say.

Pure
methamphetamine,
known as pure or
"P", has become more
popular and there
has been a
corresponding rise
in arrests of people
bringing in the
drugs used to make
it. They include flu
and cold remedies,
known as
pseudoephedrines.
"P" has been
associated with
crimes.

The one chapter of
Black Power had lost
not one but several
members to P, and
their violent
endings had deeply
shaken a culture
dependent on
excessive aggression
as a right of
passage and
acceptance.

Q: What's the best
thing about P? / A:
Only two sleeps till
Christmas.

P (crystal
methamphetamine,
burn, shabu, crystal
meth): Virtually
pure, also known as
ice. Has a
distinctive
rock-crystal
appearance. Tends to
make users feel
invincible.

Chances are they are
into New Zealand's
latest drug craze-
methamphetamine...
New Zealand is
coming a of age and
'P' is here to stay,
not just for 2002,
and is freely
available in the
'scene'.

Staff at Wellington
Women's Refuge say a
steady rise in
violent crime over
the past 18 months
is linked with
soaring use of P, or
pure
methamphetamine,
among white,
middle-aged men...
Now we're seeing
burglars being
driven by the need
to get money to feed
their P habit... She
was a full-blown
addict by 25. P
turned her into
"God".

The methamphetamine
explosion has
coincided with the
appearance of a
highly pure form of
the drug, known on
the streets as P. It
is sold in
crystalline form -
like crack cocaine -
and is 70%-80%
pure... While powder
speed is snorted,
users heat P in the
bottom of a glass
pipe and inhale the
smoke - a similar
process to taking
crack.

The current drug of
choice, "P",
otherwise known as
points, is a pure
form of crystal
methamphetamine and
is being cooked up
and smoked in
lounges, toilets and
bars throughout the
country.

I work for a
cannabis-friendly
pipe shop and
although the
procession of
unsavoury
individuals looking
for "P"-pipes has
slowed, because we
don't sell them, we
still get the new
ones: fresh-faced
young people from
good homes, poised
to try "P" for the
first time.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Moving to the
corner, with the P.
& T. workshop on his
left ...

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
The Post and
Telegraph of
Christchurch were
playing the College.
... two `All Blacks'
were included in the
P. & T. Team, Deans
and Wood, the latter
playing in the
three-quarter line.
... [67] The game
see-sawed to the
tune of P. & T.
leading.

A friend.. said he
told her he had been
"P-ing out" - on
pure speed - for
most of the weekend.

[Harry Highet's]
seven-foot P-class,
produced in 1922,
became the standard
and is arguably the
reason for New
Zealand's leadership
in international
yachting.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
They came round
raffling off a
P-class yacht for a
bob a ticket.

"I was given a
P-class by my uncle.
..."

What if she had a
hoody and some track
pants on? Does that
make her an evil
drug smoking,
alcoholic p-head as
well?

Gleefully anti-PC - the boys are described as "dumb-ass P-heads and no-hopers" by Carol Hirschfeld in a cameo - bro'Town revels in skewering Polynesian culture, Auckland, single parents, smug Pakehas, gays, and Indian dairy owners in equal measure.

P.B. - Permanent
Base.

Quaffing fiery
bumpers of P.B. [in
a pub].

Author: bath
Quote:
Thatcher, a witty
singer of topical
songs, seized upon
the incident which
he recounted at his
next entertainment
partly in recitative
interspersed with
songs, and in
describing the
incident in the bar
told how another
leading citizen
approached the
victim, and after
the manner of Madam
Escott warbled: Take
this glass of nice
P.B./ Which I now
hold in my hand,/
Tis of the brand of
Hennissy/ Taste this
most superior brand/
The amount of
drinking that went
on in those days was
very much greater
than has been the
case for very many
years. Pale brandy
or P.B. was the
favourite spirit [in
Dunedin, 1860s], and
a sparkling moselle,
which was dubbed
champagne, was
popular under the
name of No. 2. There
was even a bar on
board the harbour
steamer ... and I
have heard No. 2
called for there on
the way to Port
Chalmers. ...

P.H. HELMET. - A
kind of helmet worn
as a protection
against poison gas.

The new men are ...
Stallworthy (son of
old John of Kaipara
& head of the
P.P.A.) [ed fn:
Protestant Political
Association.]
Minister of Health.

Author: CRAWFORD
Quote:
You have bought a
good bit of the run
now ... The P.R. up
the White Rock river
is very stoney.
Notes: 1878 Jan McCaw in 1981 Crawford Station Years 122

Quote: P.U.'s. - See `Lead-Swinging.' Lead-Swinging. - See P.U.'s - they can tell you. The origin of this term is obscure - the destination, Blighty, or the clink.

Source: My Little State Home in Suburbia
Author: COOZE
Quote:
Odds and ends. ....
carted out to the

hard-working P.W.
Dears to clear.

Pink and fresh /
little townie PA
teachers, staring up
like virgins

Author: BACON
Quote:
' ... This is your
first country
appointment, isn't
it?' I nodded

appointment
anywhere. I was a
P.A. last year.'

Author: ASHTON-WARNER
Quote:
I found myself,
before the P.A. year
was over, setting up
... number 589 as an
artists' studio.

Cook describes a
hippa or eppah as
enclosed on three
sides, and the place
chosen could not
have been better if
the best engineer in
England had been
employed to choose
it.

Author: Ihimaera ed.
Quote:
She had pored over
pictures of Hokianga
- a seascape of
luminous dunes and
tides, a landscape
of pa sites and
legends...

Have since learnt that they have strongholds - or hippas, as they call them. [Hawkesworth spelt it, Heppahs] Ibid. (1955) 1/217 We pass'd round a point of land on which stood a Heppa or fortified village. [fn5] pa: Heppah from he pa, `it is a pa.'
Near the village was the ruins of an old Indian Eppah or Fort.

... they have strong
holds or happa' s as
they call them.

Author: PARKINSON
Quote:
Near the entrance to
this river, which
they named the
Thames, there was a
village, and a
Hippa, or place of
refuge, erected to
defend it, which was
surrounded by
piquets that reached
above the water when
the tide was up; ...

... several large
heppas were in sight
...

Author: MARSDEN
Quote:
This hippah (Te
Puke) is situated at
the mouth of the
fresh-water river on
a beautiful eminence
which commands the
River Thames both
above and below.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: P|a, s. An elevated village; ... a place cleared for residence.

Author: CRUISE
Quote: In the morning some of the gentlemen accompanied Krokro to his pah or fort, where he then resided, and which was about a mile from the ship.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: At 3 pm came to an Anchor at Parkinneigh [Pakanae] a Village and had I suppose 150 Natives on board and a par [pa] or Fort about 12 miles from the Heads. Ibid. 33 Hattay [crossed out by Markham] or Ettay [heti] is a Tea tree, quite different to the Tea tree bush, a sort of myrtle; as Parr a Fort and Hipparr [he pa] a Fort in Cooke, / is put down The Hip or Hit, is only the Article. Tay, it is useless, it only grows eight to twelve feet and the bark rough, and does not change. It seems very often Solitary. Away from every other Tree.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: Capt Cook went to the Hipa [p-grave] & dug there up some more ground & sowed Strawberries, ... Sellery & Parsley.

Author: DARWIN
Quote:
These are the Pas,
so frequently
mentioned by Captain
Cook under the name
of `hippah;' the
difference of sound
being owing to the
prefixed article.

Author: YATE
Quote:
The Pa, or native
fortification, is a
place in which the
natives of single
tribes ... when
living near each
other ... assemble
in times of war, and
secure themselves,
their wives, their
children, and their
slaves, from the
attacks of the
enemy.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Previous to our arrival at the Pa [a-acute], or fortified village, I halted for my companions [76] in a deep glen, from which the settlement was not visible.

They put us into a
fenced place which
they called a `par',
a sort of stockade;
there they kept us
three days, naked as
we were; they gave
us some potatoes.
Notes: 1834 Aug 22 Examination of John Guard from Sir R. Bourke's Despatch 4 in Parliamentary Papers Relating to NZ (Canterbury Public Library)

Quote: Lesson gives a footnote of which the following is a translation: `Navigators write this word in a variety of ways. The English have adopted hippa, and some of the French write pa. I prefer i-pah, which means THE PAH, as being more in keeping with the spirit of our language.
Notes: 1838-1839 R.P. Lesson footnote in Voyage autour du monde sur la corvette La Coqille transl. Diana Quarmby in 1971 Duperrey's Visit to New Zealand in 1824 54

Quote: DECLARATION of Sovereignty over Tavai Poenammoo. This island, called Tavai Poenammoo or Middle Island of New Zealand ... was accordingly taken possession of ... and Her Majesty's colours hoisted at the paa of Hoiakaka, Cloudy Bay ...
Notes: 1840 June 17 Thomas Bunbury's Report [paa] in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 112

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
The natives who
reside at Pah
Taranaki [Te Aro,

complained to me ...

Author: POLACK
Quote:
Pa or E'Pa (the
fort) and written by
Cook as Hippah.

Quote:
AAA. Reserves ...
that on Thorndon
Flat is occupied by

Quote:

. . .2200 natives

Author: FORSTER
Quote: ... where the strong hold of the Natives is & which they call a Hepa [e-grave].
pa: Heppah from he pa, `it is a pa.'

Author: KENDALL
Quote: I and Mr. Hall accompanied him to his principal hipwah (pa) or town, called Ranghee Hoo (Rangihoua). It consists of several warrees (whares) or small huts about five feet in height, seven in breadth, and eight or ten feet in length.
Notes: 1814 Sep 6 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 59

Author: KENDALL
Quote: When he landed two or three of the principal natives surrounded him, and, pointing to the island where the hippah (pa) formerly stood, ...

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote: [hippah] [Korra-Korra] thought it most advisable for us to accept an invitation, which his uncle Bennee gave us, to visit his hippah, or fortified village.

When we got upon the

which is very high,
we had a full view

which was situated

Author: ANGAS
Quote: The New Zealander has a fixed and settled habitation: he resides in his pah, which is afortified stockade; or in Kainga Maori, or native settlement, which is not enclosed, where the houses are scattered about as in a village.

Slept on the site of
former pah and in
the humu's.
To enforce this tapu they have constructed a pa on Rawiri's section on the Bell Block ...
Notes: 1854 Sep 20 Taranaki Herald in 1856 Fitton NZ 153

Quote:
[Caption to

Native village with

The Pah from the

Quote:
Curious customs in

He'd shelled an

Quote:
Another time I rode
to a `pah,' or
fortified village,
surrounded on all

fence.

A sally was made
from the pah, but it
was easily repulsed.
Within the pah the
enemy were secure.

Author: TREGEAR
Quote: A Maori village of the old days was, if of importance, always a pa or fortress, although small temporary abodes might be made among the cultivations on lower lands.

~ n. a native settlement or fort surrounded by a stockade; a fortified village. [Maori]

This pah, the

Rauparaha, ...

The Maori word for a
Maori fort with its
ditches and

Quote: The fortified hill-top village, the pa, was capable of offering resistance to weapons much more formidable than those of the Maori. Ibid. 302 [Maori glossary] pa Stockade;fortified village

Author: BRATHWAITE
Quote:
PA Fortified
village, or redoubt.

In this interval we saw several patches of Cultivation - a fortification or Heppa on the face of an [sic] hill and a few stragling flat Huts upon the ... Ibid. 1/582 a village with an Heppa contiguous situated upon an eminence.
Notes: 1769 Oct 12 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal I-575

Author: KEENE
Quote: pa: fortified village, usually situated on a mountain top. (See kainga above)

It was during this
time that Waitaha
had a pa on the

the pre-European
battle of Kokowai.

So far as our
information goes, we

fortifications to

allusion has been
made.

PA AT ROTORUA TAKEN

KILLED - MILITARY

Quote:
Mr. Luxford then

pa to hurry the

On Thursday evening,

pa n. (occas. pah.) Maori settlement, village (Hukanui Pa), or marae (Maketu Pa), in 19 c. fortified (Gate Pa). [M]

Author: Finlayson
Quote:
pa: originally a
terraced and
fortified village on

loosely, any Maori
village. To get away

assimilate into
pakeha society.

Quote:
A few Maories were
in the habit of
going over every

Author: HAAST
Quote:
I use the habitual
expression Maori
pah, but a

settlement would
give a very poor

as it did of three
miserable low huts,

couple ... were

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`Moawhango, the
postal name of the
pah, as it is

... Besides the Post
Office store and

Notes: c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 46

Quote:
I went to the pa
early and saw Wi
lying in state, the
greenstone mere at
his head and many
greenstone
ornaments. His head
had huia feathers on
either side, flowers
on his chest.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: The former [pa] is now considered the more correct spelling. A Maori word to signify a native settlement, surrounded by a stockade; a fort; a fighting village. In Maori, the verb pameans, to touch, to block up. Pa = a collection of houses to which access is blocked by means of stockades and ditches. 1769. `Captain Cook's Journal' (edition Wharton, 1893), p. 147: [and other quotations, incl. a long are from Thompson 1859].

Author: HYDE
Quote: Most Maoris still slept on the floor ... or on a mattress of sweet freshly-cut ti-tree branches, when they were in the guest-house of a big pa.

Author: BEAGLEHOLE
Quote:
Everything was quiet
in the pa by one
o'clock in the
morning.

Author: ANDERSEN
Quote: pa, fortified or stockaded place; used as a place of retreat if danger threatened the ordinary dwelling-place, the kainga; by Cook and by others much later spelt pah to get the proper sound of Maori `a'; pah, pa, in O.E.D.

pa has not for many years been spelt pah in Newzealand: pah was Captain Cook's spelling, and was useful as indicating the long vowel, but is not correct Maori, and is not used in writing. [JCA no long v]

Author: BEAGLEHOLE
Quote: pa formerly a fortified Maori place, now commonly applied ot any Maori village

Author: MANTELL
Quote: A Pah, called in old books Trippah, is a fortified village, but as all the villages are fortified, we call them Pahs, and so do the Mauri.

Author: WOOD
Quote:
The inhabitants of
the Pah or native
village would not
ferry us across the
stream ...

Author: MONRO
Quote:
In the bay in which
we landed, we found
two or three
miserable primitive
Maori cabins,
inhabited by
half-a-dozen
helpless old
creatures and a few
diseased children -
forming a pa named
Rapaki. Leaving this
pa, we passed
through a very
pretty bush, which
runs up nearly to
the top of the
range, ...
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 235

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
On each side of the
town [Wellington] is
a native `pah', or

Two Maoris from the
pa have also learned
to make cheese.
Notes: 1852 Dec 31 T.S.Grace Report of Turanga District in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 20

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
Here we found a
newly built pa named
Antioch with about a
doz. well built
houses chiefly
wharepuni, the old

springs still

... the portion of
the laid-out road

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote:
We soon reached the
Maori pah, where we
were received ...
with every sign of
welcome.

Author: MOSER
Quote: Two very natural questions arise from the heading of this article, the first being what is a pah? And the second why do I style it pah? ... A pah is strictly a fortified village, but it has ceased to be applied to a fortified one only, and a collection of huts forming a native settlement, is generally termed a pah now a days, and the pah I refer to as `Our pah' has no gns of fortifications about it.

Author: ZIMMERMAN
Quote: ... she told me that when you go to a strange pa, and have your first meal on the marae, you must always drop a bit of the food on the ground ... pa: fortified native village. Ibid. 103 One hand came up in answer to my wave, and then she turned about and strode away on her two-mile walk to the little pa.

Author: ROSIER-JONES
Quote: Emma picks it up. It's not heavy, and they walk across the road to the pa. Ibid. 89 `Everyone seems to be moving away from the pa. ... At least we're still within cooee of the pa. ...'

The bus disgorged at
the pa and Danny
trudged the dusty
road to Nana's,
gathering in his
younger brothers and
sisters to shepherd
them home.
pah var. of PA.

Author: ADAMS
Quote: To the darkness where they wept / From the pa an old chief stepped, / [fn] Village.

... the clustering
huts of the old-time
Maori Pah.

`Alexa' contributes
a note on the modern
Maori Kuri. ... the
Maori tykes that
roam the wilds of
Ohinemutu ... For
six months, while
`batching' near the
pah I made a study
of these ...
animals.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
`Alexa' contributes
a note on the modern
Maori Kuri. ... the
Maori tykes that
roam the wilds of
Ohinemutu ... For
six months, while

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
(gloss.) pah:
generally `pa', a
Maori settlement or
village, formerly
fortified.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
Absolutely free from
care and full of
childish frolic, the
children of the pa
... played around,
adding their shrill
cries to the varied
sounds of the
prowling animals.
Similar nucleated settlements, commonly if erroneously known to the paheka as pa, occurred in the vicinity of Whakatane, Opotoki, Rotorua and Gisborne.
Flowers, flowers at the pa, frothing about Hinewake. ... Flowers lapping further and further out upon the marae as the visitors arrive; adding and adding.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
I mean it's common
knowledge what
happens at the pa
when there's a big
hui.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote: ... is the cluster of tin shacks known locally as `the pa'. Ibid. 12 One night at the pah they saw the long poi done with lights.

Author: BACON
Quote: pa-Loosely, a Maori village. Properly speaking, a pa was a fortified village; a kaianga was an everyday settlement. In time of war, the populace moved from the kainga to the shelter of the pa. When Tamu spoke of the newcomers in Chapter 14 as `Real pa Maori, eh?' his meaning was, `These are not civilised Maoris; they're real bush Maoris.'

Author: WILSON
Quote:
Unlike most of the
Maoris at the pa she
looked as if she
came from the Arawa
tribe, because she
was olive-skinned
and oval of face.
~ n. originally, a native settlement surrounded by a stockade a fort, now an unfortified one [Maori].
pa, pah ... n. orig. native settlement surrounded by a stockade, a fort, now an unfortified one. (Pah is now obs.) [Maori].

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
... the lights are

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: BARRACOUTA (MANGA) Leionura atun dentatus (Bloch and Schneider) INCREDIBLE as it may seem these fish, with their well-armed jaws of sharp fang-like teeth, were usually caught on a slightly curved stick about four feet in length. Fastened to this stick was a piece of stout fishing line about three to four feet in length, carrying a piece of red-coloured wood - usually cedar - about five to six inches in length. A bent nail was secured to this piece of wood in the form of a hook but no bait was used. When a school of Barracouta was found the Couta stick, or paw, was brought out ready for fishing. From the cockpit of the launch the piece of wood with the nail was violently swirled with a circular motion in and out of the water, causing a disturbance of the water in a good imitation of a number of Sprats, Pilchards or other small fish jumping in and out of the sea. The Barracouta would swim for such a place. Seeing the piece of red wood moving rapidly through the water they would take it for a fish, snap at it or even jump out of the water for the lure and were caught by the crude iron hook. As the fish was hooked during the time the paw was being drawn through the water the fisherman would swing the fish over his head above the boat or launch and when the caught fish was midway in the air, more or less above the cockpit, would expertly give the stick a dexterous smart twist. As there was no barb on the hook the fish was released and fell into the cockpit. Ibid. 311 Should there be any Barracouta about the... Couta sticks were then set to work to paw the water and attract Barracouta to the spot. Ibid. 314 The Maori also knew he could catch Barracouta without bait and he, too, used a short piece of stick and line with a baitless hook and leaned over his canoe and threshed the water to and fro, which is known as `Kaihau manga!' When the European fisherman called his fishing outfit [315] `paw', the Maori uses the term `pa'. This fish was a great favourite with them and was caught in large numbers. On returning to the shore, the women cleaned the fish and then hung them up on racks to dry in the sun. Old Maoris of Opotiki told me they used a chip of Tawhai (Nothofagus fusca), which is dark red, in the making of a pa (paw).

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
There is controversy
over packs too, more
controversy, I
believe, than over
any other piece of
equipment.

Food and gear have to be carried. Everyone in New Zealand, almost everyone anyway, puts it in a pack, but probably no one stops to think that the word pack in this sense is not standard English. ... England since 1895 has borrowed rucksack from German dialect; New Zealand has preferred pack. Not that rucsac is not used here; it is noticeable that older Club members used it in several articles in early numbers of Tararua, and it still appears in advertisements. Rucksack seems a bit foreign, as is shown by the less correct but more foreign-looking spelling it is usually given. Pack as a synonym for rucksack is used in Australia to some extent at any rate. This sense of pack would most likely be in use long before it occurred in print. I remember having a home-made pack in Auckland in 1933.

Author: BRACKEN

The operations of
`paddocking' and
`sluicing'

Workings [at Mount
Ida, Otago, in 1871]
were for the most
part alluvial, the
distinctive process
used being
`paddocking'. [fn]
Paddocking was the
systematic sluicing
of large areas of
flat ground from
which the surface
layers were first
removed to reveal
the `wash-dirt'
beneath.

Author: EVANS

box, they began on
the second
`paddock'.

Author: NOLAN
Quote: Paddocking: working alluvial gold in a dry region by storing the paydirt in a gully or bin and washing it when water is available; also, digging or sluicing a claim one section at a time methodically.

Author: NOLAN

Paddocking: A square

was either extracted

cradle or sluice
box, or the paddock
had one open end and
was sluiced.
Paddocks were often
waterlogged and had
to be continually
bailed or pumped
dry.

who are averaging

sinking or
paddocking, the
greatest depth not

feet, with plenty of
water.

The ground is of a

nature, and in

sides are
continually falling
in...

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: The new faith was called `Pai marire', but afterwards, from the noise the votaries made in their devotions, resembling the barking of dogs, they acquired the name of Hauhaus.

Author: MEADE
Quote: ... We met a small party of [440] mounted natives, who brought news that an apostle of the new Pai Marire, or Te Hau, fanaticism had arrived at Taupo ... They are called Pai Marire, from the words which they subscribe to their signatures and use in greeting or parting from their co-religionists. The words literally mean `good! be appeased'; but the real tendency of the belief is to unite the Kingites of all sects in one common bond of fanatical hostility to the pakehas. Te Hau means only the hau (faith). Ibid 466 ... a host of perverts were chanting Pai Marire hymns round a Hau-hau post of worship, erected close to the late Christian church.
Notes: 1870 Dec 26 Meade Ride Through Disturbed Dists in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 439-440

Quote:
Down came the

The character in

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Pai Marire, or Hauhauism as it was called from the short barking cries of Hau! Hau! that besprinkled the chants, was a mxture of Old Testament borrowings with ancient native paganism and blood-rowsing ritual.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote: But there was a new and intractable fact to be taken into account in Taranaki: Pai marire- the Good and Peaceful Religion. In 1862 the Angel Gabriel had appeared in a vision to Te Ua, a Maori who had fought the Europeans in Taranaki.

Author: BRATHWAITE
Quote: PAI-MARIRE The Taranaki form of the Hauhau faith. (There was a modified form, even more barbaric, if anything, founded by Te Kooti and rife in East Coast and Urewera Country, known as. Ringa-tu Pai-marire, which revived ritual cannibalism and other revolting practices, strangely enough means `Good and Peaceful.'

Author: BELICH
Quote: Pai Marire - `The Good and Peaceful', also known as `Hauhauism' - was a syncretic religion originated by the prophet Te Ua Haumene, of the Taranaki tribe, in 1862. It had messianic and millenarian aspects, and theologically combined traditional Maori religion and the Maori versions of Christianity with Te Ua's own innovations. ... The original form of Pai Marire may have died out as early as 1866, with the death of its founder, but related or similar cults developed around leaders such as Hakaraia, Te Whiti O Rongomai, Titokowaru, Te Kooti, and Tawhiao himself.

Quote: The survey party came upon a good specimen of the pai mariri superstition.

[The document] is in Te Ua's handwriting, and is interesting as being the earliest known edition of the Pai Marire ritual, probably the earliest extant, for, besides the date (which is 26th October, 1862), there is internal evidence of its being ancient by the absence of the long since universal "hau."

The fanaticism which
believes in the
utterance of the
word "hau" in a
yelping tone, as a
powerful means of
procuring the favor
of Heaven and
bringing death on
the settlers, is not
likely to meet with
much that will
strengthen it, and
after awhile [sic]
these "Pai Marire"

Lizard Hunters of a

Politically

themselves.

The Pai Marire, or

themselves, were
full to the bung
with fanaticism...

The Bush Rangers

The natives at this

Marire poles erected

There is a flagstaff here [Waimate Plains], fenced in and surmounted by the figure of a bird, probably a kawekawea as it was a great niu or Pai Marire pole at one time.

Author: KELLY
Quote:
There remains a huge
paimariri pole,

Christians danced,

They rung the Pai
Marire bell with

The native villages could be seen through a glass scattered throughout the district, most of them distinguished by the well known pai marire pole, which is now without use, although not long since the centres of frantic dances and demoniacal absurdity.

Horomona gave the

Such being the case,

perpetrated under

Marireism.

MAF and the local
council can stomp
about in search of
painted apple moth.

We're infintely more
at risk from the
painted apple moth
than from any
gun-toting biped.

Some of it is to do
with the painted
apple moth spraying,
although that only
affects the
caterpillars they
feed on...

Biosecurity's
allocation has
fallen by $21
million to $151
million, due to
spending in the year
2005-06 year being
lifted by "one-off'
funding for all
responses to disease
- namely fall
webworm, painted
apple moth, didymo,
sea squuirt and the
southern saltmarsh
mosquito.

Author: FORSTER

Ducks of a variety of sorts, ... one, which on account of its varigated plumage we called The Painted Duck was the most beautiful bird I ever saw. [fn] the Paradise Duck Casarca variegata

We shot about 6
[ducks] - the last

Among the [wild
fowl] was four

Author: McNAB

Cook saw the

[at Dusky Sound],

Here I saw the

Islands, the Painted

Author: DOAK
Quote: Painted moki Cheilodactylus ephippium (Aust: painted morwong) ... Close relative of the red moki but more strikingly patterned, the painted moki was discovered in northern waters only in recent years.

Author: AYLING
Quote: PAINTED MOKI Cheilodactylus ephippium ...The painted moki is similar in shape and size to the red moki ... It may be distinguished from the red moki ... by its elaborate colour pattern.

Quote:
... shoving the
heavy-laden trolleys
of sheepskins from
the painters to the
pullers.

I'm pleased to see
that Helen Clark and
Labour are
campaigning on
trust. So let's see
- paintergate,
corngate, speedgate,
Winstongate,
foreshore-and-seabedgate
...

Paintergate showed
that Clark can be
cavalier with the
truth: she signed a
picture that she did
not paint.

Clark has been
denied by
paintergate, but has
largely been
forgiven by the
public for her first
offence.

[Hdg] Lawyer joins
in Paintergate saga.
The Auckland lawyer
who paid $5000 for
Prime Minister Helen
Clark's infamous
"Paintergate" piece
says he never
discussed the
painting or its
purchase with her.

It was one of those
loyal-to-a-fault
staff.. who burned
the painted icon of
government sleaze on
her barbecue; the
Paintergate artwork
that Clark did not
paint but was happy
to sign for
political points.

The Alliance has
grown a Siamese
head, the Nats are
engaged in
internecine warfare,
Labour is still
coping with the
embarrassment of
'paintergate", and
Act has Rodney Hyde
making a dick of
himself over a
shonky investment
conference.

Like Paintergate, it
catches her cutting
the corners of basic
etiquette, and being
greatly irked to be
pulled up for it.

From [flax] the
Chief's elegant and
ornamented silky
Paipairoa, and the

looking Pake and
Ngeri, - with their
many intermediate
kinds of clothing

FORSTER'S SHEARWATER, or PAKAKA Puffinus gavia).

Author: BULLER
Quote: PUFFINUS {GAVIA. (FORSTER'S SHEARWATER.) ... Native name.- Pakahaa: `Rainbird' of the colonists. ... {237} They fly low but swiftly, and utter a note resembling the native name by which the bird is called, but somewhat prolonged, as paka-ha-a - paka-ha-a.}

Quote:
I have very long
pakaka hair,

hair seal - pa'hka|k

Pakake (in one place

Quote:
The paraoa or sperm
whale, the pakake or
humpback whale, and
the black fish (a
relative of the
dolphin and the
common porpoise)
were used as food.

Pakapoo, a Chinese
game similar to
Lotto in which
numbers are marked
off on a ticket,
drew huge number of
people to the area.

At the City Court
Fee Fook and Tu Tune
were fined GBP20 or
three months for
keeping a gambling
house where the game
of pakapu was
played.

Author: DON
Quote:
He won 120 [pounds]
at a pakapu lottery.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
They went ...
sometimes down to
the Chinaman's
Place, where fantan,
pakapoo and two-up
were the sports ...

Six chinamen.. were
charged.. with
having been
concerned.. in the
play or conduct of
what the police
style "pakapoo" in a
house in Haining
Street.

Author: BODDY & MATTHEWS
Quote:
Usually pakapoo.. is
absolutely fair.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
"Pakapoo's the game
for you to make a
few quid quick."

Pakapoo, which is a
game played with 80
Chinese characters.
is a permanent
favourite.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
They went back to
the pakapoo shop at
seven

Author: McGILL & TILLY
Quote:
You paid sixpence
for a pakapoo
ticket, each ticket
bearing 80 Chinese
characters. Ten had
to be mar ked. You
won a prize if five
or more corresponded
with the master
ticket.

He got pak-a-pu
struck out of the
Gaming and Lotteries
Bill as a lottery.

For most
non-Chinese,
however, one of the
main attractions of
the street was
pakapoo - which was
similar to
modern-day Lotto or
Keno, but with
better odds.

The present furore
over race
broadcasting only
accentuates the gulf
between real lovers
of the turf, and
packapoo players.

Some weeks ago Yah
Chang was convicted
at Lawrence of being
unlawfully a partner
in a lottery called
"pak-a-pu," by which
prizes of money were
competed for by lot.

In the case of
gambling,the popular
game "pakapoo" drew
people from all over
Wellington and from
all walks of life.

Nothing was said on
the subject, beyond
a fearful confession
by Mr. Bedford that
he had been in a
pak-a-poo den.

They had been
conducting pakapoo
dens.

The Wellington
police believe that
there are from 40 to
60 houses about the
Chinese quarter of
the Capital being
used as pakapoo
dens.

We enter a pakapoo
den, as the
newspapers call one
of these places.

I had been warned
that mysterious
Chinese men lived
there in pakapoo
dens.

A police raid in
1904 uncovered a ton
of pakapoo tickets.

Two bits of
"documents printed
in a foreign
language" were
stated to be pakapoo
tickets.

Author: HYDE
Quote: The ... bawdy-houses of Upper Queen Street ... mingled happily with Chinese grocery-shops, masonic clubs, and pakapo [check ?oo] saloons, all known to the city's then very few moral uplifters as `Chinese Dens'. Ibid. 11 Grey Street remained the sort of place ... where it is possible ... to win [pounds]60 by marking your ten characters correctly on a green sixpenny pakapoo ticket.

In his hand he held
a small brush which
he used with amazing
dexterity, marking
pakapoo tickets.

There's the Chinamen
who sell pakapoo
tickets.

A serious
middle-aged man in
short sleeves.. sat
at one table with
brush and ink for
the marking of
pakapoo tickets.

Author: McGILL
Quote: pakapoo ticket, look/marked like a something confusing or incomprehensible; from Chinese lottery ticket with its (to Europeans) incomprehensible markings. Housie-type game played in illegal gambling and opium dens such as those in Haining Street, Wellington; eg `This ruddy exam's marked like a pakapoo ticket!'

His Honor [sic] said
pakapoo was an
illegal lottery, and
the sale of pakapoo
tickets was illegal.

The evidence of
detectives was that
the accused was a
seller of pak-a-poo
tickets and that
they had purchased
them from him.

Three Chinese were
to-day fined GBP25
each for selling
pak-a-poo tickets.

This man, when
ejected, shook his
fist at Lieut. Snow,
and threatened, in
the jargon that
passes current
between the two
races, to make a
"pakaru" of him
"tihoa."

Had the bullocks
four months; got it
from Haera; could
not say whether
wounds were deep or
not; spoke in
English to
defendant; don't
remember accused
saying, "bullock was
not hurt"; did not
not [sic] reply,
"you make a pukaru";
accused did not say
"its [sic] all
gammon."

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Quote: Pukkaroo, adjective and noun, (to make) worthless, useless - it could be used, for instance, of an engine that had broken down - is of dubious origin; ... perhaps from the Maori pakaru, ... or conceivably ... an adaptation of `buggered'.

Author: R. GILBERD
Quote: So common I thought it was a soldierism for buggered .... English writing `puckeroo' and it is used in Australia as buggeroo.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: Pak|adu, v. n. Bursting;

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Pakaru - breaking,
bursting

PAKARU. - Broken,
smashed.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Pakaru. Broken, crushed, smashed: New Zealand military: G.W. Ex Maori pakaru (to destroy), common as N.Z. coll. in late C. 19-20. (F. & Gibbons.) [see addenda and corrigenda]

Author: SOLJAK
Quote: New Zealand colloquialisms which are of Maori origin include; ... pakaru: broken, ruined

Author: LYON

... Bob related how
a row of Maoris
would push him off
the paths of
Wellington's main
streets, and with
many insulting
gestures, tell him
to go to Taranaki,
where they said he
would be pukaru or
finished.

Author: MASON
Quote:
WERIHE. Then they
come, to visit. But
no hui! The hui is
pakaru, pakaru.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
But there is no
doubt that more
enjoyment arose from
attempting to
`puckeroo' a top
owned by another
player, than from
smashing any other
object.

.. he said, "Rangi
says pukaru;" I
said, "The bullock
is not dead;" ...

The roar of the
musket broke the
silence, and
immediately the cry
arose: "Pakaru!
pakaru te pakeha!"
("Smite the
stranger!")`

`We will pukeru
you!' ` ... pukeru
me?'

Author: BAKER
Quote: We had begun to pukaroo things, when we broke something, confused an issue, or ruined some plan of action .... derived ... from the Maori pakaru ... though many New Zealanders [have thought] that it comes from the verb b----r.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
[It] is the surest
way to buckeroo an
axe.

As they retreated
from our troops into
the bush ... they
sung out in Maori,
`Soldier, aramay;
Pukaru the soldier,'
accompanied by
shouting and yells.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: pakaru, ... v.t. break in pieces. the usual anglicisation [k 'ru:] puckeroo, etc, the adjectival use of puckeroo (she's puckeroo, mate) and the meaning, suggests a borrowing from the Maori adjectival form; and the common meaning `ruin', and a common form as pa ptc aj puckerood, has suggested to some a co-derivation from bugger, buggered. Maori `pakaru could be heard as [bg'ru:] `buggeroo', but only buckeroo is recorded: cf, however, Australian bugaroo. spg (early) puikero, pukeru; puckaroo, puckeroo, buckeroo, pukaroo, pukkaroo.

The Mauries swore
that we should all
be Puckarooed as
well as the gun and
away they scuttled.

Author: BARNICOAT
Quote:
Gideon [a native,]
forseeing the
collision ....
shouted out Puikero!
puikero! puikero!
(broken).
[The Maoris said] `We will pukeru you' `Very well,' I said `Pukeru me.'

We remember that
when our horses were
allowed to stray off
the narrow path
among the grass how
the Wahines seizing
an axe, and calling
the Pakeha
sanguinary names,
threatened to
"pukaru" the horses.

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote:
The outside mat that
they wear over the
shoulder Pagata

Peripatetic attempts
have been made by
various sanguine
parties to make
Dunedin take an
interest in itself,
but they have had as
much effect as a
half pint of
shandygaff would
have on a Pakatoa
`reformed' drunk.
Raja nasuta Muller and Henle. SKATE, WAEWAE, OR PAKAURA.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND

Author: BUCK
Quote:
The pake, as we know
it, is the roughest
type of rain cape
with an outer thatch
of overlapping free
ends to shed the
rain.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
To be in sympathy
with this hapu..
Readers would be
well-advised .. to
imagine themselves
bare-limbed,
bare-headed, brown,
the pake of everyday
wear thrown over
their shoulders.

Their Cloathing
(both Men [and]
Women) is a kind of
matt or cloth made
of silk grass or
fine flax, curiously
wove and tied about
the shoulder that
reaches to their
knees ... [they]
call it an Ahow, [fn
ahu] and over it
they have one of a
coarser sort made of
Grass well thrumbed
with the same to
keep out the wet
which they call a
Bugy Bugy. [fn]
pakepake often made
of undressed flax.

That night they lay
... covered with
their Cloaks or
Bugge bugge's.
Notes: 1777 Feb 24 Samwell Acct in Cook Journals (1967) 3/1002

Quote:
... they add what
they call the
Bugabuga or Toga.

From [flax] the
Chief's elegant and
ornamented silky
Paipairoa, and the
shaggy bee-butt
looking Pake and
Ngeri, - with their
many intermediate
kinds of clothing
mats, - were alone
manufactured.
pake ... n. coarse mat, used by Maoris as a cloak [Maori].
pake n. a mat or piece of sacking used as a protection from rain. [Maori]

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pake[e-diereis], n. Maori name for a coarse mat used against the rain. A sack thrown over the shoulders is called by the settlers a Pake.

Author: BAKER
Quote: The colloquial uses of pake-has (the has being accented), for a wealthy white man, and pake-hasn't, for a penniless white, may be noted.

Among composite forms in which the adjective appears are pre-pakeha times, Journal of the Polynesian Society, 27 (1918), pre-pakeha days, V. Roberts Kohikohinga (1929), etc. and the jocular uses pakehas (the `has' being accented) and pakehasn't, for a rich and penniless white man respectively. (These uses may have occurred in print, but I have not seen them; only heard them.)

Why are the Pakehas
so foolish as to
bathe in
Whanganui-a-Tara
(Wellington
Harbour). Is it not
known that
Whanganui-a-Tara
abounds with sharks.

When we were
defeated by
Rauparaha we looked
about for a
protector: we
invited the pakaha
to settle here: the
French came, after
them the English.

You Pakehas burned
up the witches with
fire until there was
not one left alive.

Mr Carroll is
reported to have
advised the natives
not to sell their
land to the pakehas,
as the natives would
then become the
pakeha's [sic]
slaves, but to keep
the land and make
the pakehas slaves
of the natives.

The pakeha this time
had out-taihoa'd the
Maori.

Author: CARR
Quote:
... half the board
(i.e., half the
total shearers) are
Maori, and the other
half Pakeha (white).

I observed that the term `New Zealander' is already employed in this district; only, in lieu of `Noui-Tireni", as the natives of the Bay of Islands pronounce it, they say `Noui-Tirangui' [Nui Tirangi] [sic], which gives the word more of an indigenous sound. The word pakeha serves them to signify all whites, whom they also call `Iouropi' (Europeans). I did not observe that they had a special name for the English.
Notes: (Smith transl. D'Urville's Visit to Tolaga Bay in 1827)

Quote:
This is why the
debate of the
lowestcommon
denominator, couched
in terms suchas
"social disaster",
"utu" and
"Pakehabacklash" is
irresponsible to say
theleast.

When my lot arrived
they crowded the
rail of the ship and
cried, "What-ho,
natives" (or, among
the lower orders,
like mine, "Wotcher,
natives"). The
people on the beach,
somewhat nonplussed,
I expect, needed a
name to identify the
new arrivals. They
chose "pakeha"....
These days it is
used in government
documents, even
though there is
confusion over just
who is Pakeha: are
Pacific Islanders
Pakeha? Or Malaysian
Chinese immigrants?
Or Sudanese
refugees?... I do
not want to be
identified as
Pakeha, a colonial
term that should
have died out when
the colonial century
ended.

These white-skinned
beings of the
imagination
[patupaiarehe] were
also known as
pakepakeha and
pakehakeha. These
words are the direct
antecedents of the
word Pakeha.

Baxter was seeking
to establish an
alternative Pakeha
community that could
'learn from the
Maori side of the
fence'.

Author: Allen Curnow
Quote:
I am a Pakeha and
proud of it,
Although I seldom
brag aloud of it.
... No less than
Kumara or Kauri,
Pakeha's perfectly
good Maori;

What does it mean to
be a Pakeha in
Branch Office New
Zealand experiencing
that same sense of
dispossession that
our ancestors
inflicted upon
Maori?

The Maories, seeing
the greediness with
which the "pakehas"
hunted after old Moa
bones, have long
since carefully
found, and deposited
them in some safe
hidingplace.

Author: PAYTON
Quote: The birds naturally prefer districts where they are not likely to be molested by the pakeha and his tupara.

I am a Pakeha New
Zealander, which I
can explain and
define with
certainty. I was
born and raised in
New Zealand; my
ancestors, going
back at least five
generations, were
born and raised in
New Zealand. My
first ancestors, as
far as I can tell,
came from England.
This is what it
means to me to be a
Pakeha.

Pakeha, the Maori
term for the white
inhabitants of New
Zealand, was in use
before 1815, most
probably derived
from imaginary
beings resembling
men, or from a sea
god.

It was their duty to
keep bad pakehas
away from the camp.

When dressed on
Sundays, with a
Manilla hat and
trailing ribbons a
la pakeha, he would
stand in the yard
strutting about and
admiring himself.

I am Pakeha and
aware of my
Pakeha-ness.

A tale of Te Pakeha,
a race with a rich
cultural heritage.

My experience of the natives is that they are generally very decent sportsmen, and nearly always insist on giving way to any pakeha (i.e. white man) who comes prepared to fish the pool in the ordinary way.

Author: RENWICK
Quote:
﻿Na ko te
Kuini e hiahia ana
kia wakariteate
Kawanatanga kia kaua
ai nga kino eputa
mai ki te tangata
Maori ki te Pakehae
noho ture kore ana.
Notes: ﻿1840 Treaty of Waitangi in 1990 RENWICKThe Treaty Today 23﻿Note: The word Pakeha does not occur inthe English text given here.

Quote:
Sir George [Grey]..
addressing himself
tome, said "As long
as I have been in
thecolony, I have
never been able
todiscover the
origin of the term
pakeha.

I asked [an old
chief] why his
peoplegave the name
pakeha to the
strangehuman beings
they had seen for
the firsttime in
their lives... He
said "He
meapakewhakewha." I
took the phrase..
tosignify "A thing
wafted from the
ocean tothe shore."

In the evening we
had been surrounded
by many of the
natives (as was the
usual custom when we
rested at a pah,)
they had been giving
us information
respecting different
places on our route,
singing their wyates
or native songs, and
indulging in their
wonted easy
familiarity of
intercourse with the
pakeha.

And after dinner (it
will scarcely be
believed by those
who look upon the
New Zealanders as
savages) the young
and hospitable Chief
treated his Pakia
guest with a good
bottle of Port wine.

Te Whiti and Tohu
were taken over the
Kaiapoi Factory
to-day, where their
eyes were opened to
a still wider extent
as to the power of
the Pakeha.

Has the time arrived
for the removing of
legislative
distinctions between
the Pakeha and the
Maori? Mr. Fraser
urged that the
Maoris should be
placed on the same
electoral rolls as
the Pakeha and
allowed to vote for
the candidate he
thought best.

.. but although it
is known to most of
the Pakea that the
Maories consume
large quantities of
the juice of the
tutu in its
unfermented state as
a summer beverage, I
am not aware of its
having been
manufactured into
Wine.

"The third thing I
see is Pakeha being
able to speak in
pakeha on the marae.
..."

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
`This is a kind of
pakeha marae;/ I'm
only a lodger -
...'/

Author: GEBBIE & McGREGOR
Quote:
The bar is the
Pakeha marae.

We're all New
Zealanders of
course, but we
happen to be Pakeha
New Zealanders and
Maori New
Zealanders, not
forgetting all the
other nationalities
here of course.

I am a Pakeha New
Zealander, which I
can explain and
define with
certainty. I was
born and raised in
New Zealand; my
ancestors, going
back at least five
generations, were
born and raised in
New Zealand. My
first ancestors, as
far as I can tell,
came from England.
This is what it
means to me to be a
Pakeha.

All people who live
in urban industrial
societies have their
lives requlated by
measured time. This
concept of time is
referred to by
Maoris as `Pakeha
time' and they
conform to its
dictates inasmuch as
they are on time for
work, to catch buses
or to fulfil
engagements.
However, because
they are bicultural,
Maoris function in
their own time-frame
as well, which they
refer to as `Maori
time'.

Author: THOMPSON
Quote:
The hardest part was
getting started. No
sooner had I cast
Don Selwyn from
Wellington as the
old man, and Thomas
Ratima from Napier
as Matt, then, as if
intent on proving
right the stereotype
about `Maori
unreliability', they
both disappeared
without trace. They
turned up in the
end, of course, and,
just to prove me
prejudiced and
wrong, subscribed
more rigorously than
anyone to `pakeha
time'; but meanwhile
I was driven to
desperation trying
to find the other
twenty or so Maoris
needed to complete
the cast.

Author: PASCOE
Quote:
Today we know this
trail as the
Napier-Taupo road
and it is an
interesting
commentary on New
Zealand history that
such an old Maori
trail became a
pioneer missionary
route, a pakeha
track and ultimately
a graded road.

Tiri has been at war
with the
"Pakeha-goblins" all
her life; from the
signing of the
Treaty of Waitangi,
through the 20 years
it takes to fall
apart - "we called
them the Pakeha
Wars".

Iwi/hapu
expectations seem
driven by
opportunism and
greed, and another
chance to indulge in

In the Press, and
will shortly be
published, Price
5s., bound, a new
work, entitled, OLD
NEW ZEALAND; A TALE.
BY A PAKEHA MAORI.
Death of a Well-known Pakeha-Maori. Mr. C.O. Davis, the well-known Maori scholar died to-day. He has made valuable bequests to the Library and Museum.

Adventurers, whalers
and sealers, Pakeha
Maori were European
men and women who
came ashore in New
Zealand in the early
19th century and
took their chances
among the local
Maori. Much more
than the Europeans
who arrived after
1840, the Pakeha
Maori were
integrated into
tribes and depended
on Maori for their
livelihood and
survival.

Peta Watere.. once
dismissed him [sc. a
Maori] as a "pakeha
Maori".

Pakeha Maori, like
the Musket Wars,
have not had the
dignity of a book
before... Of Jacky
Marmon, one such
escaped convict

Bentley writes: "He
admitted to shooting
one of his Maori
wives for adultery,
feasting on human
flesh, and shooting
a fellow Pakeha
Maori in a dispute
over a pig."

Author: Stella Morice

The meaning of words

Maori is a very
beautiful language;
and English is not a
bad one as languages
go; but that
delightful 'patois'
called Pakeha-Maori,
which is the vulgar
tongue among
half-castes,
loafers,
missionaries, Maori
doctors, and other
kinds of vagabonds
in the North Island,
goes beyond either
of its component
roots for breadth of
expressions, and
euphony of sound. In
Maori again no two
consonants occur
together, so that in
using English words
in Pakeha-Maori, a
vowel must always be
stuck in between
consonants where
they happen to meet.

We had got news from

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: We now advanced along the plain [towards Moeraki], which was covered with `patiti' and ... stunted fern and `tutu'. These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. Ibid. 311 PAKIHI, open country, bare of trees, covered with coarse wiry grass, stunted fern, and low shrubs. It does not necessarily signify `a plain'. The `a' is sounded long and broad in this word, by which it is distinguished from `pakihi,' to be low water, or to drain off as a river after a flood, in which the `a' has a sound both short and soft. `Kua pakihi te wai o Waitaki,' the water of Waitahi has become low.
Notes: 1844 Jan 9 in 1851 Shortland Southern Districts of NZ 195-196

The Wakamarama Range [Nelson] is for the most part densely forested, though there are patches of open pakihi on its summit. [fn] Pakihi (bare) is a Maori term applied to flat, open spaces. Pakihis are generally swampy.

Author: HAAST
Quote: Most of [the gold-seekers] ... begged me to leave them flour enough for at least one day, which I did, ... as I had been assured ... that I should be able to obtain new provisions at the so-called Pakihi, a large forest meadow near Lake Brunner. Ibid. 82 After a mile and a half we came out of the high forest and the pakihi or paddock lay before us. This is the name given by the diggers to a grass-covered plain between one and two miles broad, bordered on both sides by thickly wooded mountains. This place, generally so desolate, was now highly animated. Cattle and horses were grazing peacefully in all directions. Numbers of tents were put up near the forest for the accommodation of gold-diggers, cattle-drivers, and storekeepers.

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote: After travelling a mile through dense bush, ... we arrived at an open tract of swampy land, a paki, as the natives call it, covered with rushes, swamp grasses, and ... with manuka and ferns ... Ibid. 131I shall now enumerate the different pakis, or open tracts of land, and give a short description of them.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
The supplies ....
had been packed by

the pakahi.

Large areas of
marshy lands on the
west coast of the
South Island of New
Zealand are known
locally as `pakihi'
lands, or the
`pakihis'.

[w. Nelson/Westland] Much of the terrace land consists of `pakihi' - barren treeless moorland with an undrained, sour, peaty soil, deficient in lime and phosphates, and resting on hard ferruginous gravel. Ibid. 807 23. Aston, B.C.: The Pakihi Soils of Westland. New Zealand Journal of Agriculture (1910), Vol. i., pp. 22-27.

Gold was found in
Whiskey Creek, which
drains the pakihi,
and flows in an
east-westerly
direction before it
enters a
steep-walled gorge.

In the Grey and
Inangaluae valleys,
on the Westport
flats and in the
Collingwood
district, .... there
are large areas of
swampy pakihi,
underlain by clay or
iron pans, and for
these no profitable
method of farming
has yet been
devised.

Instead the pakihi
(a very general term
used for most srcub
or waste land on the
West Coast, from the
Maori for `open
space') has been
selectively logged
for its large native
trees....

Author: HULME
Quote:
387 Pakihi = a term
for a swampy acidic
barren type of land

The progression from
bog to bog forest
has been studied in

island-like patches
of bog, known

lowland gravel
plain.
pakihi fern [=] swamp umbrella fern [s]

The natural cover of

rush has sufficient

to enable

oversown pasture.

In its native state,

The annual rental to
be 9d per acre for
the river flat and
6d per acre for
pakihi land.
Cladium teretifolium

Westland pakihi
starter per hectare

From Mr A. Creber,
who has just

rush to the north of

ground is worked by

about six miles from

distance from the

Their hard work and
drive are
transforming rough
pakihi terraces into

the back of their
farm at Anatoki in
Golden Bay. Theirs
is hard, demanding
country; mostly
terraces of
scrubclad pakihi,
with an underlying
pan..

This type of country
is usually known
locally as pakihi
land or 'the
pakihis.'

The successful
working of the
pakihis is dependent
to a very large
extent on cheap lime
being available.

The Collingwood
pakihis are of
limited extent,
probably.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: THE SPOTTY Pseudolabrus celidotus (Richardson) ... Maori name: PAEKIRIKIRI ... This was one of the first species of fish collected in New Zealand by Europeans, and was described and named in 1801. The Spotty belongs to the Parrotfish family (Labridae) and is also related to the Butterfish and Kelpfish.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: SPOTTY (PAEKIRIKIRI) Pseudolabrus (Lunolabrus) celidotus (Bloch and Schneider) ... [Ibid. 275] The name Spotty is derived from the presence of spots on each side of the fish. The name Butterfish used in the North Island for them is from the yellow or buttery colouring on the undersurface. In Canterbury they are called Guffy, but for what reason I have yet to learn. It is a very pretty fish, more especially when seen in the water.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Kirikiri, and pakirikiri, a rough-skinned fish, having two spines on the back, which it can elevate at pleasure; it is a short but broad fish (labrus paecilopleura). Ibid. 624 Fam. Plectognathi. - The Pakirikiri, (balistes,) file fish, is distinguished by two strong spines at the commencement of the dorsal fin, in shape like the letter V, both fronting the head, and standing out from the fin, these are elevated at pleasure, some fish have only one. The Pakirikiri is abundant in the Bay of Islands.

There's a label in
Samoa for him and
his peers which
means potato. "I'm
brown on the outside
but white on the
inside. It's a huge
insult for New
Zealand-born
Samoans, it denotes
that you are just a

palagi."
Join us for a lecture by Anthony Haas titled "An Aspect of Being Pa'alagi: Reconciling Cultures".

..when Stevenson
died in 1894 he was
wrapped in
ceremonial fine mats
and carried up a
steep track to the
summit of Mount Vaea
and there buried, a
singular honour for
a palagi.

The palagi and his
world have turned us
and people like your
rich but unhappy
father, and all the
modern Samoans, into
cartoons of
themselves - funny,
crying, ridiculous
shadows of
themselves.

Ranterstantrum is trying to explore the dynamic that I often found muyself in being the one Polynesian surrounded by a whole lot of palagis and being expected to defend the whole of the Samoan race for all of the ills that they have done.

We saw that our
bananas and produce
were bought by New
Zealand Palangi,
shipped to New
Zealand by Palangi
and, in return,
Palangi sent us
Palangi-made butter
and corned beef.

It is told from the
viewpoint of Joe, a
Samoan man.., who
finds himself
terrorised by two
Palagi strangers.

In the present
climate, Palagi will
be inclined to do
something first for
Maori as tangata
whenua and then
point to Asians and
say: "Look how well
they're doing
without any help."

To my own, I'm not a
Samoan, I'm a
Palagi, and to my
parents I am a
child.

[She] is mostly
believable, except
for some of her
scenes with Michael
Hodgson, who, as
Mervyn, the "skinny
palagi", at times
sounds a little too
skinny and Palagi to
be true.

"Palagis are scared
of us... Even though
most of us were born
in New Zealand, they
still think we eat
dogs in the backyard
and they're not sure
if we'll say 'hello'
back... This play is
to tell them just
how scared we are of
palagis"

Author: Bernard Gadd
Quote:
'You say my name
very well for a
palagi - that is a
Pakeha,' I told her.

I suppose Danny and
I expected them to
say, 'Oh, we laugh
at palagi and
stuff.' But they
actually said, 'We
laugh at our
ministers and our
parents.'

And this is palagi
history as well.

There is rumoured to
be a third - a
Palagi kid sporting
an enormous orange
growth - but he
remains as elusive
as the white whale
or the Siberian
tiger.

In contrast, Palagi
culture was viewed
as less emotional,
less respectful and
with fewer financial
obligations to the
family. Religious
life was less
pervasive and worked
on an individual
rather than
community level.

We start in New
Zealand in the 70s,
when this
five-year-old Palagi
kid meets the Island
family that moves
next door and forms
this strong
friendship with an
Island kid the same
age.

The majority [of the
Niueans] could speak
no English, had
never worn footwear
or eaten palagi
food, none had been
out of the tropics
before, and within
three months of
departure for Egypt
and then France, 82
per cent were
hospitalised,
suffering from
complications due to
lack of immunity to
European diseases.
