Quote:
.. when I was on
that place in my
mustering days we
had to travel per
'Harry Pannell.'

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
At one time
practically all the
musterers in
Canterbury got their
boots from Pannells
in Christchurch and
even now I think the
majority do; so much
so that a Canterbury
man will quite
understand if you
refer to boots
simply as Pannells.

O'Briens and
Pannells also have a
place as distinctive
boots worn by
country folk, and
particularly those
mustering sheep.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Pannells: boots, as
also are O'Briens
and R and G s. Mr
Pannell died some
years ago but his
name will stay in
musterer's parlance
for some generations
.. He kept a huge
tome containing the
measurements and
pencilled traces of
his clients' feet.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
They'll be rolling
swags in the
bunkroom, fixing the
pack saddles too,
re-nailing their
'Harry Panell's' ..
[Panells; Parnells]

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
At one time
practically all the
musterers in
Canterbury got their
boots from Pannells
in Christchurch and
even now I think the
majority do; so much
so that a Canterbury
man will quite
understand if you
refer to boots
simply as Pannells.

Author: KNOX
Quote:
Some of us [early
mountaineers] wore
Pannell's famous
mustering boots ...
Notes: 1975 Andy Anderson in The Canterbury Mountaineer Jubilee Edition in Knox Thousand Mountains Shining 219

Quote:
The fish were not
big - typical
"pannie" snapper of
the inner Hauraki
Gulf... Some may
argue that nine is a
lot of snapper per
person. It is if
they are all
substantial fish,
but if they are the
size of the standard
Hauraki Gulf pannie
snapper, it is not
excessive.

Author: H S CHAPMAN
Quote: Of course in these [bush] whares there are degrees of comfort and accommodation. In one tea is boiled in the kettle and drunk out of a pannikin: in another the tea is made in a tin teapot and drunk out of crockery.
Notes: 1847 Nov 24 H.S. Chapman Letters to His Father [TS, ATB] in 1958 Miller Early Victorian NZ 140

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
in excursions of
this nature [a bush
journey in
Auckland], the
`menage' is
necessarily very
limited. A tin pot
serves as tea-kettle
and tea-pot and each
man carries a
`pannikin' for a cup
and drinking vessel.
Notes: 1847 Johnson Notes From Jrnl in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 119

Quote:
There was only wood
enough to make one
panakin of tea.

Notes: [used often in backblocks farm context: get quot]

Author: PASCOE
Quote:
It was then arranged
what else we would
take with us, viz.,
a hatchet, a billy
for tea, no tent
..., panikins, and
some tea; ...
Notes: 1863 Lauper in 1960 Pascoe (ed) Over the Whitcombe Pass 25

Quote:
[At the abandoned
Maori camp was] a
pannikin of native
manufacture made of
totara bark ...[sic]

Author: BARKER
Quote:
We peeped in at the
men's huts - a long,
low wooden building,
with two rows of
`bunks' (berths, I
should call them) in
one compartment, and
a table with forms
around it in the
other, and piles of
tin plates and
pannikins all about.

Author: CHEVALIER
Quote:
The billey (a tin
pot for boiling the
water) and three
pannikins (tin cups)

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
The pannikins hung
in the Stockade
hall,

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
The pannikins hung
in the Stockade
hall,

Author: MONEY
Quote: ... he was considered sufficiently rewarded in having the `honour' to drink his `pannikin' of tea at the boss's deal table, where he was not half so comfortable, or half so much at his ease, as the men in their tent or hut.

Author: TINNE
Quote:
... a tin pannikin
apiece, and a
`billy' for boiling
the water.

Source: Pirate Chief and the Mummy's Complaint..., The
Author: SKEY
Quote:
With their pannikins
in hand,/ Yellow
grains to measure
off,/ That are
gathered in the
trough,/

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
A visitor to William
Rolleston's station
complains of a diet
of `baked mutton,
potatoes boiled in a
bucket, station made
bread with dripping
instead of butter,
tea without milk,
all served on tin
dishes and plates,
with pannikens for
water or tea.'

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A large round
`wheel' of bread ...
a butcher's knife
and three large
enamel pannikins
(mugs).
pannikin: A tin drinking cup.

Milking the Goats
cleaning the
pannikins making the
Tea

All ranged around, a
motley crew/ Of
pannikins and pots a
few,/ Adorned a sort
of scaffold;

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
He also found me a
pannikin which did
not look very
inviting being black
with dirt.

Author: SWAINSON
Quote:
A knife, fork,
spoon, pannikin, tin
plate, and tea-pot,
form a sufficient
yet not extravagant
equipment [for the
bush traveller].

... to purchase
timber for floors,
tables, beds, forms,
panicans, plates,
soap [etc].

Author: SMITH
Quote:
[We must not] hang
up our pannikins,
for fear of some
harm coming to the
owner of the place,
&c.
Notes: 1858 Jan 15 Smith Notes of a Journey in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 363

Quote:
Tin mugs, or
pannikins, as they
are called, holding
about a pint at
least.

Author: PASCOE
Quote:
[MS. S.J.B.]
[Westland diggers
carried a] Maorie
Hen or a Billy of
Mussells and a
pannican of skilly.

Author: MOFFAT
Quote:
[I] stripped some
bark off a cedar or
totara tree [in
Nelson], I am not
sure which, built a
maimai big enough to
crawl into, managed
to get a fire,
caught and roasted a
woodhen, boiled some
flour in my
pannikin, ... [c
1860].

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pannikin, n. a small tin cup for drinking. The word is not Australian. Webster refers to Marryat and Thackeray. The `Century' quotes Blackmore. This diminutive of pan is exceedingly common in Australia, though not confined to it. [1830]

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
Having nibbled some
cabin-bread and made
himself a panikin of
tea ...

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
PANNIKIN: Large
drinking mug.
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 187

Quote:
Pigeon and kaka
stew, ... and ...
several large
pannikins each of
choice billy tea.
pannikin n. a small cup or mug.- panni'kin boss n. an overseer, ep. one of restricted power. [dim of pan; D. baas, master]

Author: JONES
Quote: ... a pannican

Tin drinking mug, holding a pint as a rule. In the early days the explorers used them for boiling to save carrying billies. ([1874 Kennaway Crusts], p. 41; Butler A First Year in Canterbury Settlement], p. 54) They are now usually made of enamel an d called pints or mugs. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
They made tea in the
big billy and ladled
it out with a
pannikin.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
PANNIKAN: A tin
drinking cup.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
The cookshop was an
old army hut, and
this morning there
was a pile of snow
that had come in
through the ridge of
the roof down the
middle of the table.
We cooled our tea by
placing the
pannikins in it.
A small tin cup or `billy-can'.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
As the pannikins of
tea were being
passed round, Morrie
produced a bottle of
Johnny Walker and
poured a good lashin
into each.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
The ordinary enamel
pannikins generally
used by men on
stations were not
good enough for
Jeff.
pannican ... n. small tin cup used in the bush: (Coll.) the head; off one's pannican, insane, demented; pannican boss, subordinate manager or overseer as opposed to big or quartpot boss.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
`These were 240-lb
bags,' Chaffey would
stress, leaning
against the bar or
squatting with
smoke-oh pannikin of
tea, gently moving
it to and fro by
wool-greased knee.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
Early next morning
... I got up, lit
the fire, and set
the pannikins to
boil : we then ...
broke camp.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pannikin-boss, or Pannikin-overseer, n. The term is applied colloquially to a man on a station, whose position is above that of the ordinary station-hand, but who has no definite position of authority, or is only a `boss' or overseer in a small way.

The `pannikin' boss
usually is in
evidence. This is
the man who for a
wretched shilling a
day more than his
fellow Unionists
sells his body to a
mercenary employer
to rush, wear, and
sweat others.
Pannikin Boss. - Slang. B. who has little authority. B. of rouse-abouts, etc. ([1898 Morris Austral-English])

Author: R.GILBERD
Quote:
Foreman have the
same name [as in
U.S.] but `pannikin
boss' may be New
Zealand.

Author: PUGH-WILLIAMS
Quote:
The foremen of a
stevedoring gang.
Origin possibly in
the days when
watersiders did a
full day's work. He
used to make himself
responsible to see
the water pannikin
was full and
replenished often.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
... all the half-pie
pannikin bosses
ordering me about
because there's
no-one like the
working man for
putting the boot
into the working
man.
pannikin boss n. minor overseer on a station. one without much status.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: The manager of a sheepstation was called a pannikin boss, a term I have heard used, along with straw boss, for a foreman on building jobs in New Zealand.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
With the leak days
of the Depression
only a little behind
men who had known
relief camps and
pannikin bosses had
no zest for more mud
and for Army
sergeants; ... men
still on relief had
little urge to fight
for the country that
had given them so
little.

Author: McGILL
Quote: pannikin boss foreman on building and other jobs; originally manager of a sheep atation. ANZ.

Author: McGILL
Quote: pannikin boss foreman on building and other jobs; originally manager of a sheep atation. ANZ.

.. a man might be
engaged in the
street or in the
pub, more likely
after "shouting" a
few beers for the
"pannikin boss".

The "pannikin" boss
usually is in
evidence. This is
the man who for a
wretched shilling a
day more than his
fellow Unionists
sells his body to a
mercenary employer
to rush, wear and
sweat others.

Keith Snalam of
Blenheim writes: "As
an apprentice boy in
the 50s, I
frequently heard the
term 'pannikin
boss'. I'm sure it
was used as a
comment on the state
of mind of the
foreman or leading
hand, that person
having just had the
big boss from the
office on his hammer
... The foreman
would be seen
approaching the
workers in a state
which these days
would be described
as stressed out.
Hence the term,
'here comes the
panickin' boss'!"
Maybe. Dave Bijoux
of Mt Eden suggests:
"The pannikin boss
drank from the
pannikin, as did all
the workers: a boss
who metaphorically
drank from their
cup, was part of the
community, and was
somewhat despised as
a prostitute for the
workers. Ronald
Thomas of Pamlerston
North adds: "Perhaps
there is a
connection between a
metal cup that holds
a little liquid and
a trumped-up boss
who holds little
authority, but makes
a lot of noise about
it."

"He introduced
himself as a
pannikin boss," said
a witness of another
man in the
Magistrate's court
to-day. "'Pannikin
boss'?" said Chief
Detective Boddam,
"what is that?" "The
Foreman," explained
the witness.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Pannikin-boss or
pannikin-overseer ..
applied colloquially
to a man on a
station, whose
position is above
that of the ordinary
station-hand, but
who .. is only a
'boss' or overseer
in a small way.

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
At smoke-oh he used
to take a standing
jump over a bale of
wool and then
Brucksaw, the
'pannikin boss'
(head general hand)
used to carry it out
of the shed
single-handed.

Author: GOULTER
Quote:
Ted, at twenty, is
running Blairich,
and Jack, only
seventeen, is
'pannikin boss' at
Hawkesbury.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
The manager of a
sheepstation was
called a pannikin
boss ...

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
.. I'm just the
pannikin boss, not
the one who controls
the storeroom.

A person in charge
of a team of farm
workers: pannikin
boss.
My power is such to make or break - / I'm a Pannikin, get me? Ibid. 13 There's not a pannikin can say that we could not do our work.

Author: BEST
Quote: The other principal species formerly taken were the inanga and kokopu (Galaxias and Retropinna), upokororo (Prototractes), and panoko (Cheimarrichthys); while the lamprey (piharau and korokoro) and fresh water crayfish (koura) were taken in considerable numbers in some districts.

...why is a boss in New Zealand sometimes referred to as a pannikin? I can't pin down the answer to this one. A pannikin is a small drinking vessel used by workers. The expression "pannikin boss" was first recorded in 1911, in the Maoriland Worker: The 'pannikin' boss ... is the man who for a wretched shilling a day more than his fellow unionists sells his body to a mercenary employer to rush, wear and sweat others."

Author: CAIRD
Quote:
A shepherd or drover
would think himself
hardly used indeed
if he had not his
pannikin-full of tea
three or four times
a day. [check quot]

The majority are up,
dressed, washed,
andhave drunk a
pannikin of tea and
eaten asnack of cake
or dry bread.

Author: BIDWILL
Quote:
... tea boiled in a
common tin pot, or
pannikin as the
sailors call it.

Author: WILLIAM MORGAN
Quote:
... some of them new
arrivals. And they
often come without
either money, axe,
panakin, or
bill-hook.

Milking the Goats
cleaning the
pannikins making the
Tea

I have known it [sc.
the southern
woodhen] carry off a
meerschaum pipe,
spoons, pannikins,
boxes of matches;
and on one
occasion.. it
actually stole a
watch from a
bushman's hut.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote: You know how vulgar jugglers attempt to emulate this trick, .. sometimes by emptying a pannikin of flour, a pound or two of raisins, and all the et ceteras, into the same magic "beaver," and after a mumbo-jumbo whisk or two, turning out a smoking-hot, thoroughly-boiled tempting plum-pudding.

.. she then threw a
panican of soapy
water over him...

It is supposed that
he fell into the
water while getting
water in a pannikin
which is missing.

Author: THE MIXER
Quote:
He'll criticise each
one told off / As a
"pannikin devotee".

Author: BREMER
Quote:
A man called Bob
Donoghue was the
second in command or
pannikin boss of the
navvies as they were
called, and besides
being pannikin he
was also the first
aid man.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Of particular interest ... was the fact that the boat had a liquor licence. ... Singles soon turned to `double-headers' as we headed into the ... semi-darkness of the canyons. ... [The liquor] fired [the Maoris'] imagination ... Panic and fear is contagious - it was not long before several of the gang became `pannikin struck'. Ibid. 146 A bugle sounded and whistles blew. Someone yelled, `The Japs are on us.' Our tent was `pannikin struck'. Some of us were not even out of bed before the enemy struck [[on a Home Guard exercise] ...

I remember the times
when pannikin tea
and "brownie" with
the shearers was the
joy of my life.

"We made what we
call 'hoosh.' That
was made with
pemmican emergency
ration and powdered
biscuits. Each man
got a pannikin full.
..."

For breakfast each
man had a whole
pannikin full of
biscuit and seal
liver, fried in
bacon and pemmican
fat, with a spoonful
of jam to follow.

" .. I am afraid
that their position
might have been
attended with
greater disasters,
had not one of the
runholders been in a
position to supply
them with flour,
limited to a
pannikin full each,
in order that all
might have an
opportunity of
obtaining one
farinaceous meal on
the road. ..."

Author: LADY MARTIN
Quote:
We were doubly
anxious to be
liberal after
hearing a very
good-tempered Maori
man contrast the
large-handed
hospitality of his
people to English
travellers, with the
`one pannikinful' of
flour, - about half
a pound, - doled out
to him when he
visited any one in
Auckland.

... on the arrival
of the first wagon
with flour, nine
miles from the
diggings, it was
surrounded by a
crowd of miners from
the field, when the
whole of the flour
was handed out ...at
2s. 6d. a
pannikinful.

Near Timaru,
Canterbury, a man
named William
Carter, a laborer,
killed himself on
Christmas morning,
by drinking a
pannikin-full of
neat brandy off at a
draught.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
In order to have a
daily supply of
water for cradling
and panning many
miners combined to
build this dam.

No gold was visible
in the stone, but
panning-off showed a
little free gold

CHEIMARRICHTHYS FOSTERI. Panokonoko, or Papane. During March Mr. Elsdon Best secured examples caught at Hiruharama, on the Wanganui River, North Island. Large numbers are annually secured by the Maoris of this locality. The panokonoko is much esteemed as a food fish.
Notes: Phillipps and Hodgkinson Further Notes on Edible Fishes

Quote:
Pansy ropes have red
threads in their
centre cord - [R.
Mason]

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
He stood fondling a
bottle of his
Panther Purge

... a little Roger
Rum. Perhaps this
`panther's milk' was
the cause of early
slumber.

Provided that
nothing in this
[Maori land] Act
contained shall be
construed to
authorise the
alienation of
papakaingas. ...
Notes: 1900 NZ Statutes, 1900, 64 Vict., no.55, pp.469-83 in 1971 Speeches and Documents 174

Author: JOSEPH
Quote:
Hollister took a
mouthful [of wine],
and found it thin
and poor. `Panther
piss,' said
Piotr[????]. `This
is what they sell to
the workers. ...'

[One of the
bridesmaids] gave a
pantry tea.

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
Me and him was
engaged one
pantomime season at
one of the theatres
in Sydney; him to do
the panty, and me
the sprite business.
[fn] [Panty]
Pantaloon.

HE PANUI. He Panui
tenei kia matau mai
...

In the course you
will learn korero
(speaking),
whakarongo
(listening),
tuhituhi (writing),
panui
(presentation), and
language structure
in a safe and
comfortable whanau
environment.

At the Native Land
Court's enquiry
concerning the Titi
Islands, Mr John
Moffett raised an
important point. He
submitted that part
one of the `Panui'
of the Native
Minister for
ascertaining the
persons entitled to
the rights conferred
under section 24 of
the Land Act, 1908,
to the Titi Islands
off Stewart Island
as described under
that section, ...
Notes: 1910 Feb Southland Daily News in 1979 Wilson Titi Heritage 155

Quote:
He Paanui [heading]
Regular meetings are
now being held at Te
Herenga Waka Marae
for the kaiawhina
(helpers) in
preparation for the
opening of the new
wharenui on 6th
December.

Music, panui, and
korero are delivered
in a 'whanau
friendly' format,
keeping listeners
up-to-date with
what's happening in
their tribal areas,
in both Maori &
English.
[heading] PANUI All Tawhana Land Owners a hui will be held at Piripari Marae, Waimana, on Feb 26...

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote: Panui Tanga.
Notes: Sub-heading above an advertisement published in Maori

Quote:
A "panui" has been
issued by Tawhiao
and Topia declaring
against Te Kooti.

The Conservation
Minister has
promised
consultation with
Public Access New
Zealand (Panz) on
how to go about this
task. Panz and the
thousands of
citizens who
objected to previous
governments' moves
towards
privatisation expect
action but are yet
to see it.

Public Aceess New
Zealand (PANZ) has
been hammering away
at the problem for
years.

Author: MACLEAN
Quote: There are 1,200 kits of kumara, large baskets of taro, papa or bark cases of birds cooked ..., including tui ...
Notes: 1849 July 16 Maclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 48

Quote:
Good papa country:
700 acres, 5 roomed
house, shearers'
whare..

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
.. this papa country
was on the move, and
those thousands of
trees had been
planted in an
attempt to hold it.
Papa country - the
blue papa in
particular - is of
excellent quality
...

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Today the short head
has a razor back
ridge for the head
and awkward broken
papa country to pull
on.

On Sunday, the 21st,
Capt. Northcroft
ascertained the
place where they
crossed the river
and went up a papa
creek.

Author: BROOKER et al.
Quote: Geniostoma ligustrifolium A. Cunn. Common name: Maori privet Maori names: Hangehange, papa

Author: BACON
Quote: papa - In Maori mythology, Papa was the earth-god, Rangi the heavens. ... Today, in legend, Papa is still the earth, but in particular the term is applied to a type of blue-grey clay rock.

It is proposed later
to put a coat ofpapa
on the position
beyond Hicks'house.

Author: HYDE
Quote: [At Arapuni dam-site] at the slightest vibration tons of papa came tumbling down.
papa : blue clay.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
(gloss.) papa: flat
rock, applied to
soft underlying
rock, blue-grey when
exposed, chalky if
dry and greasy if
wet. After rain, a
weak support for
hillside soil.

PAPA A sofe mudstone
occurring over large
areas of New
Zealand.

The Maori word for a
soft bluish clay.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`Up here the creeks
and rivers just made
straight courses
carried away trees,
roots and branches
like straws. Cut the
green flats on the
banks back to solid
rock and papa.'
[From a letter
written by Jock
Anderson, dated 11
May 1897]

The underlying rocks
are sandstones and
marls, which are all
generally termed
"papa", which is the
native name for
earth, or the earth
or anything smooth
and flat, such as a
board.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
MANIA, thin lamina
of sandstone used
for cutting the
`pounamu'. The
natives fasten them
in frames after the
manner of a
stonecutter's saw.
The word `papa' has
a similar
signification.

Author: ST JOHN
Quote: ... a reef composed of a peculiar and disagreeable kind of rock. Its Maori name is papa, its scientific appellation I know not; it is blueish in colour when dry; gets reddish under water.
Notes: 1873 St. John Pakeha Rambles in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 565

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
Papa and other clay
formations take
longer than
limestone soils to
break in from fern
... [fn.] The term
`papa' is applied in
the South Island,
not to clay or heavy
soil, but to a
porous, brittle
limestone rock.
Underlying the limestones everywhere [in Hawkes Bay] are blue clays locally known as `papa'. Ibid.25/355 ... blue marly crumbling clays, called `papa' by the natives.

Author: REEVES
Quote: [Papa] is a blue, calcareous clay often found with limestone which it somewhat resembles. The Maori word `papa' is applied to any broad smooth, flattish surface, as a door, or to a slab of rock

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Maori word for a
bluish clay found
along the east coast
of the North Island.

Beyond the volcanic
formation - that is,
from about Urenui on
the north and Hawera
on the south - the
country is generally
broken, and the
formation is known
as papa - a
calcareous blue
clay, capped in many
places by shelly
limestone.

The blue and yellow
clays, often locally
[Parapara, Nelson]
called `papa', are
sometimes well
banded ...

These clays which
are commonly known
by the Maori name
`papa'.

The Patea claystones
are of the type
which throughout New
Zealand is popularly
called `papa'.

Underlying the
limestones
everywhere are blue

It is papa country -

eastern seaboard

unstable, crumbling
formation, which
water and weather

fertility, readily
grows and retains
the best of English
grasses and quickly
hides the scars made
by the eternal
slips.

Quote:
Papakainga -

connotations this
word implies.
Papakainga is that
area where one's
original kinship
group came from and
lived. Whether or
not the area has
buildings on it, it
has strong emotional
overtones for any
Maori. In this age
of the urban Maori,
the ability to refer
to ancestral areas -
the place where
one's own history
was made - is a
matter of deep
pride. Once known,
one can never leave
it - though one may
be physically absent
all one's life.

Author: PARKER
Quote: There are eleven species of Native Ducks belonging to nine genera, all found elsewhere, except two--the little Flightless Duck of the Auckland Islands (genus Nesonetta) and the Blue Mountain Duck (Hymenolaemus). Among the most interesting of the non-endemic forms, are the Paradise Duck or Sheldrake (Casarca variegata), the Brown Duck (Anas chlorotis), the Shoveller or Spoonbill duck (Rhynchaspis variegata), and the Scaup or Black Teal (Fuligula Novae-Zealandiae).
Notes: 1889 Prof. Parker `Catalogue of New Zealand Exhibition' 117 in 1898 Morris Austral-English 128

Quote: ... they [natives] wear shoes made of flax, which they call paralas; they are very humorous creatures ...

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: PARAERAE, a sandal formed from the plaited leaves of the phormium tenax,;or the `ti' (Cordyline Australis).;Three different descriptions of sandal are made by the natives. That called `paraerae hou' or `kuara' is made of a single layer of plaited leaves of flax; that called `takitahi' is similarly made from the leaves of the `ti;' the third, called `torua' is made of the leaves of the `ti,' but plaited in a double layer, so as to be very durable.

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: The whites would copy the native way of scraping flax for various purposes [c1840], and when their boots gave out would sometimes wear Maori `pararas' or sandals. Ibid. 178 He would walk down to Dunedin wearing pararas (Maori sandals) and carrying his boots ...

pa[a]raha, a climbing plant (Calystegia sepium), a convolvulus. The far-famed Te Rapauraha took his name from this plant as a reminder that when the body of his father was eaten by his enemies they used the leaf (rau) of this plant as a relish. another convolvulus (C. soldanella) is po[o]hue.

We followed [the sealers returned c1870s from West Coast to Stewart Island] with our eyes admiring their new hand made seal skin caps with the crest of a penguin or some other Antarctic bird sewn on front. Still wearing their flax pararos as it takes a long time to get used to wearing boots after a sealing trip. ... [78] It is in such places that the sealer is seen at his very best; travelling at great pace over rugged sea-piled rocks ... with their feet covered with flax or grass mats tightly laced ...
Notes: c1930 Capt. William McKillop The Topsail Schooner `Lark' (MS Tasmanian Collection, State Library of Tasmania) 73, 78

plaiting]
Notes: 1906 W.H.S.Roberts in 1914 History of North Otago (1978) 21

Author: COWAN
Quote: Accidentally the [Maori] fugitives ... shod with paraerae or sandals of flax-leaves, ... crossed the dividing range, descended the valley of the Rakaia, and emerged on the Canterbury Plains.

Author: COWAN
Quote: Quite accidentally the fugitives discovered a pass between the Alps ..., and toiling on ... shod with paraerae, or sandals of flax-leaves, they crossed the divide.

The party made
sandals or paraerae
of flax-leaves for
the rough passage
over the trackless
heights of rook
[sic] and snow.

... we did not see
any traces of
natives, till we
came to Open Bay
[near Jackson Bay],
where on the beach
we saw a broken
spear & a pair of
old parraras (a kind
of sandal made of
flax).
Notes: 1826 Boultbee Journal in 1979 Begg 139; see also c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 38

Quote:
shoes - pa|hra'rra
[paraerae]
Notes: c1826-1827 list of Maori words in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 111; also 1826-28 Boultbee Vocabulary in 1979 Begg 284

Quote:
... sealers `still
wearing their flax
<i>pararos</.i>
making their way to
their favourite
public house on
their return to
Riverton ... as it
takes a long time to
get used to wearing
boots after a
sealing trip'.
Notes: ?d W. McKillop The Topsail Schooner Lark 75-77 in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 38 [fn] [reference ?c1800, ?c1900]

Quote: ... sealers `still wearing their flax pararos making their way to their favourite public house on their return to Riverton ... as it takes a long time to get used to wearing boots after a sealing trip'.
Notes: ?d W. McKillop The Topsail Schooner Lark 75-77 in c1835 Boultbee Journal (1986) 38 [fn] [reference ?c1800, ?c1900]

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: This evening, Huruhuru made me a pair of sandals, such as are in common use among these natives. They are called `paraerae', and are made either with the leaves of the flax-[210]plant, or of the `ti' (cordyline Australis). ... Mine were a pair with double soles, called `torua', ...

Milking the Goats
cleaning the
pannikins making the
Tea

Herries Beattie
describes a
different method:
"This tussock was
placed in the
paraerae (sandal)
and the foot
inserted. Then the
tussock was brought
up the leg and tied
above the ankle.
This protection was
called puru and the
sandals were then
known as tupuru."
Patiti was also
regarded as "a fine
thing to put in the
paraerae to keep the
feet warm and if one
was wading it was
warmer with patiti
around the feet than
without it."
paraffin ... (normally called kerosene in NZ and Australia).

Author: HYDE
Quote:
[Island Bay,
Wellington] But
always ... [sic] the
sand had splayed out
in fawn-coloured
drifts, the pale
paraha bells had
trembled their taut
mauve silk, elastic
to the touch,
against the wind.

paraha, a climbing plant (Calystegia sepium), a convolvulus. The far-famed Te Rauparaha took his name from this plant as a reminder that when the body of his father was eaten by his enemies they used the leaf (rau) of this plant as a relish. Another convolvulus (C. soldanella) is pohue.

[Te Rauparaha's]
name signifies a
food leaf, the
paraha.

Author: HUNT
Quote: The aborigines term themselves Moriori, their conquerors still call them paraiwharas, or blackfellows - not from their complexions, ... - but, in their ideas, the term is synonymous with slavery.

Notes: Those from the Auckland Islands closely resemble the New Zealand parakeet, but are much larger.

Quote:
The list covers the
greater part of the
indigenous birds,
and practically
includes the whole
of the gulls and sea
fowl, and all the
smaller varieties of
the land birds from
the tui, huia, kiwi,
and morepork
downwards, such, for
instance, as the
fantail, wren,
Robin, kingfisher,
parrakeet, native
lark, cuckoo, blue
duck, etc., etc.

Within the last
three years all
these birds, and the
morepork as well (I
said "all," that is
a mistake, as I did
not see or hear the
parrakeet, that I
have not seen for
years), I have seen
in the thick part of
the bush on the side
of Mount Cargill.

Surely a bird had
swept by him in the
loose bush, and that
was the egregrious
cackle of a parakeet
far off!

Other toasts, both general and local, followed, the agricultural interest, the pastoral interest,and a number of other interests besides, and one gentleman convulsed the meeting by a speech on the subject of the parakeets, which are the pests of Long Bush at the present time, and like the rabbits of the west, are playing sad havoc with the products of both gardens and fields.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: In the morning ... I went ... to the Indian Cove, & shot there two new Kingfishers [[ed. fn] Now the new Zealand Kingfisher ...], some new yellow headed Flycatchers [[ed. fn] Now the Yellowhead Mohoua ochrocephala (Gmelin, 1789).], a fine large green and brown Pigeon [[ed. fn] Now the New Zealand pigeon ...] ..., a small Perrokeet, green with a red forehead ... [ed. fn] Now the Red-crowned Parakeet ...

Author: DOMETT
Quote: Let but a grass-green parrakeet alight/ To pluck from some wild coffee-bush in sight,/ And nibble .../ The scarlet berries; let some kingfisher/ Slip darting from the post .../

Author: BULLER
Quote: ... to say nothing of Korimako and Pitoitoi ..., we never saw or heard the notes of either the Piopio, the Tieke, or the Hihi, all of which birds were at one time more numerous even than the Huia. The Zosterops was everywhere abundant, also the Grey Warbler and Rifleman, and ... we found the Tomtit comparatively plentiful; the Parakeet chased its mate through the tree-tops with sharp cries of `twenty-eight'; ... and among the tangle of the underwood the ever-present Flycatcher displayed its pretty fan-like tail.

Platycercus
pacificus. Kakariki.
Parrakeet. Common.
... Platycercus
auriceps. Parrakeet.
Common.
PLATYCERCUS NOVAE-ZEALANDIAE, Sparrm. - Parrakeet.

Of these birds there
are two species, the
larger of the two
being the
red-fronted paroquet
and the smaller the
yellow-fronted
species. Of the two,
the red-headed
[*check] species is
the better linguist.

One of the bones
came from a parakeet
- Campbell's lost
parrot at last.

Author: PARKER
Quote: There are three species of parakeet, the red-fronted (Platycercus Novae-Zelandiae), the yellow-fronted (P. auriceps), and the orange-fronted (P. alpinus). The genus Platycercus is found in New Zealand, New Guinea and Polynesia.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Parrakeet, n. (various spellings) The New Zealand Green Parrakeet (called also Kakariki, q.v.) has the following species - Antipodes Island P.- tycercus unicolor,. Orange-fronted P. alpinusller Red-fronted P.- P. novae-zelandiae, Sparrm. Rowley's Parrakeet Platycercus rowleyi, Buller. Yellow-fronted P.- P. auriceps, Kuhl.

We have also no less
than four species of
parrakeets ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Kakariki. 1. n. Cyanorhamphus novae-zealandiae, small green parrot, parakeet.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
Parrakeets were very
common, and
developed a keen
appetite for fat.

The liquid notes of

[90] parakeets made

Bush robins,

pio (New Zealand

I heard a parakeet
yesterday.
It (sc. Copromea scrub) was in fruit, and on the fruit were feeding two kinds of parrakeet, unknown in New Zealand.

Parakeets were then

THE CHATHAM ISLANDS [From the Lyttleton Times.] .. The land birds now found are a large kite, the pigeon, the tui or Parson Bird, .. the parakeet ( Platycerus Sp.[sic]) .. all identical with the birds from the same genera found in New Zealand.

Author: BRUNNER

Notes: 1848 Brunner Expedition Middle Island in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 293

Paraki - this is the
small fish now
called the
`silvery'. It was

Notes: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 63

Quote: 19 RETROPINNA RETROPINNA (Richardson). Smelt. Called `paraki' by the Maoris of Arahura, on the west coast of the South Island. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: Vernacular Name.- Powell [TrNZI 2/84] was the first to point out that two fish were referred to as `smelt' in north Canterbury. These were Galaxias attenuatus and Retropinna retropinna. At present Canterbury residents refer to R. retropinna as `silvery,' on account of the silver line running along the side of the half-grown fish. Maoris refer to this `silvery' as `tikihemi,' and to the adult as `paraki.'
Retropinna retropinna: [European Name] Smelt [Maori Name] Paraki.
Retropinna retropinna (Richardson). Smelt. Paraki.

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: In some other localities these young [smelt, Retropinna] are called tuarenga. The half-grown fish is termed tikihemi and the adult paraki. Certain races of fish have a broad silvery band running along the side; hence the term `silvery.' It is to be regretted that in Canterbury the term smelt is still used to apply to the minnow, Galaxias attenuatus.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: SMELT (PARAKI) Retropinna retropinna (Richardson) ... They are often referred to as Silvery, while in other parts they are called Cucumber Fish.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: Paraki, a small fish like white bait, caught at the mouth of Waitaki.
Mouki (Asplenium bulbiferum) and parako (Asplenium obtusatum) were used for skin complaints.

Author: LINDSAY
Quote: In Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Kouradi,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North Island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. In the North [83] Island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.'

The principal sorts are large brown Parrots [ed. note [Kaka, Nestor septentrionalis.]] with white or greyish heads, green Parroquets, [ed. note [Red-fronted Parrakeet, Cyanorhamphus novae-zelandiae.]] with red foreheads, large wood Pigeons, ...
Notes: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/806 (Queen Charlotte Sound) [also entered at parroquet]

Author: MORRIS
Quote: `A fabric like merino, of worsted and cotton. So named from Paramatta, a town near Sydney, New South Wales.' (Skeat, `Etymological Dictionary,' s.v.) According to some, the place named Parramattameans, in the local Aboriginal dialect, `eels abound,' or `plenty of eels.'

are merely "tots" of

Author: POLACK

'Mauria mai he

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pisonia Sinclairii, Hook. fil. ... Nat. name, `Parapara', Col.

Quote: Para-para, Col[enso]. Pisonia Sinclairii.
The Parapara. Pisonia umbellifera, Seeman. ... This plant is found in several localities north of Whangarei ...

Author: CHEESEMAN
Quote: P[isonia] Brunoniana, Endl. ... A glabrous shrub or small tree ... [576] Parapara.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Pisonia Brunoniana (The Parapara) ... Maori name Para-para; sometimes called by the settlers the Bird-catching plant. North Island: Auckland province chiefly.
parapara, a tree (Pisonia Bruniniana), bird-catching tree: its sticky leaves are liable to entrap small birds; the tree does not eat them as the sundew does entrapped insects.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: 4. Parapara (Heimerliodenron brunoniana) leaves opposite, 4-15 in. long; ... fruits long thin, very viscous. [north N. Island].

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: PISONIA BRUNONIANA. Parapara is a small tree of quick, rather soft growth carrying leaves up to 40cm long, of dark glossy green ... Nodular ridges down the length of the `fruit' ... secrete a glutinous substance ... Most spectacular is the ability of this tarry substance to hold small birds. ... anyone who has seen a waxeye struggling to free itself from amongst a cluster of these fruits can easily understand why parapara has earned the name `bird-catching tree'. ... Where it grows with pukanui (Meryta sinclairii) two of our largest-leaved trees come together.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: On the mainland as well as on islands, and extending to East Cape and beyond, are the small trees parapara or the `bird catching tree' (Pisonia brunoniana) and tawapou (Planchonella costata).

home to..
theparapara plant

New Zealand is the

Parapox virus.

.. further tests
showed that the
animals suffered
from Parapox virus.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: We also got four kinds of Petrel in their burrows,- the Mutton Bird, Parara, Titi Wainui, and the Kuaka. Ibid. 201 Prion Vittatus - Broad-billed Petrel - Parara or Parera. The latter word is elsewhere applied to the Grey Duck - Anas Superciliosa.

Author: HOWARD
Quote: These are the names used by the southern Maori; in the North Id. Kuaka, Parara and Titi are applied to other birds. Kuaka: Pelicanoides Urinatrix, or Diving Petrel. Black Bill. Wing 4.7 inches. Titi Wainui: Prion Turtur or Dove Petrel. Parara: Prion vittatus, or Broad-billed Petrel. Bill very wide. Wing, 9.5 inches. Titi: Puffinus Griseus or Mutton-Bird. Sooty brown. Bill horn colour. Wing, 12 inches.

mat), at the

Quote:
They thoroughly

Author: ANGAS
Quote: The other garments of skins are the huru huru, and the parawai; the former is frequently worn, especially during the cold season, by the people of Cook's Straits and the districts south of Taupo [and is made of dog's skins] ... The other dress, called parawai, is exceedingly scarce; it comes from the Southern Island, and is made of strips of dog's fur, arranged indiscriminately all over a very large mat of the finest flax.

Zealand shipped

The parea or Chatham Islands pigeon ( Hemiphaga chathamensis ) is closely related to the kereru .. The parea population dropped to less than 50 in the 1980s, due to forest clearance and introduced predators ...

Quote: Again we gather in this place, here at Parihaka, on the marae of peace, to hear the word of God - we listen, we pray, we sing. Ibid. 37 The rape of Parihaka - a peaceful, and almost unarmed, defenceless village - was to be carried out not by British Imperial Forces but by true New Zealanders, and the invasion plans were hurried up because the Governor was out of the country.

the barrel of a gun.

BOYS.Among the
circumstances which
have contributed to
the popularity of
New Zealand as an
emigration-field
with intending
colonists at home,
its total freedom
from the baneful
effects of
"Convictism" is,
probably the most
powerful.

A great deal of

reformatory.

Another excitement
is the flowering of
the shrubby rata,
Metrosideros
parkinsonii, which
has springtime,
vermilion red
bottle-brush flowers
from September to
November. This rare
tree produces its
flowers on its old
bare stalks,
something no other
rata or pohutukawa
does... In nature,
this shrubby rata is
found only in Great
Barrier Island and
in northwest Nelson.

There are ten native
species of rata in
New Zealand all in
the genus
Metrosideros. Four
of these form trees
(northern rata,
southern rata,
Bartlett's rata and
Parkinson's rata)
and the remaining
six species are all
lianes.

In constitutional
terms, the word
"Parliament" refers
to all of the people
needed to pass
legislation - that
is, both the 120
members of the House
or Representatives
(known as Members or
Parliament, or MPs)
and the Sovereign
(the British
monarch,
respresented in New
Zealand by the
Governor-General).

"Parliament" also
refers to a physical
place: most
specifically the
debating chamber
where MPs meet, also
the building that
contains the
chamber, and more
generally still this
building and the
several others in
which MPs have their
offices. This
complex consist of
four buildings: the
Parliamentary
Library, Parliament
House, the Beehive
and a 22-storey
high-rise called
Bowen House.
parliament ... (Parliament) council forming the supreme legislature of NZ, consisting of the Governor-General and the House of Representatives.

Author: HEAPHY

In the lower regions

Orthornyx

Popokatea.], and
which had much the

We stock a fine

.. parrot's Beak,

2s ...

parrot's beak.

translated and

Author: PAUL
Quote: Wrasses A family (Labridae) of tropical to warm reef-dwelling fishes. Most of New Zealand's sixteen species are shared only with Australi. In most parts of the world these fish are called wrasses; the name parrotfish is incorrect, being properly applied to a separate mainly Pseudolabrus spp. (?formerly Labricthys spp. (esp. L. psittacula) [Morris] =scarlet parrot fish, soldier fish, spottie

The officer in
charge of the boat
produced lines, and
we were soon hauling
up cod and gurnets
and parrot-fish in

There are about half
a dozen different
kinds of the parrot
fish, but all
related to the
wrasse family.

Further along are
parrot fish with
their beak-like
mouths and their
round bodies.
... the natives now and then brought Hake.. parrot fish [ed. fn Pseudolabris pittensis.] and leather jackets, [ed. fn Cantherines scaber.]

Quote:
... the canoes came
alongside, bringing
us an abundant
supply, consisting
of various
descriptions of
fish; among which
were snappers,

Author: POLACK

Among the
piscivorous tribes,
are those well known
in Europe under the
appellations of
snapper, ..
parrot-fish,
flounders, skate,
cat and dog-fish,
sting-rays, eels.

A singular fish
which was new to all
on board except one
man who called it a
parrot fish.

Quote:
69. LABRICHTHYS
PSITTACULA. Rich.
Parrot Fish.
Mr Travers mentioned the recent observance of a rare parrot-fish in the market (Odax vittatus), ...

The Wrasse and
Parrotfish are
mostly caught
outside among the
kelp, and with the
Spotty are
indiscriminately
named Kelp-fish by
the fishermen,
though the term
Butterfish is also
given to the smaller
sorts.

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: PARROT FISH (Labrichthys psittacula). ... Very little is generally known about the species called in Dunedin the parrot-fish.

2. Mokohinou Islands. - Hapuku (or groper), hiwihiwi, barracouta, maomao, spotty, parrot-fish, leather jacket, korokoro-pounamou. ... 7. Portland Island. - Tarakihi, moki, frost-fish, barracouta, king-fish, john-dory, warehou, maomao, parrot-fish, flying-fish, smooth-hound, soldier fish. ... 16. Moeraki. - Rock-cod, gurnard, parrot-fish, butter-fish, sprats, conger-eel Ibid. 24/211 Parrot fish (Labrichthys psittacula). NUMBER OF FISH RECORDED - 12. LOCALITIES - Mokohinou, Portland Island, Moeraki, Cape Saunders.

When we see the
mackerel splashing
along we know they
are after squid; the
mullet, latris, and
parrot-fish are
always after them,
and even the moki
and butter-fish join
the hunt.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Parrot-fish, n. name given in Australia to Pseudoscarus pseudolabrus; called in the Australian tropics Parrot-perch. In Victoria and Tasmania, there are also several species of Labricthys. In New Zealand, it is L. psittacula, Rich.

At the Portobello Marine Fish - hatchery the swimming form has been taken from the stomachs of the following fishes: Smooth-hound (Mustelus antarcticus), .. parrot-fish (Pseudolabrus miles). ling (Genypterus blacodes), and Leather jacket (Pseudomonacanthus scaber).

Author: NATUSCH
Quote:
Family LABRIDAE
(wrasses).
Large-scaled fishes
with rather silly
faces, wrasses (Fig.
69.7) are known by
various local names:
spotties, soldiers,
kelp fish, parrot
fish, etc.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Parrot fish, scarlet, or soldier .. .. pau, puwai-whakarua .. .. Pseudolabrus coccineus
parrot fish ... n. brightly-coloured fish with parrot-like snout.
parrotfish n. a brightly-coloured fish with parrot-like snout.

Author: FISHER
Quote:
A number of
Parrotfish (they do
not live in schools)
were following me
around and picking
up the broken off
crayfish legs. The
Banded Parrotfish is
the most common in
the shallows - it
blends in with the
seaweed - but deeper
down the Sandaggers
Parrotfish and the
Scarlet Parrotfish,
often called the
`deep sea spotty',
take over.

Author: WILS
Quote:
PARROTFISH Three
varieties of
Parrotfish occur in
our waters - Banded,
Scarlet and
Sandager's (or King)
Parrotfish.

Author: AYLING
Quote:
Most members of this
family [Labridae:
wrasses] have been
known in New Zealand
as parrotfish
although in all
other countries they
are collectively
called wrasses and
the name parrotfish
is applied to a
completely different
family. A true
parrotfish (family
Scaridae) has
recently been found
in New Zealand ...

True, all new
`Parry' residents
were initially sent
there for
observation and
assessment.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote: However I'd been sloughed up for over three years by this stage ... and thought I might as well give it a bash. `Anything's a go', they used to say in Pare. Ibid. 252 PARRY, PARE (n) Paremoremo Prison.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
PARRY BLUES (n) The
uniform of inmates
at above.

Several times while
I was inside Parry
could have been the
end. I didn't care.

Patron of the

Waker; who gave an
interesting account
of her involvement
with PARS dating

... The Guest
Speaker, John
Whitty, from NZ
PARS, spoke on a
number of issues,
one of them being

lose or gain from
the two main
parties.

parsley, fool's [s] Aethusa cynapium L.

Phyllocladus
trichomanoides

The river is
bordered here and
there by grassy
flats and hanging
woods of timber
trees.. the silvery
parsley pine, with
its purplish points
...

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: ... I must especially mention [from the Middle island] a new species of the parsley-leaved pine (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), which the natives call E Hutu, to distinguish it from the tanekaha, another species of the same genus. Ibid 1/427 ... Tanekaha ... Phyllocladus trichomanoides ... one [pine] is called hutu by the natives, and is a Phyllocladus; ... Ibid. 1/307 The forest contains many tanekaha or parsley-leaved pines (Phyllocladus trichomanoides).

Author: WILSON
Quote: PARSNIP PALM (Melanoselinum decipiens) has been grown in Halfmoon Bay gardens for so long that some people call it `Stewart Island Palm'. In fact it is a curious member of the umbellifer family, not a palm, and is native to the Azores ...

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: We saw great flocks of Curlews or Oyster-catchers [at Queen Charlotte Sound], whom the people on board the Adventure called Parsons. We found several black & white ones amongst them, perfectly like those we have in England.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
The great feature of
the southern seas is
the multitude of
birds ... Huge
albatrosses,
molimorks (a smaller
albatross), Cape
hens, Cape pigeons,
parsons, boobies,
whale birds, mutton
birds and many more,
wheel continually
about the ship's
stern, ...

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
In a cage I saw a
bird called the
parson.It takes its
name from two
curious white
feathers on its
breast.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: Toi or Parson

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
The whalers call
[tuis] parsons from
the two white
feathers hanging
out. The native name
is paaroo [acutes
second a, first o].

Source: Narrative of Eight Months Sojourn in NZ, A
Author: HODGSKIN
Quote:
... the most
harmonious is the
toi or tue, to which
we gave the nickname
of parson, from its
being a beautiful
glossy black, and
having a small patch
of snow-white
feathers on the neck
... Some call this
the mocking-bird, as
it imitates the
voice of almost
every other bird,
...

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
[Morris] Cook named
this beautiful and
lively bird the
parson and
mocking-bird. It
acquired the first
name from its having
two remarkable white
feathers on the neck
like a pair of
clergyman's bands.
[Mr. Taylor is not
correct. Cook called
it the Poe-bird
(qv.) The name
`Parson-bird' is
later.]

On again, calling at
different stations
on the road till I
come to Te Aute
station, commonly
known as Parson
Williams. This is
where the famous
Maori College is,
and it is supposed
to be one of the
wealthiest stations
in the Hawke's Bay
province
[from a letter to the Spectator] The coming of the long-tailed cuckoo to New Zealand every springtime, from the warmer Polynesian islands is a great source of trouble to the parson bird.

Writing of the tui,
or parson bird, Mr
Buller, in his book
on New Zealand
birds, says:- "The
Maoris fully
appreciate the
mocking powers of
this bird, and often
devote much time and
patience to its
instruction ..."

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote:
The tuis or
parson-birds will
not take the trouble
to insert their
brush-tongues to get
at the honey, but in
their hurry, tear
open the flowers
with their beaks.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Prosthemadera ... novae zealandiae. ... [75] Parson Bird. TUI.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Tui, n. Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae, parson bird.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Tuuii, n. parson bird; ...

Author: BULLER
Quote: PROSTHEMADRA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (TUI OR PARSON-BIRD.) ... Native names. Tui and Koko; the young bird distinguished as Pi-tui or Pikari. Ibid. 88 The early colonists named it the `Parson-bird',in allusion to the peculiar tufts of white feathers that adorn its throat, and their fancied resemblance to the clerical bands.

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
No sign of human
life that morning;
the shrill cry of
the curlew on the
beach and the full
rich carol of the
tui or parson-bird
from the brushwood
skirting the shore
fell faintly upon
the ear.

Author: HAY
Quote:
Pigeons, nestors,
parrots, rail, kiwi,
swamp-fowl,
water-fowl, owls,
parson-birds, all
these and more were
eaten; while the
native dogs and rats
were held to be
great dainties.

11. Prosthemadera Novae Zealandiae, Gml. Parson-bird, Poe-bird, Tui, Koko. - Often builds under the shelter of Rubus twines, which many of us have learnt to fear or respect as bush-lawyer ... More than once I have found it near the top of a matipo (Myrsine) ...

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: TUI Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae Other name: Parson Bird.
parson bird n. the grey-crowned babbler; in New Zealand the tiri [Sic] named from two white feathers on the neck like a parson's bands.
parson bird ... n. grey-crowned babbler; in N.Z. the tui [Named from two white feathers on the neck like a parson's bands].

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Tui, [macrons u, i] n. ..., parson bird.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Parson bird's
benediction.
parson bird n. another name for tui.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Tui Prosthemadera novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1788) ... Chatham Island Tui P.n. chathamensis HARTET, 1928. ... OTHER NAME: Parson bird.

(Reprinted from the Hawke's Bay Herald November 8.) .. for I am like the nestlings of the Tui (or "parson-bird,") [sic] the dam goes to seek food, which having found she returns with it, and then the young gape their beaks wide open to receive their food.

The'tui' as he is
called by the Maori,
or 'parson-bird', as
named by the Briton,
is the delightful
little comforter and
joy of every tennis
party or five
o'clock tea that is
held by the bird
world of the New
Zealand bush.

In a certain school
the master in one of
the upper standards
had gone to great
pains to tell the
children about the
colour,
characteristics,
etc., of the Tui, or
Parson Bird.

Author: MORELAND
Quote:
The tuis were going
mad with delight;
cheerful birds
dressed in sober
black, with two
white feathers at
the throat, earning
them the name of the
'parson-bird'.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: ... and also the Toi [tui] bird or Parson. ... With two bands under the Chin of white Feathers, ... called Parson birds.

Author: YATE
Quote: [The Tui] has been called by some `the Mocking Bird' ... by others ... `the Parson Bird'. Ibid. 53 Tui - This remarkable bird, from the versatility of its talents for imitation, has, by some, been called `the Mocking Bird'; and, from its pecu-[53]liar plumage, has by others been denominated the Parson Bird'.

Author: ANGAS
Quote: The graceful tui, or parson-bird (prosthemadera Novae Selandicae) sported amongst the yellow blossoms of the kowai

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
[The Tui] from the
versatility of its
talent for
imitation, has, by
some, been called
the `Mocking Bird',
... by others, from
its peculiar
plumage, the `Parson
Bird'.

Author: HALL-JONES
Quote:
... but our parson
bird being beyond
reach held on his
discourse with much
nonchalance.
Altogether this bird
is a most remarkable
one: clothed in
feathers of deep
black from head to
foot, he wears a
most grave and
sacerdotal aspect.
This is not all: he
bears out closer the
clerical resemblance
by the possession of
two pure white
feathers under his
chin, and the parody
is complete when he
commences to utter
his guttural yet
energetic notes.
Sitting on the
branch of a tree as
a pro tempoire
[????] pulpit, he
wags his paw [????]
and shakes his head,
bending to one side,
and then to another;
as if he remarked to
this one and to that
one ... etc
Notes: 1850s in 1971 Hall-Jones Mr Surveyor Thomson 55-56 (Griffiths Collection)

Author: MACKIE
Quote: In Wm. Swainson's garden saw numerous Parson birds among the trees uttering their loud clear whistle ... they a good deal resemble our blackbirds. Ibid. 96 The only native bird we find commonly kept in cages is the `tue', Parson bird.

Author: EARP
Quote:
[Quoting a recent
letter of Sept. 17]
We had a pudding for
dinner today ...
composed of a green
parrot and some
parson-birds which
one of our
fellow-pasengers
shot; they were
delicious,
particularly the
parrot.

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
The parson bird is
as big as a starling
with a glossy
starling looking
appearance save that
from his throat
projects a
cravat-like tuft of
white feathers -
whence his name.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
Then we crept softly
up ... to have a
good look at the
Tui, or Parson-bird,
most respectable and
clerical-looking in
its glossy black
suit, ... and white
wattles of very
slender feathers ...
curled coquettishly
at each side of his
throat, exactly like
bands.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Several kinds of
birds are indigenous
to the woods and
waters; among them
the oyster-catcher,
bittern, kingfisher,
cormorant, quail,
wild-duck, mocking
or [16] parson bird,
parrots, parroquets,
woodhen, pigeon,
etc. (the [sic]
gigantic Moa bird is
believed to be now
quite extinct).

PROSTHEMADERA NOVAE
ZELANDIAE, Gml. Tui.
Parson-bird. ... in
the eyes of the
omnivorous settler,
it possesses the
higher merit of
furnishing an
article of food, and
no weak sentimental
feeling saves it
from the camp-oven.

Author: HUTTON
Quote:
11. PROSTHEMADERA
NOVAE ZEALANDIAE.
Gray. Parson Bird.
Tui.

A popular name for
the New Zealand tui;
the two white tufts
on the throat
suggested the white
bands often worn by
clergymen.
parson bird n : TUI

Author: DOMETT
Quote:
`Tui,' Parson-bird
or Poe-bird of Capt.
Cook Melliphagidae;
Prosthemadera Novae
Zealandiae.

It is very pleasing
to hear the deep
rich notes of the
parson-bird ....

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Parson-bird, n. the New Zealand bird Prosthemadera novae-zelandiae, Gmel.; Maori name, Tui (q.v.). See also Poe.

Author: WHITE
Quote:
The Tui, or `Parson
Bird,' as he is
irreverently called,
because he has a
tuft of white
feathers on his
throat which are
supposed to resemble
a clergyman's bands,
is shining black and
metallic blue.

Author: GORST
Quote:
The most striking
objects were the
kohai [sic] trees
...generally full of
large black parson
birds which suck the
flowers.

The tui is called
the parson bird
because it has a
small tuft of white
feathers growing

Partial Impact
explains light,
heat, electricity,
gravitation,
Freethought,
Socialism, epidemic
diseases, -
explainds in short
everything in the
heavens above, the
earth beneath, and
the waters under the
earth, except the
unwillingness of the
world to receive
thte theory itself.

At the meeting of
the members of the
Philosophical
Institute last
evening, Professor
Bickerton read a
paper "On temporary
and variable stars,"
in which he treated
of the partial
impact of two large
bodies as a possible
frequent occurence,
and as giving a
perfectly
satisfactory
explanation of
temporary and
variable stars, of
double stars, of all
kinds of nebulae, of
comets, and indeed
of all the varied
phenomena of the
universe.

This appears to be
the position of
Professor
Bickerton's theory
of Partial Impact,
and we should say
that he is justified
in asserting that,
"The fact that
astronomers are
working without it
has already caused
irreparable loss to
science ..."

Putting on full
steam ahead, Hoani
steered straight for
the electric freight
car, and
disregarding
Professor
Bickerton's partial
impact theory, he
crashed full into
Trow's wagon.

In 1878 Bickerton
revealed his partial
impact theory of the
creation of new
stars which formed
the basis of his
theory of cosmic
evolution. The
notion that the
oblique collision of
two stars produces a
new, hot, rapidly
expanding body
without destroying
the original two in
the process
explained virtually
all astronomical
mysteries for
Bickerton, but
provoked only
indifference or
scepticism from
scientists.

Partial impact
appears competent to
explain the
occurrence of
temporary, double,
and variable stars,
nebulae of various
kinds (the kind
depending on the
nature of the
impact), comets, and
finally stars or
suns accompanied by
bodies of smaller
size.

The hypothesis I am
about to describe
suggests that this
is the case, but
especially says
further, that if
they do knock
against each other
that the blow may be
a mere graze of the
two outside, or
sometimes a large
piece of each may be
struck off, and in
extremely rare cases
they may meet fair;
but as this latter
isso extremely rare,
the other cases are
those chiefly
considered, and so
the theory is called
Partial Impact.

Author: JENKINSON
Quote:
It was on 4 July
1878.. that
Bickerton read
before the
Philosophical
Institute of
Canterbury his paper
"On Temporary and
Variable Stars" in
which the main facts
of the theory of
partial impact were
first announced.

Source: Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast
Author: von HAAST
Quote:
This was the first
occasion upon which
the Professor was to
enunciate publicly
his theory of
"Partial Impact"
which was to become
an obsession with
him.
Partial Impact: a possible Explanation of the Origin of the Solar System, Comets, and other Phenomena of the Universe. By Professor A.W. Bickerton, F.C.S. ...

Source: Life & Times of Sir Julius von Haast
Author: HAAST
Quote: The hypothesis that I am about to describe suggests that this [collisions] is the case, but especially says further that if they do knock against each other, the blow may be a mere graze of the two outsides, or sometimes a large piece of each other may be struck off: and in extremely rare cases they may meet fair; but as this latter is so extremely rare the other cases are those chiefly considered, and so the theory is called Partial Impact. The effect of the collision of our two stars will be to strike a piece off each other where they touch, and each star will travel on with a slice cut off the side of each. The parts of each which met will be left behind by both the retreating bodies, and will probably remain where the collision occurred. But, owing to the way it has been struck off, the two sides being impelled in opposite directions, it cannot help revolving, and it is not unlikely that nearly all the thousands of rotating bodies and systems in the universe may have thus been set spinning by partial impact. At partial impact, rotation must ensue. The matter will tend to spread out more or less in a flare, with frequently gas at the poles and the middle body produced by the collision will generally be very hot, proportional to the mass.
Notes: 188? A. W. Bickerton to the Canterbury Philosophical Institute quoted in 1948 Von Haast Life and Times of Sir Julius Von Haast 236

As a youngster I

Diagrams showing the

Author: McARA
Quote: As the mine workings reached greater depths the ground generally became more solid and stable and more and more shrinkage stopes were worked, until this method became the principal one in use for stopes up to about forty feet in width. The method consisted of putting in the level timbers in the usual way, with short chutes or `passes' installed every other set to allow all the ore in the stope to be lowered evenly as it was worked. Ibid. 209 ... including ... chutes for ore-handling, or `passes' as they were generally known. Ibid. 315 Chutes or passes: Chutes for running the broken ore out of the stopes into the hand-trucks were, for shrinkage stopes, placed between alternate sets (about 10 ft centres). They were about three feet wide, mounted three inches above the truck, and fitted with top and bottom doors. The bottom door was removed and the flow of ore into the truck controlled by jambing a pass-bar across the chute. (This was a short bar about three feet long with a D-shaped handle). The bottom of the chute was inclined at about 50 degrees from horizontal. For filled stopes, the chute was installed at the bottoms of the cribbed ore passes, leading up through the filling to the face of the stope; the ore passes were usually spaced from 18 to 25 ft apart along the stope, this being a convenient distance for men to shovel the ore. Ibid. 329 Passes: See chutes.

Americanism, and

anachronism mars a

and it is the word
that I think should
be substituted.

pastoralist n. raiser of sheep or cattle, especially in a big way, as distinct from an agriculturalist.

Author: McNEISH
Quote:
Gulls perched on top
of the pole. This
was a Pastoralists'
Club.

Author: GRIFFITHS
Quote:
But it was not so
easy to arrange for

pastoralists all to
be available at any

Author: VEITCH

`Hundreds', an old
English word

lands' or runs,

As a pastoralist he

...

... a very important

sought by

comprehensible
unless this meaning

pastoralist n. NZ & Austral. sheep-farmer, cattle-farmer, squatter, grazier. [prec.]

Author: IHIMAERA
Quote:
Turanga , as Mr
(later Sir Donald)

... `... A Veritable
Paradise for
Pastoralists.'

Author: RUTHERFORD
MACDONALD

The small run

[Fescue] is regarded

... but in a sward
the plant ... must
be only a very

from the

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
Except for Eyrewell,
Glenmark was
probably the only
place in Canterbury
where pastoralists
tried to get English
grass paddocks back
into native pasture
before sowing
tussock seed.

Paś.tor-al-ist (p&adot.ś.t&etilde.r-al-&ibreve.st), n. One whose occupation is to breed and pasture sheep; the proprietor of a sheep station. Sir Henry Parkes. This word is gradually replacing squatter in Australian use. See SQUATTER.

The slight
protection afforded
by headlands and
reefs to the south
led the district's
first pastoralists,
the Rhodes brothers,
to choose the future
site of Timaru as
the point at which
to land stores and
ship away their
wool.

We have extensive
and growing
relations with the
studmasters and
pastoralists.

A further importance
is attached to the
enterprise of the
pastoralist, just
simply as a
pastoralist.

Author: MEEK
Quote:
[squatter] has been
superseded by the
term 'pastoralist.'

I have endeavoured
in the foregoing
pages to give a
sketch of the
advantages which New
Zealand holds out to
the pastoralist,
whether as to
climate or physical
aspect.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
He took them to
admit that the
pastoralist held in
his hand a contract
which the Government
was both morally and
legally bound to
respect.

He took up a run,
and was engaged as a
pastoralist for
about seven years,
when he returned
home to Yorkshire,
intending to settle
down.

The Directors of the
New Zealand Company
having revised the
purchase of land
andpasturage for the
settlements of
Wellington, Nelson
and New Plymouth..
are now about to
publish the same.

The following
Pasturage
Regulations for the
Canterbury
settlement have just
beenissued by the
Agent of the
Association...
Licences to which
only purchasers
ofrural land are
entitled for
pasturage to the
amount of five acres
for every acreof
rural land
purchased.

A Captain Lethart,
of Sydney, also here
[at Akaroa] since
the 10th of November
last, has
established a cattle
run, with about
thirty head of
horned cattle, and
had two stockmen in

better than at the
Bay of Islands
Notes: 1840 June 28 Thomas Bunbury's Report in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 106

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The land ... affords
great facilities for
pasturage, if
distributed in
extensive portions.

The Malvern Hills
afford first-rate
pasturage for sheep,
with sufficient bush
accessible.

I have rented 1,750
acres of pasturage
for about [pounds]14
per year ...

If the conditions of
a pasturage lease
shall be duly
fulfilled, the land
forming such a run
shall not be sold
without the consent
of the lessee, until
proclaimed a
Hundred.

A return has been
published showing
the amount of land
tax payable on lands
held from the Crown
under pasturage
lease and licence in
the different land
tax districts.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote: No pasturage license should be granted but after submission to public competition; any other system would infallibly lead to jobs, to the usurpation of immense districts by grasping adventurers without sufficient capital to stock them, and to general confusion, jealousy, and ill-will.

W. Ritchie applied
for a pasturage
licence over run 80,
Mt. Argentine. -
Granted.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
A district being
declared open to
selection, if one
man applied for
either kind of
property and made
the requisite
payment, he would
receive his
land-order or
pasturage licence,
and would be free to
select the land or

he pleased without
competition from
anybody.

Holders of pastorage
[sic] licenses were
given the right to
take timber required
for fencing or for

seven year terms.

Author: HALL-JONES
Quote:
In November 1854,
Watson (his

for the
'Poro-poro-kene' Run
No. 85 ...

... they one and all

The pasturage lease
or license entitles
the holder to the
sole right of
pasturage; gives no
right to the soil,
timber, or minerals;
and is no bar
against prospecting
or mining.

Author: C W RICHMOND
Quote:
We have just advised
the Governor to

land regulations of

1d. per head on the

Source: Review of Rentals for Pastoral Leases, A

available for

Quote:
Every holder of a

(if a resident in

The terms in which

It is unprofitable

Small set of cattle

Pasture is the

of grass, clovers,

bare ground.

Author: PETER

Pasture lice is the

Pasture lice: sheep.

.. and 130 for sheep
including pasture,

Pasture-pulling

Pasture-pulling
ocurs on many dairy

Author: MONEY
Quote:
Swiftly did I return
unto `mine host',

sack' for my
refreshment,

Only a few weeks ago

against the

rather than the

Pats, because they

Quote:
This strictly to my
Pat Maloney ...

Author: POLACK
Quote: There are many other woods of much service to Europeans, differing in quality, among others: the 31 Pata.. 45 Parekireki, &c. Of all these woods there are abundant quantities.

Author: POLACK
Quote: The smallest garment woven is called the patai [a1-acute], principally worn by females for an inner garment; the korowai differs but little from the former, except in having a deep fringe of knotted flax strings. The tatata [as-acute] is similar in size to the former, having pending from every part, an infinity of small cords six inches long, of no use or ornament; its origin must be ascribed to the arbitrary taste of fashion,

Sufficient for two

Author: ANGAS

Some time before we

house and

Quote: Pataka, n. Maori word for storehouse, supported on a post to keep off rats. See Whata.

it [sc. puha] cooked

Hence, when ... a
large tangi or other

made shift with

The pataka is a

~ n. same as futtah q.v. [Maori]
*Pataka.-A correspondent tells me that this is the general name for a futtah (store on legs) in the North Island. Austral English derives our word from whata (Maori).

... the [Maori]
woman brought filled

slopes to fill the

pa[a]taka, a food-storehouse raised on posts: the one on a single post is a whata. Many pa[a]taka were as elaborately ornamented as a house.
pataka: raised storehouse.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote: Those are pataka for storing choice food like kumara, preserved birds, and hinau bread.
pataka A Maori storehouse supported on a post.
pataka n. storehouse [Maori].

PATAKA Store house,

pataka ... n. storehouse [Maori].

Author: BURTON

Author: BAXTER

pataka n. Maori store-house raised on posts. [M]
Sometimes the storehouse was set up on legs 3 ft. or 4 ft. high and called a pataka ...

On the brow of a
slight acclivity,

stage or terrace of

sit during the day.
It is called by them
a pataka.

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote: [From the Maori Messenger] They also explained that the matangohi is sacred, his flesh is never eaten, neither is his head exposed, but the body is hung up in a tree and cut up something like that of a pig, after which his remains are placed on a pataka or stage in a tree and there left.
Notes: Part of serialised journal 'by His Excellency the Governer-in-Chief of New Zealand'.

Author: HAY

It chiefly inhabits raupo swamps.

I myself will build

maere (Mira

patate (Aretia

Quote:
The posssibility of
finding a `pocket'
or better still a
good `patch' added
interest to the
[gumdigger's] day's
work.

I previously had to
patch burn against
getting burned out
in summer or autumn.

I was wearing my
colours - the
insignia of the
Epitaph Riders which
is sometimes
referred to as a
patch. ... He had
head injuries and
went to the
headquarters in
Lincoln Road where
he left a note that
his patch had been
taken. ... If a
member of the gang
lost his patch he
had to try and get
it back himself. He
had still not got
his patch back, he
said.

Author: MITCALFE
Quote:
`So, Winston's
joined a gang has
he?' ... `Hasn't got
his patches, or his
jacket yet, I know
that.'

The police said that
the gang grew to
more than 30 patches
...

Would it be true
there were about 43
members of Black
Power ... Mr marsh:
Yes, that would be
true but not patch
ones.

He was in the gang
but he wasn't a
patch.

"As to the claim, I
think it has been
proved already that
the gold is there,
but it seems as if
it is going to be
patchy, or rather we
are only going to
get the gold in
patches... If we
could get a
continuous week's
work on a patch such
as we have had it
would yield over
1000oz for the week.
.."

I don't expect there
is much in the
washing dirt, at
least what we have
thrown out yet, but
as the gold lies
very patchy we may
come across a small
patch yet before we
work our claim out.

Source: Report on Geol. of SW Nelson
Author: McKAY
Quote:
Within [the block]
lie the rich
alluvialdiggings of

of itsgold.

This field surpassed
all others in a
series of rich
patches; ... these
patches were
magnified into leads
- they did not prove

`Say, stranger! you
ain't struck a patch

there, have you?'

Again party ..

was probable they

the precious

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
Here we drive in and
ask for a
paddock[sic no .]
Past the shearing
shed - past the
homestead to a
beautiful place with
a little patch of
bush - tuis -
magpies -cattle -

Mr. Henry also
states that the
skeleton ... was
found at the edge of
a patch of bush,
about 200 acres in
extent (locally
known as the
'Wilderness') ...

On the following
morning a start for
the summit was made,
and after winding
their way from one
gorge to another,
the party at last
got on the slope of
the mountain, which
for a long way up is
covered with a dwarf
moss, and patch
plants of every hue,
which can only be
compared to a rich
Brussels carpet.

At Ophir and along
the sunny side of
Raggedy Ridge,
wherever the tussock
has been destroyed
by persistent
burning, the ground
is becoming covered
with the patch
plants Raoulia
australis and
Raoulia parkii,
which, however
beautiful they may
be, so effectually
cover the ground, as
with a carpet, that
the growth of
grasses or other
fodder plants is
impossible where
they exist.

Notes: Buchanan Notes on the Botany of Mount Egmont (And)

Quote: ... all the flowering plants ... that form wood are nearly stemless, and in most cases are aggregated in the form of hard hasssock-like patches ... forming what are known as patch plants.

Author: FEATON
Quote: HECTORELLA COESPITOSA (Hook.,F.) ... many of these class [sic] of plants, which are known as `Patch Plants', having only one terminal flower [at the end of] each branch.
This subalpine `patch plant' [Raoulia australis] ...

... the patch plants
usually found in
these alpine and
subalpine regions
are abundant.

Mr Urquhart says the
council wants to
patch poison the
blocks using 1080
carrot ...

Many of these ventures have paid well, but the progress will naturally be slow, particularly as the ground is so very patchy. As a `fossicking' locality this is a favourite place ... Ibid. [?p] The hills are also auriferous and patchy.

Archie Drummond, our

... [fn] Clown.

A few hours later, John Morrison found a pate tree with some wood rose, Dactylanthus taylorii, growing from its root system... To date Hauturu is the only offshore island where Dactylanthus has been found.

The sap of our
native pate has mild
fungicidal
properties known to

.. If that doesn't

Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: P|ate, s. A tree, the branches of which are used by the natives in producing fire by friction.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Pate [e-acute] (Aralia polygama,) trunk slender, and pithy, grows to twenty feet, leaves virent digitated and epinated at the edges; the wood is made use of for procuring fire by friction.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: The Pate tree is by no means handsome as a tree or shrub, having nothing remarkable, only that its wood when decayed produces fire by rubbing or friction, if rubbed by a harder piece of wood, ... [Glossary 119 pate, patete Schefflera digitata].
Aralia Schaefflera, Spr. ... Nat. names, `Pate', R.Cunn.; `Patate', Middle Island, Lyall.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pate, Col[enso]. Schefflera digitata.

Of our shrubs and smaller timber trees, several are of strikingly beautiful growth ... (e.g.) the Houhere, Hoheria populnea ...; .. the Pate, Schefflera digitata; the Horoeka, Panax crassifolia: and, on the sea-coast, ... the Karo, Pittosporum crassifolium; and the truly evergreen Ngaio, Myoporum laetum ...
Pate[e-acute] (Schefflera digitata). A small tree, common everywhere in Otago.

Author: KEENE
Quote: pate: much-branched small tree 15 ft. to 20 ft. high.

Author: CHEESEMAN
Quote: [Schefflera digitata, Forst.] Pate; Patete.

Source: Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs

Author: BULLER
Quote: ANAS CHLOROTIS. (BROWN DUCK.) ... Native names.- Tarawhatu, Patete, {Tete,} and Tete-whero.

Our "pets" were wild
kaka, tui and
pateke, and a kereru
which regularly
visted the homestead
to be hand-fed bread
and bananas.

Five years ago karen
Walker began looking
after the odd
pateke/brown teal
duckling and banded
rail chick abandoned
near her home on
Great Barrier ...

The same cannot be
said for nine pateke
or brown teal
released in August,
but on the day we
visited,
Conservation
Department staff
found the first
nest, with five
eggs, and were
hoping it was a good
omen for the
reclusive,
threatened native
duck.

They live in the
shadow of glamour
birds like the kiwi
and kakapo, but on
Friday the
diminutive brown
teal was a star in
its own right.

MR F N HAYES holds
one of two female
brown teal or pateke
ducks which are
being airfreighted
to a new home in
England ... The
pateke is a New
Zealand species and
was until the 1900s
widespread. Since
then numbers have
been drastically
reduced, through
habitat destruction
and by introduced
predators, to a
stage where it is in
danger of
extinction, with
less than 1000 birds
surviving. The birds
will be settled at a
wildlife sanctuary.

There was a fierce
beauty about its
scale, the precision
of its movements,
the way everything
meshed to deliver
the raw power to
haul ships out of
the water at the old
Patent Slip in Evans
Bay... Wellington
Provincial Council
let a contract for a
slip in Evans Bay in
1868 but wrangling
between the council
and contractor
stalled progress and
the job was
completed by the
Wellington Patent
Slip Company in
1873. For the next
96 years the slip
hauled 6000 ships up
the rails on its
concrete incline - a
total of more than
two million tonnes
deadweight.

A colleague of mine
calls it "path
dependency". That is
when one reaches a
forking point and
decides to embark on
a new path, try as
one might, one can
never return to the
original point of
intersection again .
. . .

These strategies
include the Paths
scheme, which pays
for health treatment
for beneficiaries to
help them get back
into work.

Upon completion, you
can pathway onto our
Pre-Employment
Carpentry Course.

Clough, Elliot ...

An 18ft open boat is

think the Bonita
could easily defeat
any Auckland patiki
in a big breeze.

A puff of wind strck
the small craft. The
patiki rocked a few
times, and then went
gunwale under.

has chopped round

their moorings
during the festive
season.
Sand Flounder New Zealand Flounder, Patiki, Three corner, Tinplate Rhombosolea plebeia. ... Black Flounder - Patiki - Rhombosolea retiaria.
RHOMBOSOLEA PLEBEIA (Richardson). Sand-flounder; Patiki. One of the commonest flounders, frequenting deeper water than the yellow flounder, and never found in estuaries of rivers.

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: PATIKI (Rhombosolea monopus). Ibid. 304 Rhombosolea monopus Gunther Patiki, or Flounder

Of the sea-fishes
that are used as
food in New Zealand,
we have among the
constant residents
on all parts of our
coast the hapuku,
tarakihi, trevally,
moki, aua, rock-cod,
wrasse, and patiki;
and while the
snapper, mullet, and
gurnet are only met
with in the north,
the trumpeter,
butterfish, and
red-cod are confined
to the south. ...
The following is a
list of the fishes
which are chiefly
met with in the
market: hapuku,
kahawai,
red-snapper,
snapper, tarakihi,
moki, trumpeter,
frostfish ...
gurnard, mullet,
sea-mullet, ...
flounder or patiki,
... grayling, smelt,
kokopu, sardine,
sprat, eel (tuna),
black-eel,
conger-eel [168],
and silver-eel.
