Author: GRAHAM
Quote: NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) Rhombosolea plebeia (Richardson) ... The common Sand-flounder is known from one end of New Zealand to the other, sometimes by other names in different localities. In Auckland it is known as the Dab.../ Some refer to it as Tinplate or Three Corner; the latter name is derived from its fancied trangular shape but why Tinplate I am at a loss to know. To other than fishermen and those intimately connected with the fishing industry it is just a Flounder. Some say it is Tinplate because when cooked it fills a plate.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle

In the bays and

RHOMBOSOLEA RETIARIA Hutton. Black Flounder; Patiki-mohoao. This species, known generally as `river-flounder,' is occasionally taken in the sea. Common in the estuaries of most large rivers, and often taken many miles inland.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: NEW ZEALAND BLACK FLOUNDER or RIVER FLOUNDER (PATIKI-MOHOAO) Rhombosolea (Adamsoma) retiaria adams Whitley and Phillipps/ It is known to fishermen and those in the fishing industry as the River Flounder as it is caught mostly inside or near the mouths of rivers and enters lakes where it lives chiefly among weeds. To some it is known as the Maori Flounder. I have helped to catch these fish in various rivers in New Zealand, Both in the North and South Islands, from the Bay of Islands, Bay of Plenty, Canterbury and Otago.

is spread to the sun
/ And yellow
taukinae* where
clear waters run . .

shrub.

The camp shelters
were made of patiti
(tussock) and taru
(grass) woven on
sticks and were of a
temporary nature
merely designed to
keep off the rain
and wind.
Notes: From Beattie "Traditional Lifeways of the Southern Maori"

Quote: Maori names for tussock varied from region to region. In one southern dialect, wi was used for silver tussock (further north the same word was applied to rushes) and patiti seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with maania an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular.

We made the trek in
through the patiti
to a spot with a
view of the sea and,
facing the other
way, inland to the
Paparoa Ranges.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: The hills [at Otakou] are clothed with wood, or a species of grass (tritium Scabrum), known by the name of `patiti'. Ibid. 19 Species of grass (tritium scabrum), known by the name of `patiti'. Ibid. 195 We now advanced along the plain [towards Moeraki], which was covered with `patiti' and ... stunted fern and `tutu'. These plains are called `pakihi,' a word used in the North Island to signify dried up. So that `tupakihi,' the name by which the `tutu' is there known, appears to be a contraction of `tutupakihi,' or `tutu' of the [196] plains, which are well called `pakihi,' being for the most part arid. Ibid. 312 PATITI, a coarse grass growing in tufts (tritium scabrum, Raoul).;

The M'Quarrie
cabbage, cotton
plant (I have an

... [178] Greatest

He was met and

unfair practices

and began to

...

comprises 5 floor

pot).

The bracken of the British Islands is represented by a closely similar plant, having as wide a range of distribution [as no other British and NZ fern has]; and the same remark applies to the representative forms, with the exception ... of the patotara (Botrychium ternatum).

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Patu, n. Maori generic term for all hand-striking weapons. The mere(q.v.) is one kind.
Patu n. any weapon used in the hand. [Maori]

Author: ELDER
Quote: [?18?] [The chiefs] were armed with their patooes (patus). (dagger) The root idea of the word patu is `to strike.' The word is applied by the Maoris to all weapons, and also, with a qualifying adjective, to pounders and beaters of flax, fern-root, etc. The early explorers, e.g. Cook, restricted the term to weapons of the mere type, and, as a generic term for this group of weapons is useful - in fact necessary - the usage, though not strictly a Maori one, has been followed by modern ethnographers.
Notes: 1932 Elder note to Letters and Journals of Samuel Marsden 86

Quote: patu: striking weapon.

... they have short Truncheons about a foot long, which they call Pattoo Pattoos 5, some made of wood some of bone and others of stone. Patoo Pattos as they calld them, a kind of small hand bludgeon of stone, bone or hard wood most admirably calculated for the cracking of sculls. [fn] [Beaglehole] ... The most beautiful of patu was of course the greenstone mere.

Author: COLLINS
Quote: Pat-too pat-too, To beat, also the name of a principal weapon.

The battle then became general. A number of women were in the heat of the action, among whom was Tippahee's old wife, not much less than seventy years of age, and Duaterra's wife bearing in her hand a patoo about seven feet long, made out of the jawbone of a whale. [fn] This weapon, the hoeroa, was made almost invariably of whale bone. All specimens extant are made from the lower jaw of the sperm whale. Both ends are rounded, one end being elaborately carved; there is often, also, some carving about the middle. About five feet in length, it seems to have been used, for the most part, as a missile weapon. - Vide Elsdon Best, The Maori As He Was, p.276 et seq.

Author: MARSDEN
Quote: The chiefs were all seated on the ground, according to their custom, and their warriors standing up with their spears fixed upright which were from 15 to 20 feet in length and upwards. They were armed also with their pattooes (patus). [fn] The root idea of the word patu is `to strike.' The word is applied by the Maoris to all weapons, and also, with a qualifying adjective, to pounders and beaters of flax, fern-root, etc. The early explorers, e.g. Cook, restricted the term to weapons of the mere type, and, as a generic term for this group of weapons is useful - in fact necessary - the usage, though not strictly a Maori one, has been followed by modern ethnographers.

We are immortal you

strangers who came

When it was time to

"I've been

The tasting platter

There's a saying in

Fritters, after

I couldn't argue

At the end of last

riesling.

If he decided to

such an "active"

.. the restaurant's
magnificent paua

The smaller, less abundant yellow-footed or queen paua, Haliotis australis, often found together with its larger cousin, is taken in much smaller quantities and has a minimum catch size of 80 mm.

Pá.u-a (pa.́.u-&adot.; colloq. pa.́.wa. or poú.&adot.), n. [Maori.] (Zoo.l.) The ear-shell (Haliotis iris); also, a fishhook made by the Maoris from this shell. [Local, N. Z.]

The Editor,The
DominionPavlova -
Name and NatureSir,
-- In spite of silly
claims regularly
surfacing especially
in Australia
(Dominion 2/2/99),
the facts of the
development of the
confections and the
date the name
`pavlova' was
applied to them have
been reasonably well
known for some years
now. They may be
found in the
Dictionary of NZ
English (1997), the
Australian National
Dictionary (1988),
and the writings of
Professor Helen
Leach of Otago
University.The name
`pavlova' post-dated
the ballerina
Pavlova's
Australasian tour of
1926, and was first
applied in New
Zealand by the Davis
Gelatine Company in
1927 to a jelly
dessert whose
moulded
multicoloured shape
may have suggested a
tutu. It was next
(in 1929) applied
independently (and
only in NZ) as
`pavlova cake' or
`sponge' or
`meringue' to the
previously well
known so-called
`meringue cake' or
`sponge'. The recipe
change to the
legendary pavlova
icon is usually
reputed in NZ to be
the addition of
vinegar to give the
soft centre, and in
Australia, the
trademark of
passionfruit in the
topping. (The name
`pavlova' does not
occur in either the
Futter book (1926)
or the Terrace
Tested Recipes
(1927) mentioned in
your report.)The
elliptical simple
form `pavlova' for
the meringue is
recorded earliest in
Australia from 1940
(so AND, two of
whose quotations
acknowledge NZ as
the originator) and
in NZ from 1953
(DNZE).There is no
evidence that the
name `pavlova' was
applied in Australia
before 1940. Both
countries share the
earliest recorded
date 1966 (and the
same quotation) for
the abbreviation
`pav'.The New
Zealand Dictionary
Centre at Victoria
University (Box 600,
Wellington) would be
glad of any
pre-datings of any
of the above, with
author, title, date,
and page
references.Harry
Orsman

Contrary to what they'll tell you in Perth, Western Australia, Bert Sache, a chef at the Esplanade Hotel did not invent the pavlova. All he did, in 1935, was to make a meringue and cream cake that he said was "light as Pavlova", the Russian ballet dancer who six years earlier had stayed at the hotel. but the name stuck and thus was born the myth about its origins. The truth is that the large meringue with the marshmallow centre - the heart of the pavlova - was common in New Zealand in the early 1930s, even earlier. In 1927, for instance, there was a recipe for a meringue cake submitted by a Mrs McRae in the second edition of Terrace Tested Recipes, collected by the ladies of the Terrace Congregational Church in Wellington.

The breakthrough [to substantiate New Zealand's claim for first use of the word] came in 1929, when the NZ Dairy Exporter Annual published the first known recipe for "Pavlova Cake" as we now know it. Granted, the recipe was for a two-layered pavlova, but this, after all, is a common variant ...

Pavlova [heading below a coloured picture of a fluted (`pleated' or `tutued') turned-out moulded jelly mound, coloured in layers from top to bottom green, white, orange-yellow, and red, and standing on a plain dish, with no background] Ingredients 1 1/2 cups hot water/ 1 cup orange juice/ 1/2 cup milk/ 3 dessertspoons Davis gelatine/ 6 dessertspoons sugar/ Flavouring/ cochineal - sap green colouring Directions Dissolve all but a teaspoonful of Gelatine ... [arrange orange or other fruits around base: serve with cream or custard]
Pavlova 8-10 servings.[The coloured picture is now larger, the background, and directions, more complex] 8-10 Servings
Pavlova 6 Servings [Picture essential;ly same as 1937: added directions for use of refrigerator.]
PAVLOVA ... hot water ... orange juice ... milk ... Davis Gelatine ... sugar ... Flavouring ... Cochineal - sap green ... serve with cream or custard ...

Pavlova. 6 Servings. Ingredients. Davis Gelatine, Hot water, Sugar, 1/4 cup milk, Slices of oranges, 3/4 cup orange juice, Lemon essence, Vanilla essence, Cochineal, Green colouring, Citric acid. Method. First layer: Dissolve 1-1/2 teaspoons gelatine and 1 dessertspoonful sugar in 1/2 cup hot water; add a pinch of citric acid and lemon essence to flavour. Divide the mixture, colour one half red and the other green. Pour the green into a mould. Second layer: Dissolve 1 teaspoon gelatine in 2 tablespoons hot water. Add 1 Dessertspoon sugar to 1/4 cup milk; stir until dissolved. Flavour with vanilla essence. Add gelatine. Carefully pour on to the green layer, which must be firm. Third layer: Dissolve 1 dessertspoon gelatine in 1/4 cup hot water, add 3/4 cup orange juice, 3 dessertspoons sugar or more. When the milk layer is firm, arrange orange circles round the mould and add the orange jelly, which should be thickening a little at a time. Fourth layer: Re-melt the red jelly, if it has set, by standing in hot water. When cold pour over the orange layer, which should be firm. If setting in an ice-chest or refrigerator, use less gelatine - First mixture: 1 teaspoon. Second mixture: 3/4 teaspoon. Third mixture: 3/4 dessertspoon.
Notes: 1937 Davis Gelatine Organisation Davis Dainty Dishes [editions 1-8 1922 to 1936] 57

It comes as a shock to realise that this all-Australian dessert was in fact first given its name in New Zealand. The great ballerina, Anna Pavlova, toured Australia and NZ in 1926, providing the occasion for the creation of this new dish. "Light as meringue, light as whipped cream", you can hear the chef saying. The first citation is from NZ, in a 1927 booklet put out by Davis Gelatine called Davis Dainty Dishes.

Author: BURTON
Quote: Pavlova is more than a national dish, it is an institution. ... Sweet, airy and laden with calories, the cake was named after Anna Pavlova who visited New Zealand in 1926. ... It is worth mentioning here that the Australians claim to have invented the pavlova, and insist that it was created in honour of Pavlova by a Melbourne woman in 1926. New Zealanders, however, might answer that in the same year a pavlova recipe appeared in a book entitled Home Cookery for New Zealand (although it went under the name of `Meringue with Fruit Filling') and that another recipe actually called `Pavlova' was published the following year. Certainly the classic kiwkfruit (Chinese gooseberry) topping which the Australians have also adopted must belong to New Zealand.

peacenikity.

Author: FUTTER
Quote: PEACH A L'AUSTRALIAN Line a mould with Florence paste ... leave paste in moulds till cold ... turn out ... whipped cream ... put a teaspoon in each half of shape, place half a cooked ... peach .. royal icing coloured with carmine, force a border round each half of shapes ... put halves together ... glaze with a glace ... dust over icing sugar ...
~ v.t. to pick out the best parts of an area so that the remainder is useless to any one else.
peacock ... v. gridiron (q.v.).
peacock same as gridiron (q.v.).

have been classified
according to their
physical properties,
and many of the
purely local names
applied to special
varieties are based
on such properties -
for instance,

The horses had
peaked on him.

The sheep `peaked',
and the six-mile
drive over the
Birdwood Saddle took
us ten hours.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
He also had another
natural talent,
which always showed
up when one of the
three sheep he was
hunting on a trial
course would look
like peaking.

The cows milk like
you wouldn't
believe. We had a
gnarly first spring
and the herd still
peaked at two
kilograms of milk
solids per cow.

Supplying
shareholders may
take capital notes
in exchange for
surrendered
co-operative shares,
supply redemption
rights, peak notes
or redeemable
preference shares.
Global Dairy must be
able to change the
price of peak notes
and the peak note
standard ...

What are they going
to do with the
developing Peak
Notes fiasco? Peak
Notes were designed
as a capital funding
mechanism for the
cost of stainless
steel required to
process farmers'
milk. If you supply
more milk at the
height [peak] of the
production season
you force the
company to install
more and bigger
plant and you
therefore help pay
for that extra
requirement by
buying more Peak
Notes .. farmers are
struggling with all
of the rules that
impact on Peak Notes
and there is a
fundamental inequity
in the system.

But they and most of
the other farmers
they know do not
want a bar of the
company's peak
rights proposal that
would see new
suppliers or
existing
shareholders pay $30
a litre for any
extra milk they
produce .. The
company maintains
that peak rights
would see new
suppliers coming
into the company
paying a fuller
share of the capital
cost to set up new
factories.

Dairy Group
directors are
unveiling changes to
its new scheme,
called peak rights,
at a series of
supplier meetings
this week. Peak
rights is designed
to make extra milk
pay for the extra
capacity needed to
process it.

Most Kiwi
shareholders, and
most industry
commentators, are
unimpressed by the
peak rights concept.

He believes winter
milking may become a
practice of the
future because,
instead of having to
pay premium prices
for peak rights,
farmers will draw
the season out to a
year-round
operation.

Author: NEWTON

PEAKED: Knocked up -
become exhausted.

... only the smaller
launch - commonly
known as `the
peanut' [at Evans
Bay Boat Club].
PEANUT CRUMPLES ... sugar ... flour ... egg ... baking powder salt ... shelled peanuts ... cocoa ... butter ... Put on a cold slide and bake ...

Strange but the
jeers and catcalls
from the peanut
gallery about the
inspiring Hikoi of
Hope came loudest
from those who
normally like to
criticise the
churches for being
"detached" from the
nastier realities of
modern life.

God was back where
he belonged in our
crazy old world once
again and the peanut
slab was where it
belonged - on my
pillow.

The British remain
immune to the
delights of
chocolate covered
marshmallow, says Ms
Kitchen, though they
do find the Peanut
Slab addictive.

Periodically [Bruno
Lawrence] zooms past
on our screens,
tossing peanut slabs
in his wake.
pearl diver: One whose job it is to retrieve any wool that went to the shutes with shorn sheep.

Here it is, a 3

boasting great

postcard water
views.

Using a contraption
called a female
urinary director, it
is "slipped into
your salopettes",
covers the necessary
area and a tube
extension directs
the urine where it
needs to go. These
"toilets" are called
pee poles as they
consist of a yellow
flag on top of a
pole. Identifying
these areas is
important as the
snow is also used
for drinking water.

I am bound to
refer.. to events as
they unfolded at
Twickenham and the
effect they had on
the national ego
compared with, say,
an occasional
victory in the
day-to-day rat-race
of political
pee-taking.

As children we
gathered the yellow
heads to use as
weapons to force
opposing gangs to
sniff them and
hopefully wet their
pants - hence
dandelion's
nickname,
"pee-the-bed.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Watching a good
huntaway peel sheep
off a broad face on
a muster,
effortlessly leaping
and backing in the
yards or, in full
song, marching a
trial trio uphill,
is to see a dog
doing exactly what
it is bred for.

Author: JEWELL
Quote: Peeler Logs (or Peelers): Logs having the necessary quality to enable them to be converted into veneer.

PEELER A log
snitable for rotary
veneer cutting.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. Then
there were the terms
referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for
example, agates,
aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cat's eyes,
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, molly-bars,
mulley-bars
[mullibars: large
marbles], peelies,
peewees, piss-wees,
pretties, Scotties,
Scottish alleys,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more
recent years
ball-bearings,
chippies, plastics,
and woodies.

They [the English]
hand their children
to the care of
nurses and cuddle
beastly Pekinese
pups, ... they allow
their peely wally
kids to occupy seats
in a train while men
and women ... have
to stand.

Author: McCREDIE
Quote:
<i>PEEP-BOO'S/i> ...
butter ... sugar ...
eggs ... ground rice
... flour ...baking
powder. Divide into
balls; make a hole
in each ... insert
... jam; ... dip in
beaten white of egg,
in sugar ... bake ..
They should crack
and show the jam.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
`Reverend Mother
talks of when she
used to give you
marbles for being a
good little boy -
pee-wees and agates,
and stonies and
glassies and a big
tor. And once she
tried to play with
you, and you said
she funked because
her knuckle was
inside the ring.'

Author: FRAME
Quote:
`Treasure' I played
ringie and holie. I
played funs and
keeps. I had
pee-wees and bully
taws and changers
that weren't made of
glass mind you. And
I won nearly every
game because the
kids were so dazzled
by the look of my
stinkers. ... They
came for miles to
play marbles with me
...

Author: PYKE
Quote:
This boundary was
always debatable
ground - it was
always imperatively
necessary that
claims should be
`pegged out', and
this rule was of
necessity `more
honoured in the
breach than in the
observance.' Pegs
were not to be had,
unless imported, and
when introduced
stood a great chance
of helping to boil
the neighbour's
`billy'.'
peg n.-peg out' v.t. to mark out a claim as required by law.

claim he told me
that there was a
piece of terrace

that hadn't been
worked out and might
be worth a trial.

Could I peg out a
claim of my own and
in a dish swill dirt
to find if there

gold in the pan?

The stone was of a
dark blue colour,
and thickly studded
with the precious
metal. The claim
from which this
stone has been taken
is peg and peg with

The Colonial

mates ... come in

The Performance
Enhancement Grants
(PEGs) are
taxpayer-funded,
handed out by High
Performance Sport
New Zealand - a
branch of Sport New
Zealand, the agency
tasked with
generating
international
sporting success.

The Performance
Enhancement Grants
(PEG) scheme being
announced today is a
new initiative
backed by the
government to
provide direct
financial assistance
to New Zealand's
elite athletes.

"The PEGs programme
is put in place to
help athletes with
living costs to
ensure that they can
train at the highest
level. It is not a
reward/bonus scheme
but is direct
athlete assistance
to ensure that they
can devote their
attention to quality
training and
competition."

Quote:

given to the

unjustly, though ...
legally seized.

procured a tent,

at work.

river claims.

Any experienced
miners who arrived
to peg out claims
hurriedly departed
after one glance at
the creek and the
surrounding country.

claims were pegged
out.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Cross-cut saws have
what is called a
peg-tooth and cut
both ways. It is a
great improvement to
sharpen every fifth
tooth, counting from
the centre to the
ends, as a drag
tooth, that is, a
tooth filed square
across and with a
considerable hook,
this arrangement
tends to keep the
cut clear of
sawdust.

Quote:
We "peg-topped" our
trees, that is, cut

instead of cutting a
deep scarf [a
V-shaped notch] on
the side we intended
the tree to fall.

the informant, at

this had caused a

Hokitika yesterday

out.

A few days ago, when
the first of the
miners began to
return, there was
nothing but pegging
out claims afresh;
others jumping
claims and, in some
instances, it ended
in a few rounds of
boxing.

PEGGING OUT A CLAIM
...Mr Neave, in
opening, stated that
the informant, at
the request of
Donald Simson, who
held a miner's
right, and was an
applicant for a
mining privilege,
proceeded to
defendant's
perpetual leasehold
at Waikaka, for the
purpose of pegging
off a mining claim.
Defendant refused to
allow the pegging to
go on, threatened
informant with a
crowbar, and with it
knocked the pegs
from his hand.

Author: SWANTON
Quote:
`Pegging out' means
planting pegs at the
four corners of the
piece of ground.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
She got a captain in
the Salvation Army
to get me my first
job on a boat ...
And I did two trips
but I was only
fireman's peggy.

At the novelty house
you will find the
very latest in gold
and colored tassels
for dress trimming,
the newest in gold
ties. In ladies'
hand bags the Peggy
bag.

A tram conductor was
charged in the
Magistrate's Court
to-day with having
stolen a peggy bag
containing GBP14 10s
from a lady
passenger.

In pretty well every
"peggy bag" are
carried a case of
"fags," and its
legitimate
accompaniment, a
match box.

See Our Window for
the New "Peggy" Bag,
The Latest London
Novelty.

The things stolen
were easily portable
and were principally
jewellery, articles
of clothing,
valuable toilet
accessories, etc.
There were a number
of `peggy' bags. ...
Gladys Wood, Bealey
Avenue, said that
between 9 and 10
p.m. on February 18
a trinket, [sic]
box, watch, purse,
enamelled bracelet,
gold neck chain, two
tiki curios and a
peggy bag were
stolen from her
bedroom.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
[Mother and daughter
c. 1890s] made
pretty necklaces
from the dried
seed-pods of the
field flax, which we
called bluebells,
tied with gay
ribbons; ... and,
most treasured of
all, little
peggy-bags of
velvet, lined with
bright silk or satin
and threaded with
silk cord for
handles.

We knitted peggy
squares for Red
Cross blankets.

They [the deserving
poor] keep their
floors spotless ...,
make peggy squares
out of unravelled
cardigans and excel
in the art of
stretching a mutton
flap to three meals.

Just as key, Veric
also saw the
implementation of
PEGS - a
Performance-Enhancing
Grants System - that
financially rewarded
elite swimmers when
(and only when) they
met specified goals
or times.

Author: BULLER
Quote: SPILOGLAUX NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW-ZEALAND OWL, OR MOREPORK.) ... Native names. Ruru, Koukou, and Peho; `Morepork' of the colonists.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: EARINA ... mucronata ... This tree-dwelling orchid ... Bamboo Orchid. PEKA AWAKA.

Author: KEENE
Quote: pekapeka: wooden spreader used for catching certain fish.

Author: JOHNSON
Quote: At times an octopus would cling to the pekapeka (a wire arrangement to spread the hooks) ...

Author: ZIMMERMAN
Quote: In the end I had many small things, pendants and pekapekas and tikis, and all of them were genuine.
Notes: The only meaning which seems to fit the text

Quote:
Unfortunately, cages
also prevent the
native pollinators
such as pekapeka,
the short-tailed
bat, and as yet
other unknown
reptile or bird
propagators from
reaching the
flowers.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote: New Zealand possesses only two distinct proven genera (of mammals]; the bat (Pekapeka, two species) and a small indigenous rat (Kiore).

Author: JOSEPH
Quote:
`The jade, the
pounamu ... It's a
beautiful stone ...
Look,' he said,
holding up a long
hooked ear-drop of
pearly translucence,
`that's tau tau and
the stone is called
inanga. And this,
the pekapeka - they
say the shape comes
from the bat. This
is for the ear, too
- the mako, like a
shark's tooth ...
And these,' - he ran
his fingers along a
row of ... nephrite
adzes - `toki. See
this one' - he held
the heavy
red-mottled adze in
his palm - `that's
the red kind,
totoweka, woodhen's
blood. The deep
green, that's
kawakawa.'

Author: BULLER
Quote:
We are standing on
the banks of the
Horowhenua Lake ...
a pair of Papango
... are floating on
the placid waters;
... a solitary
Pekapeka is flitting
silently overhead,
chasing ... the
minute insect-life
upon which this bat
subsists; ... and
the melancholy note
of the Fern-Sparrow,
calling to his
fellows among the
rushes, has grown
languid and finally
died away; ...

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Vespertilio
tuberculatus. G.
Forster. ... [182
quotes Polack 1/304]
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/181-182 1.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Peka peka - a bat, a
gamr so called

Author: REISCHEK
Quote:
The only original
New Zealand mammal
is a little bat,
called pekapeka by
the Maoris.

Author: POWELL
Quote: LONG-TAILED BAT (Chalinolobus morio), Pekapeka of the Maoris, shelters in caves and hollow trees.

South Canterbury is
one of the few
places where the
long-tailed bat or
pekapeka still
survives in a rural
landscape.

Author: POLACK
Quote: The pekapeka [a's-acute], or bat, and various small batlets, are very common in the land, but none of the vampire species.

Erechtites
quadridentata
Pekapeka

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: CARPET SHARK (PEKAPEKA) Cephaloscyllium isabella (Bonnaterre) ... It is known in Australia as the Draughtsboard Shark.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
HOOKER
Quote: Pekepekekiore, Col[enso]. Hydnum clathroides.

[Also eaten were] several Fungi [especially] ... four ... which grow on trees, - the Harori (Agaricus adiposus), the Hakeke, and the Popoiahakeke (Polyporus species, and the Pekepekekiore (Hydnum clathroides); also, three terrestrial ones, - the Paruwhatitiri (Ileodictyon cibarium), the Pukurau (Lycoperdon Fontainesii), ...

Author: COWAN
Quote: The foot of the pekerangi, about 15 feet high, was strengthened with a facing of rocks and [42] stones ...; this was a variation of the usual Maori method of leaving the foot of the pekerangi open for the garrison's fire. <.i>Ibid. 51-52 The outer wall, the pekerangi, or curtain, was formed of stout timbers ... sunk deeply in the ground at short intervals, with saplings and split timbers closely set between the larger posts, all bound firmly [52] together with cross-rails and torotoro, or bush-vines.

Author: BELICH
Quote: pekerangi light outer fence of a pa

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Peki-peki, Middle Island, Lyall. Erechtites quadridentata.

Author: BROOKS
Quote:
Most of us were now
loaded with heavy
pekoes or swags on
our backs.

The rest of [the
farmer's] luggage
would be a peko
slung on his
shoulders.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pellitory. Parietaria debils.
pellitory [s] Parietaria judiaca L.

"Pelorus Jack," the
well-known denizen
ofthe French Pass..
has been missing
forthe last couple
of months.

Author: BARR
Quote:
Passing through the
home of
"PelorousJack" [sic]
several members of
the teamremained in
deck to catch a
sight of thecurious
white pilot.

Various suggestions
are ventured as to
the species of the
finny mystery, and
it is suggested that
it is a cousin to
"Pelorus Jack," the
mysterious white
fish of the French
Pass.

One or two five- or
six-feet members of
the finny [t]ribe
were caught by
caterers for the
camp at School Bay,
and it is reported
that " Pelorus Jack"
has forsaken his old
haunt outside the
Heads, where for
many months he has
patiently awaited a
victim, to forage in
Queen Charlotte
Sound; at any rate
passengers from
Nelson to Picton no
longer see the
curious creature
disporting itself at
the heads, and, so
the story goes, a
huge black fin like
a cross cut saw
leaves a long wake
in divers places in
the Sound.

While many believed
he was guiding ships
safely through the
treacherous waters
of French Pass, Mr
Webber said Pelorus
Jack didn't enter
the pass at all...
For Maori, the
dolphin's history
goes even further
back than the 1880s.
It is believed
Pelorus Jack, known
as Kaikaiawaro (food
of the deep) to
Maori, escorted
descendants of Ngati
Kuia into Pelorus
Sound hundreds of
years later.

He took [his camera]
to Nelson with him..
waiting for "Pelorus
Jack" to do his
fancy diving turn.

The porpoise is a
much smaller animal
than was the
original grey
dolphin, Pelorus
Jack.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
"Pelorus Jack" used
to sport around the
boats.

And Champagne was a
place before it was
a drink, with the
original Champagne
Charlie personally
selling his
delightful bubbles
here when Pelorus
Jack was playing
pilot and
Marlborough didn't
sound like wineland
at all.

A Maoriland oddity
is Pelorus Jack of
the French Pass.
Jack is an albino
porpoise.

Quicker 'un Pelorus
Jack after a chunk
ofrump steak.. I
wus.

New Zealand has the
comforting news
to-day that Pelorus
Jack can say "not
me" to the body of
the marine mammal
washed ashore at
D'Urville Island.

It was [in 1956] the
solo butchers who
were given the
tougher jobs like
legging and pelt
punching.

Author: PERRIAM
Quote:
Ron Summers, a
pelter, fell down
the skin hole one
day.

A marine sponge with anti-tumour properties may well become a lucrative aquaculture crop. The bioactive compound Peluroside works in the same way as an anti-cancer drug which is currently worth NZ$9 billion a year.
Notes: National Centre for Aquatic Biodiversity and Biosecurity Update

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote: He taught me more about handling cargo ... than anyone else I met. Every morning I used to look for him among the crowd at the pen. Ibid./ 228 The morning found me down at the pen as usual. The ... pen was full of seagulls looking for work.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
Presently I heard a
[pig-]dog sing out
`pen and ink'. ...
Next morning he came
crawling up to the
outstation dragging
one of his hind
legs, which appeared
to be useless.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Pen and ink. 4. Pen and Ink, Gallipoli Peninsula: New Zealand soldiers': in 1915; occ. after. Cf. Pinch an Inch.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: [The] following [were] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ...Pen and Ink and Inch and Pinch, the Peninsula of Gallipoli;

We wander over to
the bar for a pen
and ink, where the
talk gets round to
tomato sauces. pen
and ink....drink

Author: POLACK
Quote:
These vessels are
fitted with tryworks
or fire-places above
which is a battery
containing two, and
sometimes three iron
pots, sufficiently
capacious to contain
from one hundred and
fifty to two hundred
gallons each; the
fire-place is built
of bricks, so laid
below as to form
channels for water
to preserve the
floor or main deck
from injury. The
water is kept
confined by a
square, formed with
a two-inch plank,
around the sides,
negligence in
leaving this pen (as
it is termed) dry,
has caused many
accidents; ... These
fire-works are taken
down when the cargo
is completed, ...

Best wethers 24s to
27s 6d (one pen: up
to 29s).

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
Clayton was an `open
shed', that is, the
shearers were not
engaged beforehand,
but turned up and
took their chance of
a pen on the
advertised starting
day.

Phillips over with
Wedders, joined the
lot in the pens &
counted mob (see
Sheep book).

Author: BENNETT
Quote:
Each man has his
pen, which is
cleared out and
refilled as often as
necessary...

Pen.- (1) A small yard; a division in the sheep-holding part of a woolshed. (2) Shearers catch out of a p., and when they apply for work they ask for a p. `Will you keep me a p. for next year, boss?' is often their farewell. Two shearers usually catch out of one pen and are called p.-mates.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
I'd been out among
the stations,/
Vainly seeking for a
pen;/ ...

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
... before the
following shearing
season a letter ...
with the customary
[pound]1 deposit was
in the Station mail
bag, ... asking for
a pen next shearing,
...

Author: DICK
Quote:
`... Lend me some
suitable clothes and
I'll take a pen
alongside you. Must
be nigh on forty
years since I held a
pair of shears.'

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
There isn't a pen
for the type of men/
That try to hang the
boss!

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
When Charlie told me
that the award for
shearing in
Australia was two
pounds one shilling
per 100, I told him
I would like to get
a pen over there.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote: Pen. A small fenced-in area. The sheep-holding part of a wool shed is divided into pens connected to the board by a swing door. Shearers catch their sheep out of these pens, which are usually shared, the shearers being pen-mates.

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Choose a sheep with
its head held in a
natural position in
the pen.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
From the press the
bales were stacked
ir a loft above the
sheep pens.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote:
The brow on the
larboard side of the
Ship, which a few
days ago was
impenetrable forest,
is now clear & airy,
& contains an
Observatory, a
forge, a green hut
for the woodcutters
& a pen for our
Sheep; and more than
an acre of ground is
cleared of the
woods; ...

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
In those days when
men were glad of
jobs, shearers used
to write asking for
a 'pen', just as the
musterers did to ask
for a 'beat' on the
station of their
choice.

At the Newmarket
yards, on Tuesday,
dairy and store
stock were penned in
usual numbers.

The yarding of 8553
stores and primes
that were penned at
Temuka on April 9
saw the condition of
the stores clearly
illustrating the
effects of the
drought ...

In addition to three
shearers, there are
two baling, two at
the wool table, a
fleecepicker, one
sweeping and a man
penning.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
The Maori buck did
the shearing, with
machines, boys
penned, and did
pick-up work.
Wahines ... did the
sorting, and Maori
girls did the
sweeping on the
shearing board.

They are brought to
the sheep yards,
where any dirty
animals are `dagged'
(any stained wool
and pieces of dung
hanging around the
tail are clipped
off). They are then
`penned' overnight
in the woolshed to
protect them from
rain or heavy dew.

Before penning, two
sheep have to be
separated ...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
pen: one dog-trial
event end when the
sheep have been
eventually confined
in a little yard of
four hurdles. The
dog is then said to
have penned.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
What with mustering,
drafting and
mouthing on the
farm; then the
11-mile drive to the
saleyards, then more
drafting and sorting
into age-groups and
pen lots on the day
of the sale ...

He also penned the
best of seven shorn
ewe hoggets.

Should she not take
to the lamb she must
be penned up until
she alters her mind.

There should be
someone penning up
for the crutchers
and also picking
over the wool.

Source: Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock
Author: MILLS ET AL
Quote:
This [labelling pens
with capacity]
avoided any risks of
smothering and was
also of great help
when penning up in
semi-darkness.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
For some hours
before the sale we'd
be at the yards
helping the local
agents draft and pen
up incoming stock.

Author: MACINTOSH
Quote:
In the shed I picked
up, skirted and
rolled fleeces while
the boss penned up
and mustered sheep
...

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
pen-up, to: to fill
up a - usually
catching - pen.
Besides penning
them, a trial dog
can be said to pen
up his sheep.

Author: ASPINALL
Quote:
It was always my job
to turn the
grindstone for them
(shearers); top shed
up, pick up, pen up,
press up and be
there pronto with
the tar pot ...

Author: LILICO
Quote:
A bitch pup I sold
... went direct to
freezing works to
pen up and developed
into a first class
forcer and backer
... The finest
backing dogs I have
ever seen are in the
saleyards at
Addington ...

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
The bell rang, the
whole procedure
stopped, shearers
trooped out, half
shorn sheep were
pushed back into the
catching pens. Jimmy
Greave the classer
hurriedly whispered
to William Steuart
to desist, but
loppies, rousies,
and even young Jim,
who was assisting to
pen up, followed out
from the side door
to where the shoots
from the stands gave
the nearest exit, to
the level space of
the outside turf,
that made eventually
the [boxing] ring.

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
There was nothing
new to me in picking
up fleeces. ... I
had often given a
hand in the smaller
woolsheds at
shearing time,
either penning up
with the shepherds
or picking up and
helping the presser.

Author: MACNICOL
Quote:
He had to be warned
... not to abuse the
sheep while penning
up....

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
Jack Frost ... was
`picking up'. and I
was the rouseabout -
penning up the
sheep, sweeping the
shearing board and
bailing [sic] the
wool.

Some men are good
pen-men. Those who
havewatches are
working hard to get
the sheepthey have
on the board off,
and catchanother,
before the manager
calls out:"Clear the
board."

Much of the offering
was of doubtful
yield, of mixed
combing length, and
affected by light
discoloration, dust
and/or 'penstain.'

Author: BARTON
Quote:
Ewe, wether and
hogget bodywool -
free from all
discolouration
(remove all yellow
and penstain.)

There could be
confusion in the
guidelines .. the
good style [of wool]
'remove definite
yellow and
penstain.'

.. large confined
mobs, particularly
if moved, can build
up pen stain in the
wool.

Shearing: Don't pack
them [sheep] in too
tightly or they will
dung on each other's
wool causing 'pen
stain.' [penstain;
pen stain]

Author: BARTON
Quote:
Locks, second pieces
and pizzle or
pen-stained wool
must be kept
separate.

Author: M H-B P
Quote:
Pen-stained wools
may be discounted in
price. [penstained.]

Author: M H-B P
Quote:
These requirements
are: prevention of
pen-staining of
sheep ...

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
At the back of the
shed worked the
`penners-up' whose
job was to keep the
small catching pens
full for the
shearers. We always
alluded to them as
the `pen-uppers'.

Aussie employers
face added burdens.
What we call penal
rates - time and a
half or double time
for working
Saturdays, Sundays
or unsociable hours
- are still the norm
in their hospitality
and service sectors.

Until recently, in
New Zealand people
were seen as
entitled to extra
pay for working
their weekends, for
working while others
slept, for
sacrificing their
home life for their
job. We called these
payments penal
rates, shift
allowances,
overtime...
penalty rates pl. n. Austral. rates of pay for employees working outside normal hours.

Author: KENWAY
Quote:
I remember an old
hand's scornful
remark on a bit of
bush I had myself
felled: `They've got
some bally new chum
at work here; pencil
pointing the trees
like that.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
It is not uncommon
to find that fleeces
which have a high
expression of staple
character also have
lean or pencil type
staples,
particularly on the
fore-arm and the
britch. Wool buyers
and their
manufacturers have
no objection to
these pencil
staples, but with
breeders they find
little favour, and a
sheep is expected to
produce meaty
staples throughout
the fleece.

Source: A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms
Author: SQUIRES
Quote:
Pencilly staple - a
wool staple of thin,
narrow structure
being pencil-like in
appearance.
[pencilly staple.]

Wool with a thin
staple.

... where a few
`pencil veins' of
dark ore, assaying
from [pound]1.10s to
[pounds]3 per ton in
bullion, were met
with.

Paddy Hilton, the
local penciller ...

To enter simply grab
a pene and write to
us but don't forget
to include your
name, address and
birth date.

Quote:
157. EUDYPTES
ANTIPODES. Homb. et
Jacq. Great Penguin.
Hoiho.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Blue Penguin Eudyptula minor (FORSTER, 1781) ENDEMIC Northern Blue Penguin E.m. iredalei MATHEWS, 1911. Cook Strait Blue Penguin E.m. variabilis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. White-flippered Penguin E.m. albosignata FINSCH, 1874. Southern Blue Penguin E.m. minor (FORSTER, 1781). Chatham Island Blue Penguin E.m. chathamensis KINSKY & FALLA, 1976. OTHER NAMES: Little blue penguin, little penguin, fairy penguin, korara.

Canterbury has its
own distinctive
penguin, the
white-flippered
penguin, which is a
local variant of the
Little [sic] blue or
fairy penguin found
only in New Zealand
and Australia. It is
slightly heavier
than the northern
Little blue penguin,
and has a
distinctive white
band along both
edges of the
flippers. They breed
only on Banks
Peninsula, Motunau
Island and the
neighbouring coasts.
Eudyptes filholi, `Victoria Penguin.'
Eudyptes pachyrhynchus. (The Victoria penguin.)
A little to the southward of Lusitania beach [Macquarie Isd] is a breeding place of the victoria penguin (E. filholi) ...

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote:
Of the fossil
remains of birds,
the present
collection contains
above 500 specimens,
referable to the
various species of
Dinornis, and allied
genera; and to
species of
albatross, penguin,

Author: FORSTER
Quote: Many birds about the Ship of every kind: & especially we saw two Penguins & two bunches of Seaweeds called at the Cape Sea-Bamboos. (Fucus buccinalis linn.). [ed. fn] Probably Chinstrap Penguins Pygoscelis anarctica (Forster, 1781).

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The

Author: PARKER
Quote: `The Penguins are characteristic Southern Hemisphere sea-birds, being represented in the Northern by the Puffins. They are flightless, but their wings are modified into powerful fins or flappers. Among the most interesting forms are the following - the King Penguin, Aptenodytes longirostris; Rock Hopper P., Pygoscelis taeniatus; Yellow-Crowned P., Eudyptes antipodum; Crested P., E. pachyrhynchus; Little Blue P., E. minor and undina.'

Peń.ner (p&ebreve.ń.n&etilde.r),n. [From pen to confine.] A workman employed at shearing time to bring in sheep from the flock outside the woolshed and confine them in pens within the shed, so that they may be ready for the shearers.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote: The `sheep-oh' (penner-up) also held an important position. In addition to filling up the catching pens, he weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions in the wool book. Ibid. 130 The shearers were, of course, the autocrats of the shed, but the `sheep-oh' (penner-up) also held an important position. In addition to filling up the catching pens, he weighed the bales and recorded them, with their descriptions, in the wool book. Ibid. 208 At shearing time [at Benmore, 1892] about 55 men were employed in the shed: 28 to 30 shearers, 2 penners-up, 4 pickers-up, 2 broomies, 6 rollers, 1 classer, 1 fleece carrier, 4 piece sorters, 3 pressers, 1 bale brander, 1 butcher and brander.

Penny Doctor beetles, also known as `Butcher bats' is a game widely reported by Wellington Training College students as being played in many parts of the North Island. In this game straws moistened by spittle are pushed down the hole of the appropriate beetle. The beetle seizes the end of the straw. When the player feels the straw moving he or she flicks out the beetle. The player who can catch the most beetles wins the game.
Notes: 1951 JPS 60/93-107 (Sutton-Smith) in 1972 Sutton-Smith Folkgames of Children 328

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Fred has the
`pensions' used for
fantan, round metal
discs with a square
hole in the middle,
and a `dew nappy',
the ivory half-ball
that the game was
played with.
Pensions were put on
the four corners of
the card, or points
between, and two
people took the
bank. Even money was
paid on the corners
and three to one in
the middle. There
would be several
hundred pounds
sometimes waiting on
the half-roll of the
dew nappy.

The nomination of a
fit and proper
person to represent
the Pensioner
Settlements in the
next session of the
General Assembly
took place at noon
yesterday.

The following
gentlemen were
nominated .. for the
Southern Division
and the Pensioner
Settlements, and
returned without
opposition :- .. For
the Pensioner
Settlements: Messrs.
J. Kelly, J.
Brennan, V.
Powditch, and J H.
Wilson.

Author: BURGESS
Quote:
I left this honest
employ to go to
Adelaide with a
young man who was a
very clever pensman
[forger]. We were
disappointed when we
got there as we had
been informed it was
a more flourishing
place than
Melbourne. While
here we effected
several minor
forgeries, but in my
absence he tendered
a fake cheque and
got detected.

Author: KIRK
Quote:
Notothlaspi
rosulatum pen-wiper
plant
Amongst the most remarkable are the fleshy-leaved buttercup [fn Ranunculus hasstii.], the black daisy [fn Cotula atrata.], the pen-wiper plant [fn Notothlaspi rosulatum.], ...

Notothlaspi

Notothlaspi

Quote:
On the higher
levels, up to 5,000
feet and over, a
scattered alpine
vegetation,
including pen-wiper
and mountain
buttercups.

Author: MARK & ADAMS
Quote: Notothlaspi rosulatum Hook. f. PENWIPER PLANT

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: NOTOTHLASPI ROSULATUM. The penwiper plant, like Ranunculus haastii, grows on South Island scree slopes ... The leaves form a neat circular rosette, ... in appearance much like the now forgotten penwipers made of overlapping strips of soft cloth on which Edwardian writers wiped the ink off their steel-nibbed pens.

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
... everywhere I
walked I found a
dozen penwiper
plants. This lovely
little rosette grows
in deep, cool
shingle ...where its
long roots ...feed
the huge flower head
which rises and
scents the air as
strongly as
carnation or
gardenia.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: The best known scree species is the penwiper plant (Notothlaspi rosulatum) ... which belongs to the cabbage family (Cruciferae). Its rosettes of grey, fleshy leaves closely overlap in a dome-like arrangement, which reminded early settlers of the similarly arranged and sewn together diamonds of felt on which they wiped their quill pens.

Author: No. 53/35
Quote: Unlikely as it may seem, many fascinating plants, including the distinctive penwiper, Notothlaspi rosulatum, not only survive but flourish amid the shifting screes and windswept gullies far above the treeline. Ibid. 42 One scree specialist found in eatern parts of the Southern Alps from Marlborough to Canterbury, the attractive penwiper (Notothlaspi rosulatum), grows in a rosette of grey leaves which blend perfectly with their surroundings.

The slide is too
recent to be
weathered, but on
its edge there is a
small patch of
penwiper plant, shy
and bulging with an
unflowered stem that
will in a few weeks
open with a
honey-scented head
of white flowers.

The strange-looking
Notothlaspi
rosulatum, or
penwiper, grows in
scree and got its
name because it
reminded early
botanists of the
felt wipers they
used to wipe their
quill pens.

I was desirous of
securing Notothlaspi
rosulatum, the
pen-wiper plant, but
found no trace of
it.

Author: MCCASKILL
Quote:
On the higher
levels, up to 5,000
feet and over, a
scattered alpine
vegetation,
including pen-wiper
and mountain
buttercups.

Author: DAWSON
Quote:
The best known scree
species is the
penwiper plant which
belongs to the
cabbage family
(Cruciferae).

Author: STACEY
Quote:
The fragrant
penwiper plants can
be smelt out from a
great distance by
wild sheep.
[pen-wiper]

The People's Bank has more populist promise. Ibid. 17 If the People's Bank could shame bank fees down and bring sorely needed banking facilities to communities brutally deserted by the foreign-controlled banks, that would be a ginormous political coup.

Which brings me
circuitously to the
People's Bank issue.
Other than the
minnows, TSB and
Southland Building
Society, all of our
banks are owned
offshore.

It was about three
years ago that Jim
Anderton began to
channel this
small-town anguish
into a demand for a
People's Bank. The
best that NZ Post..
could come up with
appeared to be a
rather limited
banking clip-on to
its regular Post
Shop services.

Those who think the
People's Bank or NZ
Post Bank will come
a gutser will be in
for a surprise.

For weeks, Cabinet
has been mulling
over whether to give
the green light to
the People's Bank.

On the subject of
the People's Bank,
[Cullen's face] has
till now ignored his
soothing words on
the subject, and
come alive with
malice and barely
suppressed
one-liners every
time the bank is
mentioned... But the
People's Bank is
expressly aimed at
giving low-income
New Zealanders
low-cost accessible
banking.

The weather on the
first day was wet
but the people's day
was beautifully fine
and there was a very
large attendance.

Friday is the
people's day, when
visitors gather in
their thousands.

.. though the next
or People's day
(Saturday) was
everything that
could be desired as
to weather.

On People's Day the
sum of L88 was taken
at the gates.

This is how
machinery row looked
at Stratford
Showgrounds on the
afternoon of
people's day.

For People's Day on
the second day
brilliant sunshine
followed the
overcast conditions
of the first day and
there was a large
attendance.

Kahawai are
sometimes dubbed
"the people's fish"
because they can be
caught with a modest
rod from boat, beach
or wharf and are
often the first
catch of young
fishers.

The People's Palace,
as Trekkers was
originally known,
has been a stop-over
for many thousands
of New Zealanders
over its 95-year
history... The
Salvation Army owned
and operated The
People's Palace,
which was later
called the
Railton... The first
section of The
People's Palace,
203-205 Cuba St, had
been opened as a
home for "wayward"
women in 1904...
Many older New
Zealanders have
mentioned staying in
The People's Palace
during visits to
Wellington, or as a
staging point
between the
overnight train from
Auckland and the
Christchurch ferry.

Author: STEWART
Quote:
At the People's
Palace, where
frugally Ihad
arranged to
establish myself,
therewas a note
saying, 'Man called
withbulldog.'

"Would you please
tell me which of
your many schemes
like PEP, Steps,
Taps or even the new
Access have actually
worked overseas?"

Author: CHAVASSE
Quote:
The next time we
went ... some young
men were building on
a new room. ...`PEP
workers. I don't pay
them. I only have to
pay for the
materials. [fn]
Government-sponsored
Project Employment
Programme.

Author: David Geary
Quote:
Turns out Gary
wasn't actually a
fencing contractor
in his own
right...but he was
making fences on a
PEP scheme.

When I first started
really smoking it
[sc. cannabis] I was
on a PEP scheme.

The best scheme they
ever had was PEP.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: ...this caterpillar is of the genus sphinx, and is named by the New Zealanders pepe.

Author: IHIMAERA
Quote:
And the pepes used
to come down from
the bush and hit
against the windows
attracted by the
light in their room.
Big ones. The
children had not
seen pepes as big as
them before and they
used to sit up a
little afraid in
bed... But after a
while they got used
to the knockings of
the pepes against
their windows at
night.

Inspired by his
favourite pepeha -
"Do not die a
rotting death like
mine, but instead
pass from this world
via the fragrant
ovens of a
battlefield" - Te
Radar set out to
find and tell
stories about some
of Te Wai Pounamu's
unsung, often
unhinged, heroes.
Hitori is an idiosyncratic jaunt through some of the sillier aspects of the South Island's history, told through pepeha (traditional Maori sayings).

New Zealand had
seven native frogs
(pepeketua) of which
three are extinct
and four highly
endangered.

There are now just
four species of
native frogs
(pepeketua) and
three species of
introduced frogs in
New Zealand.

New Zealand's native
frogs (pepeketua)
belong to the genus
Leiopelma, an
ancient group of
frogs that have
changed very little
in the last 70
million years.

A tropical species
that is gaining in
popularity in the
milder districts of
New Zealand is the
Pepino (Solanum
muricatum).

The word pepino is
also used for the
cucumber in Latin
America... To
distinguish between
the two plants the
pepino as we know it
is referred to as
pepino dulce,
meaning "sweet".

Among the lesser
known and more
exotic fruit bearing
plants.. are..
jujube.. pepino..
and sapodilla.

The subtropical
South American
pepino or 'melon
shrub' has been
developed..
especially to suit
Canterbury
conditions.

Two more pepino
cultivars have
recently been
released.. by..
D.S.I.R.

This fruit is most
commonly known as
'pepino' (the
Spanish word for
cucumber), but also
as melon shrub or
melon pear.

He cites the
economic potential
of the pepino on a
par with the
tamarillo.

Pepino is a small
shrub three feet in
neght belonging to
the same family as
the tomato and
producing egg-shaped
fruits, yellow
streaked with purple
lines.

Pepino (Solanum
muricatum)... The
fruits have a
delicious flavour
and may be eaten
like a melon, or
made into jams or
preserves.

The pepino is known
botanically as
Solanaceae Solanum
muricatum Ait,
although it is
commonly referred to
as pepino dulce,
pepino melon, melon
pear, melon shrub
and pear melon. (In
New Zealand, we
mostly just call it
pepino).

Author: MATTHEWS
Quote:
The pepino, Solanum
muricatum, has oval
shaped fruits of
delicious flavour,
the taste and aroma
reminiscent of musk
melon.

For the future, keep
your eyes open for
kiwanos, okra,
pepino, bitter
melons and asparagus
beans.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
... New Zealand
horticulturalists
have been on
expeditions to the
Andes and brought
back other
sub-tropicals to
test under New
Zealand conditions.
These fruits include
casanas,
naranjillas,
cherimoyas,
casimiroas,
carambolas,
toronchis and
pepinos. The last
named are now
available
commercially.

/p |pi:n u/. N.Z. & Austral. [S. Amer. Sp. (Peru).] (See quot. 1968.) 1968 J.C. Th. UPHOF Dict. Economic Plants (ed.2) 490/2 Solanum muricatum Ait. Pepino (Solanaceae). Herbaceous plant. Subtropics. Origin probably Peru. Cultivated in Centr. and S. America. Often sold in markets. Fruits frequently seedless, round to long, greenish yellow with purplish red blotches, juicy, agreeable flavor, somewhat aromatic, crisp; eaten raw. 1980 Ann. Appl. Biol. XCIV. 61 Pepino mosaic virus .. was found in fields of pepino (Solanum muricatum) in the Canete valley in coastal Peru. 1981 Southern Horticulture (N.Z.) Spring 16/1 Group three: blueberries, feijoas, avocado, tamarillos, cherries, babaco, persimmon, Asian pears, macadamias, pepino etc. 1984 Sydney Morning Herald 4 Sept. (Good Living) 1 Pepino or Melon Pear or Melon Shrub - a shape and size simialr to an apple cucumber ... Good for decorating dishes such as pavlova and fruit salad, because when sliced the hollow centre and surrounding flesh look like a wheel.

The small shrubby
pepino, that is
native to Central
America is grown
widely, but is
cultivated most
extensively in
Chile.

Keen gardeners..
will have noticed
the pepino, which
has been described
as a fruit with a
flavour something
like a rock melon...
The pepino is a
member of the
Colonaceae family
and, as a true
subtropical,
requires a fairly
long, hot growing
season.

Author: BOLLARD
Quote:
The pepino grows
well in New Zealand
and offers some
promise as a
commercial fruit for
both fresh use and
processing.
It is the pepino Solanum muricatum. Ibid, 3 The pepino is closely related to the potato, tomato, and capsicum peppers; they all belong to.. the Solenaceae.

Stray notes on
Australia and the
Diggings (Griffiths
Collection) Origin
of the word
`Nugget'. - This
word, now so common
amongst our
population, is a
strange sounding
word, and destitute
of any apparent
entymological
meaning. It
originated at the
Ophir diggings in
New South Wales, and
is probably a
corruption of
`ingot', which is
itself a corruption
of `lingot', a
little tongue. The
wedge of gold which
Achan purloined is
called, in the
original Hebrew, a
`tongue' of gold, as
a reference to a
Bible with marginal
readings will show.
In California, the
word `lump' is
generally used, and
sometimes the
Spanish word
`pepite.'

Even the semi-tropical true pepper [fn Piper excelsum.] disputes with the false native pepper [fn Drimys colorata.] the right to its name, and yet another semi-tropical plant, the nikau [fn Areca sapida.] - New Zealand's only palm - extends as far south as Banks Peninsula, though not found on the Port Hills.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pepper, native. Piper excelsum.

Even the semi-tropical true pepper [fn Piper excelsum.] disputes with the false native pepper [fn Drimys colorata.] the right to its name, and yet another semi-tropical plant, the nikau [fn Areca sapida.] - New Zealand's only palm - extends as far south as Banks Peninsula, though not found on the Port Hills.

Quote:
The New Zealand
Pepper is a small
tree, 12-20 feet
high, or sometimes a
rambling shrub, with
a very aromatic
smell; it has been
used for Tea, and
for the cure of
toothache; it is
found also in
Norfolk Island, and
belongs to a
subgenus
(Macropiper) ...

An interesting fact
is stated by our
West Coast war
correspendent,
namely, that the
pepper plant has
been discovered in
the bush district,
the scene of recent
operations there.

There were many
small shrubs growing
there, too, among

Quote:
The use of perch as
a square measure in
New Zealand - one
fortieth of a rood -
may be noted. NSOD
gives this as 'rare,
except historical'.
It became historical
here only in 1968
with the advent of
metrication, and was
until then anything
but rare. The area
of every piece of
land that could not
be expressed simply
in acres or roods
was described in
perches. The word
occurred in
thousands of land
titles, and was used
to define the size
of any section
smaller than the
quarter-acre 'norm'.
Perch as a linear
measure on the other
hand (as in NZPOD) I
have never seen
outside the backs of
school exercise
books!

Quote:
1980 saw the
introduction of a
new stratigraphic
parameter, the
Percy. No longer do
geologists
illustrate the scale
of the outcrop
photographs with
such mundane objects
as hammer, lens
caps, 2 cent pieces
and bananas. If in
the forefront of
geological technique
they now take as an
essential item of
field equipment,
Percy Strong. Such
is Percy's
usefulness as a unit
of stratigraphic
thickness, and so
great is the
magnetism of his
image on screen,
that one lecturer
introduced his
choicest slide with
the pronouncement
"that's Percy", and
only then proceeded
to describe the
rocks. It is
understood that
Cathy, with callous
disregard for the
visual effect on her
husband's figure, is
knitting for Percy a
cap-a-pie jumpsuit
with 100 horizontal
stripes so that
thin-bedded
sequences may be
measured in
centi-Percies (cPe);
and further that
Percy himself now
steers clear of
field trips in areas
of steeply-dipping
strata, to avoid the
necessity of being
photographed in a
horizontal position
in stream beds.

It is most commonly called peripatus - from the same Greek root as peripatetic, meaning itinerant or wandering... The animal is also called the velvet worm or walking worm - references to two of its more obvious traits. Peripatus are found largely in the southern hemisphere - in Australasia, south-east Asia, Africa and Central and South America. Ibid. 66 I have to roll my peripatus onto its back again to view the circular, lobe-lipped mouth with double pair of sickle-shaped mandibles, and the two lumpy "gun turrets" - oral papillae - used to such effect in the capture and consumption of prey. Both the jaws and oral papillae, as well as the antennae, are pairs of modified limbs. Peripatus are opportunistic and will scavenge in preference to expending energy on hunting. Ibid. 74 Peripatus may boast a lineage more ancient than that of New Zealand's other, more famous, "living fossil," the tuatara. Early marine animals, such as this 500-million-year-old fossil from the Burgess Shale in British Columbia, appear remarkably similar to living onycophorans... P. novaezealandiae females.. have been found to carry embryos at all stages of development at all times of year, and to give birth regardless of the season, albiet more abundantly in summer.

PERKING is the name
for fringe benefits
that are taken by
employees and should
not be confused with
the `perk' that is
an authorised
addition to a
salary. The word
originated on the
floor of the factory
but the practice is
not confined to that
area. Those who make
a habit of perking
don't consider it
dishonest but
factory owners
disagree and waste
time and effort
trying to stamp it
out.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Perpetual Lease, though a misnomer, is a statutory expression in New Zealand. Under the former Land Acts, the grantee of a perpetual lease took a term of thirty years, with a right of renewal at a revalued rent, subject to conditions as to improvement and cultivation, with a right to purchase the freehold after six years' occupation.

Roasted peru peru. So named because they were first brough here by Peruvian sailors, peru peru are unusual long-shaped tubers that have a delicious flavour similar to new potatoes, and are marbled with purple to varying degrees inside. You might also see them labelled as urenika potatoes.

Author: FORSTER
Quote: We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross (Diomedea exulans & palpebrata). The black & sooty Petrel, (Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa) the black banded Petrel (Procellaria vittata); the small white rumped Petrel (Proc. pelagica) & we saw likewise three times a Port Egmont Hen, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; Pachyptila spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua. .

Author: MORRIS
Quote: a little child. The word is certainly not Australian. It comes from the West Indies (Cuban piquinini, little, which is from the Spanish pequeno small, and nino, child). The English who came to Australia, having heard the word applied to negro children of the aborigines. After a while English people thought the word was aboriginal Australian, while the aborigines thought it was correct English. It is pigeon-English. [1696: Aust 1830] [351] used as adj. and figuratively, to mean little

A boy or man to five

chapter on

When a shearer finishes a sheep, the f. is left lying on the board (q.v.). It is picked up by a boy (the f.-p.), who carries it to a table throws it out flat to be skirted, rolled and classed. The verb, to f.-pick, means `to be a fleece-picker'. To p. up is to do the actual job.

either penning up
with the shepherds
or picking up and
helping the presser.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: picking up fleeces: the rouseabout (shearer's hand) picks up the newly-shorn fleece, throws it so that it lands spread out on the table, pulls off the short and dirty wool which had been under the belly (bellies), rolls the fleece and puts it into the press. Nowadays the shearer usually shears the belly separately before starting on the fleece.

Pickle can usually

However, in

Zealand preserving,
the word pickle is
usually reserved for
preserves in which
the pieces of fruit
or vegetable remain
separate, most
obviously in onions
and gherkins, but
also in chow chow
and picalilli in
which the vegetables
are preserved in a
thickened mustard
sauce.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Picnic, n. Besides the ordinary meaning of this word, there is a slang Australian use denoting an awkward adventure, an unpleasant experience, a troublesome job. In America the slang `an easy or agreeable thing.' (`Standard.') The Australasian use is an ironical inversion of this. -->1896. Modern: -->`If a man's horse is awkward and gives him trouble, he will say, `I had a picnic with that horse,' and so of any misadventure or disagreeable experience in travelling. So also of a troublesome business or other affair; a nursemaid, for instance, will say, `I had a nice picnic with Miss Nora's hair.'' [Check: omit ?]

Source: English as it is spoken in NZ
Author: BENNETT
Quote: The expressions `too true,' `too right,' in which too has its old intensive value, are in common use; so are `that'll be a picnic', `what a picnic' (where picnic = `trouble, bother')
~ n. sl. a troublesome job; an awkward expirience; a difficult adventure.
picnic n. a wild confusion, a messup, a difficult task, unpleasant experience.

Roman conqueror

Maori."

They wanted to marry

A Maori abroad would

The tax paid by a

PIE is changing the

It remained to be

Reserve bank]

to earn interest".

Author: POTTS
Quote: ... we find the flycatcher, of which there are here two species, namely, the pied fantail, Rhipidura flabellifera, called by the Maoris piwakawaka ...
35. Rhipidura flabellifera, Gml. Pied Fantail, Pied Flycatcher, Ti-waka-waka
Rhipidura flabellifera Gm. Pied Fantail.
Rhipidura flabellifera Gm. Pied Fantail.

pi[i]wakawaka, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: FANTAIL Rhipidura flabellifera Maori name: Piwakawaka. ... Birds of normal colour pattern (`Pied Fantail') make up most of the population in North Island, but the `Black Fantail' (i.e. dark phase) accounts for perhaps a quarter of the population of the South Island subpecies; ...

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Fantail Rhipidura fuliginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Fantail R.f. placabilis BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail R.f. fulginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail R.f. penitus BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: Piwakawaka, pied fantail, black fantail.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
A great deal of
research work has
been done in
Australia recently
in the use of
`enzyme'
preparations to get
quick sanitary
`pieing', but
unfortunately so far

too high.

Pierce's Disease, the latest outbreak of agricultural pestilence to rattle the West, is relentlessly tearing through Californian vineyards, worrying winemakers around the world, not least in Australia and New Zealand, for whom California's wine culture has long been a source of inspiration and grapevines... Pierce's Disease is caused by Xylella fastidiosa, a bacteria that lives in the xylem of plants, the thin layer beneath the surface that transports water and nutrients from the roots.

It begins by stating
that the threat of
Pierce's Disease to
vineyards and the
wine industry was
enough for Australia
to ban all imports
of Californian table
grapes.

Just when the
Californian wine
industry is on the
verge of defeating
its old-world
masters of the
international wine
trade, it is
attacked by an
apparently
invulnerable enemy,
Pierce's Disease...
Beavering away
assiduously in their
University of
Florida laboratories
in search of a
masterstroke with
which to defeat the
evil Pierce's..
these heroes have
devised a
brilliantly tricky
plan.

[Names used for Air
NZ fleet aircraft
include:] ZK-NAX
`PIERE' (NZ Robin)

Quote:
The bottom of the
pig-bucket.

there'd] be your

Author: HOSKEN
Quote:
At that time Mrs T.
was helping me and
as she cleaned up
some spilt sugar and
flour, said, `What
shall I do with
this?' I looked at
it and said, `Oh put
it in the pig
bucket.' Next she
showed me some dried
bread, etc., and
said, `What shall I
do with this?' Again
I said `Put it in
the pig bucket.'

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
The pig bucket was
half full ...

Author: PRESTON
Quote:
Leaving the
cookhouse, they
scraped their plates
into the pig bucket,
then filed past
three basins of hot
water ...

There was a
pig-bucket in her
own yard, in which
the refuse of her
house was kept, but
the smell could not
have proceeded from
it.

.. from that point
to the top of the
mountain saddle was
famous pig country,
and many a good hunt
for tuskers and
their progeny was
held there ...

Author: CARR
Quote:
All was pig country
in fact except for
100 acres, more or
less, along the top
of a ridge,
beginning at the far
north-west end of
the airstrip and
running south-east
from there to the
neighbour's
boundary.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
Wally had told me
that he had no
experience in pig
country, so when I

side gully, I
thought it would be
a good chance to
initiate him into
the noble art of
wrestling
razorbacks.

Author: CARR
Quote:
We all peered at the
vista of bush

patches, stands of
kanuka and
devil-weed - real
pig country.

When we were under
way again, finding
our cut path through
the dwarf bush and
the fog, Rob, the
pig-dog, provided us
with a sensation.

The party should
provide themselves
with a couple of
good Maori guides;
with a supply of
salt pork, biscuits,
tea, a little
brandy, tobacco (for
their own use and
for presents to the
Natives), pepper and
salt, a couple of
good pig dogs, a gun
or two, and, at this
season, stout
blankets sewn into
the shape of a sack
for bedding.

LOST - Yellow Pig
Dog, small scar on
front leg; answers
to name "King."

Unfortunately, birds
caught by pig-dogs
are generally torn
and useless.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
We had a couple of
pig dogs with us,

Hursthouse had

wahine at Te Kuiti
...

Mildred and Hongi,
after an exciting
day with the

behind the
homestead, were
wandering down ...
under the scented
wattles.

ws with us he only

pig-dog NZ & Austral. dog used in hunting wild pigs.

Quote:

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: Many kinds of dogs have been introduced by the Colonists; including Bull-dogs, by the whalers, Kangaroo-dogs, (a mixture of greyhound and mastiff) from New South Wales, and various crosses between these and the natives' dogs, which go under the general name of pig-dogs, and combine courage with speed, being used chiefly to hunt the wild hog, and taught to hold him, when caught, by ear or jowl, until the hunter comes up.

TO BE SOLD, two very
handsome and
Powerful DOG
PUPPIES, excellent
Watch-dogs, and now
ready for breaking
as Pig-dogs, or
Retrievers, or both.

Author: FITTON

Pig-hunting is a
most ignoble and
stupid sport; there
are in the country
plenty of so-called
pig dogs.

[We] started with
tent blankets,
knives, spears,
stockwhips, pig dogs
and a large amount
of provisions

We could seldom
procure the loan of

trains pig dogs, and
we always had the
best.

came back with a pig

round the wards.

pig.' ... All went

bottle.

covered with pig
face, and a foghorn

mornings, my mother
and I lived
everywhere.

The New Zealand wild pigs supposedly descended from farm animals brought here by James Cook gave rise.. to the coloquial but unflattering Pig Islands (or less logically Pig Island), which is found from 1906, and is well known.. from James K. Baxter's.. poem sequence Pig Island Letters (1966). A DNZE citation from 1946 reports Pig Island as an Australian usage, but there is no entry for it in AND.

"I think Parbury
could beat the two
in the one ring, so
you can inform
Sydney boxers who
are thinking of
crossing the Tasman
to keep as far away
from Pig Island as
they can."

Whilst in Sydney Ned
Perry ran into a lot
of the boys well
known in New
Zealand. Amongst
those he met and who
wish to be kindly
remembered to
friends in Pig
Island were Gene
Volaire, Havilah and
Tommy Uren, Ern
Baxter and Ike
Kutner.

He had been let in
for it by a "Pig
Island mug."

Seventy years later
James K Baxter
added: Love is not
valued much in Pig
Island / Though we
admire its walking
parody.

...if [small towns]
see you're not some
pig island wanker
... they're willing
to share.

I don't think the
States offer
betterliving
conditions than old
Pig Island.

I think I will wait
and give some
PigIsland girl the
chance of turning
medown.

He thought he was
back on the old farm
inPig Island.

Christchurch
appointed itself
cultural capital
and, pretty soon,
those snooty
southerners took to
calling the north
Pig Island, because
of its introduced
wildlife and the

pigfern, which

We kicked up our
heels and resolved
to cross over to New
Zealand (Pig Island
it was called where
we hang out); and
share in the good
things provided by
Vogel and Co. to all
comers.

There is some
feeling of
patriotism to be
found in every grade
of New Zealand
society .. First
there is the liberal
type, chiefly
notable for a
magnificent
ignorance of all
things outside that
infinitesimal speck
of land which he
fondly and
poetically describes
as "Pig Island".

One morning he sang,
or hummed, the song
again, and one of
the hands said
sneeringly, 'I
didn't know you were
a Pig Islander,
Hermann!'

Peregrinating
Pig-Islander Pulls
Leg of Patriotic
Pressman.

Every night will
seem novel to New
Zealanders, or, as
the W.A. men style
us, "Pig Islanders".
[sic]

A soldier writing in
a recent issue of
the "Chronicles of
the N.Z.E.F.,"
edited by Clutha
MacKenzie, waxes
enthusiastic over
the service which
the Y.M.C.A. is
rendering our troops
.. "When we arrived
at this sector, he
writes, " .. You
cannot imagine a Pig
Islander enjoying
soup, can you? Tea
and coffee, yes! ...

IT IS TOWN TALK ..
That "Pig Islander"
is a term of
endearment reserved
by Australians for
New Zealand friends.

He said that the
"Noo Zealanders
'adn't got a
bloomin' 'ope," he
opined that the
Walers would wallop
Hades out of them,
and that things
generally were to be
made to hum for the
"Pig Islanders."

There were three
brave Pigislanders

Every night will
seem novel to New
Zealanders, or, as
the W.A. men style
us, "Pig Islanders."

"Course not,
y'iggerant
Pig-Islander".

The common method of
addressing a New
Zealander is to call
him "digger," which,
from being an
abusive term, has
been readily and
universally adopted
and approved by the
Pig Islanders
themselves. We, the
N.Z.R.B., prefer to
be addressed as
"diggers" rather
than "dinks" which
was the original
mode of address.

Towards the end, the
cry of "Come on, you
Pig Islanders" was
often heard.

At the darne [sic]
he didn't hear
gentle Ellen chuck
off, although it
might have happened.
... He heard Arthur
say he had enough of
her slinging off.
The lady didn't call
Arthur a blanky
pig-islander, and
she didn't tell him
to go to a warm
place.

A few wounded "Pig
Islanders" have
occasionally risked
a drenching in order
to have their
accustomed "Wow on
the Wivver.

The Pig Islanders
turned out in force.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
"You are leetle Peeg
Islander!". Oh! Why
did the Dalmatian
boarders have to
keep calling me
that. I hated it
when they did. But I
saw even then that
calling a born New
Zealander a name
like Pig Islander
was some
satisfaction, the
pay-off for what
ranked them.

Quote:
We Pig Islanders are
not nearly so
hot-blooded in our
manner of speaking
[as Aussies].

turned out in force.

`But, Tom, do yer

Homies.' `A lot of

Islanders, and the
Australians the

Author: BENN
Quote: A citizen of New Zealand by birth is, or was (the word is obsolescent) a pig-islander.

Since the pig was introduced by Captain Cook ... [fn] Hence modern Newzealand slang a Captain Cook or Captain Cooker, for a wild pig. (Current since the late 19th century.) Also, slang, Pig-islands, Newzealand, Pig-islander, a Newzealander.

[The Maori] desire
