of land for pig and
cattle runs, over
which the herds may
range without danger
of trespass on the
white man's
cultivation, ...

Their customers are
the city's homeless,
who will be waiting
for them in K Road's
Pigeon Park, Myers
Park, and down near
the docks.

Also for Auckland,
if it could not
accomodate families
of "ten, nine, and
eight children!!"
This argument might
satisfy a person who
wanted a pig-run,
but we cannot see
the application in
this case.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
.. he takes his
rifle and we go over
the hills
pig-stalking ...

Author: DAVIDSON
Quote:
By this time our
gallant pig-sticker
had returned to the
charge ...

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
... predatory bands
of pig-stickers
ravaged the remotest
regions

He buckled on his
pig sticker

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
A long tom .303/ Lay
easy on his knee./
He'd a whacking
great pig-sticker
and an axe!

Usually there's just
one gun and everyone
else has knifes -
pig stickers.

There is nothing
whatever doing at
Manawapou, where the
General and the most
advanced force were
stationed, and the
soldiers appear to
be employed in
destroying native
crops, with
occasional intervals
of amusement at
cattle hunting and
pig sticking.

Alec Beattie also
corroborated, and
said that with
regard to the
bayonet, he took it
to the shop to get a
handle on it for
pig-sticking, but
found that to do so
would destroy the
catch that fixed the
bayonet to the
rifle.

In a speech at
Adelaide two weeks
ago, the Earl of
Onslow, Governor of
New Zealand,
expressed great
delight that in his
newly-adopted land
the noble sport of
"pig-sticking" was
to be had, and
intimated his
intention of
entering lustily
into that elevating
pastime.

They go pig
sticking.

Sports:
Pig-Sticking, Haggis
Netting.

Author: LINDSAY-BUCKNALL
Quote:
We had any amount of
`pig-sticking' all
round our new
quarters.

Author: CHAMIER
Quote:
Still less did
pig-sticking
resemble the grand
wild boar hunt of
yore.

Author: ARTHUR
Quote:
Wild-pig hunting,
or, as it is more
commonly called,
pig-sticking.

The Minister
caustically remarked
that he was
evidently unfit to
earn his living at
bushwacking or
pigsticking,
qualifications more
highly prized here
than literary
powers.

The book proper has
shape as a large
aggregation of
well-ordered
paragraphs, from
among which the
interested, would-be
sportsman will find
.. such information
as will help him
towards success in
fly-fishing,
pig-sticking,
deer-stalking, the
pursuit of winged
game, etc.

[Helen bought
eighty-five of that
fruit for two
shillings. No doubt
peaches here will be
pigs' meat in a year
or two].

A pigeon shot on the
way made a very good
supper.

He was chopping a
tree when a pigeon
(a loose branch)
fell on his head.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
Every day we applied
pigeon fat to
ourhands to prevent
cracking.

Author: LAMBERT
Quote: We had been out fishing and were expecting at any time to hear the signal, `There she spouts!' or `Ehi pauta!' the pigeon-Maori version of the warning.

Source: NZ Woman's Weekly: The First 60 Years
Quote:
The unofficial name
by which [this
reserve] is known to
the citizens of
Wellington is
"Pigeon Park," and
most fitting is this
description, for
over the years the
pigeons have
established
forthemselves a
veritable sanctuary
in the heart of one
of the city's
busiest
thoroughfares.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
I lay down on the
grass / In Pigeon
Park

On Wednesday.. the
Public Trial and
execution of Merv
Wellington was
staged at Pigeon
Park.

[Caption] Walking
past Pigeon Park /
Hopelessly late...

At least one person
in Wellington loves
the sculpture in
Pigeon Park. I do.

So we are to have a
film about the
making of Pigeon
Park.

I remember Pigeon
Park. A little oasis
of grass and bird
droppings in the
middle of
Wellington's central
shopping precinct -
the sort of place
you could crash on a
sunny afternoon,
read a book, meet a
street kid and laugh
at the motorists who
didn't know not to
park under the tree
where all the
pigeons hung out.

Perhaps [he] would
like to end all
usage of nick-names.
No more Pigeon Park,
no Beehive, and no
more references to
the Dom'.

A Wellington police
spokesman says
police have problems
with drunken teens
in Pigeon Park.

I hope the renaming
of Chaffers Park
will be as
unsuccessful as the
renaming of Pigeon
Park.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
THE PIGEON "POST."
[sic]- Carrier
pigeons were, in the
old times, long
enough before the
invention of
electric telegraphs,
or before
post-offices were
established, used
instead of both.

By private
enterprise a pigeon
post has just been
established between
Great Barrier Island
and the city of
Auckland.

We saw again the
island's unique
pigeon post mail
service and then it
was on to Waiheke.

A message received
by pigeon post from
the search party
reports the finding
of the dead body of
the captain of the
Alfheld on
Golddiggers' Beach.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote:
After about a
month's incubation,
an almost naked
chick [native
pigeon] hatches
which is fed for a
time on a secretion
from the parent's
crop called
`pigeon's milk',
later supplanted by
partially digested
berries.

For most of the
[snow] gut we faced
inwards and
pigeon-holed down as
it was a bit steep.
In addition to the karaka and nikau ... the most notable were the pigeon-berry, titoki, and broad-leaved cabbage-tree (Cordyline indivisa) ...

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Ash ... Pigeonberry A. Elaeocarpus obovatus, G. Don., N.O. Tiliaceae.

"A MESSAGE FROM THE SEA." - Under this heading the Auckland Star received two pigeongrams - why should we not coin a new word like our neighbours? - received by carrier pigeons from on board the ship City of Auckland, which recently sailed from the port of that name.

The Premier has
accepted an offer by
the Great Barrier
Pigeongram Agency to
supply 10 homing
pigeons.

The following
pigeongram was
received to-day but
was dispatched from
the Terawhiti at 1
p.m. yesterday:-
"Tide gone back.
Indrabarah is
heading west to
seaward ..."

A Star pigeongram
from Te Aroha says
that gold has been
got at the reef at
the prospectors'
claim to-day.

A Thames Star
pigeongram from
Paeroa, this
afternoon, states
that the judgment of
the native council
was delivered at 3
p.m. today.

The Barrier Island
offered not one but
two pigeongram
services, each
struggling to assert
its aerial supremacy
over the other... On
one well-publicised
occasion a bird was
despatched wih a
pigeongram to
Auckland at 8 am and
a reply received by
9.15 the same
morning.

A Thames Star
pigeongram states
that "Samuel Young
got the first
miner's right, and
every horse in the
place was engaged
last night."

The following
pigeongram was
received at
Grahamstown during
the afternoon.

A pigeongram from
Ohinemuri to-day
reports rumours of
reef and alluvial
finds, but nothing
definite.
Hedycarya arborea (pigeonwood).. [is one of] a good list to select from; most have grown and are growing on the ranges about Wellington.

﻿There is a
large amount of towa
[sic] inthis bush,
nio, matipo, some
rimu,pigeon wood,
etc., struggle one
withanother in rich
profusion for
anexistence

AGRIOPUS LEUCOPOECILUS. Richardson. Pig Fish.

There is another fish, termed the Agriopus leucopoecilus [leucopoccilus sic] (Leather Jacket, or Pigfish), quite different from the fish of that name in the North, which is very palatable, ... but it is very seldom eaten ...
24. Puysegur Point - Hapuku, kahawai, trumpeter, moki, pig-fish, trevally, rock-cod, perch, butter-fish, red-cod, dog-fish
4. Pig-fish - Agriopus leucopoecilus. This is called `leather-jacket' in Dunedin, where the fish occurs in immense numbers.
On the Anatomy of the Pig-fish (Agriopus leucopoecilus).

Congiopodus leucopoecilus, [sic] Richardson. The fish is popularly known as `pig-fish', on account of the grunting noise it makes when taken out of the water and has to gasp for air. It is sometimes called `leather-jacket', a name which, however, is more correctly applied to [Navodon] scaber, another very common fish in Otago Harbour.

CONGIOPODUS LEUCOPAECILUS (Richardson). Pigfish; Puramorua. Large numbers commonly sold throughout the year in Christchurch under the name of `silver trumpeter.' Rarely seen in Dunedin markets unless other fish are scarce. ... Distribution: South Island and southern coasts of North Island.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: SPEIGHT

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: PIGFISH (PURAMORUA) Congiopodus leucopaecilus (Richardson) ...This fish is sometimes called Leather-jacket by many fishermen, probably on account of its leathery skin, but this name is misleading as the proper and popular Leather Jacket is a smaller fish with a tough rough and leathery skin and with one single spine on its back. Many years ago these fish were sold to the public in large numbers but only for a short period when others were exceptionally scarce. scarce. The fish were skinned so that they looked quite different from the fish in its natural state. They were then railed to a country town and sold readily under the name of Snap Jacks or Skip Jacks.

Among New Zealand
most-threatened
species, the pygmy
button daisy,

coast, one of just
three colonies left
in the country which
are being carefully
nurtured back to
being
self-sustaining in
the wild.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Hunting pignuts on
all fours/ In the
great funfair none
do well./ Tom likes
boys and Bob likes
whores/ And both
will share a bunk in
Hell.

Some gravelling
between the Pigroot
and Red cutting was
required, and from
present end of metal
at Daddy's Pinch
towards Pigroot.

Palmerston folk, I
notice, intend to
endeavour to prevent
us from getting out
rights; but it won't
do, dear friends;
Mrs. Partington
could not keep back
the Atlantic,
neither can you keep
Craig and Co. on the
Pigroot line.

Author: Owen Marshall
Quote:
Dansey's Pass often
had heavy snow at
that time of the
year, so Theo took
the route through
Oamaru and then up
the Pigroot from
Palmerston.

Author: WILLIAMS & REEVES
Quote: Only think how much more graceful all the landscape will appear. / No more pigroots, whalebacks, hogbacks - these names that shall not last; / ... Negro-heads shall be re-christened. I for one will take no heed, / While to me there yet remaineth Negrohead, the fragrant weed.

No map the collector
has consulted has
shown Pigroot Hill
or hotel, and yet it
is the most
prominent and most
used name between
Palmerston and
Kyeburn. Again and
again the collector
has heard the
remark, `I am going
into the Central by
the Pigroot,' or `I
came down by the
Pigroot.' So
frequently is it
used that one might
imagine that certain
people used it
thinking that the
word `root' is in
reality `route,' but
be that as it may,
common usage is the
deciding factor in
place-names, and
Pigroot, with its
associations back
into the fifties,
has come to stay.
The name was
originally [9]
bestowed because the
wild pigs rooted up
the hillside looking
for the roots of the
taramea, or
speargrass, which
they enjoy eating,
and which is
probably one of the
main reasons why
speargrass is so
rare nowadays.
(Reprinted from the Molyneux Mail) Mr. Kilgour.. has called for tenders to remove and re-erect his premises from the Pigroot to this place.

On the Waihemo road
the Shag River has
similarly prevented
the coach from
reaching the
Pigroot.

Author: SPENCER
Quote:
They stopped for the
night at Peg 58.
They made a 'Pigs
Nest' of dried twigs
and punga fronds.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
Never since the
memorable year 1804,
when "Mrs. Thornton"
appeared on the
pigskin as the
jockey of Col.
Thornton's
Vinagarella.. has
York witnessed so
extraordinary an
assemblage of
people.

He would rather
stick to the pigskin
than take his ease
in a carriage.

Now the veriest tyro
in equitation knows
the difference
between riding and
bumping the pigskin
in the awkward
fashion these clumsy
equestrians are set
to do.

His mount negotiated
the first two fences
well, but slewed
over the wing of the
last and tripped to
somersault and land
on the rider, who
stuck to the
pigskin.

They seemed to
understand the
management of their
horses, and stuck
well to the pigskin.

This horse had a big
spill at the bank,
but Northcott stuck
to the pigskin.

scratcher's a bunk
and when you're

they hoof it or ride
their hobnails, and
on horseback they
ride the pigskin.

Pigweed

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: WIREWEED (Polygonum aviculare), also called road weed, mat weed, knot grass, `pig weed,' and hog weed, is common in cultivated land all over the country. It is an annual, with stems up to 2ft. in length trailing over the ground. The stems have swollen nodes (`knot grass') and are very tough (`wireweed').

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: RED ROOT (Amaranthus [hybridus and A. retroflexus), also called red shank and pig weed, is found in gardens and waste places all over the North Island and as far south as Nelson [Canterbury].

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: GENIOSTOMA LIGUSTRIFOLIUM, hangehange. A common, lightly branched shrub of lowland forest margins and track-sides in the North Island ... The waxy-surfaced, apple-green leaves ... might commend this as a desirable garden shrub were it not that the small greenish flowers, ... have an odd smell that gives rise to the name `pigwood' in some districts.
pihanga, window of a Maori whare: the sliding shutter closing the same.

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote:
From 8 a.m. to 4
p.m., preparations
were made for the
refreshment of the
people, when 200
birds (titi), 200
fishes (piharau),
200 loaves of bread,
besides several pigs
and a supply of
potatoes, were
served up.

They caught some of
those fish as well
as tuna and piharau.

Author: EDWARDS
Quote:
Blind eels like
tuere and piharau -
veryunusual taste.

It is a species of
lamprey, and known
to the Maoris as
piharau.

These people had
certain fishing
rights in the
Huatoki river, and
had set the usual
traps for the
piharau, or lamprey
eels, in the river
bed.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: I found my former quarters not very fragrant, having about 400 piha piharau [?piha error], (lampreys) which were presented to us when we were here before ...

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: Geotria chilensis Gray Lamprey, Piharau, or Puhikorokoro

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Piharau, n. Maori name for Geotria chilensis, Gray, a New Zealand Lamprey (q.v.).

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
`We procured an
abundant supply of
piarau, a `lamprey,'
which is taken in
large numbers in
this river, and some
others in the
neighbourhood, when
the waters are
swollen.'

Author: TREGEAR
Quote: Lampreys (piharau) were caught in loose mats of fern laid in small streams ...
GEOTRIA AUSTRALIS. Lamprey. Called `piharu' [sic] and `korokoro' by the Maoris.
Notes: Phillipps and Hodgkinson Further Notes on Edible Fishes

Quote: 1. Geotria australis Gray. Lamprey. Maori: Korokoro, Piharau.

Author: MILLER
Quote: Here the sea teemed with fish, the streams with eels, and in the season the piharau or whitebait was to be found in the Waitara River.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Pihapiharau (the lamprey), is almost eighteen inches long, of a silvery color; there is a saying, `No Rangiriri te pihapiharau,' `The lamprey comes from the fountain of Rangiriri.' The name of the fish is derived from its many gills. Ibid. 627 Fam. Petromyzidae, (Pihapiharau,) the Lamprey, which is found in most of the rivers to the south.

Author: MOSER
Quote:
... in every kind of
dress from the most
select slop fashions
... to the normal
kaitaka (bordered
mat) and pihe-pihe
of fig leaf
simplicity.

Maoris have some
nine names for
white-eyes. Pihipihi
and tauhou are in
most general use.

The "Pihoihoi" (or
swallow sitting
aloneon the
housetop) was too
weak an advocateto
be admitted to tread
with impunity onthe
infirmities of the
self-satisfiedstate
of affairs than
[sic]
subsistingamongst
the Maoris of the
Waikato.

Author: BULLER
Quote: Anthus novae-zelandiae, Gray, Voy. Ereb. and Terror, Birds, p. 4 (1844) ..Pihoihoi and Whioi; "Ground-Lark" of the colonists.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote:
Pi o|i |oi; A bird
so called.

Author: YATE
Quote: Pihoihoi - This bird resembles the canary in shape and size .. It might not be improperly designated the ground-lark, which it very much resembles.

Author: POLACK
Quote: The piohiohi is a species of `poor cock-robin,' equally fitted to `point a moral, and adorn a tale,' as his antipodal species.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: Alanda Novae Seelandiae. Gmel. .. Kogoo aroure of the natives of Queen Charlotte's Sound. Forst. Kataitai of the natives of Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach. A `Ground Lark' is given under the name of Pihoihoi, by Mr Yate; Piohiohi, by Mr Polack; Pi-o-oie, by M. Lesson, which may prove to be the above species.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/192 35.

Quote:
Pihoi hoi - name of
a little bird

Anthus Novae
Zelandiae. Pihoihoi.
Lark. Common.

ANTHUS NOVAE
ZELANDIAE, Gml.
Pihoihoi. Lark.
ANTHUS NOVAE-ZEALANDIAE. - Ground Lark (Pihoihoi).

Quote:
33. ANTHUS NOVAE
ZEALANDIAE. Gml.
Ground Lark.
Pihoihoi.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ANTHUS NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (NEW -ZEALAND PIPIT.) .. Native names. Pihoihoi and Whioi; `Ground-Lark' of the colonists.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Piihoihoi n. ground lark; anthus Novae Zelandiae.

Author: HAY
Quote: The Pihoi (Anthus N.Z.) is the so-called native `lark.' It is a ground pipit, and may often be seen fluttering and chirping about a bush road.
32. Anthus Novae-Zealandiae, Gml. Lark, Pipit, Pihoihoi.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pihoihoi .. Maori name for a New Zealand bird, the Ground-lark (q.v.). The word has five syllables.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
I never saw the
native quail, the
cuckoo nor the
morepork in the
Central [Otago,
c1860s], but I saw
the sparrow-hawk,
the rock wren, and
plenty of hawks and
pihoihoi (ground
larks).

The Government paper
was christened Te
Pihoihoi Mohemohe or
"The Sparrow that
sitteth alone upon
the house-top."
pihoihoi: New Zealand pipit.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: NEW ZEALAND PIPIT Anthus novaeseelandiae Other names: Pihoihoi, Sandlark (Chathams). .. The Skylark, with which it is commonly confused, lives in pasture land where the Pipit is generally absent, but the ranges of the two species overlap in rough open country, etc.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Pipit Anthus novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789) .. New Zealand Pipit A.n. novaeseelandiae (GMELIN, 1789). Auckland Islands Pipit A.n. aucklandicus GRAY, 1862. Antipodes Pipit A.n. steindachneri REISCHEK, 1889. .. OTHER NAMES: Pihoihoi, groundlark, native lark.

[Names used for Air
NZ fleet aircraft
include:] ZK-NAT
`PIHOIHOI' (NZ Lark)

The sweet notes of
the pihoihoi or New
Zealand robin -
first chorister of
the dawn - echo from
the bush.

The pihoihoi, the
native ground-lark,
is a common bird
here.

Author: BULLER
Quote: PROSTHEMADRA NOVAE ZEALANDIAE. (TUI OR PARSON-BIRD.) ... Native names. Tui and Koko; the young bird distinguished as Pi-tui or Pikari.

ANY one found
tresspassing on the
property of the
undersigned with
spade, spear or
pikau in his
possession will be
prosecuted.

Author: SATCHELL
Quote: He commenced to fill his pikau.

The last time he saw
deceased alive was
about 9 a.m. on
April 5 going by the
Wairakei bridge to
follow his
occupation of
gum-digging, having
his pikau, with
spear, spade, and
axe in his
possession.

Author: REED
Quote:
... lonehand
gumdiggers ... spade
in hand, pikau on
back ...

The gumdiggers used a pikau , a bag with shoulder straps, a good deal smaller than the usual tramper's pack. They were sold under that name by Leroy's in Auckland in the thirties. If pikau had been current further south trampers might have adopted it.

Author: REED
Quote: Pouch strap-ped at his [the gum-digger's] side, pikau (bag with shoulder straps) thrown down in the shelter of a clump of tea tree.

Author: SATCHELL
Quote: [`pikau']

Author: FRANCIS
Quote:
... the heavy canvas
pikau bags which
draped over the
saddle and hung down
on either side to
about stirrup level
... were waterproof
when fording rivers.

The farthest
back-settler could
bring in the produce
in one pikau on his
horse.

Rua very kindly
strapped the "pikau
nui" on one of his
steeds.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`I often wonder on
looking back now,'
remarked Jane, `how
I ever managed, wet
and almost numb with
the cold as I
sometimes was, to
keep the pikau of
mail and parcels in
place, and get
through some of
those dreadful gates
... [1890's]

Author: HELMER
Quote:
...pulling a
hindquarter of
vension from his
sugar-sack pikau...

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
.. and what the
Maoris call a pikau
- a split sack which
forms two capacious
pouches across the
withers of a horse.

Author: FERNANDEZ
Quote:
David hunted up a
sacking pikau to
drop over his saddle
in case there should
be venison and skins
to bring home.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
.. In a farming
context it is
usually a sugarbag
made into an
extemporised
rucksack with some
rope or a strip of
flaxleaf. It can
also be a
chaff-sack, closed
at both ends, and
one side slit across
at the centre and
used with this side
uppermost. Thrown
across, either under
or over the saddle,
the two large
saddlebags thus
formed could be used
to bring home some
wool plucked from a
dead sheep, or as a
sheltered place to
carry a weakling
lamb.

The couple were
loaned an old horse
and went off home
with a pikau loaded
up with meat,
vegetables and fresh
bread. 3.

Author: WATTS
Quote:
They would arrive
about lunchtime with
peacows slung over
their saddles. A
peacow is a chaff
sack, sewn up at
both ends with a
slit made across the
centre of one side
of the sack. When
slung over the
saddle it formed two
large pockets in
which the men
carried their 'glad
rags' or best
clothes.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
He vaguely
remembered ...
cutting the tail off
the animal and
putting it in the
pekau on the saddle
of his horse.

Author: FERNANDEZ
Quote:
David hunted up a
sacking pikau to
drop over his saddle
in case there should
be venison ... to
bring back.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Dad led the pack horse, and a troop of us youngsters followed on our ponies (bareback), each with a pikau laden with goods. Occasionally an unevenly balanced pikau would slide off, taking the unlucky rider with it. ... Mum supervised the unpacking of the cases [of big stores orders]. Certain packages and parcels were placed in her pikau, ... Ibid. 66 After removing our pikaus, saddle bags and swag, we unharnessed the horses and turned them loose in the `house paddock'.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: P|ikau, s. A garment so called.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Pikau - a load,
burden, a garment

We carefully packed
in our blankets,
which, fitted with
'pikau' straps,
formed our swags.

We were 6 in party,
ourselves, young
Stark and 3 Maoris
with `pikau'
burdens.

On their arrival at
Mokau, the people
were all away; and
Newton, supposing
that due deference
would be paid to his
visit, returned -
and Mr. Swainson,
with his "pikau" men
(native carriers)
proceeded.

Author: LOCKE
Quote:
At night we made a
pikau - a bag slung
on the back - for me
to carry my gum in.

Hers was a life of
constant moving..
always labouring, in
the gum fields or at
the pa, carrying
pikaus of gum or
preparing the food.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Once somebody asked
him where he was
going, pikau on his
back, rifle slung
over his shoulder
and axe in hand.

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
Deceased had a pekau
on his back.

They had to endure
all these
discomforts, carry
their own pikau (as
I have seen Bishop
Selwyn do alone)
climb slippery mud
hills, and encounter
all the petty ills
so graphically
sketched by your
correspondent, and
what else?

When Harry first
came to these hills
hecarried his
supplies in a sugar
sackpikau over his
shoulder.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
I left some of my
pikaus with Mr.
Duncan.

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Several [natives] carried their pikau (or knapsacks strapped over their shoulders with leaves of flax.

The Maoris .... made
up all our packages
... into three
pikaws or bundles of
about 35lb. each
which they tied up
and slung over their
shoulders with
strips of native
flax leaf.

Author: ABRAHAM
Quote: My pikau (or burden) weighed 30lbs.

Author: WILLIAM MORGAN
Quote:
One [Maori prisoner]
... had on an
oilskin, a hat, and
carried a small
`pikau', his
wardrobe I suppose.

On his return fron
Rangatiki, the blue
blanket pikau was
gone.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
... our pikaus
became apparently
heavier ... as we
trudged to our
destination.

Author: COWAN
Quote: These Ngati-Mutunga ... mde up small casks of powder in flax-basket pikaus or back-loads, and transported them through all the forests and ranges of Pukerua and along the northern shore of the bay.

Author: LYON
Quote:
.. this huge midden
[of shellfish] ..
had been brought by
pikau on the backs
of old Maori women
...

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
[He] sat down with
his pikau, in which
he had a
freshly-slain leg of
pork, strategically
placed in his lap.

Author: HOGAN
Quote:
Days of Billy-can
and Pikau,/ Horse
and Buggy, sleet and
snow,/ Railway camp
and crowded
`Boozer',/

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
pikau: sugar-bag
used for carrying
food or other
things, shouldered
by means of ropes
attached to the
corners.

Author: MOORE
Quote:
As we leave the hut
for the day's work
we each have on our
backs a `pikau' - a
sugar-bag rucksack
containing tucker
for our lunch and
`smoke-o's'.

Author: REED
Quote:
The pikau (load for
the back) was a
half-sack, with a
strap attached to
each of the bottom
corners and joined
at the middle of the
top - in the manner
of a knapsack.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: I had on my shoulders my few items of clothing ... all packed into a sugar bag transformed by a loop of light rope into that handy pack for trampers which the Maoris called pikau .

Stories are still told of the prodigious loads they would carry over the hills in their pikaus. Ibid. 33 Still another sack made the standard haversack type of container with shoulder straps for carrying loads on the back. This essential piece of equipment was invariably called a pikau, a Maori word meaning to carry on the back, but also used in either language as a noun.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: The rest of his luggage would be a pikau slung on his shoulders; and my mother ... would ask him what he meant by daring to appear before respectable people looking like a swagger.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote: [The pighunter] ... dipping his hand into his pikau and lifting out the remarkably well-preserved skull ... Ibid. 43 Both of [the Canterbury pighunters] carried a pikau (a daypack which fits snugly over one's shoulders and is often fashioned out of a sugar-bag) as they ranged those big [sheep] stations.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
After sowing grass
seed ... by hand
from pikaus carried
on their backs, they
started on the
farm's first
permanent buildings.
pikau n. NZ swag. [M]
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 366]

Quote:
We were 6 in party,
ourselves, young
Stark & 3 Maoris
with `pikau'
burdens. ... After
tiring of [singing]
they set off with
burning brand &
tomahawk to catch
crawfish & tuna, the
eels of the country,
in a little brook
near our encampment.
pikau , pack carried on the back: to carry on the back: to mount on the back of another. Connected with pick-a-back.

Author: KEENE
Quote: pikau : pack carried on the back.

Author: POLACK
Quote:
I then ordered the
pikaus', or
packages, to be
shouldered, ...

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Pikau - a load,
burden, a garment

... but all ideas of carrying anything ourselves, were dispelled by the Maoris, who speedily made up all our packages together with some of their own, into three pikaws or bundles of about 35lb each which they tied up & slung over their shoulders with strips of native flax leaf which serves for such purposes without any preparation.

The outfit required
[for gum-digging] is
a spade, a spear,
and a pikau.

Author: J WILLIAMS
Quote:
Nonekai who went to
carry one of Henry's
pikaus as far as
Toanga, not having
returned, I began to
fear he might be in
some difficulty ...

Author: J WILLIAMS
Quote:
The horses at the
door for Wm & Mr
Dudley on one side,
and the Waiapu
natives clamouring
for their pikaus at
the garden gate on
the other side...

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
We were 6 in party,
ourselves, young
Stark and 3 Maoris
with 'pikau'
burdens.

Author: WATERSON
Quote:
The tackle, bait and
a few sandwiches
were carried out of
harm's way in a
pikau on our backs
... 2.

A meal you eat in a
paddock or on the
job: a pikau.

Author: BAINES
Quote: So `there and then' [the wild pig's] inside was torn out ... and, his legs tied together so as to make him a handy `pikau' ... Ibid. 201 My quarry (pig) - a la pikau - on my back ...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
... a week's
provisions and other
fixings in your
rolled-up `Pikau' of
oilskin on your
back; ...

... then swag and
footslog for the
roadless forest. ...
our provisions ...
divided into equal
sized `pikaus' among
us ...

Author: COWAN
Quote: ... Maclean ... must have walked some thousands of miles ... carrying his swag as the Maoris carried their pikau .

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Clad in our `bush' costume, but without weapons, and each with a toko toko or long walking-staff in our hands, my fellow traveller and myself set off in excellent spirits, accompanied by five Maori lads, who carried our baggage ... in their pikau or knapsacks, strapped over their shoulders with the leaves of flax.

One who seemed
somewhat of a
"swell", had on an
oilskin, a hat, and
carried a small
"pikau", his
wardrobe I suppose.

We found it no joke
to travel through
the bush with mud in
many places nearly
to our knees with a
pikau on our backs.
The settler found he could not swim ashore with the pikau on his back, and asked the natives for help.

The whole of the
stolen articles..
were placed upon the
prisoner's back, and
he was compelled to
pikau them to the
Hill Farm, whence he
had taken them.

The winding nature
of the river makes
the distance up to
where the reef was
found very long and
wearisome, all the
stores, &c.,
necessary on such an
expedition having to
be carried "pikau,"
as there is no means
of getting horses
in.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: I crossed a Stream a dozen times, mostly on a Mans back called a Pekow (pikau). Ibid. 72 He picked out two of the strongest of the Boys about the place to carry "Pekow" us over the River.

"You pikau te canoe,
quick."

Author: POLACK
Quote: ... nay, he may with due deference to public opinion, carry (pekau) pickback, the said foreigner, be his dimensions long or short, ... Ibid. 1/171-172 The flax in a basket generally weighs about from [172] eighty to a hundred pounds, and is either carried (pikou), on men's shoulders or in canoes, to the house of the purchaser.

They do not need to
pikau, or carry,
their produce to the
town.
It will scarcely be argued that exhibitors will pikau the result of their labours 10 or 15 miles to a show when they have neglected one at their own doors.

Author: J WILLIAMS
Quote:
Henry plastered it
[the gash] under my
directions and we
sent for a couple of
his mates to pikau
him home.

Author: HAY
Quote:
Both men and women
are able to pikau (
hump, or carry on
the back and
shoulders ) great
weights.

News arrived that
200 men are expected
to be down from the
Waikato, to "pikau"
these guns across
the country.

Many of them
continue for years
to pikau their
provisions over
roads that can never
be made passable for
drays.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote:
... Jake exerted
himself and got five
Boys to Pekow the
Traps across at 2lb
[tobacco] each to
Kiddy Kiddy.

Author: MANING
Quote: `I tell you what we must do ... we will not carry (pikau ) the provisions, we will hiki them' (Hiki is the word in Maori which describes the act of carrying an infant in the arms.)

Author: A TRAMP
Quote: `Tommy' and Rairaina pikaued the swag.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Three grand days in
the saddle, the last
winding down the
bush road that
skirted the ...
Ohura ... then
`pikau' and
foot-slog for the
great roadless
forest.

Author: POLACK
Quote:
[The Maori] may with
due deference to
public opinion,
carry (Pekau)
Pickback the said
foreigner.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
Some natives pikaued
me across them

Author: FEATON
Quote:
Riria Raihi came to
his assistance and
although Mr Graham
was no light weight,
took him on her back
and pikaued him to
the top

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
... woe betide the
tender, forming
backs, as they grew
strong enough to
waha, or pikau
(carry) the baby.

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote:
To get upon the back
Pekou
Pikau, pack carried on the back: to carry on the back: to mount on the back of another. Connected with pick-a-back.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
My father took
charge of his
offspring, carrying
him on his back
'pikau' (Maori
fashion.)
`Connected with pick-a-back' This is incorrect pikau seems to have Polynesian cognates. The word itself may have been associated with pickaback by English speakers.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote: I crossed a Stream a dozen times, mostly on a Mans back called a (Pekow [pikau] is to carry Upanga [hapainga], lift me up.) [1963 fn] Though the meaning of this sentence is fairly clear, punctuation and syntax are even more defective than usual: pikau means to carry on the back; hapainga is the passive form of hapai, lift up, raise.

Author: COWAN
Quote: But the Maori generally is manfully shouldering the pikau of this twentieth century and is in some quarters showing that, given the same facilities, he can even outstrip the pakeha in the walks of civilized life.

Author: BROOKS
Quote:
Most of us were now
loaded with heavy
pekoes or swags on
our backs.
The rest of [the farmer's] luggage would be a peko slung on his shoulders.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
He.. sat down again
with his pikau, in
which he had a
freshly-slain leg of
pork strategically
in his lap.

One of the natives
left us at Woon's
.... so we had to
put the pico on the
mule and trudge
along.

The couple were
loaned an old horse
and went off home
with a pikau loaded
up with meat,
vegetables and fresh
bread.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
The few possessions
that we had at the
homestead we were
able to pack over on
a pack saddle, plus
a pikau load on the
hack ...

.. but all ideas of
carrying anything
ourselves, were
dispelled by the
Maoris, who speedily
made up all our
packages together
with some of their
own, into three
pikaws or bundles of
about 35lb each
which they tied up &
slung over their
shoulders with
strips of native
flax leaf which
serves for such
purposes without any
preparation.

Author: SIMONS
Quote:
Nagged at me every
day to show her. And
now she's piking -
the `scaredy cat'.

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Sphyraena obtusata Cuv. & Val. PIKE.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Pike Sphyraena grandisquamis Steindachner
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405

Author: SORENSON
Quote: BARRACOUTA (a) Scientific name: Thyrsites atun. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Sea Pike; Couta; Snoek; Barra Fillets. (c) Other common names: B/couta; Bait. (d) Principal localities where taken: Gisborne, Motueka, Nelson, Timaru, Port Chalmers.

Author: GRADY
Quote: Stickleback - A minke whale. Balaenoptera acutorostrata . The Peranos killed only one of these. They found them uneconomic to hunt. The stickleback was also sometimes called the pike whale by the Perano whalers.
The pike whale ( Balaenoptera acutorostrata ) is the smallest of the rorquals, reaching a length of 33 ft. only

To his astonishment,
however, on
approaching the raft
with men and gear,
he found it manned
by about a dozen
excited Maoris armed

eight or nine
Europeans, together
with the gentleman

The men chopped and

pike poles for

little streams of
water shot through
between the massed
timbers, and as the
spray arose it
covered their
clothing with ice,
which together with
their great efforts
benumbed arms, legs,
and body, and added
to their exhaustion
greatly.

Author: LELAND
Quote: pikelet: A small pancake (like a silver dollar pancake) usually served cold, topped with butter, jam or whipped cream to accompany morning or afternoon tea. The English call these griddle scones or scotch pancakes.

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote:
Pikelets are to
afternoon tea what
pavlova is to the
wedding breakfast :
indispensable! Early
Scottish immigrants
added baking powder
to a recipe known in
their home country
as `drop scones' and
the result -
pikelets - has
become a New Zealand
specialty.

Author: SHERWOOD
Quote:
The words flew, and
enriched Celia's [an
English visitor's]
vocabulary. `Duck
shoving' was the
local name for
buck-passing between
government
departments. A
`Queen Street
farmer' was a city
slicker who owned
land or stock for
tax-fiddle reasons.
`Skite' and `drongo'
were terms of abuse.
A `cow-cockie' was a
dairy farmer and
inferior for some
reason to a
`runholder'
concerned only with
sheep. A `piker' was
a faint-hearted
person who gave up
the fight too soon,
...
piker n. NZ & Austral. sl. one who avoids doing his fair share, a shirker.

Quote:
So to cope with the
rituals of tramping
... a slang language
has developed to
suit. ... `Crud'
(cloud),
`bush-bash', a
`gunn' tramper
(which must have
originated from Davy
Gunn's famous trek
up the Hollyford
Valley to help
victims of a plane
crash in 1936
...[Not so: HWO]),
`windfall' (a
collapsed pile of
trees), `pit' (the
tramper's true
friend, a sleeping
bag), `pog'
(porridge), `bastard
grass' and `lawyer'
(two unpleasant
plants), `piker'
(one who stayed
home), `Huey'
(all-powerful god of
weather) ...

Author: KEINZLY
Quote:

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
So to cope with the
rituals of tramping,
its pains and
camaraderie, a slang
language has
developed to suit.
Lots of quick short
words to fit in the
breathless pauses as
you pant uphill.
`Crud' (cloud),
`bush-bash', a
`gunn' tramper
(which must have
originated from Davy
Gunn's famous trek
up the Hollyford
Valley to help
victims of a plane
crash in 1936; he
travelled 40 km by
rowing boat, horse
and foot in 21
hours), `windfall'
(a collapsed pile of
trees), `pit' (the
tramper's true
friend, a sleeping
bag), `pog'
(porridge), `bastard
grass' and `lawyer'
(two unpleasant
plants), `piker'
(one who stayed
home), `Huey'
(all-powerful god of
weather), and many,
many more.

The kiwi is passable
when one is hungry,
though personally I
do not like him, but
being more
nutritious than
savoury, it is not
to be despised, and
is almost nice when
boiled with
piki-piki fern and
rice.

Thick leafy willows
trail their long
streamers in the
stream, and further
up give place to
native vegetation,
festooned in the too
brief season of bush
blossoms with the
white starry flowers
of the pikiarero,
the New Zealand
clematis.

Every one of them,
even Paul Tuhaere,
who was related by
marriage to the
deceased chief, had
around their heads
or hats massive
wreaths of the
creeping plant known
as pohue, and in
some places as
pikiarero.

6d Pikiarero
(Clematis).

In most lowland
forest areas of New
Zealand spring is
heralded by the
flowering of the
climber now called
clematis paniculata
but formerly known
as clematis indivisa
.. In his original
drawing Mr Fuller
showed the Maori
name of the flower
as "puawananga''.
The Botany Division
of the Department of
Scientific and
Industrial Research
advised that it
should be shown as
"pikiarero".

ligament of the

plant

Pitopito [sic] are fern fronds, which taste like lightly flavoured asparagus when cooked. .. "It's a good time to pick pikopiko. Matariki is a time for putting the past to rest and looking forward to the future."

Among the kawakawa,
koromiko, puha and
horopito inhabiting
wild menus is the
peppery premature
ponga frond pikopiko
.. It turned up in a

Ohio-born,

'fern shoots.'"

Pikopiko (Polystichum richardii) is a native fern easily found throughout the local bush. I call it New Zealand asparagus but it doesn't taste anything like vegetable asparagus (Asparagus officinalis).

Pikopiko - shield
fern - tastes like
asparagus, and is a
special spring
treat, because there
are only about nine
edible shoots per
plant.

(Reprinted from the Auckland Herald ) "I am a Pikopo," (the Maori word for Catholic) Scott replied.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: Protestant natives regard their Roman Catholic brethren as belonging to the devils: they are called pikipo, which M. Pompalier explained as being derived from episcopus, which seems to me the most probable derivation. The Protestant missionaries however, say that it means piki-po - always bowing [370] - (piki, bend - po, night). The Protestants, therefore, call their bishop pihopa, while the Roman Catholics have retained the title pikipo for theirs.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
We were Pikapo (the
Maori corruption of
episcopoi, or Roman
Catholics)
The natives at Taupo are nearly all pikipoi (episcopoi) as they call themselves.

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Mungahaku [of Tongariro], the chief of this pah, is a pikopo, or Roman Catholic; several of his people have also embraced Popery, ... Ibid. 2/152-153 Those natives who are still heathen are generally styled `devils' by the Christianized people; and they themselves adhere to the [153] appellation. Hongi Hongi, ... in answer to my inquiry as to whether he was a `mihorari' or a `pikopo'(Catholic), confessed with evident delight that he was a `devil'.

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Mungahaku [of Tongariro], the chief of this pah, is a pikopo, or Roman Catholic; several of his people have also embraced Popery, ... Hongi Hongi, ... in answer to my inquiry as to whether he was a `mihorari' or a `pikopo'(Catholic), confessed with evident delight that he was a `devil'.

Author: BULLER
Quote: They took the name of Pikopo. This no doubt was maorified from the Latin word episcopos; but, unfortunately for them, it had the ominous meaning in the Maori tongue, - creeping in the dark.

Author: PINFOLD
Quote: Even their name [sc Roman Catholics] may have hindered their progress. They were called Pikopo; the Maori attempt to reproduce the word episcopos. Unhappily for them, the word also means `creeping in the dark' : an idea which would not be helpful.

Author: BUICK
Quote: In his discussions with the Maoris, Bishop Pompallier had stresed the point that he held the advantage over the Protestant missionaries in that he was a member of the Episcopacy. The best attempt on the part of the natives to render into their own language the word Episcopos, in its varied forms, was pikopo, hence the Bishop and his converts became known as Pikopo.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
pilchard 515-40

There are plenty of
mackerel here, but

... large numbers of aua or kataha (Agonostoma forsteri); about 60 lb. ... weight of pilchard or mohimohi (Clupea sagax), two varieties; ... hundreds of young red-cod, rarii (Lotella bacchus), and what I believe are young rock-cod, or kokopu or rawaru (Percis colias). The red-cod were from 3 in. to 4 in. in length, and the rawaru, or, as the natives here call them, `toitoi' or `panepane', from 2 in. to 6 in. long.

There appear to be three species of fish belonging to the family Clupeidae in New Zealand waters, viz., Engraulis antipodum, or anchovy; Sardinia neopilchardus, or pilchard, and Harengula antipoda, or sprat. Ibid. 316 The sprat is the smaller of the two, but in the numerous notices of these fish, the name `sprat' probably includes in many cases immature pilchards. Ibid. 319 In the case of fish-stomachs examined at the station, sprats have been found in red cod, blue cod, southern king-fish, barracouta, and spined dog-fish; and pilchards in barracouta.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: ANCHOVY (a) Scientific name: Engraulis australis. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Anchovy. (c) Other common names: the following names of related Clupeids and Engraulid fish are sometimes applied to anchovy - Herring, Sprat, Sardine, Pilchard, although the true Herring of European waters (Clupea harengus), does not occur in New Zealand. (d) Principal localities where taken: Hauraki Gulf, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds. Ibid. 40 PILCHARD (a) Scientific name: Sardinops neopilchardus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Pilchard; Sardine. (c) Other common names: Sardine; Sprat; Anchovy; Herring. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Gisborne, Tasman Bay, Marlborough Sounds.

Author: PAUL
Quote: Pilchard Sardinops neopilchardus ... Sometimes called the sardine. Also occurs around southern Australia. ... In the 1880s a fishery in the Marlborough Sounds produced salted and smoked `Picton Herring', and small fisheries have developed briefly elsewhere. ... Pilchard are caught for groper bait (`bloater'), and have been used also for tuna.

Sardinia neopicharda : Sardine, pilchard, or `Picton herring.'

Author: MAY
Quote:
It was a matter of
nice judgement. The
digger recognized
four classes of
payable ground:
`tucker ground' kept
him in food with
nothing to spare; a
`wages claim' gave
him a pound or two
above living
expenses; a `riser'
was a rich claim;
and a `piler' or
`homeward bounder'
the richest of all.
Probably most of the
`pilers' were
beach-claims, where
the leads were
shallow and rich,
the outlay small and
provisions cheap
because of easy
access.

Author: HEINZ
Quote: Pilers: See CLAIMS below.(?) ... CLAIMS Worthless claims or ground were called schicers or duffers. Those yielding up to [pounds]3 per week per man were known as `tucker' claims; up to [pounds]8 per week were known as `wages' claims; above [pounds]8 were known as `pilers'; the richest of all were known as `Home-ward-bounders.'

silly men! wool pays

Quote:
The Canterbury
Settlers, or

[1851 Apr 19
Lyttelton Times
`Government might
have founded a
colony composed of

`Dream of Shagroon'
[title] I saw men of

The Pilgrims looked
with contemptuous

land, - the land of
the Canterbury
Pilgrims.
Notes: 1851 May 7 NZ Spectator and Cook's Strait Guardian (Wellington) in 1947 Reed Story of Canterbury 111

Quote: I have been gathering all the information I can on the subject from old settlers, old Australians, and Canterbury Pilgrims, who are novis [sic] homines in the pastoral world.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
... it is worthy of
notice, that the
colonists, soon
after the formation
of all the
settlements,
acquired
distinguishing
epithets; thus there
was an Auckland
cove, a Wellington
swell, a Nelson
snob, a Taranaki
exquisite, an Otago
cockney, and a
Canterbury pilgrim.
These epithets,
already forgotten,
are too
characteristic to be
buried in oblivion,
as each originated
in some peculiarity
of the leading
colonists. The Otago
settlers derived
theirs from their
ignorance of the
country in which
they lived; the
Auckland people from
their extensive
Sydney connexions;
and the origin of
the other names are
sufficiently obvious
without explanation.

Author: HART
Quote: In the month of September [1850] the band of Canterbury Pilgrims ... set sail for Canterbury from Gravesend in four vessels, now known as the historical four ships, viz., Sir George Seymour, Charlotte Jane, Randolph, and the Cressy.

Quote: At the same time frequent letters kept him appraised of what was happening to the Canterbury Pilgrims of the Southern seas.

Author: HASCOMBE
Quote: We learnt that those who can claim to belong to a family who came out to New Zealand in one of the first four ships to arrive in Lyttelton ... in 1850 belong to an &eacut.lite society known as the Canterbury Pilgrims.
canterbury pilgrim n. first English settlers of Canterbury province, South Island, N.Z.

The Canterbury
"Pilgrims" had
arrived on the scene
and taken possession
of their "promised
land."

One of the six
remaining Canterbury
pilgrims who arrived
in the First Four
Ships in 1850 to
found the province
of Canterbury..
celebrated his
ninetieth birthday
on Thursday.

Another Canterbury
pilgrim, Mrs. Thomas
Abrahams, has passed
away. She arrived in
Lyttleton in 1850,
in the first of the
pioneer ships, the
Charlotte Jane.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Canterbury Pilgrims,
The first settlers
in Canterbury, New
Zealand, were so
called in allusion
to the pilgrims to
the shrine of St.
Thomas Becket.
Chaucer's
`Canterbury Tales'
were told by such
pilgrims. The name
was given probably
by Mr William Lyon,
who in 1851 wrote
the `Dream.' See
quotation, 1877.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
`The `Pilgrims,' as
the first comers are
always called. I
like the name; it is
so pretty and
suggestive.'

Author: PRATT
Quote:
In the `Dream of a
Shagroon', which
bore the date Ko
Matinau, April 1851,
and which first
appearted in the
`Wellington
Spectator' of May 7,
the term `Pilgrim'
was first applied to
the settlers; it was
also predicted in it
that the `Pilgrims'
would be `smashed',
and the Shagroons
left in undisputed
possession of the
country for their
flocks and herds.'

Shortly the pilgrim
and prophet agreed
The plough and the
crook couldn't live
far apart.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
An old Australian
squatter, who
visited the
Canterbury
settlement in 1851,
divided the
inhabitants into
pilgrims, shagruns
and prophets; the
first were the
original colonists,
the second were
people from other
parts of New Zealand
and the last were
settlers from
Australia.

ibid. 125 The
Canterbury pasturage
system was quickly
adapted to the
requirements of
sheep-farming on a
large scale and
'pilgrims' and
prophets were soon
merged into one
class as Canterbury
runholders.

Author: HAWES
Quote:
To get the coal out,
you divvied the seam
up into 'pillars' a
square chain wide.
Then you drove
alleyways called
'bords' to the very
back of the pillar
and you worked back
towards the main
shaft, taking
'lifts' off the
pillars as you
went... As you
worked at the pillar
- picking,
shotfiring,
shovelling an' that
- it got thinner an'
thinner until in the
end it looked like a
big black tornado,
or a tree holding up
the sky. That's why
the last strand of
the pillar is called
a 'mahuta'.

When the seam is
worked out in this
way the question of
taking out the
remaining blocks of
coal, or pillars
arises.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
I made a pretty good
cheque off the
pillars this pay

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
... drives were
broken off at right
angles to [the dip
heading] at
distances of two
chains apart ; thus
forming pillars on
either side of the
dip, two chains
square. These drives
were called main
levels. The bords
were driven about
two chains off the
dip, and the
`stenton' would be
driven from the
lower level to the
one above.

Author: BLYTH
Quote: Pillar: That portion of a lode left standing as a support to keep the ore in place.

Author: McARA
Quote: Pillars: The vertical blocks of quartz left in position between two stopes or round the shafts to support the country.

The system of work
[in the Grey
coalfield] is mainly
by bord and pillar,
a small portion only
of this coal having
been worked by the
longwall method. In
the bord-and-pillar
system the bords are
18ft. wide, and
pillars 14 yards
thick. The pillars
are left intact
until the boundary
of a section is
reached, when they
are worked back. The
roof has in [418]
main proved good,
enabling a large
percentage of the
pillar-coal to be
won.

.. for the miner ...
what is termed
pillaring is really
the most dangerous
work.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Pin dips were also
another popular
amusement. `A pin or
a bull or a button,
To see a rary rary
show show show!'
(1875; Tahataki). A
piece of glass
backed by cardboard
was covered with a
piece of paper that
could be flicked up
to show the `rary
rary show' or had a
slit in it through
which one could
peep. One saw
through the glass a
variety of colors,
pieces of colored
paper, flower
petals, pictures,
and later pieces off
cigarette boxes.
Sometimes these had
been arranged in
some pattern, at
other times they
were kaleidoscopic
only, and the
perceiver had
himself to add the
configurations of
intelligibility. The
price for the view
was always a pin
`which we did not
want anyhow but
always accepted,' a
relic from an age
when such things
were rare. Pin dips
were known also as
`poppy shows'
(perhaps it was the
similar flash of
color that gave the
same name - `the
poppy show' - to the
exciting experience
of seeing a girl's
dress blown upward
by the wind; pins
were not charged for
flowers of this
sort). In fact, the
pin dip or the prick
book may have
developed from the
poppy show. The
poppy show was
common before 1900
and the prick book
after that date, a
fact connected with
the ever-increasing
stock of picture
cards and magazine
pictures available
to children.
Pin-ended- The designation of an end condition of struts or columns in which the end is held in position while little or no effective restraint is offered to rotation.

[The mountains in

The trees are easily

There are several

Pine (p&imacr.n), n. (Bot.) [Add.] ... In New Zealand the word pine is applied to many trees, some of which also bear other names. Thus, - black pine (see MATAI and MIRO), celery-topped pine (Phyllocladus trichomanoides), kauri pine, called also cowdie pine (Dacrydium pine, or Westland pine (Dacrydium Westlandicum), white pine see KAHIKATEA

The panting bushmen

At the Chinaman's

From the Mungaroa

The eight families

Penetrating the pine

reached on which to

and the fish were
soon broiling on
wooden spits.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: The tawheras that had been missed had dried and shrivelled, and the white of the tiore had decayed, but the fingers of the `gentlemen' had swollen considerably and now provided us with New Zealand `pineapples.' The really good ones were eight inches long and two-and-a-half inches in diameter. They were wrenched out in the same way as giggies. These `pineapples' were never very much sought after by the general public. They needed what might be called an acquired taste. They were tricky eating too. You bit off all the outside hard, nobbly but not prickly covering, and then gnawed the soft, sweet flesh to the bone.
Notes: 1880 Taranaki in Sutton-Smith History of Children's Play (1981) 117

Now the tawny spread
of pingao has
vanished.

The bright yellow
leaves of the pingao
were woven into
useful purse-like
girdles.

..pingao, the golden
sand sedge.
Desmoschoenus
spiralis, pigao (if
you're from the
north) or pikao (if
you're from the
south)...

It is true that
pingao is an
endangered species,
and also the only
plant of its kind in
the world.

Pingao, a native
sandsedge unique to
New Zealand,
stabilises sand
dunes in the coast
areas where it
grows, by trapping
wind-blown sand
around its base and
in its leaves ands
roots. The biggest
threats to pingao
are beach vehicles
and introduced
plants.

In places there were
tufts of the pingao
grass, whose tough
leathery leaves were
formerly used by the
Maoris for making
girdles, and are
still used for the
manufacture of kits.

Black sand sparkles
and the afternoon
sun catches the
pingau grass in the
dunes, turning it
flame orange.

[Hdg] Running short

(SOUTH-ISLAND TOMTIT.) Native names. Miromiro, Komiromiro, Pimiromiro, Ngirungiru, Pingirungiru, and Pipitori. ... Aynsley admits that
it might seem
strange for someone
who never bets at
the races to risk
tens of thousands of
dollars on the
pinhooking game, one
of racing's biggest
gambles... It also
failed to clear the
most tricky hurdle
facing pinhookers -
trying to pick the
sire which will be
fashionable in six
months' time.

They came to enhance
their health in
mineral spas, enjoy
the natural features
like the Pink and
White Terraces -
destroyed in the
1886 eruption of Mt
Tarawera - and soak
up the rich history
and culture of the
local Maori.

Mr. Crompton Smith's
letter may have
satisfied your
readers that there
is little likelihood
of the Terraces at
Rotomahana ever
being seen again;
but I should like to
supplement his
letter with a
description of the
scene, Lake
Rotomahana,
immediately after
the outburst.

Cascading down
opposite sides of
Lake Rotomahana, the
Pink and White
Terraces were
colonial New
Zealand's premier
tourist attraction.
Visitors were
spellbound by the
beauty of the
terraces' silica
buttresses and
mineral pools,
which, according to
one writer,
shimmered "such a
blue as is seen
nowhere else in
nature."

At Rotomahana we saw
the terraces of
enamelled baths of
pink and white.

The photographs
Valentine took of
Otukapuarangi and Te
Tarata or Mt
Tarawera's Pink and
White Terraces, as
well as other
landscapes, are
striking for their
clarity and
composition.

The celebrated White
Terrace.. is a thing
of the past, having
changed from a pure
white to a dirty
brown... There is no
change in the colour
of the pink terrace.

THE NEW POSTAGE
STAMPS .. The design
at present in use
for 1d (Lake Taupo)
will be used for the
4d, and the present
4d design (White
Terrace) for 1d.

Sir Robert Stout
wishes it to be
understood, says the
Argus that "he is
the centre of
political activity
in New Zealand; that
his policy takes the
place of the famous
Pink and White
Terraces of the
colony".

An elderly
vulcanologist...
knocked on the door
of the Limbs Dance
Studio in Auckland
and suggested they
do a dance about the
destruction of the
Pink and White
Terraces.

WHERE THE FAMOUS
PINK AND WHITE
TERRACES WERE
SITUATED, DESTROYED
BY THE TARAWERA
ERUPTION IN 1886.

The project that has
been mooted more
than once before is
being seriously
discussed again,
namely, the
possibility of
recovering the
famous terraces at
Rotomahana.

The fairyland
beauties of the
white and pink
terraces of the
Rotomahana.. have
often been
celebrated.

It must have taken
countless ages to
gradually build up
the Pink and White
Terraces into the
beautiful
proportions they
assumed previous to
their destruction.

The Pink and White
Terraces, whose
peerless beauty was
a petrified dream of
fairyland, are now,
alas! only a memory.

The most well-known
brand of insulation
is, probably,
fibreglass Pink
Batts, which have
ben advertised in
New Zealand for
years.

PINK BATTS Keep you
warm in winter and
cool in summer.

shelter. Had to

The Gaiety Hall in

are completely safe.
They won't burn.
Neither will they
spread flame or
develop smoke.

[Advt] Just as new
Pink Batt control
heat, new Sound
Barrier reduces
sound.

A Hamilton seizure

- is the first

`pink rock', which
takes its name from
the discolouration
[sic] caused by
shoddy manufacture,
came from Thailand
... The `pink rock'
has less than 40 per
cent purity. It can
also be coloured

impurities, and is a
number three grade
heroin.

Of the cars

"The two cars have

We can slap a pink

Quote:

*Pink-eye.-Ophthalmia: an affliction of sheep's eyes resulting in partial or temporary blindness. Generally caused by dust with travelling mobs. In general use throughout New Zealand.
Notes: (1941 Baker NZ Slang 40 adds to this `ophthalmia suffered by sheep and shepherd ...')

Quote: pink-eye n. eye-disease of sheep and cattle, caused by dust.
pink-eye n. eye-disease of sheep and cattle, caused by dust.

The name pink-eye is
given to an acute
inflammation of the
eyes of sheep and is
referred to as
contagious opthalmia
or contagious
irido-cyclitis.

For the treatment of
pink-eye old
shepherds use a
barbarous method,
that of putting
powdered glass or
sugar in the eye ...

Antepartum paralysis
or 'sleepy sickness'
was the major
complaint, but
'pink-eye' also
caused several
fatalities.

Another and more
practical use of
chloromycetin is in
the treatment of
pink eye, which is
often seen in sheep
that have travelled
in mobs or are being
held in paddocks
during periods of
danger in facial
eczema.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
Pink Eye (Contagious
Ophthalmia) Pink eye
is a very common
contagious disease
affecting the eyes
of sheep. It is
caused by
micro-organisms
which spread from
sheep to sheep when
they are in close
contact, as during
handling in yards
under hot dusty
conditions.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
The small
blood-vessels of the
eye become congested
and red, giving rise
to the name pink
eye.

with hoggets on a

before when they had

Leptospermum Chapmanii red-flowered manuka

Hypoleucus chalconotus Gray. Bronze Shag; Pink-footed Shag. Guthrie-Smith (1914) records this with the other Stewart Island species, with which he thinks it probably conspecific; at least, he found them almost certainly interbreeding.

In this case the damage is serious; all other stains which have come under Waters' notice merely affect the use of the wool for undyed goods, the tensile strength of the fibres being apparently normal, but in the case of so-called `Pink Rot' the fibres are reduced to their component cells or retted and are quite useless. Ibid. 815 `Pink-Rot of Wool,' N.Z. Jnl. Agric., Vol. xliv, p. 35, 1932.

SQUALUS FERNANDINUS (Molina). Spiny Dogfish; Pioke. Large numbers are smoked and readily sold in the Auckland markets under the name of `silver-spots.' Distribution: New Zealand coasts.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: SQUALUS FERNANDINUS. Pioke. The pioke has been found in the Auckland market continuously throughout the year. It is popularly sold as `silver-strips,' or `silver-spots.' Probably many of the fish are Mustelus antarcticus.
Notes: Phillipps and Hodgkinson Further Notes on Edible Fishes

Kennard went

Long after the time

...a maid, a cook

Instead of

more acute

James Clarke, one of

He has remained at

years, following the

and fishing, so that
he was one of New
Zealand's earliest
pioneers.

Quote: Of stalwart frame, great endurance, and an excellent pedestrian, he was the beau ideal of a pioneer. By the middle of 1847 the staff of surveyors had completed their labours [at Port Chalmers], ... Everything was ready for the advent of the pioneers; ... Ibid. 200 Amongst the older pioneers there was much regret and some demur at the great change [of the 1860s].

Anyone who considers
what Canterbury is
to-day and what she
was fifty years ago
must be filled with
admiration for those
early settlers we
well name
`pioneers'.

At the fringes of
settlement, where
the pioneers are
hewing their homes
out of the

history of
road-making is as
follows: First comes
the bridle-track,
that gradually grows
into the dray-road;
and then comes the
metal, ...

Author: COWAN

Trees were the

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Here on hundreds of
acres of brown
grass, ringed in by
the stately old
English trees
planted by the
pioneers, tents went
up like toadstools.

A pioneer is `one who goes before, as into the wilderness, preparing for others to follow,' and today women are still preparing the way for those who will follow after them. Ibid. 30 There were ... wild pigs in the surrounding bush; fuchsia berries could be gathered for tarts ... For tea, a concoction of bidi-bidi was used, and I have heard it described by one of these early pioneer women as horrible stuff to! Ibid. 299 These are a few examples of the pioneers of the '40s and '50s. Several of them ...have recorded details of their daily lives; the slush lamps, ... the plague of mice and rats that necessitated the erection of futtahs (whatas) ...

Quote:
Mr. Bell's name is

George Wakelin, an

The pioneers who got
everything into

then turned out of
their tents bag and
baggage to find a
new place the best
way they could.

Today, he says, we
wrongly see the
Maori Pioneers as
somehow being
second-class
soldiers... While
there were many
Maori serving in the
ranks of the
Wellington and
Auckland infantry
battalions, the
principal Maori
effort in World War
I was with the

Another welcome
additon was made by
a detachment of 43
Maori Pioneers lent
to assist in the big
job. The pioneers
were great
favourites with
everybody, splendid
toilers, always
willing and
cheerful; they
supplied an
inexhaustible fund
of drollery and
laughter that was
sadly missed when
they were recalled.

Unfortunately,
though we could
fight likethe
Infantry, the
Infantry could not
diglike us. So the
Powers that be made
usPioneers. [Fn. The
Pioneer Battalion
wasformed from the
Otago Mounted Rifles
andthe Maori
Contingent.]

[Hdg] With the Maori
(Pioneer)Battalion.

We remember further
back than that, when
the small community
that then pioneered
the destinies of
this town found
sufficient talent
and leisure to give
capital musical
entertainments.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
A study ... shows
that there was a
marked interest in
these lands by
Australian settlers
who ... settled and
pioneered them ...

He anticipated not only material but intellectual eminence for New Zealand - material, first indeed, for the pioneer settlers in a new country are impelled by necessity to direct primary attention to what is immediately and practically useful; but intellectual also.

It may be said that
we who were early
pioneer settlers had
as great or greater
hardships to
undergo, and this
may be true.

The death is
announced of William
Telford, one of the
pioneer settlers of
Clutha.

With the passing of
Mr John Lindsay, of
"Strathmore," there
is removed from the
Western district of
Southland one of its
typical outstanding
pioneer settlers,
and one of the most
transparently loved
and upright men that
have transplanted
themselves from the
Old World to this
far outpost of
Empire.

She was born at
Gropers Bush in
1863, being a
daughter of the late
Guiseppi Valli, one
of the pioneer
settlers of the
district.

Mr John Hugh Murray,
a pioneer settler in
the Waituna
district, is dead.

The natural pastures
provided the only
grazing available
for the stock of the
pioneer settlers,
and in consequence
early New Zealand
settlement began
mainly in the South
Island.

... by this means
the bush was
thoroughly explored
by Natives and
pioneer settlers ...

Thomas Munro, a
pioneer settler of
Mangaweka, is dead,
aged 65.

A pioneer settler of
this district, Mr.
Samuel Oates, died
at Alfredton
yesterday, aged 78.
It is said of him
that he brought the
first vehicle over
the Rimutaka - viz,
a wheelbarrow, with
6cwt of goods, which
he wheeled from
Wellington, there
being no road for
the greater part of
the journey.

We readily admit the
palm of pioneering
in the colony of New
Zealand to be due to
the settlers in
Wellington, ...

We have tried ... to
depict every phase
of women's part in
pioneering. There
are stories of the
wives of
missionaries, ...
storekeepers, ...
farmers, runholders,
accommodation-house
keepers, and
numerous others.

The expenditure was
incurred in
providing Church and
School for a small
and slowly
increasing number,
who could do nothing
for themselves
whilst engaged in
the rough and
thriftless task of
pioneering for the
whole settlement ...

This was the
pleasantest sight of
all - this young
settler, pioneering
just as faithfully
as father and
grandfather
pioneered.

As one of this
community - alive to
this pioneering - I
tender my mite of
knowledge, in
support of the
appropriate
selection of the
site of Auckland for
the capital of the
colony of New
Zealand.

In support of the
motion the mover
dwelt at some length
on the great
pioneering services
rendered New Zealand
by Wakefield.

The sooner any
person arrives in a
new country after
the first pioneering
difficulties are
over, the better
chance he has of
succeeding.

"Good progress has
been made with the
preparation of a
standard history of
the wars in New
Zealand, embracing
the pioneering
period between 1840
and 1872," states
the annual report of
the Department of
Internal Affairs.

Author: LANGDALE-HUNT
Quote:
Everyone in latter
years seems to want
to equate living
conditions of today
with the pioneering
conditions of the
nineteenth century
and even of the
first half of the
twentieth.
It is interesting to note that the Piopio, or Native Thrush<./i> (Turnagra crassirostris), and the Long-tailed Cuckoo ... are somewhat [similar] in appearance.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
... we never saw or
heard the notes of
either the Piopio,
the Tieke, or the
Hihi, all of which
birds were at one
time more numerous
even than the Huia.
The Zosterops was
everywhere abundant,
also the Grey
Warbler and
Rifleman, and ... we
found the Tomtit
comparatively
plentiful; the
Parakeet chased its
mate through the
tree-tops with sharp
cries of
`twenty-eight'; ...
and among the tangle
of the underwood the
ever-present
Flycatcher displayed
its pretty fan-like
tail.

piopio, a bush-bird (Turnagra tanagara), the North Island thrush and (T. capensis) the South Island form: both extinct soon after 1900. A riverbed bird, the dotterel, and a naroow-leaved plant, dianella, also bear this name, but the thrush is usually associated with the name: in any case the dianella has a name tuurutu.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
In the strictest
sense of the term,
New Zealand is
without

such species as the
Tui, the Korimako,
and the Piopio
possess vocal powers
of a very
respectable kind,
the compass and
variety of their
notes adding greatly
to the charm of the
New-Zealand woods.
Potts (1882: 199) observed that the South Island piopio (Turnagra c. capensis) was "indifferent" as to food, feeding on insects when procurable, or on grasses, seeds, or fruit.

The.. following
native birds should
be saved, if
possible.. Piopio: A
thrush. Has a short
bill, red tail,
yellow breast, and
brown back.
The natural history specimens shown included specimens of the fast disappearing native thrush or piopio (Tanagra hectori).

Author: SARGESON

We'd stand in shop
doorways and Terry'd
pipe off everyone
that went past.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
pipe off: watch
(someone) critically
and perhaps make
comments.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
The hop had started
when we got inside,
so we took a seat
and piped off all
the good-lookers. I
could see Gus's eye
following a tall,
willowy fairy as she
waltzed round ... .

This [purakau at the
base of a kauri] ...
once ignited will
burn for weeks
together,
smouldering
underneath ... and
`piping up' with
every drying breeze.

The lowest bed is
exposed on the bank
of the river at the
Chinese camp. It is
(1) a greyish-white
plastic clay,
locally known as
pipe-clay.

Clay stone areas are
locally known as
pipe clay country
[North Auckland],
and are
characterized by the
stunted vegetation
which they carry ...

Author: WALL & CRANWELL
Quote:
Usually the soil
profile shows
several bands of
colour beginning
with a few inches of
dark grey, peaty
material overlying
the famous white
`pipeclay', so rich
in silica.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
This was a
musterer's
'pipe-owner' which
went straight up the
steepest part of the
hill.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
In those days the
climb to the
junction was a good
pipe-opener,
especially as
everything to
sustain us for three
weeks was on our
backs.

We had our
pipe-opener for the
year's mustering
with the bringing-in
of the ewes for
pre-lamb shearing.
Syngnathus blainvillianus Eydoux and Gervais. The pipe-fish is not uncommon in Otago Harbour.

piper'.

HEMIRAMPHUS INTERMEDIUS Cantor. Garfish, or Piper; Takeke. Occurs in abundance around all the northern coasts. Common, Otago, in spring and early summer. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts. ... SCOMBRESOX FORSTERI Cuvier and Valenciennes. Skipper. A highly esteemed edible fish, known as `deep-sea piper' at Bay of Islands. Secured midwinter. ... Distribution: Examples have been secured as far south as Hokitika.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote: The well-known garfish or piper (Hyporhamphus intermedius) has the lower jaw protruding far beyond the upper, and uses it for grubbing among the seagrass in shallow bays.

The tip of Point
Chevalier was a park
known as `the
Reserve', ringed
with pine trees and
macrocarpa which led
to the Piper Rocks,
where boys and men
... caught sprats
and piper, which
were excellent
eating.

The piper we caught
at Cornwallis
[Manukau] were
superb, but still
not a patch on the
mau-mau we caught
off a single rock
...

Piper schools feed
around us, like
miniature marlins,
the sun glinting off
their blue-green
flanks.

The waste bran..
used to attract
myriads of piper, or
gar fish.

We used to go
fishing at Huia
orCornwallis with a
dinghy and net
andbring home
barrowloads of
piper.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: (Liver fluke of sheep and cattle occurs in parts of New Zealand, but this fluke, Fasciola is an introduced parasite whose intermediate hosts, the freshwater snails Myxas Limnaea, are also introduced. In New Zealand the adult fluke has been reported only in cattle, sheep and goats, in which unpleasant symptoms such as `pipey liver' and `bottle jaw' may occur. Black disease can kill a sheep within a few hours. The fluke concerned occurs in many parts of the world

[Hdg] I knew it
wouldn't be easy
says pipfruit permit
chief.

He has been at the
helm of grower
organisation
Pipfruit New Zealand
for five of the
stormiest years of
the industry's
100-year life.

Went on to Kapoai
... had dinner -
well supplied with
pipis but alas no
tupakihi ... saw
another noteworthy
sight ...[sic] a
young karoro just
out of the nest,
running along in a
curious human way
all by himself.
pipi, cockle in general among the Maori: but by Pakeha more applied to Mesodesma australe. Pipi-komore and pipi-taiari was applied to Dentalium, the tusk-shell.

women gather cockles

Author: LEE & KENDALL

The rivers are well
stocked with fine
fish ... - the very
creeks swarm with
them. There are
abundance of
lobsters, crawfish,
oysters, prawns, and
shrimps; besides
clams, peppies,

Author: MARKHAM
Quote:
I have many times
made a grand Meal in
a Kanga Mouri or
Native Village on
Pippies [pipi],
sitting round the
Coppre Mouries, each
helping themselves
till all was done,
then I would give
the Natives, a dram
of Rum to wash it
down. .... Now Why
heckie was the name
of a bed of Pippies
or Cockles, in the
River.

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
... pippies, or
native cockles.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: ... pippy ...

Author: ANGAS
Quote: ...as the tide was out, the [Maori] women were busily employed in gathering pipis , a species of cockle, from the uncovered flats. The pinna mussel (pinna Zealandica) was found in considerable abundance, sticking in the mud at the mouth of a small river that discharged itself into the [Wellington] harbour. Ibid. 1/296 ... the whitened heaps of pepi shells that lie scattered in immense quantities about these slopes, that once formed the sites of their fortified pahs.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
The `pipi', a shell
fish, which is to be
found on the beach,
appears to be its
favourite food.

Author: MUNDY
Quote:
The white shells of
the `pipi' or cockle

Quote: The common name for all fish is ika, or ngohengohe; of all univalve shells, pupu; and of bivalves, pipi and anga, which includes both kinds.

Quote:
(no date) [pepi] ...
one of them scooped
out his eyes with a

shell and eat [sic]
them ...

The women boiled our
kettle, and when
food was ready they
set before us some
boiled flour,
potatoes and `pipis'
(cockles).

Quote: With most deliciously cooked kumeras, potatoes and peppies. Ibid. 321 [We dug] peppies out of the beach at low water.

Quote: Pipi (pip-pee): A kind of cockle.
CLAMS (OR PIPIS) ... Fry bacon and ... onion, add chopped potato and ... tomato ... Simmer ... add clams, and cook ... Thicken the gravy ...

pipi: shellfish.

The Maori name of a
common edible
shellfish which
supplied the

pippy n. small shellfish; marine worm; in New Zealand pipi [Maori].

Author: WILSON
Quote:
PIPI Once the staple
diet of
coastal-dwelling
Maori tribes the
name pipi covers a
variety of small
shellfish which
include tuatuas and
cockles.

The pipi were
delicious and salty,
raw or cooked. The
kuia had their backs
to us, selling the
rewena bread and
pottles of
pipi...and they
didn't see how much
we ate.

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
A large species of
cockle called by the
natives "pippi" are
very abundant on the
coast.

One youthful urchin
afterwards declared
that for two days
they had been
"living on pipis."

It appeared that the
Natives in crossing
the plain to
Papakura, had taken
a short cut across a
creek, where one of
them had stopped to
search in the mud
for pipi, a species
of mussel.

Quote: PIPI CHOWDER ... Shell-fish ... Potatoes ... Bacon ... Milk and Water ... Onion ... Pepper and Salt ... Cook slowly ...

Quote: Pipi Paphies australis The name pipi is sometimes applied to a number of New Zealand's common bivalves which are collected for food, but it properly refers to this species, a close relative of the tuatua and toheroa ...

Bad news for those
of us of simple
pleasures. Two Gold
Coast residents have
written to me
complaining about
this new scheme of
dredging for pipis
in-shore along the
Paraparamu beaches.

We looked in vain to see what is said to be seen on the hard sand between Opotiki and Wakatane [sic] - a green and white penguin, the Korora, (Spheniscus minor) taking a pipi shell to a great height, from whence it lets it fall on the beach, and then descends itself to pick out the flesh from the broken fragments of the shell.

[Photo caption] The
above is a photo of
the representation
of a fish in what
appears to be mother
of pearl within a
pipi shell.

Their true history,
so far as it can be
ascertained; their
mythical history,
which is abundant if
collected, as to
some extent it has
been in the records
of the Native Lands
Court .. the records
of their existence
and works exhibited
in the enormous pipi
beds, and in their
hangis, all over the
country .. all these
would tend to throw
light on the history
of the race.

Indeed, pipis
abounded in many
places along the
main beach, while
other shellfish made
their homes on the
rocks, and even when
the winning of land
from the sea had
removed some of the
sources of supply
there were - right
up to less than two
decades ago - well
stocked pipi beds at
Pipitea and Evans
Bay, and in Oriental
Bay, where Maoris
used to improve the
shining hour by
obtaining supplies,
not only for their
own use but for
European tables - it
was a common sight
to see Maori women
carrying flax kits
of pipis from house
to house for sale.

The designs are
produced by cutting
the face with a
sharp "pipi" shell
in the required
patterns, and the
soot of ferns is
rubbed into the
cuts.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Pipis, on his
death-bed, he
desired, pipis (a
small shellfish
similar to the
English cockle) he
must have: ...

Quote: PIPI Shellfish, cockle group. Chione Stutchburyi, Mesodesma australe, etc.

Quote: pepi shells.

Quote:
`There, she is a
wife for you,' he

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: The common Acaena was called by the Maoris Piri-piri, but colonists frequently [usually] corrupt the Maori name, and call the plant Bidi-bidi. As a general rule, the Maori names are more incorrectly pronounced as we go southward from Auckland to Otago. This is largely due to the fact that, in the north, Europeans have been brought into closer contact with the Maoris than in the south. In some few cases, the difference in pronunciation may be due to differences in the Maori dialects. The changes that take place often follow phonetic laws - thus the Maori `p' is softened into the European `b' as above, while `r' is replaced by `l' or `d'. Poro-poro (Solanum aviculare) becomes Bulli-bulli, and Puriri becomes Boradi. This also explains such a form as `Kowdie' pine for Kauri pine. Korari - a flax-stalk - similarly becomes Koradi or even Kaladi [1907 edn ?mistakenly, Kalladi]. `K' is also sometimes altered into `g,' this Kie-kie (Freycinetia Banksii) becomes ghi-ghi. The last vowel in a reduplicated syllable was faintly pronounced in Maori, and often disappears altogether in the European form of the word, e.g., Poro-poro gives Bulli-bull, and Piri-piri gives Bidi-bid.

A saxifragaceous tree of New Zealand (Carodetus serratus); - called also white mapau, white maple, and birch. In the house, big

tete-a-weka wood

oven swinging above

sizzling in their

fat, the fine fat
from the intestines,
is more precious.

Their favourite

was a compound of
whale oil and
turpentine, and was
applied
promiscuously
anywhere.

Disobedient
teenagers, the
