Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. Then
there were the terms
referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for
example, agates,
aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cat's eyes,
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, molly-bars,
mulley-bars
[mullibars: large
marbles], peelies,
peewees, piss-wees,
pretties, Scotties,
Scottish alleys,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more
recent years
ball-bearings,
chippies, plastics,
and woodies.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: BINNEY
Quote:
`Your mate's as
pissed as a chook
and you don't look
too steady on your
pins.'

Author: NEALE
Quote:
I was always waiting
for her to bring it
up first, for her to
crack some smarmy
comment about Marion
being smashed,
half-cut,
pissed-as-a-fart,
arse-faced as usual.

... caught up in an
inane conversation
about some barmaid
with big tits. Mason
kept saying she was
in Palmerston and
Boswell kept saying
[132] there were no
pissers in
Palmerston.

Author: McGILL

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
PISSPOT PARADE.
Morning ritual in
most New Zealand

SLOPPING OUT.

[He] says his meal
will not only help

but may also help

Author: McGILL
Quote: pissy-eyed drunk, but probably mildly so; eg `Bert had only two Steiniesand already he felt pissy-eyed. Probably still had a skinful from the night before.'

Emma and her family
will have been
cleaned out of
coconut bread, of
pisu (tapioca with

pineapple pies.

The Samoans call
tinned corn beef
pisupo. You can buy

supermarkets. As a
celebration of the
Anzac spirit and our
Pacific Island
spirit, why not try

Author: McGEE
Quote:
By the time they get
into the pit they're
too shikkered and
tired and knocked up
to even think about
giving someone else
a bit of pleasure.

WHILE YOU are
lurking slothfully
in your pit - bed
for those not
familiar with the
language of the
hills- ...

Author: PICKERING
Quote:
So to cope with the
rituals of tramping,
its pains and
camaraderie, a slang
language has
developed to suit.
Lots of quick short
words to fit in the
breathless pauses as
you pant uphill.
`Crud' (cloud),
`bush-bash', a
`gunn' tramper
(which must have
originated from Davy
Gunn's famous trek
up the Hollyford
Valley to help
victims of a plane
crash in 1936; he
travelled 40 km by
rowing boat, horse
and foot in 21
hours), `windfall'
(a collapsed pile of
trees), `pit' (the
tramper's true
friend, a sleeping
bag), `pog'
(porridge), `bastard
grass' and `lawyer'
(two unpleasant
plants), `piker'
(one who stayed
home), `Huey'
(all-powerful god of
weather), and many,
many more.

He went and hid in
the pit when he
found the parade was
held over ten weeks
ago.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
And they'd go down
the mine, ... scrape
the coal down and
load it into the
skips by hand with
great big `banjo'
shovels. Then there
were the old
`pit-spiders', steel
hooks you'd jab into
the mine wall and
hang your lamp on.

The latter [the
Morioris] were pit
dwellers, and their
pits are still to be
seen in various
places in
Marlborough.

Mr. Rutland appeared
convinced there were
two distinctly
marked periods in
the history of New
Zealand - viz., that
of the pit-dwellers
and of the modern
Maoris. The evidence
for the pit-dwellers
had been mainly
collected by Mr.
Rutland himself, and
the general consent
of Maori scholars to
the theory had not
yet been expressed.

I think they are
merely a slight
infusion of the
aboriginal race, a
small, dark race
that occupied the
Marlborough Sounds,
and dwelt in those
pit dwellings
described in my
"Maori and
Polynesian.'

We have positive evidence of two very distinct periods in the history of New Zealand - the period of the pit-dwellers, and the modern Maori period, which virtually closed when Cook rediscovered the group. That the greenstone ... was known to the ancient ... inhabitants is proved beyond question by the numerous articles found in the Pelorus district, contiguous to pit-dwellings, and beneath the roots of large forest trees. Ibid. 325 The abandoned pit-dwellings of the ancient Moriori inhabitants ... prove beyond question that much of the bush on the [326] shores of the Pelorus Sound was a regrowth.

Author: ELLIOT
Quote:
The pit-fly is
erected over the pit
so that work can
still proceed in wet
weather.

Author: MARSDEN
Quote: A List of Articles Wanted for the Use of the Active and the Settlement in New Zealand, 1815 [heading] ... [138] ... twenty dozen tommy hawkes, twenty dozen of sickles, eight pit and four crosscut saws (two pit saws as long as can be procured), ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: The Colonist's attention should be directed to the following articles, with which he must provide himself according to his means and his intentions. For clearing and cultivating timbered land:- ... pit-saws. ...

But the four honeyed
kauri pillars,
pitsawn on the
island and sent to
England for turning,
still stand, as they
did when Grey was
forced to prop the
sagging ceiling 120
years ago.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
All three.. built a
scrimlined
four-roomed house,
the outside sheathed
in flat galvanised
iron over walls of
cedar they'd pitsawn
themselves.

Source: Brief History of Gold Mining, A
Author: EASTWOOD
Quote:
The only means of
getting sawn timber
was to cut it
yourself, by what
was called pit
sawing. Dad used to
make a pit about 20
ft long, and 6 ft
deep, place logs
around it, roll the
logs he wanted sawn
into position in the
middle... Dad's mate
used to go into the
pit and dad, who was
the taller, stood on
top of the log. Dad
had to drive the saw
downwards, and his
mate pulled it, and
up and down they
sawed, squared the
log, cut boards and
four by two and so
on until they had
sufficient timber
for rafters,
uprights and floor
joists.

The first such
memory is from an
1860 pit sawing site
in Stewart Island.

The original lodge..
was built around
1895 from pit-sawn
timber milled close
by.

First a punga whare
would be erected, to
be replaced later by
a two-roomed house..
from pit-sawn
timber.

The church was built
of the robust heart
totara which was
donated by settler
John Ings Daysh and
pit-sawn by Abraham
Harris.

Below decks you can
still see the
pit-sawn timbers
from the one large
kauri used in her
construction.

Author: REED
Quote: ... the predecessors of numerous pakeha-built vessels of Kauri, constructed first of pit-sawn and later of mill-sawn planks. Ibid. 190 ... wood, split and pit-sawn in the bush ... [B]ut the rails ... had to be pit-sawn.

Author: SINCLAIR & HARREX
Quote:
First there was,
especially in the
north, the raupo
whare, shortly to be
followed by a simple
cottage, made of
pit-sawn timber.

The pit-sawn whare
we called
"OurSchool".

Author: HUNT
Quote:
They built a pitsawn
house... All those
sleepers were
pitsawn.

Author: LE PROU
Quote:
A pit-sawyer was a
most skilled
craftsman of his
time.

He waited on some
pitsawyers hard by.

Author: BULLER
Quote: RHIPIDURA FLABILLIFERA. (PIED -FANTAIL.) ... Native names. Piwaiwaka, Tiwai-waka, Piwakawaka, Tirairaka, Pirairaka and Tiwakawaka and Pitakataka.

Many families are
practically
starving, and
reduced to living on
the pitau (a fern),
and such other food
as they could obtain
out of the bush.

...detailed
observations of bush
are used as
frieze-like
ornaments around a

(referred to by the

mandala), in which
the distinctive
flora of the region
such as the scrolled
fronds of pitau or
the tiny
umbrella-like kidney
ferns are shown.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
... at the bottom of

nikau], a fruit or

This substance is
called by the

[pitau]). The middle

from its resemblance
to the flax, eaten
by the natives, ...

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
[We] received
several presents of
Pitau the inside of

which forms a
wholesome and
palatable food ...

At Korinito a bowl

It is a very
palatable dish and
soon disappeared.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pitau, Lindsay. Cyathea medullaris.

Author: TREGEAR

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pitau, n. Maori name for the Tree-fern. In Maori, the word means - (I) Soft, tender, young shoots. The verb pihi means `begin to grow'; pimeans `young of birds,' also `the flow of the tide.' (2) Centre-fronds of a fern. (3) Name of a large fern.
pitau ... n. N.Z. tree fern [Maori].

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote: Alternatively, it [tutu juice] was boiled with the pith of the pitau fern or pieces of bull kelp seaweed (rimurapu).

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
The pith of the
boiled mamaku
(pitau) is, when
dried in the sun, an
excellent substitute
for sago.

We have four species of Cyathea in our forests, namely, C. medullaris or pithy; C.dealbata or whitened; C. cunninghamii or Cunningham's; and C. smithii or Smith's. The native names for this genus are Mamaku, Pitau, Korau, and Ponga.

Some examples [of
adaptive cultivars]
are matua prairie
grass .. pitau and
tahora white clover,
oranga lucerne ...

Pitau is a more
erect and open
growing plant than
Huia. The production
advantages of Pitau
appear later in
Summer and continues
through the Winter.

The aim of including
matua with nui,
pawera and pitau in
a 4-species mix is
to grow more grass
in autumn-winter ...

Pitau is a more
erect and open
growing plant than
Huia (longer stem
with fewer stolons)
with markedly larger
leaves in winter.

Source: Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants
Quote:
Pitau - medium to
large-leaved with
winter growth in
warmer climates.

PITCH.- A portion of
a vein prepared and
set apart for
working.

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote:
In consequence of

mountainous the

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
Now and then he was
visited by stray
diggers, who dropped

Author: MURRY
Quote:
Capt. Cook has given
so good a
description of the
Spruce Fire, that it
is impossible to
mistake it. But he
has not taken any
notice of the Pitch
Pine - Birch - And
large Myrtle. The
Pitch Pine is
remarkable for its
black bark, which
when cut and rubbed
with the finger
smells agreeably. It
generally grows from
20 to 40 feet
without branches,
and the wood is much
like Norway Pitch
Pine, but whiter.
Notes: 1796 Jan Murry's Journal of the `Britannia' in 1908 McNab Hist. Recs 2/534

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote: Phyllocladus trichomanoides pitch pine

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote: Phyllocladus trichomanoides New Zealand pitch pine
Phyocladus alpinus pitch pine (probably because the bark contains a large amount of tannin, which will stain the wood; and named after European species)

These and many other
shrubs or trees,
such as the pitch
pine and [84]
totara, furnish some
of the means of life
to [the kea.]

Quote: [The kea] feeds on ... the black berries of Aristotelia fruticosa (the `native currant'), as well as the fruit of the pitch-pine and the totara.

was given to that
tract of land lying
to the N.W. of

patches of clay and
pitch pine scrub.
pitch tree n [1 pitch] : any of several resinous conifers: as a : KAURI PINE

Author: McARA
Quote: Pitcher-drill: A short drill-steel of large diameter used to `pitch' or start a drill-hole. When using the drifter, the pitcher-drill had to be firmly held in position by the man at the nose of the machine until it had bitten far enough into the rock to remain there. Once the hole was pitched the drill was re-aligned on the hole and drilling continued.

Author: BENTLEY & FRASER
Quote:
It's Fair Day at
Mangatainoka,/
What's the guts for
your average joker?/
Pitching possums is
big,/ There's calf
roping, greased
pig,/ And a yahoo,

pittosporum n. member of large genus of NZ and Australian evergreen shrubs with white or yellowish flowers and having seeds embedded in a viscous substance. [Gk pitta pitch, sporos seed]

Pit́.toś.po-rum (p&ibreve.t-t&obreve.ś.po.-r&ubreve.m), n. [NL., fr. Gr. {pitta} pitch + {sporos} seed.] (Bot.) A genus of trees and shrubs, the type of the order Pittosporeae. The seeds, imbedded in a black gluten (whence the name) are contained in berries, which grow in clusters and are indehiscent. Of 55 species 9 are found in Australia and 6 in New Zealand. The scientific term is used as the vernacular name; but various species are also known by other names. Thus Pittosporum undulatum is called native laurel or mock orange; P. tenuifolium, black mapou; P. eugenoides, tarata or white mapou; P. phillyraeoides, poison berry tree, butter bush, willow, and native willow. See under LAUREL, MAPOU, POISON, and TARATA.

pi[i]wakawaka, a bird (Rhipidura flabellifera), pied fantail: the so-called black fantail, which is chocolate-colour (R. fuliginosa) is ti[i]wakawaka. The former is common throughout Newzealand; the latter is common in the South Island but rather rare in the North and is thought to be a mutant of the former. Both names were applied to both birds by the Maori, but for distinction pi[i]wakawaka for the pied and ti[i]wakawaka for the black have been adopted by the Pakeha. The bird is noted for the disaster it caused to Maui in his struggle with the mother of night, Hine-nui-te-po, Death personified.

Quote:
No wether should be
crutched without
being pizzle-ringed.
pizzleguard: An imaginary piece of equipment called for when shearing rams or wethers. Good for a joke with a green shedhand.

To cut a long story
short, Jeannie had
left her PJs to soak
with a pair of
stocking and the dye
had run.

I remember watching
Diana get married -
everyone crowded
into the TV room, in
their nighties and
pjs, glued to the
TV.

Author: GRIFFITHS
Quote:
Also besides
`Jarmies' childish
for `pajamas'
[Macquarie] could
have two common NZ
expressions `PJ's'
and `pyjams'.

... he rushed
outside in pjs and
lucky no page 3
blonde was there to
see him haka???.
Notes: 1986 Macrae (The Kingsland Kid) in New Outlook 21/50

Quote:
J.A.McColl got his
early training on
the run, and became
one of the best
horsemen on a place
noted for high-class
cross-country horses
and good hacks.

The wind was so
strong it blew
everything off the
place except the
mortgage; best cow
on the place, the
place was in need of
a good manager, he
knew every inch of
the place.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Rock, log,
nettle-clump, bush,
or tree-stump may,
as chance
determines, become
the foster-parent of
the 'placer'...

Placer - when a ewe
dies, her lamb
usually stays by her
body .. he sometimes
transfers his filial
affection to some
object close to
where his mother
died, perhaps a bush
or large stone.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
Lambs which lose
their mothers when
they are young
sometimes form an
attachment for an
inanimate object
like a bush or rock
and become what are
known as 'hermits',
sometimes known as
'placer sheep.'

Author: MCGILL
Quote:
placer: a lamb whose
mother has died and
who has adopted a
stone, bush or other
object as a mother
substitute.
Australians also use
the word for a lamb
or sheep that stays
in one place.

First, quartz reefs
and mineral lodes.
Second,
placer-mining, as in
California, and
surface workings, as
in many parts of
Victoria and New
South Wales.

As far as Nelson is
concerned, ... it
appears that the
metal is found ...
in placer or
detrital formations.

It must be
remembered that gold
is now chiefly
obtained by
quartz-mining. The
placer-claim is no
longer the chief
source of the
gold-supply, and
consequently the
supply is no longer
subject to the
vicissitudes
invariably connected
with alluvial-gold
mining.

[T]he alluvial miner
.. is one who works
the deeper deposits,
or deep placer
mines, as they have
been denominated.

A convenient
distinction is drawn
between the alluvial
digger and the
alluvial miner, the
former term being
applied to the man
who extracts gold
from the surface and
from the more recent
deposits only; the
latter to the worker
of deep placers.

The prospectors
state that the
placer field
embraces a tract of
gravel about 225,000
acres in extent.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Here are some
[marble] terms from
Taranaki around
1880-1890: firsts,
lay-up, stakes,
tips, sticking-taw,
nothings, anythings,
fade-it, knuckledown
stiff, dubs, finking
[sic, ?funking],
sips, spanning,
placing; and from
Dunedin School in
1949: knee high,
manyies, tracks,
screws, nuts,
sleets, kills,
forces, dig, dubs,
cheats.

(Reprinted from the Southern News) [The fish of Stewart's Island] comprise black cod, grouper, rock cod, trumpeter, barracouta, perch, hug, congie [sic] eel, whiting, white fish, bastard trumpeter, skate, and plaice.

Source: Voyage of Discovery to North Pacific Ocean
Author: ROSS
Quote:
... the soles,
though small, are
very good, and the
plaice of large size
are equal in flavour
to the Dutch fish :
the Barracouta is
caught in proper
season, ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: Fish of all sorts and sizes abound on every part of the sea-coast. The only sorts similar to ours are the Conger-eel, Sole, Plaice, and Flounder

[Flatfish submitted
for opinion
included] (1.) The
flounder, or patiki,
wrongly named
`plaice,' about
one-tenth adult
size. (2) The turbot
sole, wrongly [559]
named `brill,' about
one-fortieth its
adult size: ... (3.)
The lemon sole,
wrongly named
`flounder,' ... (4.)
The New Zealand sole
...

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: NEW ZEALAND SAND-FLOUNDER (PATIKI) Rhombosolea plebeia (Richardson)... In and around Nelson the Sand-flounder is known as Plaice. It is not unlike this fish in shape, but the English Plaice is of a deep brown colour with orange-red spots on the upper surface.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii) Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
plaice 2284, 2301,
2306

The patiki, an
excellent fish,
which is something
like a plaice, comes
in about the middle
of October. These
are taken with
spears in great
numbers on the sand
banks.

The part of New
Zealand to which I
belong is the
Province of
Canterbury; the
harbour is six or
seven miles long. In
the neighbouring
rivers and rocks are
plaice and cod, very
similar to ours.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
plaice, diamond 2289

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Diamond Plaice Rhombosolea (Adamasoma) retiaria adamas Whitley and Phillipps
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 405

Quote: [heading of political commentary] Plain as a pikelet It's candidate selection time again, and all over the country aspiring MPs are jockeying for position in a sort of political beauty contest.

The lower hills,
downs, and better
kinds of plain
country have been
widely cultivated,
...

In my teens when I
began reading
cookbooks, I was hit
with the realisation
that what we had
thought was plain
ice cream was
actually vanilla.
Vanilla wasn't
plain, it was a
flavour.

A Christchurch paper
remarks: "As a plain
matter of
demonstrable fact,
there is more
potential wealth
buried away in the
great stretch of
country between
Auckland and
Doubtless Bay than
there is in any
similar stretch of
country in any other
part of the
Dominion, not
excepting the
fruitful plains of
Canterbury and
Otago."

One of the most
favourable
localities .... was
not far from the
gorge of one our
Southern rivers,
where the monotonous
flatness of `the
plains' gives way to
a more broken and
undulating surface.

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
Although the
Pilgrims could cross
the hills to the
Plain over the
Bridle Path - and
could carry their
lighter belongings;
all heavy luggage
had to go to
Christchurch by sea
and then up the Avon
River.

Author: HART
Quote:
(The Shagroon's
Lament) All huddled
in vain are the
sheep of the Plain,/

Ashburton. There was
a sharp thunderstorm
on the plains
yesterday, and a
horse was struck
dead by lightning at
Valetta.

[I]t appears that
beyond the mountains
in which the Hutt
has its source,
there is an
extensive champaign
[sic] country which
stretches away to
the east coast ..
Nearly the whole of
this plain belongs
to the New Zealand
Land Company.

In ascending Mount
Egmont I walked
during ten days
through an almost
level country,
before I came to the
foot of the
mountain, which is a
cone rising from the
plain.

The Ngatiruanui
portion of the
released prisoners
returned to the
plains yesterday. On
their way they are
reported to have
destroyed part of a
ditch and bank fence
which intersected
one of their old
dray tracks on the
Plains.

His ram was 18
months, bred by
Hardie, of Napier,
was a
magnificently-woolled
sheep, plain-headed
and plain-bodied,
and the judges could
not overlook its
wool and condition,
although Bell and
Son's entry was
better figured.

Author: BOWEN
Quote: However, with the modern trend of breeding, tending to eliminate excessive skin folds and wrinkles, there are many nice-cutting reasonably plain-bodied Merinos that shear well. Ibid. 132 The average Corriedale is ... plain-bodied apart from an odd neck wrinkle or dew-lap, ...

The largest class in
the show was
composed of merinos
of Vermont blood -
that is, for
unwrinkled sheep, or
plain-bodied, the
condition being that
there should be no
wrinkles behind the
elbow.

His choice, however,
was considerably
limited by the fact
that the Tasmanian
merinos are now
mostly bred with
heavy folds or
wrinkles on thin
skins, whereas Mr.
Hugonin required
plain-bodied sheep.

The halfbreds which
command the highest
prices year after
year .. are bred
from merino ewes of
what is popularly
known as the
"Murray" type -
plain-bodied sheep
...

Author: NEWTON
Quote: Plain-eyed:Most of our heading dogs show what is known as `eye', i.e. when working a few sheep they `set' them much as does a setter or pointing dog setting game. Those that do not have this trait are called plain-eyed.

Author: LETHBRIDGE
Quote:
Glen was a
plain-eyed heading
dog. That is, he did
not try to mesmerise
the sheep by staring
them in the eyes
till their wills
broke and they would
turn and run.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: He was plain-eyed and barked when pulling, but was an outstanding hill dog. ... He used to `clap' and would lie there barking. Ibid. 168 (Glossary) A very strong-eyed dog ... works sheep in a manner similar to a cat stalking a bird. A plain-eyed dog is one which does not have this characteristic.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
My dog, Boss, was
also a plain-eyed
dog and he too was
one of those born
hill dogs.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Jack McIver had his
Bruce, a big heavy
plain-eyed dog that
he's picked up down
on the mudflats.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
Bob had a very fine,
smooth-haired,
black, tan and white
plain-eyed heading
dog called Spike.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
Lady was a safe
header but, like
most plain-eyed
dogs, a poor puller.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
Many of these
so-called colonial
dogs were what's
known as plain-eyed
and could be best
described as
gathering or
stopping dogs ...

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
At Molesworth in
those days most of
our heading dogs
were the
`plain-working'
kind. They did not
`eye' the sheep or
exercise any
mesmerism, as is
done by the
present-day trial
dog.

Author: McLEOD
Quote: Plain Working Dog: Heading dog with no `eye'.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Quote: ... its large size, more pointed wings, and dark colour distinguished it at once from the New Zealand Harrier (Circus Gouldii), so common on our plains, but which I never observed in the alpine regions.

61. Charadrius obscurus, Gml. Dusky, Red-breasted, or Mountain Plover, Big Dottrel [si], Tuturiwatu, Paturiwhata, Tituriwhatu-pukunui. - This excellent gamebird formerly bred on the Canterbury Plains ...; since farms and settlements have occupied the waste lands of the plains, for the most part it has retired to the mountains of the back country.
67. Haematopus unicolor, Forst. Black Oyster-catcher, Black Red-bill, Torea. - Breeds out on `the plains' in riverbeds ...

The merino occupies
and thrives on the
wild lands of the
colony, from the
snow-line to the
border of the
plains, ...

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
Some of them
remained in the
emigrant barracks at
Port Cooper for a
few days; but almost
immediately the
greater number
started to walk over
a recently made
Bridle Path to the
plains beyond.

Author: LOVELL-SMITH
Quote:
`When daylight broke
I found we were on
the descent from the
mountain country to
the plains. We were
passing through a
fine pastoral
country, with grassy
valleys and hills
decreasing in
height.'

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Wallie was rather
lethargic socially,
but did enjoy the
jaunts around the
agricultural areas,
situated near the
environs of the city
of `The Plains'.

People were
cooheeing all over
the plains last
night, they lost
their ways.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
Anyone acquainted
with our `plains'
must have observed
... how certain
parts (termed by the
geologists `fans')
are thickly covered
with stones, as ...
some miles below the
gorges of the Rakaia
and Rangitata.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
The sharp prickles
of the small shrub
`Tumatakuru' ...
which is very common
on the plains ...

I walked with Cass
over the plains
fixing on
trigonometrical
stations, at
Courtenay, ... &c.

Author: FITTON
Quote:
The plains are
certainly, at first
sight, monotonous,
but they improve as
you know them.

[Advt] GENTLEMEN and
FAMILIES visiting
the Plains will find
every accommodation
at the above
Establishment.

Author: FITTON
Quote:
The Plains -
extending from the
river Waipara to
Timaru ..

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
The greatest
drawback of the
[Canterbury] Plains
is the want of
shelter in the
strong gales,
`Southerly
Bursters', which
occasionally occur.

... the folks on the
plains/ Turned ...
uncommonly brown,/
In all the
Nor'-westers and
easterly rains,/

Cook sums up his
account by saying
that the hills and
mountains are
covered with wood,
and every valley has
a rivulet of water;
the soil in these
valleys, and in the
plains, of which
there are many that
are not overgrown
with wood, is in
general light but
fertile; and, in the
opinion of Mr Banks
and Dr Solander, as
well as of every
other gentleman on
board, every kind of
European grain,
plant, and fruit,
would flourish here
in the utmost
luxuriance.

Attention is being
paid to the vast
area of Dr. Peak's
lands which are to
be known as the
Hauraki Plains.

A fire at Hauraki
Plains did
considerable damage
to some unoccupied
sections.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
... we bid farewell
to the Mania or
plains and entered
the wood about 6 ...
[97] these plains
[about Taupo] or
Mania agree with the
prairie and pampas
of America Mar 18 We
passed through
several small Manias
today ...

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Travellers talk of
the solitude of the
forests, but there
is society in trees
which men miss on
immense plains; it
is on the prairie
alone that the
solitary traveller
has a sensation of
loneliness ... On
the coast plains in
the North Island
ferns and flax
plants supply the
place of grasses.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
Never was he happier
than ... when, as at
mustering [57]
seasons, madly
galloping over the
plains, he chased
the wild cattle,
waking the echoes
with the crack of
the long stockman's
whip, which none
could more
dexterously [sic]
flourish than he.

Author: WISNIOWSKI
Quote:
We frequently
emerged into open
spaces, almost
completely bare of
trees, known locally
as `plains',
altogether unlike
our European
meadows.

Author: HAY
Quote:
The river [Thames]
winds through what
are called plains
here, but the term
is only relatively
applied. The
`plains' are broken
with spurs and
undulations from the
higher ranges that
bound them, and the
country is anything
but one uniform
level.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
There were
innumerable lagoons
on the plains in
those days [c1860s]
- mostly storm
water, and not deep.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
It was some time
before the terrified
women could be
induced to get into
the coach again; and
it was only by Jim's
asseverations ...
that if they were
not `all aboard' in
half a minute, he
would drive on and
leave them in the
middle of the
plains, that they
were persuaded to
clamber in ...

[One] was not far from the gorge of one of our great southern rivers, where the monotonous flatness of `the plains' gives way to a more broken ... surface ... Ibid. 49 Thousands of sheep now depasture on that well-remembered corner of `the plains,' on those gently-swelling downs; ... we have the bleating of flocks, the bark of the colley[sic] as it rounds up its charge, the loud crack of the stockwhip, the hearty curse of the bullock driver delivered `ore rotundo'; ...

For fences were not,
...and kennelled
boundary-dogs strung
off the invisible
line that severed
the runs throughout
the plains.
Notes: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 105

Author: ACLAND
Quote:
On some of the
plains stations
'crow's nests' were
built - platforms on
poles or up cabbage
trees.

Author: McLEOD
Quote:
`As soon as I put
the yellow dog after
him he took off.
Gawd, didn't he
plait! The yellow
dog never blew wind
in his arse!'.

Author: DONALDSON
Quote:
Through the day we
will rough it, at
night we will plank
it. We know feather
beds are scarce
things in the bush.

Author: LOVELL-SMITH
Quote:
The formation of the
road surface, at
this place,
consisted of tree
trunks fastened
together and laid
across the road
going over the
swamp. It was known
as a `plank' or
`corduroy' road. ...
The other passengers
were shaken off
while going over the
`corduroy' section
of the road

Author: GODLEY
Quote:
You would laugh if
you saw the place
from which I am
writing. It is a
little `plank tent'
or `V. hut', as a
thing made of long
boards leaning
against each other
is indiscriminately
called; its locality
is the side of a
small wood, by which
runs a clear stream,
on the plain, about
ten miles from
Lyttelton.
Notes: 1851 Feb 27 Godley letter in 1950 Carrington Godley 125

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
The Second World
War, as in many
other countries,
encouraged what was
already the chief
tendency of the
Labour Government,
and speeded the
progress towards a
`planned economy'
via `price control'
and `stabilization'.

Something called the
Planning Council -
yes, Virginia, they
had planning then -
called for an end to
import licensing,
then hastily had to
retract this radical
view, lest it offend
the government.

Resource and
environment law has
contributed a
substantial number
of terms to NZE.
.Some of these have
not found their way
into dictionaries,
for instance
Planning Tribunal,
now the Environment
Court.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
.. and the pine
plantations, to be
known as the
`plannies";...

A young man .. has
confessed to
stealing from the
sluice-boxes about
50oz of gold, which
had been planted.

GBP200 worth of
jewellery, stolen
from the Wellington,
has been found
planted in Freeman's
Bay.

The new-born lamb
will follow its
mother, and does not
plant. ... Even when
well grown and
following in the
flock the kid is
liable to `plant' or
bolt away for hiding
when the flock is
mustered.

If compelled to give
up the guns I shall
`plant' the locks.

I had always carried
the gold about with
me; but on the day I
left it planted in
my stretcher.
Notes: 1864 Apr 2 All the Year Round in 1974 Heinz Bright Fine Gold 18

Author: MONEY
Quote:
Here we began to
look out for signs
of stores ... that
we should find
`planted' in the
bush out of reach of
rats. [113] It
appeared that a
party had been sent
up with the stores
to plant them in the
bush, and to blaze a
track some distance
up ...

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Some may wonder we
did not dig a hole
and bury all our
gear in preference
to `planting' them
forty feet from the
earth in the fork of
a big tree.

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
It was ... [167] on
a regatta day that I
became acquainted
with a singular
colonial institution
known by the name of
`planting.' ...
There were plants
(of the class
alcoholic) in all
direction that day,
from the humble beer
to the haughty three
star branding plant.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: common in Australia for to hide, and for the thing hidden away. As remarked in the quotations, the word is thieves' English. [1827]

The main crime [of
the University
students] was
entering the girls'
quarters with no
other ulterior
motive than to
`plant' their
academic gowns.

They either mix the
stolen [sheep] with
their own flock, or
travel at night, or
`plant' them.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
I carried it home
and tied it in the
cow-yard, in the
hope that if I
planted [Hawera Star
edition: `planked':
possibly the other
meaning of `plant
oneself down' (to
settle firmly) is
meant] myself out of
sight the heifer
would eventually
pluck up enough
resolution to pay it
a visit.
Plant.-To hide (trans. and intrans.)

Waters and Elliot,
notorious in
connection with the
still planting case,
have been convicted
and sentenced.

Author: VOGEL
Quote:
Here [on the marae]
the dogs fight and
the Maori youth
plays `plant about'
with an old
football.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
plant, to: a cow or
hind hides while she
is grazing.

Made a plant of some
60 yds. of rope near
22 trig pole.

Well, now, I guess
the plant ain't
sprung; though for
the matter of that
I'd ante up every
ounce of gold to
have saved poor
Harry, I would, Sir.

Author: REID
Quote:
The inscription had
no relation to the
`plant' near the
beach.

Author: BARLOW
Quote:
It was on our first
regatta day I became
acquainted with a
singular colonial
institution known by
the name of
`planting' .... A
gentleman ...
whispered ... that
he had a plant near
... He conmenced
groping about in the
undergrowth and
produced a bottle
containing ...
brandy and water.

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote:
He guessed that ...
every man about the
place knew of the
plant of money at
the boss's cottage
awaiting the arrival
of the bush
contractor.

Author: HATHAWAY
Quote:
The cook was
constantly
discovering some
`plants' of food,
hidden by those who
had fled.

Author: DUNCAN
Quote:
... he therefore
began by accusing Mr
Rees of keeping the
stores back, so that
they would have to
pay the boat fare at
the Shotover ferry -
several times for
every pannikin of
flour they got; and
he said the whole
thing was a got up
plant in order to
rob them and fill
his own purse

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Make sure, however,
that the handpiece
is in good order, as
it is the most
important part of
all shearing plant
and must be right.

We all looked for
him [sc. a horse]
... but could not
finde him. I
supposed him to be
planted in the bush
as he is given to
that.

I returned to the
cattle again. Alan
had found the eight
[missing ones]
planted two miles in
the bush. When we
got these, three
more planted, and it
was four p.m. when
we reached Hokitika.
The new-born lamb will follow its mother, and does not `plant'. ... Ibid.] The kid is liable to `plant' or bolt away for hiding when the flock is mustered.
to plant the boot: to accelerate rapidly in a car

If the area to be
planted up is
scrubby or has gorse
or blackberry, this
must be dealt with
as soon as possible.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: name given in Australasia to species of caterpillars which are attacked by spores of certain fungi; when chrysalating in the earth the fungus frows inside the body of the caterpillar, kills the latter, and then forces its way out between the head joints, and sends an upgrowth which projects beyond the surface of the ground and gives rise to fresh spores. Many examples are known, of which the more common are Cordyceps robertsii, Hook., in New Zealand; Cordyceps gunnii, berk, in Tasmania; Cordyceps taylori Berk, in Australia. See Aweto.

Author: REISCHEK
Quote:
I remained in this
forest till the
20th, finding many
kauri grubs; while
under the rata roots
I also found the
Aweta, or
plant-caterpillar,
which to change into
a chrysalis creeps
underground, and in
many cases instead
of becoming a moth
becomes - a
mushroom!

Author: COOKE
Quote:
`The New Zealanders'
name for this
plant-caterpillar is
`Hotete,' `Weri,'
and `Anuhe'... The
interior of the
insect becomes
completely filled by
the inner plant, or
thallus (mycelium):
after which the
growing head of the
outer plant or
fungus, passing to a
state of maturity,
usually forces its
way out through the
tissue of the joint
between the head and
the first segment of
the thorax ... it is
stated that this
caterpillar settles
head upward to
undergo its change,
when the vegetable
developes [sic]
itself.'

The operations of
the gardener this
month are very
light, being chiefly
in eradicating sow
thistle, dock,
plantain, and other
weeds - collecting
the flower seeds
that have now
ripened - cutting
away withered stems,
and staking the
dahliahs and
chrysanthemums.

Plantains, grass,
thistles, and docks,
are perhaps the most
difficult to
eradicate.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: PLANTAIN (Plantago lanceolata) is commonly called rib grass, lamb's tongue, horse plantain, and soldiers. It is common in pastures and waste places throughout. It forms a rosette of lanceolate leaves about 6 inches long, with prominent or converging veins, giving the name `rib grass'. From the rosette rises the slender flower stalk a foot or more in length, with a crowded mass of tiny brown or black flowers at its tip. These heads are used by children for playing `soldiers,' and so in Scotland the weed is called `Carl Doddie"-that is `Charles and George"- a souvenir of 1745.
plantain [=] broad-leaved plantain: narrow-leaved plantain: swamp plantain [s]

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: BROAD-LEAVED PLANTAIN ( Plantago major ), also called ratstail, birdseed, lamb's tongue, and greater plantain, is common on roadsides and trodden places throughout the country and in pastures in the King Country. ... From the middle of the rosette ascends the flower stalk ..., which afterwards give[s] place to seeds, and produce[s] the ratstail appearance that gives the plant one of its trivial names. The long spikes of seed pods are often used for feeding caged birds.

[Hdg] Plimmer's Ark back from the dead. A new chapter in the eventful saga of the Inconstant - the ship that became a building - has started following the recent opening of the new Plimmer's Ark Gallery on Queens Wharf... For many years life in Wellington basically revolved around the hulk of the Inconstant... Built in 1847 and launched on 3 Jan 1848 at Cape Breton in Nova Scotia, the Inconstant sailed to England and there had her hull clad with copper...On entering Wellington Harbour [in 1849] the ship ran on to the rocky beach between Pencarrow and the point now named Inconstant Point. The Inconstant was towed across the harbour to Te Aro. John Plimmer bought the by then derelict ship and had it moved in 1850 to Lambton Beach where he built a pitched roof over the mid section. It became known as Noah's [sic] Ark because of its appearance.

Plimmer's Ark is one of the most significant pieces of maritime history entrusted to the Maritime Archaeological Association. In 1977, construction workers digging in the old Bank of New Zealand building on Wellington's Lambton Quay discovered a slab of wood. Archaeologists identified it as part of the Inconstant, a ship that was towed into Wellington and was eventually bought by John Plimmer who dragged it ashore and modified it for use as business premises. The ship became known as Plimmer's Ark.

The new bio-control agent for the obscure mealybug was released in New Zealand after six years' work and approval from Erma... The wasp, with the scientific name Pseudaphycus maculipennis, is called Pmac for short. About 60,000 Pmacs were released into six apple orchards around Hastings in Februiary 2001, and have been left to their own devices.

The posssibility of

work.

Author: TINNE
Quote:
If a man hits on a
good `pocket' of gum
...

Author: TINNE
Quote:
If a man hits on a
good `pocket' of
gum, he may make
five or six pounds a
week ...

In the shelf a
"pocket" is scooped
capable of
containing a quart
or two, and the gum
is made to collect
in it by scarifying
the bark
triangularly, with
an angle pointing to
the pocket ... When
the "pocket" has
become full, the gum
is barreled and
carried away to be
distilled.

Shallow fern gum,
which is the most
prized for the
manufacture of
varnish, is still in
places fairly
plentiful, and the
fortunate digger who
strikes a pocket of
such is renumerated
to a degree which
his forerunners
never in their
wildest dreams
imagined.

The heaviest gold

heaviest gold always

crevices.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
The Dunstan gold
workings were of two
kinds - technically
known as `beach
claims' and `bank
claims'. The latter
were on the gravelly
river banks which
the miners sluiced
away bodily for the
golden grains ...
The former were on
the sandy margins of
the river, and were
often extended by
means of `wing-dams'
and other ingenious
devices far into the
rushing waters. In
these claims the
gold was found
lodged in `pockets'
or fissures formed
by the slate bars
...

Author: PYKE
Quote:
Gold lay in a series
of rich `pockets'
(as the crevices
were termed)

sand under the loose
stones.

hole was very large

presumably a variety

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: The great noise caused by the Cascade is now & then conquered by the shriller note of a small bird, & by the graver pipe of wattle birds [[ed. fn] Either the South Island Kokako ... or the South Island Saddleback Philesturnus carunculatus carunculatus, or both.], Pohebirds [[ed. fn] Now the New Zealand Tui ...] & Mocking-birds [[ed. fn] Now the bellbird ...].

Author: BAYLY
Quote: There are great plenty of a kind of birds much resembling our black birds, except they have a few white feathers in the wings and tail and some fine loose downy feathers round the neck which grow out among the black ones & has the appearance of fine white hairs intermixed with the feathers & under the throat are 4 fine curling white feathers growing in a tuff. These are called Poey-birds. They are thought to be the finest eating for delicacy & richness ... Ibid. 2/213 During our ramble [in Queen Charlotte's Sound] I saw Wood Pigeons, Parroquets, Grey Parrots, Poey Birds & Quails & vast variety of singing Birds but no animal great or small or any fruit Trees of any kind whatever.
Notes: 1773 April 12 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/206

Author: DIEFFENBACH

Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/187

Quote:
`Tui,' Parson-bird
or Poe-bird of Capt.
Cook Melliphagidae;
Prosthemadera Novae
Zealandiae.
(T.H. Potts)

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Poe/[dieresis], n. same as Tui (q.v.) and Parson-bird (q.v.). The name, which was not the Maori name, did not endure.
~ n. the parson bird; noted for its plumage, fineness of song and powers of mimicry. [origin uncertain]

Author: HOWITT
Quote:
`This bird they
called the
Wattle-bird, and
also the Poy-bird,
from its having
little tufts of
curled hair under
its throat, which
they called poies,
from the Otaheitan
word for ear-rings.
The sweetness of
this bird's note
they described as
extraordinary, and
that its flesh was
delicious, but that
it was a shame to
kill it.'

Author: CRAIK
Quote:
The most remarkable
bird is one to which
Cook's people gave
the name of
mocking-bird, from
the extraordinary
variety of its
notes. There is also
another which is
called by the
English the poe, or
poi bird, from a
little tuft of white
curled feathers
which it has under
its throat, and
which seemed to them
to resemble certain
white flowers worn
as ornaments by the
people of otaheite,
and known there
[188] by a similar
name.

"Pog" is.. Kiwi
parlance for
porridge, and
"scroggin" is the
mix of nuts, dried
fruit and bits of
choccy that trampers
munch on the trail.

Pog for breakfast,
stew for dinner,
Scrog for lunch sure
is a winner

We hope you'll
always burn the pog
And ev'ry bite
contain a wog.

Clean up your space,
clean up any tools.
Be a tidy kiwi. This
may seem
counteractive to
letting creativity
flow, but once
you've been
creative, if you
don't clean up after
yourself, you could
be destroying
someone else's flow
by leaving pog
(untidy mess) behind
you.

As temperatures
fell, drips from the
paddles slicked the
kayak decks with
ice, and fingers and
faces were numbed to
the bone. At such
times, the paddlers
were thankful for
their foam "pogies"
- hand insulators
fixed to the
paddles.

There is a lot of
gentle snobbery and
stirring that goes
on between the teeth
arms and the service
corps or 'pogues' as
they are known.
(Americans call them
'REMFs' - Rear
Echelon Mother
Fuckers).

Author: HUGHES
Quote:
I had to ask what a
BAW was. It stood
for 'Base Area
Wellington', an
administrative
grouping of the
camps and units in
that area... BAW
comprised the
inhabitants of
Trentham Camp, Fort
Dorset and other
miscellaneous
ordnance depots and
TF units. It was
quartered at
Trentham, which was
a crumbling old
man's camp that
housed a base
workshop and a base
supply battalion. It
was pogue central.

Author: HUGHES
Quote:
I was also favoured
by the fact that
Martin Taylor, the
epitome of
licentious poguery,
was posted to the
camp.

They are one of only
a few whanau who
continue the
tradition of making
poha, or containers
used for preserving
muttonbirds.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
... the cargo with
which they had been
freighted,
consisting chiefly
of `poha-titi' or
casks of preserved
mutton birds. Many
of these were from
five to six feet
high, and ornamented
with feathers: they
were all designed as
presents to
relatives at
Waiateruati, or
Banks's Peninsula;
... The `poha,'
which I have called
a cask - as it
performs the office
of one - is
constructed by the
natives in an
ingenious manner,
worthy of
description. A kelp
bag - the air
bladder of a fucus -
is easily found of
the size required,
made by nature. In
this the young
`titi' are packed,
after being cooked,
and the oil which
has escaped in the
cooking is poured on
them. Over the
exterior of the bag
is then laid the
bark of the `totara'
tree, ...

Author: BRUNNER
Quote:
There is great taste
shown by the natives
in the poha, or bag
of preserved wekas.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
POHA, a sort of cask
shaped like a sugar
loaf, constructed
from the air bladder
of a species of
sea-weed,
strengthened outside
by layers of the
bark of the
`totara,' and kept
firmly together by
means of stakes tied
with flax.

Out on line by door
bull-kelp bags blown
up and drying. Under
the table finished
pohas stacked. Birds
in kelp bags with
totara bark
wrapping, looking
fine in their new
flax baskets.
Notes: 1952 Apr 20 diary in 1982 Sansom In the Grip of an Island 153

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
There is great taste
shown by the natives
in the poha, or bag
of preserved wekas;
and I believe it is
always made for a
present, for which
they expect a
return.

Then there is the
"whare whata", or
storehouse, in which
the finished kits of
mutton birds
("poha") are stored
ready for shipment
home.

For the tangi there
were five bullocks,
10 sheep, 2000
mutton birds in poha
(Maori bags), 1 ton
potatoes, 60 or 70
tins of biscuits and
lollies ...

Pohiri at Maromahue
Marae, Waiotahe 10
30 am: Waiotahe
Urupa 12noon: RSA
Cemetery, Whakatane
1.00: Hakari, 53
Goulstone Rd
Whakatane

Uncle's coming home
from overseas. It
might be a big
pohiri because he
was away for a long
time.

The name `tutu' is applied to three distinct species of the ... natural order Coriariae: Coriaria ruscifolia, L. (C. sarmentosa, Forst., C. arborea and C. tutu, Lindsay, tutu, pohou, and tupakihi of the Maori), is commonly known as the tree-toot ...

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: 48. Charadrius obscurus. Gmel. ... Ha-poko-wera of the natives of Dusky Bay. Forst Tuturiwatu of the natives. Yate. To this order may also be referred two other birds spoken of by Mr. Yate under the names of Pukunui, Pututo.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/195

Author: HUTTON
Quote:
64. CHARADRIUS
BICINCTUS. Jard.
Dotterel. Pokowera

Author: BULLER
Quote: CHARADRIUS BICINCTUS. (BANDED DOTTREL.) ... Native names.- Tuturiwhata {, Tuturiwhatu,} and Pohowera.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Ochthodromus ... bicinctus ... below white with a band of black on the chest and another of chestnut on the [80] upper abdomen; ... Banded Dotterel. POHOWERA.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: BANDED DOTTEREL Charadrius bicinctus Other names: Double-banded Dotterel, Mountain Plover, Tuturiwhatu, Pohowera.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Banded Dotterel Charadrius bicinctus JARDINE & SELBY, 1827 ... OTHER NAMES: Pohowera, tuturiwhatu, double-banded plover.

Every one of them,
even Paul Tuhaere,
who was related by
marriage to the
deceased chief, had
around their heads
or hats massive
wreaths of the
creeping plant known
as pohue, and in
some places as
pikiarero.

"When a warrior of old wished to warn of the deviousness of an enemy," says Murdoch Riley in his book Maori Healing and Herbal, "he would say simply 'the roots of the pohue are many,' or 'his mouth is like the creeping convolvulus' - meaning that his thoughts spread underground like the runners of the convolvulus."
po[o]hue, a vine (Calystegia Soldanella), sand-bine: C. sepium is paraha.
The roots of the pohue, the common convolvulus or bindweed (Convolvulus sepium), were also ... dug up and cooked for food.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
When the Maories
[sic] reached New
Zealand, they lived
on such things as
were indigenous to
the island, vis.,
manuka giant, low
fern, pohue (a
creeping plant),
some few fruits, the
native dog and rat,
the guana, the kiwi,
and the moa.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
[Word list] Pohua
the convolvulus

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Calystegia sepium, Br. ... Nat. name, `Panake and Pohue', Col. ... This beautiful plant, the English `Bind-weed', is as common in the Southern Hemisphere as it is in the Northern, being found in Chili, Australia, Tasmania, and Java ...

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pohue, Col[enso]. Convolvulus sepium.

Author: TREGEAR
Quote: The roots of the common convolvulus (pohue: Convolvulus sepium) were carefully dug up and cooked ...

Author: CHEESEMAN
Quote: [Calystegia sepium, R.Br.] Pohue; Panahe; Bindweed. ... Widely dispersed in most temperate countries and everywhere highly variable.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: C. sepium was known to the Maoris as ` pohue,' and the roots were used by them for food.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: GREATER CONVOLVULUS [BINDWEED] ( Calystegia sepium ) has the same popular names as the last species, [i.e. convolvulus] and in additions, beautiful white devil, and its native name of pohue. It is much like convolvulus [bindweed], but is larger in all its parts. The leaves are 3 to 5 inches in length and the flower 2 inches across, more usually white than pink.

a vine (Calystegia
Soldanella),
sand-bine: C. sepium
is paraha.
pohuehue [=] large-leaved muehlenbeckia: wire vine [s]

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: Muehlenbeckia ... australis ... [51] Maori Vine. PO-HUE-HUE (creeper).

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pohuehue, Col[enso]. Polygonum complexum .

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pohuihui, Geolog. Surv. Passiflora tetrandra.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: SCRUB POHUEHUE M. complexa

The following
interest list of the
native and botanical
names of a number of
indigenous trees and
shrubs has been
prepared by Mr. H.
Graham, of the
Brunner railway
service, and placed
at our disposal for
publication ..
Pohuehue,
Muhlenbeckia
complexa [sic] ...
small-leaved pohuehue [=] wire vine [s]

Source: Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail
Author: CHAPPLE
Quote:
I climbed to old
slip faces where the
big bush had
gone,replaced by
grassy colonising
plants - the densely
laced cushions, the
myriad small, round
leaves of pohuehue,
the toetoe, the
mangemange, the
sharp grasses.

Typical of the sites
he surveyed was
Macraes Flat, where,
in 1986, he noted
that porcupine
shrubs, snowberry
plants and pohuehue
vines were stripped
of all their ripe
fruit where they
grew on outcrops
inhabited by grand
skinks, while plants
on nearby outcrops
without skinks were
untouched.

Taupata are a
versatile plant -
I've seen them grown
as a beautiful
windblown hedge,
planted with
creeping
small-leafed
pohuehue
(Muehlenbackia
complexa) along the
base to fill in any
gaps, making a
fantastic foliage
contrast.

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: SEA PERCH ( Sebastes percoides ). ... `The pohuiakaroa,' Dr. Hector says, `deserves mention, as it represents in these seas the genus to which the Norway haddock belongs. It is one of the most frequent and troublesome fish, caught in a moderate depth of water round the coast, and especially in rocky harbours, being almost worthless as food, and armed with so many sharp spines that it is a difficult task to detach it from the hook. It is the proper sea-perch of these waters.'

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Red Gurnet-Perch, n. name given in Victoria to the fish Sebastes percoides, Richards., family Scorpeaenidae. It is also called Poddy; Red Gurnard , or Gurnet; and in New Zealand, Pohuikaroa . [sic]

HELICOLENUS PERCOIDES (Richardson). Sea-perch; Pohuiakaroa . Secured in rocky localities among blue cod. Large numbers common in Christchurch Markets during early summer months. ... Distribution: New Zealand coasts (not so common in the north).
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: SEAPERCH (POHUIAKAROA) JOCK STUART, HIGHLANDER, FIVEFINGER, SOLDIERFISH or SCRODDIE Helicolenus papillosus (Bloch and Schneider) The seaperch is a fish well known to all fishermen both sports and commercial fishermen alike, who give it quite a number of vernacular names, ...
Helicolenus percoides (Richardson). SEA-PERCH; POHUIAKAROA.
47. Scorpaena percoides Richardson. Sea Perch. Maori: Pohuiakaroa

Their Maori name is
Pohui-akaroa, and
their scientific
name Sebastes
percoldes [sic]; but
no fisherman could
use such a name as
that, so we call
them "Stuarts,"
because that is the
sort of colours they
generally wear...

Author: MASON
Quote:
[LOMAS] ... bends to
avoid the hanging
branch of the
pohutukawa. Tell
Johnny his first
job's to cut back
the pohute.

Ten Pounds Reward ..
will be paid for
such information as
will convict the
person or persons
who within the last
month have been
cutting and removing
the roots or
branches or both of
the pohutukawa from
my land near the
Watchman.

In a narrow valley a
little distance from
the hut a path led
along a steep bank
and descended
abruptly by a drop
of about ten feet
through a small
opening in a thick
mat of the foliage
of stunted
pohutukawa.

Author: CARMAN
Quote:
Pohutukawa are our
remarkable trees -
the symbol of New
Zealand, as the oak
is the emblem of
England. Like the
oak, the pohutukawa
has a short, stout
gnarled trunk that
becomes beautifully
gnarled with time,
the wide-spreading
branches forming a
most stately and
memorable tree...
The name
"pohutukawa" comes
from "hutukawa" (a
head-dress of red
feathers) and "po"
which has meany
meanings, including
night or underworld.
Governor Grey
interpreted this as
meaning "the tree
with red adornment
near the sea", but
"po" could equally
be a reference to
the traditional tree
at Cape Reinga where
the spirits of the
dead descend via the
pohutukawa tree to a
secret cave, the
entrance to Te
Reinga, the spirit
or underworld [sic].
A small, scrubby
version still clings
to the cliff edge at
the leaping-off
place of the
spirits. In Maori,
to say someone "has
slid down the
pohutukawa root" is
a lyrical way of
saying he has joined
the ancestors.

Pohutukawas are
overrunning
protected scrubland
in Western Cape,
South Africa...

Pohutukawa N.Z
Christmas tree -
Metosideras[sic]
excelsior

Pohutukawa honey
from Barrier was so
sought after, claims
Les, that it found
its way to King
George's table.

Author: PARK
Quote:
His farmhouse was on
a headland,
sheltered by unkempt
pohutukawas, the
pakeha's Christmas
tree.

... the fact remains that in some localities [the non-epiphytic rata M. robusta [contrast M. florida]] are frequent enough to attract the special attention of the bushman, who calls this form the `inland pohutukawa', a designation he also bestows upon symmetrical specimens of true pohutukawa sometimes found in the forest.

Coromandel's
Pohutukawa Festival
runs Nov 25-Dec 11,
celebrating the
summer flower that
enhances
Coromandel's coastal
beauty.

The rhythmic
properties of the
Maori language and
the poi rhythms are
the root, they're in
all the songs.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
Now, also, are
sedulously
practised, haka and
poi swinging; but
these do not irk;
oh, dear, no!

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
[The Maoris] sang
grandly, especially
a very fine poi
song.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
... the rhythm of
their dancing and
the beauty of their
poi girls.

Author: ASHTON-WARNER
Quote:
And the poi tunes
and melodies
[Maoris] use in
canoes. [fn] poi =
Maori dance

Author: GUTHRIE
Quote:
... the poi women
began their dance to
slow chanting ...
the tiny pois danced
against arms and
shoulders and
breasts ...

[Photo caption] Some
of the Poi Girls who
performed at the
Maori Carnival in
the Choral Hall.

The poi balls
commence to spin,
the deft hands
twirling them move
up and down,
sideways, backwards
and forwards,
hovering over the
shoulders, now over
and across the knee,
the whirling balls
appearing to
surround, as with a
network of gossamer,
the bodies of the
dancers as they sway
from side to side,
lifting alternate
feet and throwing
one across, gently
forward with a
lilting motion,
giving the general
effect of a waltz
step.
The old men often amused themselves with ... encouraging the younger ones ...in playing with the poi-ball.

The arts and crafts
section comprised
tukutuku, ...
plaiting (rourou [fn
A small basket used
for cooked food.],
rough kits and floor
mats), taniko work
and making poi
balls.

The poi balls fell
to rest.

Author: CRAIK
Quote:
The most remarkable
bird is one to which
Cook's people gave
the name of
mocking-bird, from
the extraordinary
variety of its
notes. There is also
another which is
called by the
English the poe, or
poi bird, from a
little tuft of white
curled feathers
which it has under
its throat, and
which seemed to them
to resemble certain
white flowers worn
as ornaments by the
people of otaheite,
and known there
[188] by a similar
name.

Author: HARSANT
Quote:
Following the big
feast there were
haka,songs, poi
dances and stick
games, untilit was
time for the evening
meal.

Doing poi dances on
the stage in front
of lots of people.

POI DANCE AT THE
OPENING OF THE MAORI
HOUSE AT PORIRUA,
WELLINGTON.

One of the most
interesting features
of the programme was
a succession of
old-time Maori
dances, including
various hakas and
poi dances, and the
result was both
picturesque and
interesting.

Author: WHITE
Quote:
The women go through
a pretty and curious
performance called
the `poi' dance. Its
chief feature is the
excellent time that
they keep with their
`pois,' or inflated
bladders, held by
strings and thrown
about with the
utmost precision to
their weird, droning
notes.

Author: GRIEVE
Quote: ... he contorted his pseudo-tattooed features and performed frenzied hakas, or lent his voice to the haunting rhythm of the poi-dances.

Author: ANDERSEN
Quote: poi, a light ball made from raupo blades, with a short string attached to it which is swung and twisted rhythmically, in the manner of Indian clubs, to the accompaniment of a song; the so-called poi-dance, which is less a dance than a whirling of the balls and a swaying of the body in time with the song. There is a long-poi, in which the string is perhaps a yard long.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
Be sure that when a
poi dance is
suggested, and while
the maidens are
displaying their
most captivating
attitudes, one of
them ... glides
outside [to a
tryst].

They also did poi
dances and sang
songs in Maori.

At the Maori
demonstration at
Rotorua, the poi
dancers from the
West Coast signified
the change of
movement by
different calls,
commencing with
"Palmerston North"
out of compliment to
the member of this
district, who was
present, and giving
amongst other cries,
"Duke and Duchess of
York."

Warriors, Wahines,
Kuri, Poaka,
Tamariki, Kumeras,
Karos, Interpreters
(1st, 2nd and 3rd
grade), Poets
Laureate, Poi
Dancers, Guides, &c.
on application to
the Registrar.
...WAIPIRO - - An
acursed drink ...
TAIHOA - - The
Police have the
matter in hand POAKA
- -a pig PUKEKO A
bokakker out of
season KORERO A long
talk UTU - - The
spike HAPU - - A
Tribe KUMERA - - A
sweet Spud

[Photo caption] The
girl with the poi
balls in her hand is
a noted poi dancer,
and leads the whole
party at the
different dances.

Among the amusements
was the "poi" game,
in which rows of
girls stood up and
juggled poi balls to
the rhythmic
accompaniments of a
song and graceful
movements of the
body.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Another game is with
one ball (poi)
suspended from a
string.

Author: DOMETT
Quote: Amid her damsels, scarlet-crowned/ With kowhai-flowers, a lively ring/ Playing at `poi' sent flying round/ [157] The ornamented ball o'erwound ...

The Maori game of poi (ball) has been brought before the public lately in connection with some utterances of the great Maori prophet Te Whiti, and here for the first time we saw the girls playing poi.

[Photo caption]
Canoe Poi by Maori
Women.

The poi, a ball
dance by
Titokowaru's young
women was a novelty.

The performers were
attired in Native
costume, and opened
the programme with a
haka of welcome;
then followed the
poi Waero (the most
ancient poi), most
gracefully given by
the champion prize
poi performers.
Among other dances was the poi, danced by Maori maidens, who ... manipulated a couple of balls, ... one in each hand.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote: The open marae where the sun beats down relentlessly is now deserted. Afterwards there were pois and there were hakas, ... and there was to be a korero on politics and the land question ...

Author: HILLIARD
Quote: Mum taught them the short, long and double poi [fn] poi - dance performed to music with a light ball attached to a string.

After a stirring poi
performed by Putiki
Maori Club, Prince
Edward said he was
delighted to be be
back in New Zealand
...

Author: MASON
Quote:
MIRI. Oh yes! I'm
going to do the long
poi!

After the single poi
had finished, the
tots dropped out and
the others gave the
more difficult and
elaborate double poi
dance, which was
performed with the
precision of
clockwork.

In all, the royal
visitors to-day
received 40 flax
mats, 20 feather
mats (many of them
made from rare kiwi
feathers), six
greenstone meres,
three clubs or
taiahas of carved
whalebone, a large
model of a canoe,
and many feather
kits and poi balls.

The poi is a small
hollow ball, of
plaited flax, and is
swung from the wrist
in movements very
similar to those of
modern
club-swinging.

We recorded real poi
- Mina had to poi
her arms off!

Author: Nicholas
Quote:
They made Mr.
Marsden [318] a
present of a ball
called a poe, with
which the ladies
amuse themselves by
throwing it
repeatedly backward
and forward; it is
... made of their
cloth or canvas,
stuffed with the
down of the
bull-rush, having a
long string appended
to it, ...

At the conclusion of
this troupe's
performance, which
was arrived at by
the whole making a
curious sidling
movement towards the
entrance of the
ring, and then with
a simultaneous shout
rushing tumultuously
away, Titikowaru was
seen outside the
chequered ring of
humanity which
bounded the
amphitheatre, at the
head of the damsels
who were to bring
the performance to a
close by executing
the haka of the poi
or ball.

In this poi half of
the dancers dress in
plain,
light-coloured
"korowai", the other
half in the "kahu
kiwi," the sombre
yet valuable kiwi
feathered mat. [9]
The word "poi" means
a to and fro motion.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: P|oi, s. A round ball with which children play.

Author: YATE
Quote: Running, climbing, swimming, wrestling, flying kites, and tossing the poi, a ball about the size of a good cricket-ball, are most of the games of native origin.

Author: ANDERSEN
Quote: poi, a light ball made from raupo blades, with a short string attached to it which is swung and twisted rhythmically, in the manner of Indian clubs, to the accompaniment of a song; the so-called poi-dance, which is less a dance than a whirling of the balls and a swaying of the body in time with the song. There is a long-poi, in which the string is perhaps a yard long.

Author: ZIMMERMAN
Quote: The poi is an egg-shaped thing, made of the pith from a swamp plant covered with a woven cover of raupo, somewhat like the leaves of the cattail.
poi: small stuffed ball; ball game.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
(gloss.) poi: a
light ball of flax
swung by a string,
used in Maori
dances.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
Whirling poi was
easy, but flipping
it so that it
slapped first on the
top of the wrist,
then underneath, was
the hard part.

poi n, pl poi or pois [Maori]: a small ball which is made typically of flax, grass, or rushes, to which a string of varying length is attached, and which is swung rhythmically by Maori performers in various dances and songs

Quote: The Corriedale ... grows more wool than hair on the hocks, thereby making it imperative that they be shorn trimmed to the feet. These points or socks do not have a tendency to lift or rise off the skin. Ibid. 137 The Romney is a well-woolled sheep, covered right down on to the points. At the right time of the year these points lift or rise off the skin allowing the comb and the handpiece to enter easily and the blows to finish out on the points without poking.

The documentary Pokarekare Ana: A Maori Love Song.. on the origins of the song, surrounds the contributions made by Sir Apirana Ngata and Paraire Tomoana with a misleading element of mystery... For a number of reasons, "Pokarekare" is unlikely tobeen the original work of either of these men. (1) "Pokarekare" was published in sheet music form in 1926 (twice), in 1927, 1936 and 1940 prior to Paraire Tomoana's death in 1946. The two 1926 versions are said to have been arranged by "Hemi Piripata" and "Alfred Hill": respectively. the 1927 version is said to have been arranged by "P H Tomoana and Archie Don". The 1936 version is said to have been "collected and sung by Ernest McKinley" and the 1940 version is again said to have ben arranged by "Hemi Piripata". in short, no published version of the song, including the 1919 booklet entry, gave any credit to either Apirana Ngata or to P H Tomoana for composing the song in their lifetimes... The most likely conclusion would seem to be that what has affectionately become "New Zealand's unofficial anthem" originated in the far north of New Zealand circa 1900 and was adapted. modified and developed in its journey through the country by a number of gifted Maori composers of the day.

...Tomoana explains
the song's origin:
"7. Pakarekare.
These ditties
emanated in the
North of Auckland
and were popularised
in Narrowneck Camp,
and eventually
drifted to ... the
East Cape. There
they took the
present form ... and
acquired close
association with the
last drafts of
single men from the
East Cape and Wairoa
districts ... the
19th and 20th Maori
Reinforcements."

In 1978 I went with
a Hamilton Teachers
College kapa haka
student group on a
tour of Aboriginal
settlements in
Australia's Northern
Territory... The
group refused to
include "Pokarekare
Ana" in their
repertoire because
in their eyes the
song had become a
parody of the
original, with
"squashed banana"
lyrics... At the
Adelaide Festival,
Rolf Harris asked us
to accompany him in
his latest hit,
"Pokarekare Ana."...
Anyone from Dame
Kiri Te Kanawa down

"Pokarekare". It
adds to the popular
culture of New
Zealand.

On hearing

first time George
Bernard Shaw
immediately

as a Swiss cradle
song.

...all too often

stumbles on to

medley involving
"Pokarekareana". The
full lyrics to which
are "Pokarekareana
Something Something
Roto-rua".

pre-cooked sausage.

[Advt] May be German
sausage is the
titbit you most
prize / Or else you
on polonies dote. or
count your earthly
joys / By occasional
refreshment in the

Normally, any

pink-skinned,
pre-cooked sausages
- known as polonies

south - would be

[Auckland

Club.

"The play starts off

The authors also

A poly pill unlike
any other poly pill
- when taken it will
have so many
constituent bits
that it will deliver
eternal life,
overcoming any of
our activities that
could shorten life.

[Caption] Peter
Smith shows off a
young Polydale ram,
a composite of four
breeds that he says
is high-performing,
intelligent and easy
to handle.... The
inclusion of the
Cheviot is what
surprises most
farmers, but Mr
Smith says this has
made the Polydale an
alert, intelligent
breed that is easy
to handle.

Mr Smith has
christened the new
breed, which he has
been raising on his
Tahoraiti property
near Dannevirke,
Polydale, which
means "many lambs".

He dislikes cosmetic
Polynesianisation,
just as he dislikes
those who take the
shabbiness of the
Royal Family and use
it as a way of
disregarding the
whole of British
civilisation.

Dr Mayhew called it
the "Polynesisation
of New Zealand
rugby."

Quote:
I was amused...
There is no
obscurity about the
origin of "Pommy".
The origin is the
obvious one -
"Emigrant". The
emigrants themselves
corrupted this to
"Pomegranate". From
1914 to 1925
Ifrequently heard
and used the term
"pomegranate" to
describe a new
arrival. Over recent
years this has been
abbreviated to
"Pommy". I am,
etc...Thick-skinned
Pommy.

The term is of
Australian origin,
of a period long ago
when the military
and other
authorities of the
time called the men
of the penal
settlement,
"Prisoners of Mother
England," which was
shortenedto P.O.M.E.
and later made
"Pommie". The New
Zealand term was
"Homie" until
superseded by the
Australian
adjective. And even
now "Pommie" is
being superseded by
the term "Pongo".

Author: Davin
Quote:
We never really
talked the same
language anyhow. `I
don't know,' he said
and his accent
seemed to have gone
a bit pommier than
usual, or what he
thought was pommy,
only that was
another thing that

pommies had made

Author: THE MIXER
Quote:
He'll corner a bloke
often that's
"shickered", / Who
looks like a
"pommie" or a "yob".

(Corresp. col) Sir,
- Your
correspondents are
incorrect regarding
the origin of the
term `Pommie',
meaning English
immigrant. The term
is of Australian
origin, of a period
long ago when the
military and other
authorities of the
time called the men
of the penal
settlements,
`Prisoners of Mother
England', which was
shortened to
P.O.M.E. and later
made `Pommie'. The
New Zealand term was
`Homie' until
superseded by the
Australian
adjective. And even
now Pommie is being
superseded by the
term `Pongo'. The
term certainly was
derisive in origin,
and as to whether it
is still derisive
depends entirely
upon the individual
addressed as such.
The writer is of the
fourth generation
(N.Z. with Austr.
connections).
Winther Pedersen.

I was amused by your
reply to `T.P.P.'
There is no
obscurity about the
origin of `Pommy'.
The origin is the
obvious one -
`Emigrant'. The
emigrants themselves
corrupted this to
`pomegranate'. From
1914 to 1925 I
frequently heard and
used `pomegranate'
to describe a new
arrival. Over recent
years this has
become abbreviated
to `Pommy'.
Thick-Skinned Pommy.

A Tasmanian gave the
origin definitely as
being `pomegranate',
the colour of that
fruit being similar
to the high colour
of the complexions
of the English, and
very noticeable
against the
sun-dried appearance
of the Aussie
complexion. This has
been acceptable to
many knowing the
Aussies'
susceptibility to
using phrases such
as `plates of meat'
for feet and
`trouble for strife'
for wife. Pommy to
many has become a
most objectionable
word owing to the
way it has been used
with other words.
Only the most
ignorant use of such
terms, not thinking
that their
forefathers came
from that same brave
country. If my
comrades of the
Homeland, newly
arrived, who use the
nom-de-plume, or
refer to themselves
as `Pommies', read
this they will now
understand why it is
objectionable even
when used in a
friendly manner.
British and Proud of
it.

Sir, - Fifty years
ago a shipload of
passengers arrived
in Australia. Coming
through the tropics,
they got badly
burned and their
faces were scarlet.
The word `Pommie'
was derived from a
well-known
Australian fruit at
the time, the
scarlet pomegranate.
So the Australians
named the new
arrivals `Pommies'
(just fun), and
`Pommie' is still
used occasionally.
-E.M.W.

Sir, -A
correspondent wishes
to know the origin
of the word
`Pommie.' The famous
war correspondent,
the late Ashmad
Barlett, in his
book, `Despatches
from the
Dardanelles,'
written at the time
of the campaign,
says that the term
`Pommie' was applied
by veteran troops of
the campaign to
newly arrived troops
from Britain. Their
fresh pink
complexions were
likened to the fruit
pomegranate, in
contrast to the
bronzed features of
the veteran troops.
They were referred
to as `Pommies.' The
term, therefore, was
not applied by
Dominion troops in
particular to those
from Britain, but by
veteran troops, both
British and
Dominion, to new
arrivals. -KIWI.

Sir, - In reply to
O.J. Davis and `Very
Interested' relating
to the origin of the
word `Pommie.' The
word apparently came
into being during
the 1914-18 War and
is derived from the
French word pommes,
meaning, I believe,
potatoes. During the
war the front line
troops of the
British Army were
very seriously short
of food, except for
potatoes, on which
they subsisted for
many weeks. Hence on
the fields at
Flanders this
peculiar and, I
might say, very
controversial word
came into being. I
am sure that any
British World War I
veteran could affirm
this
explanation.-W.J.BRACKS.

Sir, - It is
`POM-E,' not
`Pommie.' These four
letters originated
in the old sailing
ship days. Migrants
leaving the British
Isles were issued
with a permit of
migration
certificate which
was headed, `Permit
of
migration-Ireland,'
`Permit of
migration-England,'
depending on the
part of the British
Isles one was from.
The first letters in
these four words
`Permit of
migration-England'
are `POM-E,' spelt
now, as pronounced
then, `Pommie.'
-SAILS.

Sir, - The red coat
of the soldier gave
rise to the sailors'
nickname for him of
`Pommy,' a
corruption of the
French `pomme.' This
derivation is far
more likely than
`Prisoner of Mother
England.' The
derogatory nickname
would be more likely
to stick to the
guards than to the
convicts. If my
explanation is
incorrect am I
entitled to call our
trans-Tasman cousins
(and others)
`Pommies?' - I am,
etc., A PENSIONER OF
MOTHER ENGLAND.

Sir, - Unfortunately
previous
correspondents have
been confused by the
spelling of `Pommy.'
I understand the
correct spelling to
be P.O.M.M.I.E.,
this being derived
from the initial
letters of the
phrase, `People of
Many Magnificient
Immortal Epics.'
This derivation was
given in the
Australian R.S.L.
magazine several
years ago. - I am,
etc, DRONGATUS
PONGORUM.

EVERY now and then
some one puts
forward a new theory
on why Englishmen
are occasionally
referred to in these
southern latitudes
as `Pommies'. The
following note from
Mr. G.T.M., of the
coastal motor vessel
Squall, at
Wellington, may
clear things up: `I
first visited Aussie
in 1911-Western
Australia, Victoria,
New South Wales, and
Queensland.
Immigrants were
variously
termed-Immygrant',
`Jimmy grants', and
up among the
bananalanders, quite
often `Pommy grants'
(pomegranates). Very
soon this became
`Pommy'; and this, I
think, would be the
true derivation.'

Author: GOLDIE BROWN
Quote:

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
We got into this
hullabaloo with some
poor damned
immigrants. What
system, they were
brought out under, I
don't know, but they
were 'Homeys' - the
word 'Pommy' wasn't
in use then.

Inferior English
residents,
called"Homies" more
often than
"Pommies", spokein a
variety of non-U
accents andoccupied
a variety of non-U
jobs.

I have never felt
any hostility
towards any"homie"
or "pommie" until
recently.

Has anybody heard of
`Pommy-ism' and, if
so, what is it. Says
`The Soldier'
(Sydney) ... The
name `Pommy' is
strongly resented by
immigrants after
they have been
resident in
Australia a few
weeks, yet they are
entirely to blame if
the name sticks.
Some of the
newcomers will not
drop their
`pommy-ism' and they
assume a silly air
of `superiority',
even going to the
extent of trying to
keep ex-Imperial
sevice men in a sort
of private
organisaion. ...
What is written of
Australia might well
apply with R.S.A.
substituted for
R.S.S.I.L.

He'll comer a bloke
off that's
`shickered', / Who
looks like a
`pommie' or a `yob'

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
`[New Zealanders]
like the English,
provided they are
the right type; the
educated young man
gets on well. They
don't like the
`Pommie' as they
call him, God knows
why, and no one can
tell you where the
name came from, but
its more common in
Australia than in
New Zealand'. `What
is a Pommie?' `Blest
if I know; it's hard
to define, but
usually the short,
shrunken industrial
worker, the man with
the broad accent,
from Yorkshire or
Lancashire. The
stunted product of
sweated labour, from
mills factories and
mines. I've heard
him referred to as a
Pommie, but never
the upstanding
educated young
fellow. They seem to
welcome him; he is
like themselves'.

some day will be
recognised even in
the schools.
