Author: DAVIN
Quote:
Being a pommy or a
homey as they called
it I was just as
much a freak for the
rest as I was for
the Irish.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
New Zealanders
themselves may have
been subconsciously
aware of this
difference of
approach. They never
quite knew where
they had Mr. Nash.
Was he one of them
or was he still, if
you scratched below
the surface, just
another Pommy?
Certainly he never
exchanged his
Worcestershire
accent for the very
individual New
Zealand version of
our language.
Notes: 1965 Mallaby From My Level 80 in 1976 Sinclair Nash 318

Quote: pommy n. an English newcomer to Australia [contraction of pomegranate, possibly by rhyming play on word immigrant, as extended to jimmygrant].
pommy ... n. an English newcomer to Australia [contraction of pomegranate, possibly by rhyming play on word immigrant, as extended to Jimmy Grant].

Author: LELAND
Quote: pom, pommie: A ruddy (BLOODY? op.cit.) ENGLISHMAN. ...
pommy n., pl. -ies. (sometimes cap.) Sl. a mildly offensive word used by Australians and New Zealanders for a British person. Sometimes shortened to pom. [C20:

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
[The immigrants]
were `Homeys' - the
word `Pommy' wasn't
in use then [early
1930s depression],
and [79] we called
them `Homeys', and
this was used in a
derogatory manner
... as if it was
something
contemptible.

He says he hasn't
heard any criticism
about a Pommie
landing a top job.

He has had a rough
time of it surveying
a block on the
ranges up the
Wai-o-hine in the
Wairarapa ...[sic]
Once ...[sic] they
had nothing to eat
but a tui and a
more-pork. ... They
were stewing the two
birds when a kuku-pa
(bush pigeon) flew
up and perched. Bob
shot it ... This is
not exactly what the
Britishers call
`sport' - but there
is more of nature
about it than 30
gents in pink and
tops ... waiting for
a wretched little
fox who, when he is
killed, is not equal
for culinary
purposes to a
more-pork. Once
coming up the
Waikato in 1851 your
Uncle James got a
pot-shot at a lot of
parera (grey duck)
...

Inferior English
residents, called
`Homies' more often
than `Pommies',
spoke in a variety
of non-U accents and
occupied a variety
of non-U jobs [in
Tauranga in the
1930s].

Pearson's keen sense
of rejection was
sharpened by the
nation's
Pommy-bashing phase
and he became even
more prickly.

Apart from
pommie-bashing, the
commentators in the
world cup matches
spent an
extraordinary amount
of time telling
viewers what they
could easily see.

Two women, a cook
and a nurse, were
gaoled for three
months in Wallasey,
England, recently
for "communicating"
with German
prisoners. The two
"tarts" used to
sneak out and
"communicate" with
the 'orrid 'Uns
under cover of
darkness. Food is
certainly not the
only shortage in
Pommie-land
nowadays, as far as
the womenfolk are
concerned, at any
rate. Nor, it is
fairly evident, are
all the ministering
angels as
noble-hearted as was
Nurse Cavell.

Author: CASEY
Quote:
A fellow that's come
all the way from
Pommieland to have a
quick look at
Kiwi-Country, ... at
least ought to have
an overcoat to put
on himself.

Noel Virtue is a
pommified Kiwi who
wandered off on his
OE in 1967 and only
came back for brief
time.

Source: Medieval English Religious and Ethical Literature
Author: RUSSELL
Quote:
... one took out an
undergraduate degree
in New Zealand, and
went on to Oxford,
where one took on
the Schools, the
undergraduate
examination, over
again. This was
held, I assume, to
be a kind of
correction, a kind
of deepening, a kind
(I suspect) of what
some might call
Pommising.

Has anybody heard of
`Pommy-ism' and, if
so, what is it. Says
`The Soldier'
(Sydney) ... The
name `Pommy' is
strongly resented by
immigrants after
they have been
resident in
Australia a few
weeks, yet they are
entirely to blame if
the name sticks.
Some of the
newcomers will not
drop their
`pommy-ism' and they
assume a silly air
of `superiority',
even going to the
extent of trying to
keep ex-Imperial
sevice men in a sort
of private
organisaion. ...
What is written of
Australia might well
apply with R.S.A.
substituted for
R.S.S.I.L.

These supported
wine-berry poles ...

Some people speak
and write of them as

this is of course
loose and
misleading. There
are fern-trees on my
section up to fifty
feet in height, and
at least one of them
- the wheki variety,
is a hard-bitten
fellow ... The
unobservant are apt
to lump all
fern-trees together,
as pongas, or, in
the vernacular,
`bungers'.

- It is to be
regretted that the
artist who labelled

punga does not mean

Bushmen usually
called a pukatea,
buckyteer; a kowhai,
goey; and a kaponga,
[variant of ponga] a
bunger whence comes
the word punga, both
a noun and a verb in

or brown tree fern
is not nearly so
handsome as the
mamaku, or black
tree fern [Cyathea
medullaris], the
latter often being a
chief's prerogative
for the white heart
in the middle of the
young leaves, which
was baked and eaten.

Author: FORSTER
Quote: ... I got a Man who went & fetched me a Fern-tree with root and all, he called it Ma[macron]a[macron,grave]gu, & as I pointed to a large ferntree near me, with leaves whose underside is white, he shewed me the difference & called the latter Po[grave]nga. This Tree is full of tender pulp, ... and I believe this Fern is nearly related to the Sago-tree, which is likewise a Fern.

Author: SLATTER
Quote: We strolled up the main strada in the evening ... and the Pongo red-cap stopped us to demand where our hats were. Bloody cheek said Mick, as if we're in their damned Pongo army ... The poor old Pongos in their hairy battle-dress, on skimpy rations and poor pay, the poor old Pongos with their white skins, calling their sergeants sir and saluting right left and centre all over the place. And nattering in incomprehensible dialects and county idiom. Ibid. 95 A real Pongo outlook because he'd only been out a few years when the war came and he went into our army. He didn't belong. He had that Pommie accent and that Pommie outlook. It's in the book he'd say. Do it as per the book. Ibid. 219 `Bloody Reginald. What a name to give a kid. A real sissy Pongo name.' ... `This Pongo business annoys me. You haven't even got it right. Pongo's the naval word for soldiers or marines. Out here they use it as just another form of Pommie.'

Author: McGILL
Quote: pongo British person; originally used by British sailors to describe marine or soldier they were required to join forces with in WWI, probably not unaware that the word meant `monkey', though derivation credited to forage cap resembling that worn by the dog Pongo in a Punch and Judy show; brought back by Anzacs as name for their British counterpart.

Author: LAWLOR
Quote:
...Tom says I am a
sheeler for playing
Poor Jenny ... My
spelling cannot have
improved much with
the years for I had
to look up the
dictionary to find
whether one spelt
the word `sheila' or
`sheilagh'. Of
course `Poor Jenny'
or `Poor Sally', as
it is perhaps better
known, was and no
doubt still is a
girl's game. As I
had three doting
sisters I cheerfully
joined their games
when my boy friends
were not looking.
Remember the words
of the song? Poor
Sally is a-weeping,
a-weeping,
a-weeping, Poor
Sally is a-weeping,
On a bright summer's
day. On the carpet
she shall kneel
While the grass
grows in the field -
Stand up, stand up,
upon your feet, And
choose the one you
love so sweet. Then
followed `the moment
of truth' and with
girl and boy
standing demurely in
the middle of the
ring of children,
the circle danced
around them singing:
Now you're married I
wish you joy, First
a girl and then a
boy. I forget the
final words, if any.
Usually this game
was followed by
`Ring-a-ring a
rosie, Pop down a
posie.' Strange,
though, how the
love-making aspect
would come into many
of these old games.
I must have been a
pronounced `sheeler'
about this time
because I also
remember joining in
the singing of I
sent a letter to my
love And on the way
I dropped it, Some
of you have picked
it up And put it in
your pocket. Dropped
it - dropped it! And
so on. A year or two
later at the
mellowing age of 10
years I abhorred all
these `sissy' games
though I still had a
hankering to play
`Oranges and
Lemons', even at the
great age of 12.
Notes: (1903 June 27) Pat Lawlor Wellington Diary in 1977 Aug. 27 Dominion 6 June 27 1903

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: In the early 'eighties occurred two dry seasons during which grass fires were run over the hot western and northern faces of certain portions on eastern Tutira; on the blackened ground then and once again seedlings of brome-grass (Bromus mollis) appeared in so great profusion that other grasses were temporarily submerged in hillsides of waving hay. [284] `Poor Pretences' was then the name by which this brome-grass was known on the east coast : it may be worth putting on record a suggestion as to how the plant came by such a curious designation. It was a `poor pretence' compared with ryegrass, cock's-foot, and white clover, the mixture sown then almost as a religious duty on Hawke's Bay runs, good and bad alike. So much for the sense; as regards the sound, `poor pretences' can, I think, only be a corruption of Poa pratensis; the Latin name of the one plant done into English has been fitted to another. The reader will recollect how this grass - more widely known as goose-grass - was sown wholesale over the trough of the run.

orange, grapefruit
... and what is
known as the Poorman
Orange, which is
much in demand for
marmalade making.

`What's that you
brought for us?'
`Poorman's oranges.'
.. I hate
grapefruit.
Notes: 1986 Macrae (The Kingsland Kid) in New Outlook 21/48

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
The Fenian
gold-field was a
poorman's field and,
like others in
Nelson, served to
supplement the
earnings of local
farmers.

Liver Savoury
(Poorman's Goose)...
1 lb. liver. 1 lb.
potatoes. 4 oz.
onion. 1 teaspoon
salt. 1/2 teaspoon
pepper. 1/2 pint
water. Little
powdered sage.

Finally, beware of
the big purple
poozle person (to
poozle is to
snaffle; to
take).Things do go
missing if left
lying around - that
includes tools,
resources,
equipment, materials
and artwork. Put
things away, be
conscious of what
you're using and
where it comes from.
If something
disappears whilst
you're using it, let
the tutor know. And
don't poozle other
people's stuff
without asking, or
the original owner
might forget to look
after you and may
break some furniture
in their effort to
get at you.

When it turns
translucent, add the
mushrooms, cover the
pan with a lid,
you've poozled off a
saucepan, lower the
heat right down and
allow the mixture to
very gently stew
while you cook the
risotto.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
Leo would spend his
sober periods
worrying about
Jill's poozles - a
variety of antics
with great
sentimental and
artistic value.

Peter was fighting
to save old houses/
once he felt so
strong/ he was
shouting about the
old people/ who had
lived in Grafton so
long/ for instance
himself/ he had
built his own room/
out of poozled
pieces of glass/

Author: McGILL
Quote: poozling scavenging in abandoned buildings before the demolisher gets there, old bottles favoured, but anything of antique significance or value.

Source: Te Araroa: the New Zealand Trail
Author: CHAPPLE
Quote: ...as usual, when the pressure went on, I couldn't find my start, of course - poozle a construction from the best first line in New Zealand literature - Ronald Hugh Morrieson, The Scarecrow, out of 1963. 'The same week our fowls were stolen, Daphne Moran had her throat cut.' Right.

Antique Alley is
poozler heaven on
Dominion Road.

Author: HUGHES
Quote:
My old friend Kae
Miller used to drive
a gaily decorated
van with "A Pride of
Poozlers" inscribed
on the side. My son
Jonathan, who has
driven that van,
believes it was
around in the early
1770. I am sure it
was some time in the
70s. I have the
impression, perhaps
wrongly, that Kae
invented the words
poozle, poozling and
poozler. Jonathan
has the same belief
but neither of us is
sure if it is
correct. She
certainly used these
words. Kae (single
name Katrine
Hursthouse), was a
dedicated
environmentalist,long
before it was
fashionable.
Poozling was a part
of her
environmentalism.
She poozled (I think
she would have
resisted the word
"scavenge")
diligently in the
old Wilton tip and
claimed to have
rescued valuable
antiques.

Author: LELAND
Quote: poozling: Going through abandoned houses scheduled for demolition and removing the (usually antique) fittings that strike your fancy. Until recently this was a socially acceptable practice (although not strictly legal), however, as demolition contractors catch on to the value of these fittings legal and moral pressure is exerted to discourage the practice.

Source: Beachcomber: a New Zealand & Pacific Miscellany
Author: TREWBY
Quote:
poozling: scavenging
among cargoes for
'loose' goods, also,
scavenging in
about-to-be
demolioshed
buildings for
anything of value

Author: McGILL
Quote: pop, phr. have a pop at a fight; NZA. - to go off pop to start speaking angrily. - not a fair pop not a fair chance; eg `I'd like to have a pop at the little basket, but I apologise for going off pop at you. It's not a fair pop you having to be involved.' c. 1925.

[Stags need good
feeding] especially
when they are
popping their
coronets.

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote:
Thank God, she
doesn't look too big
yet. A man would
look a proper Joe
Hunt if she popped a
sprog at his wedding
`do'.

Author: STEPHENS
Quote:
Many is the sly pop
made on these
generally useless
animals [sc. dogs].

Author: MARSH
Quote:
How about having a
pop at Mr Liversidge
[sc a go at
questioning him.]
But, then again, if you had told me just after Bad Taste that he would go on to make a movie as big as Star Wars, I would have laughed so hard I would have popped me rivets!

Flanker Joe Lawn
dived over from a
ruck three minutes
later before
fullback James
Hilgendorf finished
off a pop pass from
flanker Jason Eaton
after a break from
first five-eighth
Todd Feather.

But Masoe juggled
the pop pass from
Umaga, who was
felled just short of
the line and the
video referee ruled
correctly that he
had knocked it on.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
People whizzing
round the harbour in
motor-boats like the
pop-pop boats we
used to whizz round
in the bath on
Christmas morning.

But every sun
umbrella, every
pop-top trailer,
Lilo, chillybin,
every one of them,
as the song says,
screams no no no.

The pop-up mall that
I am not allowed to
call pop-up in case
Indignant of London
asks His
Bigwiggedness the
lawyer to send me a
letter, popped up.
(Wallace Shearing Glossary) popgun: A shearer who has occassional flashes of brilliance. [cf gun]

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Popi-hui, Hector. Libertia micrantha.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Popohui, Hector. Arthropodium cirrhatum.

[Also eaten were] several Fungi [especially] ... four ... which grow on trees, - the Harori ( Agaricus adiposus ), the Hakeke, and the Popoiahakeke ( Polyporus species, and the Pekepekekiore ( Hydnum clathroides ); also, three terrestrial ones, - the Paruwhatitiri (Ileodictyon cibarium), the Pukurau (Lycoperdon Fontainesii), ...

[Also eaten were] several Fungi [especially] ... four ... which grow on trees, - the Harori ( Agaricus adiposus ), the Hakeke, and the Popoiahakeke ( Polyporus species, and the Pekepekekiore ( Hydnum clathroides ); also, three terrestrial ones, - the Paruwhatitiri (Ileodictyon cibarium), the Pukurau (Lycoperdon Fontainesii), ...

This quartet of
tieke, or
saddlebacks, are
vanguard to the main
body of 20-odd
popokatea, or
whiteheads.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: 14. Mohoua ochrocephala. G.R.Gray, ... Mohoua houa of the natives of Tasman Bay. Quoy et Gaim. Popokatea, natives of Cook's Straits. Dieffenbach.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/189

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
In the lower regions
the forest was much
enlivened by birds.
I shot some parrots
[fn Nestor
meridionalis. Kaka
of the natives.],
pigeons [fn Columba
spadicea, Lath.
Kukupa.], and
wattle-birds [fn
Glaucopis cinerea,
Gmel. Kokako.].
Among the branches
of the trees hopped
the neat fantail
flycatcher [fn
Muscicapa
flabellifera, Gml.
Piwakawaka.], and a
social bird of a
yellow colour, which
has been depicted by
Forster [fn
Orthornyx
heteroclytus, Lef.
Popokatea.], and
which had much the
habits of the finch.

I have seen the
yellow-head, the
popokotea or
'canary,' in the
bush on Mount
M'Kerrow, Wellington
...

[The whitehead] is
best known to
bushmen, probably,
as the bush canary,
although it is not a
canary. Its
commonest name is
popokatea.

[they] have recorded
three sightings of
the native,
Popokatea, or
Whitehead, in the
Porirua Scenic
Reserve - the first
time the birds have
been sighted in more
the 100 years.

I have paid special attention to the nests of three birds- the Native Canary (Orthonyx ochrocephala ), the Robin (Myiomoira albifrons ), and the Tomtit (Myiomoira macropcephala ). ir Walter Buller says ... that the Blue Crow (Glaucopis cinerea ) lays a single egg, and ... leaves the care of the chick to the to the Popokatea, or Canary (Orthonyx albicilla ).

Author: THOMSON
Quote: The Certhidae, or Creeper family of birds, possesses five species, none of which are very remarkable save the Pokokatea, a social bird not unlike the English finch in its habits.

The Popokatea (Mohoua albicilla) is represented by another species (M. ochrocephala) differing in colour but so closely allied to it that the natives apply the same name to both; the Toutouwai (Petroica longipes) ... is represented by (Petroica albifrons) ...

Mohoua albicilla.
Popokotea. Very
common.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
10. ORTHONYX
OCHROCEPHALA. Gml.
Canary. Yellow-head.
Popokatea.

Author: BUL.LER
Quote: ORTHONYX ALBICILLA {CLITONYX ALBICAPILLA}. (The WHITE-HEAD.) ... Native names. Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea. Ibid. 103 {1888 2nd edn 1/56} ORTHONYX {CLITONYX} OCHROCEPHALA. (The YELLOW-HEAD.) ... Native names. The same [Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea] as those applied to the preceding species [White-head]: `Canary' of the colonists.
19. Orthonyx ochrocephala, Gml. Canary, Popokatea. - Perhaps amongst the native avifauna this genus is one of the most puzzling to understand.
popokatea: whitehead, forest bird.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: WHITEHEAD Mohoua albicilla Maori name: Popokatea.

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 252. Mohoua albicilla (Lesson) Whitehead (Popokatea) ... North Island

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Whitehead Mohoua albicilla (LESSON, 1830) ... OTHER NAME: Popokatea.

Source: Notes of a Tour in the England of the Antipodes
Author: WADDINGTON
Quote:
Near [Rotorua],
after a little
climb, a small
plateau was gained
where the `porridge
pot' was continually
on the boil, the mud
is relished by the
natives, but its
appearance was not
tempting to us.
... porridge pots [frequently passim]

He generally sees
the whitehead, the
Maori's popokotea,
when he visits the
bush behind Day's
Bay.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Popero, Lindsay. Solanum aviculare.

Author: CHEESEMAN
Quote: [ Solanum aviculare, Forst.] Poporo; Poroporo; Kohoho . Also common in many parts of Australia ... The fruit is edible, and was made into jam by the early colonists.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ZOSTEROPS LATERALIS {CAERULESCENS}. (THE SILVER-EYE.) .. Native names. Tau-hou, {Whiorangi, Hiraka, Motingitingi,} Kanohi-mowhiti, Karu-patene, {Karu-ringi,} Karu-hiriwha, Poporohe, and Iringatau.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
The natives
distinguish the bird
as Tau-hou (which
means stranger), or
Kanohi-mowhiti
(which may be
interpreted as
spectacle-eye or
ring-eye). It is
also called Poporoke
[check = poporohe]
and Iringatu, names
suggested by its
accidental or
periodical
occurrence.

In the centre [of
the beautiful table
top] is a group of
birds, the tui and
the yellow and white
beaked popotea, and
puriri, berries and
flowers.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ORTHONYX ALBICILLA {CLITONYX ALBICAPILLA}. (The WHITE-HEAD.) ... Native names. Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea. Ibid. 103 ORTHONYX {CLITONYX} OCHROCEPHALA. (The YELLOW-HEAD.) ... Native names. The same [Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea] as those applied to the preceding species [White-head]: `Canary' of the colonists. Ibid. 2/224 The Popo or Popotea (Orthonyx albicilla) is a little brown bird with a white head, which sings like a chaffinch, and principally lives about rata trees. We see them not infrequently.

He considered that
`poppers' (a small
boring machine)
should be abolished
altogether as they
caused dust. [in the
coal mines].

Author: HYDE
Quote: The air beat and shimmered with sound . . . [sic] the poppers, eating with their thin blue tongues into rock ... Ibid. 186 The air [in the hydro tunnel] was filled with a ceaseless roar of air-compressors, poppers, and the biggest air-picks they had ever seen, all new machinery ... As the men's hands steadied the poppers (the tongues of flame eating into rotten sandstone ...), you could watch their taut arms vibrate, their bodies tremble.

Author: McARA
Quote:
It was not until
considerably later
that the `swing
type' stoper with
its
pneumatic-feed-leg
for drilling uppers,
and known as the
`popper', came into
use. In it the drill
was rotated in the
hole by swinging the
machine handle
backwards and
forwards. At first
the miners did not
like it, as they
considered it `shook
up' the roof too
much, causing falls
of ground, but it
was light and easily
transportable and
was fast in good
ground. It remained
in use in the stopes
for many years,
until the much later
introduction of the
rotary stoper. At
one stage the popper
was given the rather
undeserved name of
the `widow-maker'.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
For the first time
in my life I saw,
and heard, pneumatic
drills at work. They
were referred to as
`poppers'.

The miners at
Blackwater have
refused to work the
popper, and only
surface hands are
now at work.

In theory the rock
drill which figures
so prominently in
the dispute at
Reefton is a Waugh,
but in practice it
is a "popper." It is
worked by compressed
air, and a hammer,
stirking 500 blows a
minute, pops like a
Maxim gun on the
quartz overhead.
Hence the name
"popper."

Sir Arthur Guinness
interviewed the
Prime Minister this
morning, and urged
him to appoint a
Royal Commission to
enquire and report
whether the "popper"
drill could with
safety, and
especially in regard
to the health of the
miners, be worked by
one man.

Source: Tramping in South Island Forest Parks
Quote:
A poppet-head is a
frame at the top of
a shaft which
supports the pulleys
used for hoisting...

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
POPPET HEAD: Fifty-
to sixty-foot high
frame, square
four-foot top,
carrying jenny-wheel
on dredges.
Notes: c1900-1920 A Teamster's Glossary in 1961 Henderson Friends In Chains 188

Quote:
Gold Rush,
1868-1878' There,
`poppet heads,' Big
Pump, deep shaft;/

Author: MAY
Quote:
POPPET HEADS:
cross-pieces of
timber above the
mouth of a shaft on
which rest the axles
of the pulleys used
for winding. At
Ballarat and at Ross
`Poppet Heads'
covered the whole
erection at the
mouth of a deep
shaft.
poppy, field [s] Papaver rhoeas L.
horned poppy [s] Glaucium flavum Crantz Ibid. 60 poppy, horned [s] Glaucium flavum Crantz
poppy, long-headed [s] Papaver dubium L.
poppy, Mexican [s] Argemone ochroleuca Sweet
poppy, opium [s] Papaver somniferum L
poppy, prickly-headed [s] Papaver hybridum L.
poppy, water [s] Hydrocleis nymphaeoides (H. & B.) Buchen. Ibid. 84 water poppy [s] Hydrocleis nymphaeoides (H.& B.) Buchen.

When I was a child,
a well-used term for
any female
accidentally showing
too much underwear
was "poppy show" -
just saying the two
words ensured a
rapid hitching of
petticoat or
smoothing of rumpled
skirts.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
For example, when a
girl's dress blows
in the air, boys
will claim they have
seen a `poppy show'.
This is a widespread
term.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Pin dips were also
another popular
amusement. `A pin or
a bull or a button,
To see a rary rary
show show show!'
(1875; Tahataki). A
piece of glass
backed by cardboard
was covered with a
piece of paper that
could be flicked up
to show the `rary
rary show' or had a
slit in it through
which one could
peep. One saw
through the glass a
variety of colors,
pieces of colored
paper, flower
petals, pictures,
and later pieces off
cigarette boxes.
Sometimes these had
been arranged in
some pattern, at
other times they
were kaleidoscopic
only, and the
perceiver had
himself to add the
configurations of
intelligibility. The
price for the view
was always a pin
`which we did not
want anyhow but
always accepted,' a
relic from an age
when such things
were rare. Pin dips
were known also as
`poppy shows'
(perhaps it was the
similar flash of
color that gave the
same name - `the
poppy show' - to the
exciting experience
of seeing a girl's
dress blown upward
by the wind; pins
were not charged for
flowers of this
sort). In fact, the
pin dip or the prick
book may have
developed from the
poppy show. The
poppy show was
common before 1900
and the prick book
after that date, a
fact connected with
the ever-increasing
stock of picture
cards and magazine
pictures available
to children.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
The poppy shows with
the Robertson tart
in the pine
plantation behind
the hospital ... .

Unfair, you say? A
bit of uncharitable
stroppy-poppy-chopping?

Because no one since
Mark Inglis and Phil
Doole had survived
so many days at such
high altitude, the
crew believed they
were probably
looking for bodies,
or "popsicles", as
black-humoured
mountaineers refer
to fatalities.

Author: McGILL
Quote: pork chop, phr. like a pork chop in a synagogue inappropriate or ill at ease; eg `That umpire's about as popular with the Kiwis as a pork chop in a synagogue.' NZA.

Author: FAIRBURN
Quote:
I'm going to be as
popular as shit at a
nightmen's picnic if
it ever gets into
print intact.

Author: McGILL
Quote: popular as shit at a nightmen's picnic unpopular; A.R.D. Fairburn Letters, 1981

He said it would
result in "tribal
infighting at its
worst" as the
populationists and
coastliners kept
squaring off.

Pora is an
introduced vegetable
run wild. The word
`pora' means a ship.
The plant flourished
up the rivers, and
the first settlers
called it `Maori
cabbage'. The lists
also call it
Pora-kawa-kawa, but
this is amalgamating
two names, for the
kawakawa is another
vegetable run wild.
Notes: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 65

Quote:
For vegetables there
was plenty of pora,
the Maori turnip,
and puwha (rauriki)
or sowthistle.

Author: BEST
Quote:
The other plant
looked for by
travellers along
certain Maori routes
in the interior of
Otago was the pora.

Author: BEST
Quote:
Regarding the kumara
and the pora; these
were prized food
plants grown by my
ancestors in olden
times .. They
possessed the pora
long before
Europeans reached
this land .. The
pora mentioned by
Tikao is evidently a
turnip, and was
probably obtained
from early European
voyagers at Queen
Charlotte Sound.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: Por|ae, s. A fish so called.

CHILODACTYLUS
DOUGLASII. ...
Native name - Porae.

Author: HAY
Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). Ibid. 2/231 We prefer the substantial schnapper, the goodly whapuka or kanae, or the luscious poraki. [ceck transcr. if use:?= porahi = porae]

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: PORAE (Chilodactylus Douglasii).
Its nearest allies amongst New Zealand fish are Cheilodactylus macropterus (the tarakihi) and Douglasi (the porae).

DACTYLOSPARUS [Dactylopagrus 1922 ibid V/92] DOUGLASII (Hector). Porae. Secured up to 40 fathoms among tarakihi. Uncommon at Russell, but more plentiful in Hauraki Gulf ... Distribution: Unknown south of Bay of Plenty.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Cheilodactylus douglasii Hector. PORAE.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Porae Nemadactylus douglasii (Hector)
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 407

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Porae .. .. porae .. .. Cheilodactylus douglasi

Author: MORELAND
Quote: PORAE [Cheilodactylus douglasi ] ... known as morwong in Australia.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: PORAE ... Other names: Cheilodactylus douglasi ; morwong (Australia).

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: Family CHEILODACTYLIDAE. The tarakihi,Dactylopagrus macropterus ... is commonest south of East Cape; the porae, Cheilodactylus douglasii .. is greenish-grey above and commonest north of Cook Strait;

Author: SORENSON
Quote: TARAKIHI (a) Scientific name: Cheilodactylus macropterus. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Tarakihi. (c) Other common names: Tiki (Kaikoura); Porae (Cheilodactylus douglasi ) is normally lumped with Tarakihi and is known as Morwong in Australia and also as Sea Bream. (d) Principal localities where taken: [all except far south]

Author: WILSON
Quote:
PORAE A big, green,
delicious inhabitant
of our warmer waters
found in a variety
of habitats from
surf-beaches to
rocky depths of up
to 500 feet.
porae n. NZ fish similar to tarakihi. [M]

Author: PAUL
Quote: Porae Nemadactylus douglasi Also occurs off southern Australia, where it is known as the grey morwong. ... Most common along the north-east coast, straggling south to Cook Strait.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] porae .. [scientific name] Nemadactylus douglasi .. [other name(s)] morwong

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293] porae
1568, 1601
PORAE (Morwong) Nemadactylus douglasi Cheilodactylus douglasi ... [242] In Australia this species is known as the morwong or douglas morwong ...

Author: IHIMAERA & LONG
Quote:
My Nanny, she used
to be all right
once. She never used
to be porangi all
the time.

Harry McIntosh,..
some time known to
Wellingtonians as
'Porangi' has left
Australia.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote: P|orangi, a. Hasty.

DoC goes porangi
[heading]

We had words you
didn't find in the
dictionary but which
we all used:
"porangi", "whare",
"taihoa".
porangi, out of one's mind; mad: other meanings, but this is the one intended when used by the Pakeha, generally in an abusive way.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
... porangi or
foolish

The bearer is
porangi to get off
and makes me almost
raruraru by his
impatience.

Author: MOSER
Quote:
The majority ... did
not appear to pay
much attention, [one
observing] ... that
the koroheka (old
man) was `porangi'
(foolish) ...

Author: GRACE
Quote:
He said he was a
prophet and that we
must go back. At
first I thought he
was a Hauhau; but,
when I came up to
some other Maoris,
they told me that he
was porangi (mad).
Notes: 1867 Dec 18 T.S.Grace Journal in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 167

Author: DOMETT
Quote: `'Twas nothing - he was not to mind her - she / Was foolish - was `porangi- and would / be Better directly - and her tears she dried.'

A man who told such
marvellous stories
that he was deemed
to be porangi or
insane

Author: DOMETT
Quote: 'Twas nothing - he was not to mind her - she/ Was foolish - was `porangi' - and would be/ Better directly

All the witnesses on
one side declare the
testatrix was
`porangi' (mad). The
other side say she
was a `tohunga' and
a prophet and had
gifts of healing ...

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Porangi, adj. Maori word for sad, sorry, or sick; cranky.

He t'e plurry
Porangi, I t'ink.

Author: EADDY
Quote:
(Northland `pidgin')
Te Maori, he can't
get to sreep. Bruddy
well porangi.

out of one's mind;
mad: other meanings,
but this is the one
intended when used
by the Pakeha,
generally in an
abusive way.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote:
He's porangi, that
fellow, sick in the
head

Author: McCALLUM
Quote:
If you mention these
things to a pakeha
wahine she think you
are porangi.

Some people called
my nanny crazy,
porangi.

Author: BAKER
Quote: We slipped into the easy way of calling a person porangi instead of crazy or stupid.
porangi; out of one's mind, mad: other meanings but this is the one intended when used by the Pakeha, generally in an abusive way.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Porangi. (extremely) eccentric, crazy; (very) stupid: New Zealand coll.: late C. 19-20. B., 1941. Adoption of Maori word.
porangi adj. out of one's mind, mad [Maori].
porangi adj. N.Z. inf. crazy; mad. [< Maori]

The class was in
fits. The teacher
marched him off to
the headmaster where
Patu did his porangi
act again.

Author: MITCALFE
Quote:
He would ... give
Winston a shout,
telling him to shut
up, don'y be so
porangi. [fn]
porangi: mad

Author: MITCALFE
Quote:
He would ... give
Winston a shout,
telling him to shut
up, don'y be so
porangi. [fn]
porangi: mad

Author: McGILL
Quote: porangi mad, eccentric, stupid; eg `Hey, there's a joker in the public bar's gone completely porangi.' Maori adopted colloquialism late C19.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
`Hey, you gone
porangi?' asked
Tuku, taking a firm
grip of the business
end of his suntan.

Rawiri Taonui, the
expedition leader,
says all along the
way Maori families
and marae gave the
team help and
hospitality ... but
maybe wondered if
they were porangi.

Author: EDWARDS
Quote:
I decide to tone
down a bit because
maybethey think I am
porangi!

Their reception has
been variable; with
the kingites, it has
been very hearty;
but with others they
are looked upon as a
lot of idle fools,
"Nui Nui Mungarie
and Porangi," who
would do much better
by staying at home,
cultivating the
soil, and looking
after their stock,
than wasting their
time in gossiping
expeditions over the
country.

The natives called
him a "porangi," or
talkat[i]ve babbler.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: `The combatants ... took especial pains to tell us that it was no fault of ours, but the porangi or `foolishness' of the Maori.'Ibid. vol. ii. p. 238. -->`Watanui said E Ahu was porangi, `a fool.''

During the debate
... I frequently
heard him called by
leading men as Hori
te Waru, Wiremu
Tamihana etc. etc.,
`a porangi'.

Author: BAXTER
Quote: porangi mad; madman

porangi n. foolishness; silliness;-a. silly; crazy; cranky. [Maori]

On the Occurrence of Lamna cornubica , Porbeagle Shark, Flem., the Mako of the Maoris, in New Zealand.
Porbeagle shark (Lamna cornubica )
Lamna nasus Bonnaterre. ... The porbeagle-shark.

Synonyms: Squalus nasus; Squalus cornubicus; Lamna cornubica; Isurus cornubicus; Isurus nasus. There is only one published notice of the occurrence of the porbeagle, Lamna nasus , on New Zealand coasts ...

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote: Three sharks built for speed are the Mako, the Porbeagle and the Great White Shark. ... The Porbeagle (Lamna nasus ) has long sharp teeth, each with a small cusp at the base on either side; the Mako (Isurus glaucus ) has teeth of similar shape without the cusps, and the Great White Shark (Carcharodon carcharias ) has large triangular teeth with serrated edges.
Notes: Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury

Quote: New Zealand porbeagle shark, Lamna whitleyi.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: The porbeagle [Lamma Whitleyi Phillips] is often called the Mackerel Shark on account of its habit of devouring so many Mackerel. It is sometimes erroneously called Mako Shark, but when the two species are seen the difference is most apparent.

Author: WILSON
Quote: PORBEAGLE SHARK Lamna nasus: A swife-swimming shark similar in appearance to the mako, but not rated highly by game fishermen as it lacks the mako's superb fighting qualities. Also known as Beaumaris-shark and Mackerel-shark. Prominent in New Zealand, particularly in Cook Strait. and pelagic shark of cool to temperate waters.
Lamna nasus (Bonnaterre). Porbeagle shark (moki shark).

flavour of his songs

Author: IRELAND
Quote:
The old men, smoking
on their porches /
squint like experts
/ down the barrel of
the bay.

Author: ASHFORD

In houses with more
than one verandah,
the verandahs - now
called porches -
adopted specialised
functions, with

entry porch, sun
porch, sleeping

A small tea table
for the porch is
indispensable, as

chairs, a goodly
supply of cushions,
and if possible a
good hammock.

Barracouta,/
Sergeants of the
under - deep?/
Porcupines like
sleepy mayors/ With
poison in their
spikes?

I was visited by a
porcupine fish,
which kept sticking
its quills up and
bobbing in front of
my helmet.

Mr. C. Coomber, of
the Taranaki Hotel,
picked up a
porcupine fish,
about two feet long,

Huatoke River.

Quote: Hymenanthera alpina PORCUPINE SHRUB ... Rigid shrub with short, stout, whitish or grey branchlets.

Typical of the sites
he surveyed was
Macraes Flat, where,
in 1986, he noted
that porcupine
shrubs, snowberry
plants and pohuehue
vines were stripped
of all their ripe
fruit where they
grew on outcrops
inhabited by grand
skinks, while plants
on nearby outcrops
without skinks were
untouched.

Ibid. 62 {1888 2nd edn 1/142} PLATYCERCUS AURICEPS. (YELLOW-FRONTED PARRAKEET.) ... Native names. PORGIES 1455-73
p - caterpillar

Author: COWLEY
Quote:
Night insects
orbited the bulb on
the end of the
working lead, midges
and flying beetles,
fat porina moths.
The true grass grub, Odontria zealandica, occurs in association with the subterranean grass caterpillar, Oxycanus cervinata (formerly called Porina) ...

Author: LEVY
Quote:
It is a fascinating
concept to envisage
the control of weeds
and insects - grass
grub, porina, ...
porina or porina grub n -s [NL] : a subterranean caterpillar destructive to turf in New Zealand

While porina larvae
are still too small
to be seen easily by
the naked eye at
this stage, [he]
believes they will
become a problem
later in the year

The depredations of the subterranean grass caterpillar [Oxycanus sp.] in the rye-grass and clover pastures, particularly in ... the east coast of the South Island, have been recognized for some years as demanding control measures. The damage ... is probably only second in importance to that done by the true `grass grub,' Odontria zealandica. Until recently, practically all damage done to pasture was attributed to Odontria, [310] and only recently have farmers commenced to distinguish between the two pests, and to refer to [Oxycanus] as `grass caterpillar,' or`Porina caterpillar.' It is unfortunate that the generic name Porina, which was coming into general use, must now be changed to Oxycanus, since the name Porina is preoccupied as a molluscan genus.

Hence the renowned
vegetable
caterpillar is
nothing more than a
larva of Porina
enysii, which has
been attacked and
killed by the
parasitic fungus
known as Cordiceps
robertsii.

I heard someone say
that they were
beginning to see
traces of the Porina
cervinata grub in a
grass paddock or two
on the plain.

The writer .. does
not accept Mr.
Hudson's view that
it is the larva of
Porina mairi,
Buller, which is a
very rare moth,
whereas the
"vegetable
caterpillar" is
extemely common in
certain localities.
The true host has,
he considers, not
yet been identified.

.. but Mr. Philpott
has at last found
that in parts of the
South Island, at all
events, the larva of
the butterfly Porina
dinodes is selected
by the fatal fungus
as its "host."

The Porina moth
makes its first
appearance in early
October ...

Porina.. and grass
grub are a serious
hindrance.

Follow carefully
advice of Research
Centres and
Department of
Agriculture in
combating Grass Grub
and Porina
Caterpillar ...

Porina caterpillars
become more
difficult to control
as they mature.

Porina strikes when
pasture is most
needed. The surest
way of checking for
porina is soil
sampling to a full
spade's depth at
different sites in
the pasture.

Source: Grasslands Range of Forage and Conservation Plants
Quote:
Major pests are
grass grub, porina
and Argentine stem
weevil.
[subterranean
caterpillar]

"The so-called
'vegetable
caterpillar'
(infested with the
sphoerid [sic]
fungus) is, I think,
very probably the
lava [sic] of this
insect (Porina
mairi). .."

Author: GILLESPIE
Quote: The ones attracting most attention were the owlet moths, the caterpillars of which destroyed the first pastures and cereal and root crops. There were also porina moths (Oxycanus spp.) whose caterpillars also destroyed pastures; the bag moth (Oeceticus omnivorus) which left cigar-shaped cocoons hanging from shrubs and tree [sic]; and the ghost-like white moth ... of the flax grub (Orthoclydon praefectata) which eats longitudinal slits on the surface of [flax] leaves ...

One of the most destructive pests in New Zealand is the grass-grub or brown beetle (Odontria zealandica). This insect, together with the caterpillar of the Porina moth, has been responsible for the destruction of ... crops.

PORIRO. - Of unknown
origin, not in
Debrett's. The
English form is used
as an expletive or
term of endearment,
as the occasion
demands.

In the late 1930s,
when Ngaere and Rita
began nursing at
Porirua Mental
Hospital (originally
called Porirua
Lunatic Asylum).

Madness was there,
sure, on every
street. But mad
people were "sent to
Porirua".

Porirua -
universally
pronounced Porarua
back then - meant
only one thing: the
loony bin, the
nut-house, the place
where mad people
were locked away,
the place where, if
you weren't good,
you might wind up
yourself. They might
even come and get
you and drag you
there screaming if
you didn't look out.

To generations of
New Zealanders,
Porirua meant - in
the politically
incorrect language
of the time - the
loony bin.

I probably won't
still be living in
Porirua, but I'll
still be a hard-out
Poriruvian.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Pork and Beans. The New Zealanders called them Pork and Cheese.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
The Portugese or
`Pork and Cheese'
camp [at Sling]

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: [at Pork and Beans] The New Zealanders called them Pork and Cheese.

The Natives subsist
on the food we have
brought them, pork
and potatoes; and
till we came, they
wandered over a fair
portion of the
earth, without
knowing the use of
it.

As there are plenty
of settlements to be
passed on the road,
and no lack of pork
and potates, I do
not anticipate they
will arrive at their
destination before
the end of the week.

Once or twice they
had taken up the
pork and potatoes
from the native
ovens and had found
them nearly raw.

Groceries: Am living
on wild pork and
potatoes, instead,
thank God.

On the same day
(Friday) our forces,
minus the Arawas,
proceeded on to the
next village, which
they found deserted,
destroyed the
village, captured
several pigs and
took them to camp,
and had a sumptuous
repast of pork and
potatoes.

These men through
bad food and bad
water were all down
at one time with
fever; so sick were
some of them that
they could not dress
themselves, aad
[sic] all the food
they could get was
Maori pork and
potatoes.

In those days GBP5
was the price of a
bag of flour, which
was then looked upon
as a delicacy, pork
and potatoes being
the chief and often
only food available.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
Very light winds
almost becalmed ...
our fare [on the
schooner] very
ordinary tea pork
and potatoes for
breakfast, dinner
and supper.

Author: MATHEW
Quote:
After taking some
dinner - the usual
New Zealand fare,
pork and potatoes -
we left on our
return in Fairburn's
boat, ...
Notes: 1840 Feb 26 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 63

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
... had he not
brought his own it
could only have been
the hospitality of
pork and potatoes
that we could have
offered, for as yet
we were destitute of
any more civilized
supplies.

The everlasting pork
and potatoes of the
Maori are giving
place to the fine,
fat, full-flavoured
beef and mutton of
Old England.

Ex barque "Eleanor"
and other late
arrivals. Five tons
fresh colonial
flour, White and
brown sugar in mats,
coffee, Black and
green tea, tobacco
in 200 lb. kegs,
Blankets, loaf
sugar, piece goods,
New Zealand pork and
potatoes ...

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
One's appetite here
.. is always like a
raging lion, going
about seeking what
it may devour, and
finding generally
pork and potates.

Our pork and puha
boil-up is almost in
this category.

The biggest
challenge has been
getting the taste of
pork and puha and
fried food out of
his mouth.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
What do we eat [in
the Northland bush
in the late 19
century]? Is it the
usual pigeons and
potatoes? Is it the
pickled pork and
puha? Is it even the
dumplings with
golden syrup?

Author: FRANCIS
Quote: `When this big bloke, the young chap's stepfather, got up in court, you could almost taste the puha and pork.'

Author: STEAD
Quote:
But before the pork
and puha, the
mussels and pipi and
kumara and pumpkin
were out on plates,
beer was being
dispensed.

It's clumsy in
places, preachy in
others, a real stew
of a book, mixing
pork bones and puha
with polemic and
poetry...

Author: Ihimaera
Quote:
'I'll bring our
dinner in soon. It's
pork bones and
puha.' As it turned
out dinner was
actually a mussel
bisque, followed by
swordfish steaks...

The programmers at
Ruia Mai are an
eclectic bunch; you
can catch sleek
soul, rap, dance,
pop, hip-hop and
pork-and-puha Maori
traditional,
complete with
strummy guitars and
large groups of
mommas banging out
the choruses.

Whether it's an
Irish stew, a
delicious French
pot-au-feu, or an
old-fashioned Kiwi
pork and puha, a
boil-up will satisfy
winter appetites.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
There would be kiwi
and pigeon, wild
duck and trout, pork
and puha, potatoes
and kumara - a great
feast, with plum
pudding to follow.

The boil-up is
perhaps better known
to Pakeha as pork
bones and puha,
though as Mr
Tamihere recounts
it, the meat could
be anything from a
leg of mutton to
beef brisket (other
Maori tell me
sausages are also
common) while the
green vegetables
might be cabbage or
silverbeet, grown in
their back garden.

Author: McNAB
Quote: In February, 1840, a Mr. Walter Brodie chartered the schooner Hope, and proceeded ... to Chatham Island to farm there two pork stations.

Author: McGILL
Quote: pork sword penis; eg `Exercise the old pork sword last night, did you, Batesy?' NZA and US.

Source: Speech and Idiom of Maori Children
Author: ANDERSON & AITKEN
Quote: Terms such as `moo-cow' and `baa-lamb' were not encountered once [among Maori schoolchildren]. In the light of this, it is interesting to note the common form `pork' or `Porky' for `pig'. This occurs several times and in contexts which would not lead one to suspect baby talk of any kind; We just about got some pork. This usage refers not to the meat, but to the living animals, and against this usage the form `pig' occurs only once. Ibid 105 Please, it's a porky. I'm a pork ... When they use [`pig'] themselves it tends to be only in derogatorative [sic] contexts; Get out of my sight, you dirty pig!

Author: WODZICKI
Quote:
Quoting? Angus 1847
Savage Life and
Scenes. At that time
there were parties
of men called
`pork-traders'. They
used to go up the
rivers and procure
pigs from the
natives in order to
sell pork, either to
people in the pakeha
settlements or to
captains of whalers
and trading vessels.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
It is to be observed
that 20 poles of
good ground, well
cultivated, will
yield a greater
quantity of
vegetables than can
be economically used
by a labourer, his
wife, and three or
four children; in
which case the
overplus must either
be sold or employed
in fattening a
porker and a
baconer.

Author: POLACK
Quote: The puorka (so pronounced for pork or pig) is especially well acclimated to the country; ...

During the day we
killed many pigs and
at length so
satiated were our
party [of Mauries]
that they cruelly
murdered the
wretched porkers
only taking their
hearts and livers.

Author: POWER
Quote:
... long-legged,
bumptious, Irish
porker. ... If a
Maori porker objects
to go into a canoe,
he is not forthwith
kicked and punched
... but he is
coaxed, and patted,
...

The Maori word poaka, for pig, was probably given them by the Tahitian interpreter, Tupaea, who was with Captain Cook when he gave the New-Zealanders their first pigs. Had the Englishmen given a word they would probably have said `pig,' not `porker,' and the Maoris would have called the animals piki.

Author: VOGEL
Quote: The Maori Porker

Author: SMYTH
Quote:
The dogs were
holding a `porker'
somewhere

Author: EADDY
Quote: How far to go for the wild porker [to a Maori in Northland. His Maoris use te porker frequently in Maori English.]

Author: HUNT
Quote:
`Captain Cookers',
with sharp snouts
and formidable
tusks, waged
constant war with a
group of dogs ...
that rushed towards
... food thrown out
on to the open
spaces [of the pa].
Running from place
to place, the
half-grown porkers
led a precarious
life ...

Author: BOSWELL
Quote:
... when the boys
had leisure to go
hunting, it would be
a joint of tender
young wild porker;

Three little porkers
...

"'Twas in the good
old days of yore /
That Waimate porkers
abounded; / But 'tis
my belief, they've
all come to grief, /
And this is what
makes me confounded
..."

Pigs: 29 yarded, all
sold under hammer at
exceptionally good
prices: 2 weaners
18s 3d, 2 porkers
25s ...

For Sale .. Porkers
(delivered if
required at
Slaughter House).

But Sonny had
already gone,
charging through the
brush, the ti-tree
slapping and
stinging at his
face, his hands on
the hocks and his
head between the
haunches of a
Captain Cooker,
almost as long as he
was, five-foot-five.
He'll be a tough
porker, this one,
Sonny was thinking,
but smoke him in
manuka and he'll
keep the hui going
for a day or two.

Author: CARR
Quote:
He had a hunk of
wood in his hand and
a pocket knife - the
wood to hit it over
the head and the
pocket-knife to
bleed it once it was
down. Only it wasn't
a 50 pound porker,
but a very angry
full-grown boar
which at that moment
left the dogs and
came galloping up
the hill.

There were numbers
of wild porkers, all
young and fat
fern-rooters ...

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol II
Author: TAIT
Quote:
Wild pigs have been
troublesome in the
past, and will
possibly need the
attention of amateur
hunters for many
years, since the
mountainous country
close to the Urewera
forests remains one
of the porkers' best
breeding grounds.

Author: DAVIS
Quote:
"You need a pig dog
for the porkers.."

Their hearts will go
out to Alex when
they read that
Enrico, his computer
cob, has become
besotted with porn
instead of healthy
doses of traditional
corn. And has Enrico
added a new word to
our language -
pornucopia?

Author: SHERRIN
Quote:
The Natives say the
whitebait is the
spawn of the mohi,
which may be the
Maori name for the
smelt. The Maori
name for whitebait
is porohe.

porokaiwhiri, a tree (Hedycarya arborea), pigeon-wood.

porokaiwhiria n -s [Maori porokaiwhiri] : a small or shrubby New Zealand tree (Hedycarya arborea) of the family Monimiaceae with opposite short-petioled leaves and inconspicuous flowers in axillary panicles followed by bright red drupes

pigeonwood
(hedycarya [sic]

freely around
Wellington and

lower east coast of

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Hedycarya arborea [(The Pigeon Wood)] ... Maori name Porokaiwhiria or Poporo-kaiwhiri.

(from the Australasian) .. The yellow clusters of the spreading dark-leaved pura-pura .. the little fiery branches of the red porokaiwhiria; the rich luscious berries of the kotukutuku, or giant fucshia, whose flowers hang side by side with ripe fruit, and unopened buds. All these, and many another fruit of the woods, fell upon the warrior's path, and allayed their hunger.

Author: ALLOM
Quote: The pura-pura berry is another fruit much prized by the natives. ... The pura-pura is beginning to be highly esteemed for preserving.

To add to [the

eating in the season

Even in the North
Island the average

people see it as a

a gothic weedy look

flowers are

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
... bura bura ...
beads of berries

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Poraporo [sic] -
berry, fruit

Poroporo (solanum
aviculare) leaves
were used by Mother
Aubert to relieve
"itch" and Maori
also used them on
bruises and skin
infections, and used
the soot from burned
leaves for tattoo
colouring.

The tieke glides to
a branch, then
bounds through the
poroporo shrubbery
like a fast-forward
version of its
larger cousin, the
kokako.

Author: HUDSON
Quote: Solanum aviculare (Poro-poro, or Potato Plant). A shrub with very dark green pointed leaves, purple underneath, and bright purple flowers resembling those of the potato.

Poroporo is a
common, leafy
soft-wooded shrub
that grows
throughout New
Zealand. It is
quickly growing
colonising plant,
reaching a height of
three metres (ideal
for native bush
revegetation sites)
and grows on the
edge of coastal and
lowland forests and
along road edges and
clearings. ...
Reputedly having a
mild acidic taste
similar to the cape
gooseberry, poroporo
was cultivated and
eaten by Maori and
early European
colonists who made
jam from it.

When transmitters
attached to two
kererū were
tracked to a patch
of poroporo, the
remains of six more
kererū were
found.

But there were
sweetly innocent
letters, too, from..
Kate of
Christchurch, who
wrote of the thrush
that perched in the
poroporo to inspect
the ripening berries
in late March...

Author: Crowe
Quote:
The fruits of the
local poroporo taste
like something
between a sweet date
and a tomato and
were an important
food of Maori...

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: SOLANUM LACINIATUM. Poroporo (bullibul) is a soft-wooded shrub ... Two species are called by one Maori name. Two Latin names, S. laciniatum and S. aviculare, are both more than a hundred years old but it was only in 1954 that Baylis defined clearly the difference between the two species and then the two names came into general use.
poroporo [s] Solanum aviculare Forst.f. Solanum laciniatum Ait.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Poroporo, n. Maori name for the flowering shrub Solanum aviculare, Forst., called in Australia, Kangaroo Apple. Corrupted into Bully-bul (q.v.).

Poraporo [sic] -
berry, fruit

Quote:

sight behind the
pura puras - `Cassy'
in a kit slung over

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
The poroporo, the
nicest or least

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Poroporo, Col[enso]. Solanum aviculare and nigrum.

As a cataplasm for ulcers they used the leaves of the kohoho or poroporo (Solanum aviculare ) - and for wounds ... they used ... also the hune, or pappus down of the large Bulrush, but merely as a protection against dust, etc.
Notes: Colenso(On the Botany of the North Island) in 1981 Brooker et al. NZ Medicinal Plants

Quote:
Poroporo. Solanum
aviculare, Forst.

The berry of the Kohutuhutu, or Kotukutuku (Fuchsia excorticata); the Kohoho, or Poroporo, (Solanum aviculare ), which ... was sometimes planted ... Also, the cooked leaves and herbaceous tops of [32] the Toi (Barbarea Australis), and of the Poroporo, or Raupeti (Solanum nigrum); and the baked inner stems and sago-like pith of the large black fern tree, Korau, or Mamaku (Cyathea medullaris).

Soft aromatic pepper-spikes were seen;/ Potato-apples of the Solanum aviculare tall/ Rich-mellowing from their crude lip-burning green;/ Ibid. 2/337 Poro poro (potatoe, apples of) ..... O. Solaneae; G. Solanum; S. S. aviculare and S. nigrum. `Berry ovoid, edible, one to one and a half inches long; three-quarters of an inch thick. Sweet and rather richly flavoured when quite ripe.

Quote: [Solanum aviculare, Forst.] Poporo; Poroporo; Kohoho. Also common in many parts of Australia ... The fruit is edible, and was made into jam by the early colonists.

Notes: c1920s Eliza McKenzie in Outlook in 1975 Knight Poyntzfield 13 [reference 1850s]

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: PORO PORO (Solanum aviculare ), also called bullibull (a corruption of the Maori name), and potato berry. It is found commonly on the bush edge in lowland districts throughout both islands. It is a perennial leafy spreading bush 4 to 8 ft. high,. . .

Author: ANDERSEN
Quote: poroporo, a plant (Solanum aviculare) with beautiful large blue flowers and large orange-coloured berry eaten by boys and birds: often corrupted to bullybul. S. nigrum is raupeti.

Quote:

few; the purapura,

Quote: PIRI PIRI (Aceara ... sanguisorbae). This name is commonly corrupted into [called] bidi bid. In the North Island the plant is called hutiwai or utiwai and by mistake poroporo. It is a native species well known to all New Zealanders, and is a weed chiefly on land in process of being brought into occupation.

Succesful
establishment and
management of the
native poroporo
(Solanum laciniatum
and Solanum
aviculare) in
cultivated blocks
may produce
exportable
quantities of
solasodine, an
alternative to
present steroid raw
materials. Poroporo
is regarded as a
weed in many parts
of New Zealand.

In two year's time
(by 1981)
Solanum..expects to
have 1000 hectares
of poroporo (Solanum
aviculare) under

34 The company spent

...

Author: HINDMARSH
Quote:
A little poroporo
and second growth
had made it a dark
private place ...

"The question must
be asked why, having
been granted that
respect on their
arrival, they could
not be afforded the
dignity of a
poroporoaki or
farewell," she said
in ruling that
mental health worker
Heather Burberry was
dismissed
unjustifiably.

So the conference
ended as it began in
the Maori protocol
of poroporoaki with
the three kaumatua
who attended the
whole symposium
praising the
organisers for their
foresight...

Author: EDMOND
Quote:
He [a Maori friend]
stepped forward and
said a poroporoaki,
a farewell to you
[in your coffin] and
then began to sing.

Ms Bullock was
suspended in July
after speaking to
the media about an
oral warning she was
given for refusing
to stand behind men
at a poroporoaki in
December.

Your Editorial
championing former
probation officer
Josie Bullock's wish
to place her
backside wherever
she wished during a
poroporoaki (Oct 12)
has me puzzled.

I would like to
express my
disappointment at
your decision to
follow the
poroporoaki for my
brother..with a
letter.. suggesting
that [he] had shown
intolerance in
supporting demands
by student leaders
that Paul Dunmore be
brought to account
for his "boycott
Maori blessings"
campaign.

How ridiculous that
MP Turiana Turia
believes in women
being forced to sit
behind men at
powhiri and
poroporoaki.

Tonight is our
poroporoaki to
Auntie Puapua... We
say goodbye to her,
tomorrow...the four
graves will become
five.

[She] complained to
the media..because
she was put in the
degrading position
of being asked to
give up her front
seat to a male at a
poroporoaki, or
farewell, for
prisoners at a
Probation Service
office.

Poroporokaiwhiria.
Hedycarya dentata,
Forst.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pororua, Col[enso]. Sonchus oleraceus.

Pororua. Sonchus
oleraceus, Linn.

... I used to take
seven pieces of
porou rewana or
Maori bread to
school for lunch ...
Notes: 1970 Ihimaera in 1977 N.Z. Listener Short Stories 86

Quote:
Mr. Gould infers
that [the Notornis]
affects low and
humid situations,
marshes, the banks
of rivers, and the
coverts of dripping
ferns, and, like the
Porphyrio, doubtless
enjoys the power of
swimming but would
seem, from the
structure of its
legs, to be more
terrestrial in its
habits than the
members of that
genus.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
[The] native rat
still lingers here
and there [in the
central North
Island], although it
has disappeared on
the coast; the
native dog has
become a mongrel;
ducks, teals, the
red-billed porphyrio
or pukeko, a large
bittern, a tern, two
kinds of gulls,
cormorants ... are
found here.

Author: DOMETT
Quote:
`The crimson-billed
porphyrio, that
jerking struts/
Among the cool thick
rushes.'

Author: DOMETT
Quote: With jetty black and violet blue,/ [274] Of the crimson-billed porphyrio,/

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Porphyrio, n. the
Sultana-bird, or
Sultana. The bird
exists elsewhere. In
Australia it is
generally called the
Swamp-Hen(q.v.).

The takahe is
closely allied to
the pukeko
(Porphyrio), and not
far removed from the
brown woodhen
(Ocydromus), all
these belonging to
the family of Rails,
which usually
frequent more or
less marshy ground,
and in other
countries are able
to fly as well as
other birds.

Scented dried skins
of porphyrio, down
from the albatross'
bosom - / Never had
Pua beheld gifts so
bewildering to see.

On rising in the
morning we found the
lake covered with
waterfowl, among
which were the
beautiful porphyrio,
ducks, and snipes,
and also gulls,
which feed upon a
small fish that
abound in the lake.
Before our guides
returned, I had shot
a great many of the
unweary pukeko, or
porphyrio, which
proved excellent
game.

At this place, along
with the bones of
the Moa and other
extinct birds, were
found those of dogs,
seals, and many
species of birds ..
such as the ..
porphyrio, and
notably the notornis
.. of which as yet
only two living
examples have been
obtained.

Author: HINTZ
Quote:
At times one could
fish the Whanganui
mouth in slippers,
standing dry shod on
the beach and
casting about twenty
yards across the
current, with fish
splashing and
porpoising close
inshore.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote: [From the Australian and New Zealand Gazette 2 April] .. these remains were the right tarso-metatarsal bone of a member of the Penguin family .. and the left humerus of a small cetacean [sic], more nearly resembling that of a common porpoise than that of any other member of the order with which the author had been able to compare it.

They returned with
full loads in the
afternoon, one of
them bringing in a
porpoise, which,
with a good sized
cod in its mouth,
was placed in the
head sheets, and did
duty as an original
description of
figure-head.

The dolphin and
porpoise attain the
age of thirty.

In the Auckland Times of this week we perceive a letter signed "Robert D'Oyley," and written, we presume, by the Attorney of that name, regarding the capture of some porpoises at the Bay of Islands by an [sic] European, which porpoises were, it appears from the said letter, afterwards stolen by a native chief named Teraia.

No porpoises were
seen in the river
during the trip, but
one was heard of.

The Marlborough
Herald says a
visitor to Picton a
few days ago watched
a shoal of porpoises
follow the steamer
Penguin to the
wharf, and their
appearance was the
cause of shoals of
herrings [sic] being
run on shore, where
they continue to be
piled up like so
much sand.

The Marlborough

few days ago watched
a shoal of porpoises
follow the steamer
Penguin to the
wharf, and their
appearance was the
cause of shoals of
herrings [sic] being
run on shore, where

A settler at
Endeavour Bay
observed that the
porpoises were in

fish into the

For Sale ...
Porpoise Harpoons
...

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote:
.. the Captain
seized hold of the
gaft [sic], when
Stephen Potts drew
out a porpoise spear
and held it as if he
was going to strike
the Captain ...

It was described as
having a long beak,
and was probably a
porpoise whale, a
variety which
sometimes attains
the length of 30
feet.

All beaked whales
are rare, and the
porpoise-whale
particularly so.

The porpoise whale ( Berardius arnouxi ) is a large beaked whale separted from its allies by the possession of two pairs of teeth in the lower jaw, but, like all the whales of the family Ziphiidae, functional teeth are not present in the upper jaw.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
porpoise-beagle 154

A.Hogg, Masterton's
M.P., articulates
with a strong
porridge accent, but
he likes a pawky
joke at the expense
of his own
countrymen. `The
Scawtchman,' he told
a big Christchurch
audience, `is a
pur-r-son who keeps
the Sawbath - and
everything else he
can lay his hauns
on.'

The party was next
shown the Maori
Porridge Pot, a
hollow cone raised
four feet above the
level of the ground,
half full of boiling
clay, said to be
edible; a portion
was served out to
all present, but no
one asked for a
second helping, so
there will probably
be plenty left for
future visitors.

ROTORUA, 25th
October.The Porridge
Pot, consisting of
liquid mud, at
Whaka, erupted to a
height of 20ft
to-day. This
phenomenon occurs
only at long
intervals.

Climbing up the side
to see what was
inside, we found a
narrow ledge or
margin all round
encircling a
boiling, spluttering
mass of thick liquid
mud, but for the
colour, reminding me
of a huge boiling
porridge pot.

It is absolutely the
finest film of its
class ever shown
embodying Panorama
of Rotorua. The
Porridge Pot.
Whakarewarewa. The
Valley of the
Geysers. Pohutu at
Play. The Boiling
Cauldron. The
Swimming Pools.
Maoris Cooking in
the Boiling Springs.
The Brain Pot.

Author: KERSHAW
Quote:
`Pretty hot business
in Auckland some
years ago,' said
Mac, ... look [ing]
down on the twenty
extinct porridge
pots.

The porridge
province [Otago]
travelled over the
plains and halted at
Christchurch where
last Saturday they
began their invasion
of northern unions,
and msde a fair
start by drawing
with Canterbury, ...

Telecom's general
manager... said New
Zealand already had
well-functioning
number portability,
where consumers kept
the Telecom number
even if they changed
to TelstraClear or
another carrier and
Telecom had a system
of transferring
(porting)) the call.
Telecom charged the
carrier $17.50 to
set up the change
and 0.5 cents a
minute for any
"ported" call.

There are fat white
cucumbers, known as
Port Albert
cucumbers, which
grow all around the
Kaipara district.
The seeds are said
to have been left
behind by summer
picnickers dining on
cucumber sandwiches.
The cucumber's skin
turns yellow with
age, but the flesh
stays juicy, without
any bitterness.

FOR SALE 2 1/2 TONS

Author: McCLENAGHAN
Quote:
`I got on to Port
Craig cocktails
once' ... He
explained, `You get
a cup, drop in an
egg, add a spoonful
of Worcester sauce,
an egg cup of
methylated spirits,
hold your nose and

Author: MILLER
Quote: They decided to try as a reviver a "Port Craig cocktail", made as follows:: Take a cup - or a round tobacco tin - and drop in one egg. Add one tablespoon of Worcester sauce and one eggcup of methylated spirits. Mix well, hold nose, swallow rapidly. Ibid. 177 The Port Craig cocktail was made and sampled.

Author: FORSTER
Quote: We saw a great Variety of bird this day viz. A white & sooty Albatross Diomedea exulans & palpebrata). The black & sooty Petrel, (Procellaria aequinoctialis & fuliginosa) the black banded Petrel (Procellaria vittata); the small white rumped Petrel (Proc. pelagica) & we saw likewise three times a Port Egmont Hen, which is commonly thought a mark of the vicinity of Land. [ed. fn] The birds listed here are, respectively, the Wandering Albatross; Light-mantled Sooty Albatross; White-chinned Petrel; Great-winged Petrel; Pachyptila spp; Wilson's Storm Petrel and Antarctic Skua.

Pack your `ports'
and hurry up.

Author: E J  WAKEFIELD
Quote:
... relief for the
distressed Port
Nicholsonites.

Shorty after the
first sale of land
in the township,
where sod and thatch
whares were
beginning to spring
up, an old woman, a
recent arrival,
gravely asked a
passer-by to tell
her how long it
would be before the
township was as
large as "Port
Nick," at which he
laughed aloud; but
if things go on
improving as they
have done for the
next few years, the
old woman's question
may not appear so
ridiculous after
all.
Port Nick n. whaling sl. for Port Nicholson, Wellington.

Author: FUSSELL
Quote: Poneka (Port Nick)

Source: Life & Recollections of an Early Colonist
Quote:
Port Nicholson, or
as the sailors like
to call it, `Port
Nick' ....

Hurrah for Port Nic.
Legislation, /
Enkindling the spark
of taxation - / From
Port NIC(k) of all
spots in creation /
We might hope for a
LUCIFER match.

My experience of
Port Nick goes back
to the days of the
Sea Serpent, Esther,
Salopian,
Shepherdess, and
similar craft, also
Cemino's cutter Fly
which were the usual
means of
communication
between coastal
ports.

"The deplorable
state of Port Nick
is now driving the
rag merchants out of
that melancholy city
with their swags on
their backs, and one
lucky one has had
the good fortune to
find out poor
insignificant
Blenheim - a place
unknown to
Wellington in its
palmy days, but soon
found out when
wanting a helping
hand to lift it out
of the mire into

POSIFoods, described.. as Star Trek-style technology, was launched last month. The name related to a new consumer-food category called "point-of-sale individualised foods". In much the same way that consumers could have their coffee flavoured in a complex range of strengths, flavours and styles, the POSIFood system could alter the formula of snack foods to suit health needs depending on a person's age, weight or physical condition.

Author: BACON
Quote: possum-The Australian marsupial introduced in the early days (in 1858, 1870, 1895) as a means of fostering a fur trade, but now one of New Zealand's greatest pests. Not to be confused with the American opposum which is carnivorous, the Australian possum is vegetarian.

of his staff of

postwomen. This is a
slang term,
derogatory and
discourteous, like
the term `cop' for
police officer,
`cockie' for farmer,
and `rag' for
newspapers. He
should be asked to
apologize to these
diligent people who
work on Saturdays
when most other
workers enjoy this
day off duty, and
when speaking about
his staff should in
future refer to them
by thier correct and
proper designation,
postmen and
postwomen. GEORGE H.
DAVIS. New Plymouth.

Like the Cuckoos in

before rainy weather

early settlers
`Potato-birds', as
they invariably came
on the scene as the
potato-planting was
going on; similarly,
in the North Island
they got the name of
`Kumara-birds'.

In many parts of

they [long-tailed

potato birds by the

Here and there

Author: BREMNER
Quote: Potstick wooden pole 6 feet long and 2 inches thick, used to stir and lift wool during the wash. Ibid. 17 The potstick woolwashers were the industry's founders. Ibid. A hot soak preceded the cold-water wash, and in the Medieval manner a strong arm wielded the six-foot potstick or the sluice fork stirring and lifting sodden wool. Scouring machines were a remote dream. Ibid. 34 Even in the mid-1960s, recalls Brian Redding, the present owner , `they were potsticking slipe wool from the fellmongery; via a wooden chute, water went into a box with a mesh base and a fellow stirred [35] the wool with a stick!'

and swished around

washboxes ... [pot
stick]
