Author: TURNER
Quote: The words pottle, punnet and chip are all used for a container for strawberries and investigation of the regional distribution of these words might be of interest ...

Author: LELAND
Quote: pottle: The South Island term for a SMALL CONTAINER. Originally applied to the little wooden boxes in which berry fruit was sold, it then transferred to the plastic boxes which replaced them. A further extension of the term applied it to small plastic containers of yoghurt and sour cream. (see: punnet, chip)
pottle n. NZ open cardboard or plastic container in which potato chips etc. are sold; closed container (for yoghurt).

Many people here in
the South Island,
where the best
strawberries are
grown, refer to a
small strawberry
container as a
pottle. On the June
29 programme one of
the teams gave the
answer `pottle' to a
question about what
small strawberry
containers were
called, and were
then penalised for a
wrong answer. Their
puzzled expressions
were quite
understandable to
anyone living south
of Cook Strait.

[Hdg] Preparing
pillars and Maori
mats The entrance to
Government House,
... will soon have a
Taranaki flavour -
carved pillars and
woven mats made in
the Te Atiawa
(Taranaki) style
Petone Technical
Institute students
carved pou out of a
100-year-old totara
pile ... Te Atiawa
women are still
plaiting the mat to
be laid at the main
door.

The pou, as it is
known, also honours
the memory of all
Moriori ancestors.

The house has at its
heart two polished
pou, vertical poles
around which a
spiral staircase
winds, drawing the
eye upward to the
ridge of the house -
just as in a
wharenui.

Mikara has travelled
with whanau /
friends from Rerenga
Wairua and will keep
walking to ki
Whanganui a Tara
(Wellington),
"following the pou -
making sure it's
kept warm and safe."
The pou whenua is
Dame Whina Cooper's
carved flagpole,
born from Te Hapua
to Poneke during the
1975 Land March.

If they side with
the aunties, "who to
paint the pou? Who
to call the dead
home? Who to keep
the fire burning?"

Author: Ihimaera
Quote:
There are a number
of carved posts
which support the
structure of the
meeting house; the
main ones are the
poutokomanawa, the
heart post, and the
poutahuhu, the ridge
post. In the old
days, the pou, which
also included wall
posts, were said to
be living, sacred,
able to talk.

Last year, for
example, the couple
created the carved
wooden pou and woven
tukutuku panel for
the New Zealand
embassy in Warsaw.

When discussing the
Pao Miere movement
in the King Country,
she forgets that the
lettering and
incisions on one pou
(pillar) of the
cruciform, assembly
house included the
date 1887, which was
a deliberate record
of the
revitalisation of
the movement by the
leader and builder
of the house, Te Ra
Karepe.

Emphasising the
conservation ethic,
local Maori have
erected a pou rahui
(above) on the bank
of the Opanuku,
visible to all who
use the river.

The carved ancestral
pou tahu came from
Poho o Mahaki which
was built in 1830.

Very much interested
in a large stratum
of lignite to be
seen under the
sandcliffs [at
Moiatoa], kapia
still in ... Watched
the karoros carrying
up the pouas &
letting them drop to
break the shells...
Saw my first korora
(dead)

Author: IHIMAERA
Quote:
The hill was a
gigantic crescent of
eleven terraces,
like the poutama
pattern, the
wondrous Stairway to
Heaven.

I knew from various
sources that the
Morioris had a
tradition of a great
bird they called the
pou[diaresis]wa.
Notes: 1893 May Fortnightly Review 669 (H.O. Forbes) in 1897 TrNZI 29/163

Quote: In this paper I will endeavour to prove that the large, mythological, and extinct bird the poua, traditionally spoken of by the remaining surrvivors of the Moriori people who inhabit the Chatham Islands, was not allied to the moa ... but was a species of swan, and belonged to the family Anatidae.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
Post-European
re-working of
different legends
about big birds..
seems even more
evident in the names
poua and pouaki.
These were alleged
by Tare te Maiharoa
an influential South
Island chief about
the turn of the 20th
century to be the
true, ancient names
for moas.

It appears that the
Morioris have
traditions about a
great bird, called
by them Puoa... The
Morioris have a song
about it, and repeat
the first syllable
as a chorus, Pu, pu
- Pu, pu - Pu, o-a,
in a manner which
recalls the hollow
drumming noise made
by the emu. The word
is probably a
contraction for
Pu-pu-moa.
Notes: This is the article by Cockburn-Hood referred to by Anderson in "Prodigious Birds"

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
Post-European
re-working of
different legends
about big birds..
seems even more
evident in the names
poua and pouaki.
These were alleged
by Tare te Maiharoa
an influential South
Island chief about
the turn of the 20th
century to be the
true, ancient names
for moas.

But he is Maori and,
because of that, he
and Hamish are able
to recognise that
the rampaging killer
of the station's
sheep is a feathery
prehistoric
eagle-taniwha, the
Pouakai.

Among the fearsome
creatures that
stalked New Zealand
in days gone by was
the pouakai - an
eagle with a
three-metre
wing-span and the
impact of a Mack
truck. It preyed on
the moa - and on
humans - and is
estimated to have
been among the
largest of all
feathered predators.

There is an ancient
wonder-tale about a
huge predatory bird
called the pouakai..
This pouakai..was
large enough to
carry human beings
off to its nest or
lair... The name
Hapagornis has been
given to this
prehistoric species.

The whanau, te
poumarumaru (board
of trustees) and
pouako (teachers)
demonstrate a strong
commitment to their
defined longterm
aspiration.

Remnants of violet
pouch fungus are
visible.
The blue fungus seen in quantity on Ed and Juliet's 28 June Mt Climie trip was Weraroa virescens , also known as the pale blue pouch fungus or tobacco pouch fungus.

It consists of two
flagpoles, pohaki,
and a treasure box,
waka huia. One of
the pohaki
represents the
natural world, from
Papauanuku to the
animals and birds of
the forest.

Home in Waikato,
Tawhiao sought
solutions to Maori
problems through the
establishment of
Maori institutions
to deal with them.
In 1885 he initiated
the institution of
Poukai, where the
King would pay
annual visits to
King movement marae
to encourage people
to return to their
home marae at least
once a year. The
first Poukai
(originally called
Puna-kai, or 'source
of food') was held
at Whatiwhatihoe in
March 1885. It was a
day for the less
fortunate to be fed
and entertained. The
Poukai developed
into an event which
would later ensure
direct consultation
of the people with
the King.
Notes: from the DNZB entry on King Tawhiao (R.T. Mahuta) (updated online version 2007)

Quote:
KOKOHINAU Marae in
Te Teko had the
honour of hosting,
for the first time
in the Mataatua
area, the Maori
King, Tuheitia on
Sunday.... Mr Eruera
said the king was
attending a poukai,
or assembly, and
this was the 44th
year it had been
held at Kokohinau.
... A copy of a
publication
celebrating the 44
years of the poukai
being held at
Kokohinau was also
given to the king by
Katerina Waiari.
Teriaki Amoamo, on
behalf of Whakatohea
and Te
Whanau-a-Apanui,
presented a
ceremonial hoe waka
(canoe paddle).Mr
Eruera said the open
debate session,
which is what a
poukai is all about,
raised a few issues.
One of those issues
was brought up
earlier in the day
by Whakatohea and Te
Whanau-a-Apanui who
requested to share
the poukai in the
future. Mr Eruera
said the request
would have to go to
hapu members to
consider.A restored
flagpole was also
erected - hapu
members, under the
direction of carver
Graham Junior Niao,
carried out the
restoration on the
carved pole - and
the special poukai
flag was flown.

Author: McGILL
Quote: poultice a large sandwich using everything in the fridge or pantry, akin to American dagwood without the toothpicks; eg `Looks like you've got the whole deli in that poultice, dear. Don't bolt it down, will you, or it'll be back to see you tonight.'

The whanau, te
poumarumaru (board
of trustees) and
pouako (teachers)
demonstrate a strong
commitment to their
defined longterm
aspiration.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote: The best pounamu pendants were worn by the chiefs ...

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
Te Pehi ... [was]
killed treacherously
by some of
Tamaiharanui's
tribe, among whom he
had trusted himself,
in order to barter
muskets for Pounamu
stone, ...

This strange weaving
caused the young
woman, with the
sunset hair and the
pounamu eyes, to be
branded a witch and
banished from the
village where she
was born.

The Chairman turned
on the pounamu
floor.

In the old days the
cutting and working
of pounamu
(greenstone) was a
most laborious
operation, and it
often took years to
work a mere or axe
to the desired shape
and smoothness.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
They found large
quantities of the
ponamu or green
stone, some of which
was clear as glass.

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote: No ponamu was found.

[Photo caption]
CASKET PRESENTED TO
THE DUKE AND DUCHESS
OF CORNWALL AND
YORK. Made of
greenstone, gold,
and silver .. A
souvenir of their
Royal Highnesses'
visit to the land of
the Moa and the
Pounamu.

Source: New Zealand Spectator & Cook's Strait Guardian
Quote:
.. In this river is
found the stone used
by the natives for
rubbing down their
ponamu, in quality
resembling a
Newcastle stone,
though somewhat
closer in the grain
and texture, and has
a fine cutting
quality.

.. During the time
that he lay on the
beach, he had,
unknown to everyone,
concealed beneath
his shirt a
"rakau-pounamu" or
weapon made from a
stone called
"pounamu", which
belonged to him and
Taiaroa.

Author: FORSTER
Quote: Among the fossil productions of this country, we must likewise reckon a green stone, which sometimes is opaque, and sometimes quite transparent ... We asked for its native place, and they called it Poenamoo [e-dieresis], from whence the abovementioned part of the country obtained the denomination of Tavai Poenamoo [e-dieresis] ...

Author: McCRAE
Quote:
They then remarked
that that might be
the way of the
Pakeha (or white
men) but with them
the belief was was
that their God had
fished up New
Zealand with three
fish hooks made of
Poeananiamiou a
green serpentine ...

Author: POLACK
Quote: .. a dark-gray and black-coloured granite, termed onewoa by the natives was made use of in its stead, or the green talc, poeanamu[a2-acute] and pieces of red jasper chipped off adroitly, resembling in shape our common gun-flints.

Author: MONRO
Quote:
1844 Monro Notes of
a Journey (Nelson
Examiner July 20 et
seq.) in 1898 Hocken
Contributions 261
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 261

Quote:
Mr. Fyfe had found a
moa's egg, at the
Kai Koras, while
digging the
foundation for his
store. It is a foot
long, about 6 inches
in diameter, and 27
inches in
circumference. The
shell is the 16th
part of an inch in
thickness. A hole is
drilled in the end
of it, and the egg
must have been
considered of great
value by the
natives, as it was
found deposited at
the head of a
skeleton, with a
number of very large
poenamu axes. Mr.
Fyfe, we understand,
is going to send
them home to the
British Museum.

Author: CAPT. RAVEN
Quote:
They [natives] took
to the woods, and we
never saw them again
[at Dusky Bay], nor
did Mr Leith see any
inhabitants during
his residence at
Poenammoo. He once
found a fire, but
the natives had fled
at his approach.
Notes: 1793 Nov 2 Capt. Raven to Lieut-Governor King in 1908 McNab Historical Records 1/179

Author: McDONNELL
Quote:
Coffee, sugar,
indigo, and rice,
would succeed well
on the North Island,
as also all the
tropical fruits. New
Zealand, more
particularly
Poenammoo, is yet
but little known.

Author: PARKINSON
Quote:
[South Island] He
had on a flaxen
garment .. and under
it a petticoat, made
of a sort of cloth
which they call
Aooree
Waow[o-grave]; on
his ears hung a
bunch of teeth, and
an ear-ring of
Poonamoo, or green
stone.

... their greatest
branch of trade is
for the green talk
or stone (called by
them Poenammoo) a
thing of no sort of
value.

Author: BAYLY
Quote:
The Indians are fond
of green stone they
have among them
which they call
Poanamo. It is a
kind of Jasper. With
this they make their
Togie, or ads of &
chissles to carve
with, & bobs for
their years [ears] &
gorgets to hang at
the breast.
Notes: 1773 June 4 Bayly's Journal in 1908 McNab Historical Records 2/209

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ
Author: LEE & KENDALL
Quote:
P|ou n|amu; A green
stone so called.

Author: YATE
Quote:
[spg] `Manatungos,'
or remembrancers ..
are always either
suspended round the
neck or to the ear;
they are mostly made
of the ponamu, the
green stone found
only in the Southern
Island.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
The native ornaments
worn in the ears are
pieces of the ponamu
(nephrite, or
oriental jade),
which are called e
tara ...

Source: Notes of an Expedition to Kawatiri and Araura
Quote: In [the Arahura's] bed, after freshets, is found the poenamu, in shingles or slabs.
Notes: 1846 Heaphy Exped. to Kawatiri in 1959 Taylor Early Travs. 241

Author: ANGAS
Quote: .. the most usual ornaments are ear-drops made of pieces of nephrite or green jade, called ponamu by the natives ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The natives procure
.. quantities of a
green jade, or
serpentine, much
prized by them for
[314] the purpose of
making war-clubs ..
It is called by them
`Ponamu', whence the
name once assigned
to the Middle Island

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: During the time .. he had .. concealed beneath his shirt a `rakau-pounamu' or weapon made from the stone called `pounamu', which belonged to him and Taiaroa. `Te Wahi Ponamu' or, `The Place of Green Stone'.

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
The most prized
ornaments amongst
them are those
manufactured of
nephrite or green
jade .. [158] called
`poenamu' by the
natives.

Source: Province of Otago in NZ, The
Quote: Serpentine occurs in two forms - as common Serpentine .. and as noble Serpentine (Tangiwai) in thin veins associated with Jade .. ordinarily known as Maori Greenstone (Poenamu) occurs in situ on several parts of the West Coast ...

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
A magnificent Mere
punamu .. cut out of
the most beautiful,
transparent
nephrite.

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote: Poenamo [title]
It is called pounamu or poenamu by the Maoris, and `jade,' `jadeite,' or `nephrite,' by various writers, while old books refer to the `green talc' of the Maoris.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Pounamu, or Poenamu, n. the Maori name for Nephrite, Jade, or Greenstone (q.v.). In the second spelling the eis hardly sounded.

Author: TREGEAR
Quote: The Maori greenstone (pounamu) called jade, jadeite, nephrite, etc., by Europeans, is a mineral very restricted in its deposits. .. one variety (tangiwai) is found at Milford Sound.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
`Pounamu'
(greenstone) was
only to be found in
the creeks of the
inland ranges of
[40] the Middle
Island, and hence
called `Te wai
pounamu.'
Pounamu (Nephrite, or Greenstone). - Used for ornamnental purposes.

Author: COWAN
Quote: .. here is an appropriate moment to tell the story of the jadeite or pounamu which first won celebrity for the West Coast.
pounamu, greenstone, chiefly (and the best) found in Arahura.
pounamu: greenstone.
pounamu, poenamu n. Maori name for nephrite, jade or greenstone (q.v.) [Maori].
pounamu ... n. Maori name for a variety of N.Z. nephrite, jade, or greenstone [used by Sir John Logan Campbell as the title of a book (Poenamu)].

New Zealand
greenstone is either
the mineral nephrite
(Maori: pounamu) or
bowenite (Maori:
tangiwai).

Author: HULME
Quote:
14 Pounamu = New
Zealand jade, also
called `greenstone'
pounamu n. NZ greenstone. [M]

Two islands .. which
[Cook] called Tovy
Poenammoo; the
literal translation
of this word is `the
water of the green
talc' ...

There is a very
interesting history
attached to the
transportation of
this monster piece
of pounamu here.

NOTICEKiaora koutouI, Iris Herewini would love to thank everyone that has come into my life and shared my passion and love through receiving my pounamu, may your journeys through life be a spiritual one...

Kahu Hoeter is
stunning as Tiri
Mahana; her
performance as
luminous and richly
hued as fine
pounamu, shifting
smoothly from past
to present and anger
to aroha.

Author: FIRTH
Quote: Among the Maori, considerations of aesthetic interest helped quite materially .. to decide the relative worth of objects made of the pounamu, the nephrite so much prized for pendants, mere, and adzes. Most prized was the kahurangi stone, bright green, translucent, hard and clear; the inanga variety perhaps comes next, with its white milky-veined appearance, 389] followed by the kawakawa, dark olive-green, dull and opaque. .. Tangiwai (`tear drop'), bowenite, a softer stone of a clear pale green, with the appearance of drops of water in the texture, was less esteemed, though more beautiful in the European eyes, whilst kahotea, green, spotted or streaked with black, was an inferior type, and was used for small chisels, and for objects of subordinate interest.

Author: JOSEPH
Quote:
`The jade, the
pounamu .. It's a
beautiful stone ..
Look,' he said,
holding up a long
hooked ear-drop of
pearly translucence,
`that's tau tau and
the stone is called
inanga. And this,
the pekapeka - they
say the shape comes
from the bat. This
is for the ear, too
- the mako, like a
shark's tooth .. And
these,' - he ran his
fingers along a row
of .. nephrite adzes
- `toki. See this
one' - he held the
heavy red-mottled
adze in his palm -
`that's the red
kind, totoweka,
woodhen's blood. The
deep green, that's
kawakawa.'
It [sc. a Maori expedition] consisted of twenty mokis, well freighted with pounamu. .. The greenstone (pounamu) was largely used for crucifixes and Roman Catholic Church symbols.

These days, though,
greenstone is the
new gold. For more
than 20 years,
chunks of pounamu
have been carted out
of the mists.

They travelled .. to
barter .. slabs of
the tuhua, or
obsidian, his being
the only stone
capable of cutting
the paunamu, or
greenstone, found in
the South.

The next day we roll
up our figurative
sleeping bags and
head south to
Greymouth to search
for pounamu.

Keri's novel has the
preciousness of a
piece of "kuru
pounamu" in its
apparent simplicity
of shape, because it
is concerned with
the universal theme
of aroha.

I can imagine that
the most abiding
memories for a lot
of viewers will be
of the hapu doggedly
cultivating their
muddy clearing, or
the two figures with
lacerated feet
shuffling across a
scree-slope on their
trek for pounamu.

Although Maori
regularly traversed
the Southern Alps to
collect pounamu
(greenstone) from
the West Coast, the
first written
accounts are those
of European
explorers.

Wanaka was at the
crossroads of the
trading routes for
pounamu, and a
school of learning -
whare kura - was
established at the
main Wanaka
settlement of
Takikarara.

Jade, nephrite,
greenstone, pounamu
- these are all
names for a stone
most New Zealanders
know and revere..
Maori were almost
certainly unfamiliar
with pounamu when
they arrived in
Aotearoa, but they
brought with them
the art of stone
tool-making.

Author: McNAUGHTON
Quote:
I am polishing my
grand-dad's tohu. It
is a / small piece
of pounamu,
translucent and /
shaped like an
elongated tear.
Notes: From Keri Hulme (1982) : Getting to the Coast

Quote:
A fellow club member
and a senior student
in the Chemistry
Department, Jack
Mitchell . . .
demonstrated to me
the power of the
petrographic
microscope by
showing me slides of
the Pounamu rocks
from the Griffin
Range in north
Westland. . . .

We heard that a lot
of our cows were
pounded last night
[in Ch.Ch.]. There
is some consolation
in knowing that the
cattle doe [sic] the
fences more harm
than the pound does.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
The day before the
following weekend I
was locked up in the
pound. A pound is
for locking up
animals. If only
we'd been animals
the RSPCA and all
the animal lovers
would have caused a
public outcry - but
we were only humans
so no one worried.
There had been no
reason for punishing
me - the official
reason given was
that I was put there
as an assistant
cleaner. The cleaner
already there had
virtually nothing to
do. So the whole
deal was hell of an
unusual - in fact no
crim I met had ever
before heard of a
situation in which
an inmate who'd
committed no offence
had been sent to the
pound - especially
as an assistant
cleaner.

Author: MacKENZIE
Quote: The punishment block, known as the `pound' or the `dummy', was a prison within the [Mt Eden] prison. In the basement, through a steel grille and a wooden door, it was a dimly lit and silent annexe leading at its far end to the tiny execution yard. Ibid. 98 pound punishment block

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote: You're in jail now, son! Another peep from you and you'll be down the fookin pound. Ibid. 145 So I settled back to do my bird. Callander came up and found I was in the pound ... . In the digger the days go by pretty slowly ... .Ibid. 252 POUND (n) Detention unit.

The tale about being
in the "pound" is
told and retold; the
rebel has returned
to the fold with
stature increased.
What isn't mentioned
is the torturous
difficulty the
"hero" had in making
it throught a few
days on his own.

Source: For the Rest of Our Lives
Author: DAVIN
Quote:
He wasn't a bad
bloke even if he was
only fifteen bob in
the pound.

Author: F W VOSSELER
Quote:
Not twenty shillings
in the pound, not to
be up to standard.

Author: HAMILTON
Quote:
Good God, said Neil,
he was barely six
shillings in the
pound, used to talk
all day about the
colours of a
motor-bike he had on
the outer.

Author: McCALLUM
Quote:
I come to the idea
that this pakeha is
only about eighteen
bob in the pound, so
I give him the brush
off on the excuse
that I must go home
...

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Every small town has
its characters: ...
Joey who was only
eighteen shillings
...

Author: OLIVER
Quote:
... or they say he
isn't/ quite the
full pound though/
useful enough in the
front/ row ...

Author: HAMILTON
Quote: ... it's a pretty rare specimen who won't do anything for a man in the pound. Ibid. 83 The exercise yard of the pound is the place where they used to hang and flog.

Author: ROLLESTON
Quote: `Mr Thomas Cowper,' announced the Hawkes Bay Provincial Gazette on the 15 October 1864, `shall be Pound-keeper at Wallingford'.

Author: PETERSON
Quote:
Many years earlier
[?c1890s] Mother had
sent Don to the Post
Office for a 2/6
postal note.
Unfortunately she
forgot to give him
the poundage.
`That's another
penny, Sonny,' said
the Postmaster
cheerfully. With
eyes flashing fire
the small boy held
up the PN.

Author: ALEXANDER
Quote:
Seeing that poupou
and tukutuku are
thetraditional means
of decorating, I
havetaken it that
both must be
employed .. The
poupou in the Maori
whare actually
supported the roof.

At the entrance a
pair of eyes fix
you. They are in the
upper part of a
carved panel, or
Maori Pou-Pou, taken
from .. inside a
Maori Council
Chamber that
formerly stood at
Tolago [sic] Bay.

A valuable piece of
Maori carved work in
the shape of a
poupou or wall slab
from a house in
Tologa [sic] Bay has
just been placed in
the Auckland museum.

The fourth poupou
challenges our
people to build
strong families and
in turn strong
communities.
poupou, upright deeply-carved slabs forming the solid framework of a whare: between every pair of poupou is the panel of tukutuku work.

The poupou or
supports, sometimes
called puketara, are
painted after very
old Maori style.

My socks slide on
the polished floor
as I follow Pare
obediently from pou
pou to pou pou. Each
one represents an
ancestor and many of
them are from
different tribes
related to Ngati
Kahungunu. She takes
my hand and slaps it
onto the genitals of
one of the male pou
pou.

"The poupou
[perpendiculars]
will be bold and
thick and bear
weight ..."

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: It was his body [sc. Te Rangi-nukai] which was to be buried beneath the poupous - uprights supporting the framework of the whare. Ibid. 131 It was his body which was to be buried beneath the poupous - uprights supporting the framework of the whare - his death which was to celebrate the house-warming.

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote:
Rafters are
supported below by
upright slabs,
poupou, which are
often carved.

"In this house we're
really trying to
create new poupou
you haven't seen in
a book and attack
new subject matter
so it will drive the
imagery in a new
way." .. Across the
back wall will be a
line of poupou
depicting ancestors
from principal hapu
...

Carvers .. at
Ohinemutu are at
present on the last
of the heavy pou pou
slabs for the Wairoa
.. meeting house.

[Photo Caption] A
Carved Poupou from
Ohinemutu. This
carved poupou, or
slab, forms part of
the carved house at
Ohinemutu, named
Tama-te-Kapua, after
the celebrated
ancestor of the
Arawa tribe.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ORTHONYX ALBICILLA {CLITONYX ALBICAPILLA}. (The WHITE-HEAD.) ... Native names. Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ORTHONYX {CLITONYX} OCHROCEPHALA. (The YELLOW-HEAD.) ... Native names. The same [Popotea, Poupoutea, Popokotea, and Upokotea] as those applied to the preceding species [White-head]: `Canary' of the colonists.

In exchange, the
NZRFU, provincial
unions and clubs
give companies
exposure through
brand names on team
clothing, signage at
matches, team naming
rights and pour
rights at events and
clubrooms.

The revolutionary
pour-on systemic
insecticide from
Ivon Watkins Dow
Limited opens up a
new concept in
cattle lice control.

For the control of
lice in beef cattle
there is a wide
variety of sprays,
pour-ons, spot-ons
and powders..

Pour-ons have been
used to control lice
on cattle for
several years.

The term 'dip' is a
hangover from when
plunge dipping was
the only option - it
has latterly been
joined first by
spray-dipping and
now by the pour-ons.

With less need and
dependency on the
use of pesticides,
insecticides,
drenches, pour-ons
and other drugs and
remedies, by
accepting a more
balanced and
broad-minded
approach ...

The Working Dog. Do
NOT put the dogs in
the sheep swim dip
or shower or use any
sheep pouron. This
could kill the dog.
[pour on; pouron]
Montana, New Zealand's biggest wine-maker, won the pourage rights with Lord of the Rings backers New Line Cinema.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: We dived for paua, sea eggs, and crayfish. Crayfish pots (called pouraka) were set at night.
Notes: 1900 Horoeka in 1981 Sutton-Smith History of Children's Play 124

Quote:
".. he met the
ploughing party
after they had been

Author: LEE & KENDALL

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Very pouri from the idleness of the boys.
When it was rumoured that Morland was missing, she [Roro] was pouri - wouldn't eat, and cried all the time ...

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
My boys are all
pouri, because they
think we have taken
the wrong ...

Author: GRACE
Quote:

Author: POLACK
Quote: [caption to carved buildings raised on posts] Na[acute] Powaka, or Village depositaries of the natives. ... [210]Next to the Warre no te Rangatira, or native palace, the village museum (po[acute]waka) in which the valuables of the community of the place are deposited, receives careful attention of the native Vitruvius. These erections are raised on four stout carved poles, the sides of the house are faced with boards, carved with a profusion of indelicate subjects, exaggerated in such a manner as to leave no spectator in any dilemma as to the actual meaning and intention of the artist. In these huts, or rather boxes (the literal meaning) are placed fowling-pieces, esteemed garments, ... There's no getting away from PPPs now - public-private partnerships. They occur when a government needs major capital works done, but the work is on a scale that would seriously unbalance the public balance sheet. Ibid. 24 Essentially, the PPP term entered the national lexicon only with the Birch report for Auckland City Council in 2001. Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: In the constitutional debates of 1854 during the first session of the New Zealand Parliament, the term `Prime Minister' was frequently used in a somewhat casual fashion. This explains in part why it was some years before the term `Premier' came into general usage. William Fox (q.v.) who took office in July 1861, was described in the Gazette as Attorney-General `with first seat in the Ministry'. In November 1864 Weld (q.v.) was gazetted as holding `a seat in the Executive Council and the office of Premier'. Stafford (q.v.) his successor, in October 1865 was termed `First Minister'. In June 1869, when Fox again headed a Ministry, he was described officially as `Premier and member of the Executive Council.' Thereafter the term `Premier' was regularly used. Nevertheless, in the Schedule of the Civil List Act of 1873, provision was made for the salary of the Leader of the Government `being the Prime Minister'. The first Premier to use the title `Prime Minister' officially was Richard John Seddon (q.v.). It was used in the New Zealand Year Book of 1900 and the Imperial Conference of 1903 confirmed the practice.

tomato sauce, made
by Mum in the huge
preserving pan at
the end of each
summer, and put back
in the bottles that
the vinegar was in,
after she's done the
cases of golden
queens which are
sent on the train
from Hawke's Bay.

Time to take down
the preserving pan.

Author: HAWES
Quote:
Not like '95 where
the fruit had been
early and hard, and
sank straight to the
bottom of the
preserving pan.

After emptying the
aluminium
preserving- pan she
told how years ago
she got it
unexpectedly at
anauction sale.

Author: GEE
Quote:
They boiled water in
the copper and
carried it to the
bath in preserving
pans and sat washing
each other,
sometimes with a
storm howling round.

Should we organise
via KR a preso to
Shipley asap (in
next week)?
Notes: Harry's dating says 1996 but this cannot be right for the matter concerned.

Quote:
.. some merchants
have them to press
wool bales and save
freight thereby.

My wish is to see a
proper use made of
all the natural
resources, and I
would even go so far
as for instance to
use the pressure of
the water, before it
is supplied to the
ships, or before a
street is filled
with it, to press
wool, or do some
other service on the
wharf.

My employment was
chiefly in packing
the woolbales which
is very heavy work.
You put from 90 to
120 fleeces in a
bail which way [sic]
from 300 to 350 lbs.
It is hard to press
the wool into so
small a compass. We
sheared some 850
sheep to-day.

`Press' and `sweep'
are technical terms
for necessary
operations in the
woolshed at shearing
time. The former
refers to pressing
the fleeces into
tight-packed bales
... to facilitate
the transport of an
otherwise bulky
commodity. The
latter is the
process of keeping
the floor (the
`boards'), on which
the sheep are shorn,
clear of loose ends
of wool, dirt and
excrement.

Source: In the Land of the Tui
Author: WILSON
Quote:
At the main entrance
of the
shearing-shed, which
is a long building
with pens down the
centre, and an
outlet at each end,
stands a wool-press,
and behind this are
the bins into which
the fleeces, after
having been classed,
are placed
preparatory to being
pressed.

368 9548 sheep
shorn, 139 bales
pressed. I think
sheep and wool will
be up to last year;
run sheep much
better. Ewe and
paddock sheep not so
good. Lice in wool
and [dust from]
ploughed ground all
through Ewe mob. All
the paddock sheeps
wool must be
scoured.

Author: PERRY
Quote:
The skirtings of the
neck and shoulder
can be called first
pieces, and the
britch ends made
into second pieces.
The `bellies' can be
placed in a pack
hung on the
shearing-board, and
when two of these
are filled they can
be pressed.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
While one press was
being filled and
pressed, the already
pressed bale would
have the cap clipped
(not sewn), and then
it would be branded
and wheeled away and
another empty bale
inserted

Pressed the
remainder of the
`Firsts' scoured
wool, in the
afternoon.

My press men are two
fools. Abner pressed
more wool in 40
minutes than they
did from 2 to 6.

Being short of bales

Romney.

Work Wanted .. I can

As it takes about

The hydraulic press

Kennards dray came

Wool shed putting up

Hydraulic presses

for the baling of
goods into the
smallest possible

The valve which
controls the
admission of the
water to the ram of
the press is perhaps
the weakest part of
the machine, in the

most liable to give

There were five wool

Quote: Press machine for pressing wool into bales.

Will Sell by Auction

It requires only to

belly - the wool off

Author: POLACK
Quote: Every one of them [sc. Maoris] came up to press noses, which I enacted with a few of the foremost; but respect for the shape and position of this ornamental member, made me abridge the ceremony, or I should never have retained its pristine form, so eager were these new friends to greet and welcome my arrival. Ibid. 85 Each presentation was accompanied by the pressing of noses (e'ongi) and expressions of `Friend, welcome; how are you all,' &c. `Ekoro airamai tenarakokoe[a2-acute],' in a whiningtone, as if each were about to condole for the loss of their entire generation.

Author: ANGAS

On entering one of

these visitors
commenced their
salutations by
pressing noses with
each in succession,
and then sat down in
silence; the women
setting up a tangi,
or `crying of
welcome'.

Notes: 1853 Dec 29 T.S.Grace letter in Grace Pioneer Missionary (1928) 35

The usual mode of

Author: CARR
Quote: The boss Maori undertakes to supply all the rouseabouts (as shed hands are termed) i.e., fleece pickers, wool rollers and `Sheep oh!' the [sic] owner or manager generally gets his own pressers and expert (where machines are run). Ibid. 15-16 Pressing. - When there is sufficient wool in one bin, the pressers (generally two) get to work. One gets into the `box' as the lower portion of the patent presses is called, while his mate ... hands him ... the fleeces. These are placed in tiers, and tramped down until the lower box is full. An upper box is then swung ... or [16] lowered on to the lower one, and the process repeated. When full, the `monkey' or cover is put into position, the spears (wire rope) affixed, and the two men lever the cover down until the top box is clear.

"That's nothing",
the presser informed
me.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Marbles had a
language of its own.
There were names for
the marbles, the
games, and all the
various aspects of
the play. There were
terms for marbles
such as `taw' or
`shooter', referring
to the marbles used
to fire with;
`dubs', `dates',
`stakes', `dukes',
or `changers',
referring to the
marbles put down to
be fired at. Then
there were the terms
referring to
particular kinds of
marbles: for
example, agates,
aggies, aggotties,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cat's eyes,
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, molly-bars,
mulley-bars
[mullibars: large
marbles], peelies,
peewees, piss-wees,
pretties, Scotties,
Scottish alleys,
smokies, stinkies,
stonies, stripies,
tom-bobblers, white
alleys, and in more
recent years
ball-bearings,
chippies, plastics,
and woodies.

Author: KEITH & MAIN
Quote:
Marbles were the
currency of
childhood and there
were an astonishing
number of names for
them, some referring
to the material or
colour, others to
value or function in
the game. There were
agates, aggies,
American alleys,
blood alleys,
bomb-squashers,
bonies, bonsers,
bottlies, bull's
eyes, bum-squashers,
cats-eye, [sic]
chinkies, connies,
duckies, eggies,
glassies, Greeks,
milkies, mollies,
peelies, peewees,
pisswees, pretties,
Scotties, smokies,
stinkies, stonies,
stripies,
tom-bobblers and
whities. The march
of technology added
ball bearings -
ballies or steelies
- which were
unbeatable when it
came to smashing an
opponent's miserable
glassie. World War
II[roman] brought
`clayeys' often
imperfectly
spherical they were
pathetic terracotta
substitutes for real
marbles.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Thus the quail which
said `Pretty Quick,
Pretty Quick' in
rapid repetition in
the day (so much so
that they were
sometimes called
Pretty Quicks) in
the evening said
`I'll put it out,
I'll put it out.'

At the other end of
the scale is the
indeterminate
sentence of
preventive
detention. A
sentence of the same
name existed in
Britain from 1908 to
1967. Introduced in
New Zealand in 1954
to replace the
sentence of
reformative
detention (1910) and
declaration as an
habitual offender
and habitual
criminal (1906), it
remains very much
alive here.

Your second

Author: BEATON
Quote:
LOU: I'm gettin'

That is the word

sexual intercourse.

Buying native trees
and ferns as

protect the habitat
for our endangered
wildlife.

`INFORMATION,' of

Seddon was New
Zealand's first
Prime Minister on
the grounds that the
term `Prime
Minister' was not
used officially till
New Zealand obtained
Dominion status on
September 26, 1907.
THE term `Prime
Minister' was first
used in New Zealand
during a
constitutional
debate in New
Zealand's first
Parliament in 1854,
and was subsequently
used on many
occasions during the
late 19th century.
In 1873, for
example, in a
schedule to the
civil list,
provision was made
for the leader of
the Government
`being the Prime
Minister.' The title
`Prime Minister' was
adopted officially
in 1899 and Richard
John Seddon was the
first New Zealand
Premier to use it.
It was officially
used in the New
Zealand Year Book in
1900 and in
Parliamentary
debates in 1902.

Author: BACON
Quote: Probationary Assistant-New Zealand student teachers normally do two years' training in one of the country's Teachers' Colleges. During this time, they work about five separate monthly practice periods in selected schools. Their third year of training is as Probationary Assistant in a larger school. If this probationary year's service is satisfactory, trainees receive their Teacher's Certificate, and are then eligible to apply for a teaching position anywhere in New Zealand or in New Zealand's Island Territories.

Author: JACKSON & MCROBIE
Quote:
The first primary
producer boards were
set up in the wake
of the collapse of
the commandeer
system (q.v.)
following the end of
World War I. In the
years that followed
[the establishment
of the meat and
Dairy Boards]
producer boards were
set up to oversee
the production and
export of fruit,
honey, poultry and
hops. After the
[second world]war
producer boards were
re-established and
extended to include
wool, eggs, kauri
gum, maize, barley,
potatoes, bobby
calves, pork,
apples, berry and
citrus fruits,
tobacco, and as
recently as 1988,
kiwifruit (q.v.).

Looking forward,
Wiggins agrees that
the days of the
producer boards are
numbered.

Government

Apple and Pear

the Kiwifruit

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
The principle of
"accrediting" and
ofabolishing the
"proficiency"

examination
intosecondary
schools, became part

Labour Party and of

Government, 1935-49.

It was resolved that
every member
endeavor to urge
upon parents having

The most important
[resolutions] are:
(1) That in
secondary schools
all pupils not
disqualified by age
be given the
opportunity of
obtaining the
proficiency
certificate
qualifying for free
education; (2) that
all now attending
secondary schools
who have passed the
proficiency
examination, and who
have obtained
scholarships be put
on an equal footing
with those eligible
for free education
next year, providing
that they have
passed the
proficiency
examinations, and
are within the
prescribed age.

[The Minister for
Education] agreed
that, at any rate
for a proficiency
certificate, there
should be a uniform
examination
throughout New
Zealand.

If a boy secures his

certificate it by no

school.

act.

order for some

Not for me the noisy proline/ but the quiet of the auger and fang-spanner - / long tom and jim crow,/ strumming on the old banjo./ ... [fn] long tom: long blade used for placing measured amount of gravel under sleepers jim crow: large horseshoe-shaped tool, with screw, used for bending rails banjo: shovel

And I haven't heard
"pronging" to refer
to sexual
intercourse for a
very long time.

He was puzzled when
a workmate called
him a pronker. At
first he thought he
had been identified
as a plonker, but
found the word
pronker was chosen
deliberately. The
South African verb
pronk means to show
off, as a springbok
might do when it
makes a spectacular
leap, perhaps to
score a try to win
the World Cup.

It was propped to me
that I write a book.

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
In London the swells

diggers drive here
with a pick
underground; / And
the props that they
use, surely everyone

for hanging up

men use them here, /
Though to cockneys
that statement may
sound very queer, /
And the fellows that
frequently hang
round hotels, / Out
here are called
loafers, at home are
called swells. -->[p
89 fn] * A fan is a
machine for pumping
air down the shafts.

Prop (pr`op), v. i. To stop suddenly; to jib; - said of a horse. [Local, Australia]

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
...An old Australian
squatter, who
visited the
Canterbury
settlement in 1851,
divided the
inhabitants into
pilgrims, shagruns,
and prophets; the
first were the
original colonists,
the second were
people from other
parts of New
Zealand, and the
last were settlers
from Australia.

`Pilgrims and Prophets'. [title of Poem] Ibid. 9. The pilgrim toiled for his crop. ... Shortly the pilgrim and prophet agreed The plough and the crook couldn't live far apart. [NOTE 1866] Ibid. 101 [Notes] During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of Sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria), who were regarded by the Settlers partly with admiration as successful colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonization and the `Canterbury System'. ... One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined ... The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nick-name their Port Philip visitors `prophets', and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. Ibid. 125. During the first year of the Settlement, Canterbury was invaded by a body of sheep-farmers from Port Philip (Victoria) who were regarded by the settlers partly with admiration as successful Colonists, and partly with horror as disbelievers in the art of colonisation and the `Canterbury System'. The visitors found the country admirably adapted for sheep-farming, and they treated with some contempt the raw emigrants from England who looked to agriculture as the foundation of their fortunes. One of the visitors, who seem to have delighted in the soubriquet of `Shagroon', ventured to prophesy, in a letter, which found its way into print, that the `Canterbury Pilgrims' would soon be ruined and their country left for occupation by his more enlightened comrades. The `pilgrims' sought no harsher revenge than to nickname their Port Philip visitors `prophets' and to take example from their experience in pastoral pursuits. The Canterbury pasturage system was quickly adapted to the requirements of sheepfarming on a large scale, and `pilgrims' and `prophets' were soon merged into one class of Canterbury runholders.

Prophet.- Nickname of the Australian squatters who came down to Canterbury in 185(1) They were caled Ps. because they prophesied ruin for the farming pilgrims. It was they who finally persuaded Godley to authorise the squatting system here. See also Shagroon. (C.R., p. 5)

Not only did
Australian sheep
arrive, but during
the 1850-60 period
many Australian
squatters
(disgruntled by the
fickle rainfall)
also sold or
abandoned their
properties and
migrated to New
Zealand. These men
arrived with capital
to invest, with
experience in
colonial farming,
knowledgeable of the
peculiar habits of
the Merino sheep,
and with
whole-hearted
support of a
`squatting' policy
of land tenure based
on the occupation of
large areas of
grazing country at
low rentals. They
became known as the
`Prophets' because
they forecast
failure for the
small-area arable
farm plans of the
established
settlements.

Shortly the pilgrim
and prophet agreed,
The plough and the
crook couldn't live
far apart .. Quickly
the prophet bred up
his flock. As he
defied dogs, scab
and catarrh.

Quote: Prospect, v. to search for gold. In the word, and in all its derivatives, the accent is thrown back on to the first syllable. This word, in such frequent use in Australia, is generally supposed to be of Australian origin, but it is in equal use in the mining districts of the United States of America. [1861]

His Excellency the Lieutenant-Governor proceeded to the island [Waiheke] on a Wednesday night, and left it at an early hour of the following Saturday, - the intermediate Thursday and Friday being days of a most tempestuous character - so that were his Excellency the most astucious of prospectors, he could scarcely have bestowed a superficial glance upon a very minute superficies. - And then, with regard to those of our citizens who flew on the wings of the morning to pick up gold, we imagine they were in no case to prosecute a sustained or scientific inquiry.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Two parties were now
[mid 1850s]
developed in the
colony; one was
called Centralists,
the other
Provincialists. The
former aimed at the
incorporation of the
provincial
governments, with a
view to their
ultimate absorption,
and maintained the
right of the General
Assembly to
intermeddle in all
provincial affairs.
The latter, on the
other hand, insisted
that the Imperial
Parliament had
established two
independent
governments in New
Zealand, each for
its own sphere, the
provinces having
exclusive
jurisdiction in all
provincial matters,
and only under the
control of the
General Assembly on
matters of general
concern.

The Provincialists
consider themselves
that they gained a

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Tepuaotereinga, Taylor. Dactylanthus Taylorii.

﻿It has
neither roots nor
green leaves, and is
found only in New
Zealand. Maori named
it Pua o te reinga,
Europeans call it
the Flower of Hades,
or Wood Rose, and to
the botanist it is
Dactylanthus
taylorii.

Its Maori name, pua
o te reinga, means
flower of the
underworld - and
refers to the way
the flowers emerge
from underground.

Dactylanthus
taylorii has a
special place n New
Zealand's native
flora as the
country's only fully
parasitic flowering
plant. Also known as
pua o te reinga,
wae-wae-atua, the
wood rose or flower
of Hades, it is hard
for the untrained
eye to spot as it
nestles among tree
roots.

Author: CHEESEMAN

Pua Reinga has a

with the
short-tailed bat,
which pollinates the
flowers.

the flower of the
underworld.

a deceased estate
and stated that no
offers had been
received for the
property.

The Public Trustee
is also authorised
by `The Lunacy Act,
1882,' to undertake
the administration
of the estates of
lunatics ...

Recently a
correspondent wrote
to "Truth"
representing that
the Public Trustee
had failed, through
apparent neglect, to
collect rent owing
on a house let by
the Public Trustee.

I find it
astonishing that
anyone could
possibly contemplate
that the Public
Trustee is expected
to be a guarantor or
insurer of such
investments where a
loss occurs. The
Public Trustee would
certainly not expect
to share in or
retain any gains
where they arise.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
He can entrust it to
the enervating
mediation of that
passe invention, The
Public Trustee,
whose very mention
dries up the blood
in their veins.

In one of the last
clauses of the Bill,
power was given to
the Public Trustee
to audit the
accounts of the
Curators of
Intestate Estates
and the accounts of
lunatic estates...
The Bill enable
Friendly Societies
and Building
Societies to intrust
their securities and
properties to the
Public Trust Office.

Mr Vogel, in moving
for leave to
introduce a Bill to
provide for the
appointment of a
Public Trustee, said
the Bill was one of
so large a nature
that he should be
doing an injustice
to it by making a
brief explanation.

The Bill would
authorize public
trust property to be
placed in charge of
a public trustee.
Private persons, as
well as charitable
bodies, might also
vest property in the
trustee, subject to
the approval of a
board, consisting of
the Colonial
Treasurer, the
Government Annuities
Commissioner, the
Auditor-General, and
the Public Trustee.

The "Public Trust
Office Act, 1872...
There shall be an
office called the
Public Trust Office,
administered by an
officer called the
Public Trustee, who
shall be appointed
by the Governor.

The "Public Trust
Office Act, 1872...
There shall be an
office called the
Public Trust Office,
administered by an
officer called the
Public Trustee, who
shall be appointed
by the Governor.

I think the Public
Works cottages are
adisgrace on any
farm.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
It was a lady's bike
to he kept his old
Public Works shovel
tied along the frame
to make it look
right.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
I limped on to the
Public Works camp.

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
After a few days on
good grub and in the
company of the
comparatively
intellectual Public
Works Maoris who
were camped at the
road a mile away, I
bailed our way round
to Te Puna Bay where
I reckoned the deer
would be feeding
after spending the
winter in the
Huiarau range.

Author: FORRESTER
Quote:
Until I became a
Government field
officer at Ruatahuna
I didn'tknow a thing
about catching trout
the legal way.
Bullets, worms ...
and that good old
Public Works bait,
gelignite... all
these methods I
could use with
deadly results.

The most capable
officers of the
Public Works
Department were from
time to time
instructed to report
on it.

It cannot be that
the Public Works
Department has
changed its opinion
as to the resources
of the country
through which the
line passes.

Author: COLE
Quote:
Here the Public
Works gangs still
use the pick and
shovel. The rattle
of their implements,
and the occasional
echoing wham of a
charge of gelly, and
the deepening engine
note of a passing
vehicle as it
changes into low
gear on the ...
slippery
bush-shadowed bends,
seem only to nibble
at the vast silence.

Author: NOONAN
Quote:
There was no Public
Works Department
inNew Zealand until
1870.

Author: NOONAN
Quote:
Under date 26 May
1948, Cabinet
approvedof the
Public Works
Department
beingmerged in the
Ministry of Works
for
alladministrative
purposes under
theCommissioner of
Works as permanent
head.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Driving along the
Wairoa-Napier road,
I was brought to a
halt by the Ministry
of Works... I myself
had worked for the
Public Works (to use
its old name) on the
Rotorua-Tirau road.

My father, out of
work as a
consequence of the
Great Depression,
desperate to find
employment ended up
in a Public Works
relief scheme on the
construction of the
Mangatiti Road
junction in the same
area.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
The Works camp was
in a small patch of
bush.

Author: COLE
Quote:
The re-opened Public
Works camp, where
Iam engaged as a
clerk, is on the
flat amile distant.

Author: COLE
Quote:
﻿Here the
Public Works gangs
still use thepick
and shovel.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: GLOBE-FISH Contusus richei (Freminville) ... It has several other popular names such as Balloon-fish and Mouse-fish. In America it is known as Rabbit-fish and Stink-fish. The most humorous name is that of Publican-fish. ... The most witty name, Publican-fish given to it by Australian fishermen, is said to have originated from the resemblance of an inflated Globe-fish to the rotundity of many successful publicans.

Author: WILSON
Quote: PUBLICANFISH: see Globefish. Ibid. 182 PUBLICAN-FISH Another name for the Globe-fish, given apparently because of its round, bloated resemblance to early New Zealand publicans.

The most active
thing, the only
thing in your body,
is the mind, your
brain. And if
anything affects
that, then you're
puckarooed. You've
had it.

His command of the Native tongue was pleasantly accurate. The words pakeha, kapi, waipero, hoea and puckaroo came rolling out of him like ribaldry from Uriah when he found the trick David had played on him.

Author: MUIR
Quote: 'I don't know. His old man was pretty strict, of course. ... Probably pukarooed any romances.'

Author: CASEY
Quote: It used to be a real crackerjack, but I'd puckerooed it completely, eh.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: The New Zealand equivalent [to go bung `break down'], puckeroo or be puckerooed sound like an English word used by the maoris and returned with some damage to the voicing of the consonants; but is is actually from the Maori pakaru `break'.
pukaru v. break [Maori pakaru, broken].

Author: MASON
Quote: WHA. Haangi puckerooed by now, I bet. Kumaras like bullets, pigs all burnt up. [note 99] puckerooed: English version of Maori pakaru, meaning shattered, or broken or rendered useless. The word is used several times in the play, both in its Maori and Pakeha form; it is much stronger in Maori.

Author: McGILL
Quote: puckeroo ruin, Maori `pakaru', broken or shattered pieces, used WWI soldiers; eg `This torch is puckerooed!'

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
... until recently
he never would have
mislaid his maul or
used his axe [to
bash in iron wedges]
instead, which is
the surest way to
buckeroo an axe
Uncle Ted says.
puckeroo: broken
puckeroo NZ sl. 1 a. useless, broken. 2 v.t. (esp. in p.p.) ruin. [M pakaru break, broken]
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 391]

Quote:
"He was scooped and
there was nothing to
suggest that he was
puckeroo," trainer
John Boon said.

`Before long he was
fair-dinkum bushed.
He had a compass ...
but it was
puckeroo'd. Well, he
decided it was a
dead loss ...'

Author: McGill
Quote:
He...said he had
heard nothing, bit
puckerooed after all
that mucking about
looking for gold in
the quarry.

Author: BAXTER
Quote: Pud-puller! he whispered bitterly to his reflection.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
I pulled more
pudding over my
side, and I curled
myself up to fit in
with her ... And
then I fell asleep.

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: We walked on to the top of the bank towards the sea about a mile [near Thames], but soon got off the good land, and passed over an entire bed of pudding-stones from 10 to 50 lb. weight. Ibid. 342 The low land did not exceed a quarter of a mile, when we came to rising ground, covered with Kaikatoa - very ordinary.

Source: Excursion in the Northern Island of NZ
Author: COLENSO
Quote:
The rocks in this
locality [East
cape], were chiefly
composed of
sand-and-pudding-stone;
the latter
containing immensely
large oyster shells.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
The eastern
extremity of this
bay is formed by a
rocky peninsula of
pudding-stone, worn
by the action of the
waves

The miner took the
naming of rocks into
his own hands, and
pronounced the
softer country
"sandstone," where
this had not to be
called
"puddingstone,"
"mullock-bands," or
hard-bars."

Also, a small parcel
of nine and a-half
tons for the Tapu
Gold-Mining Company,
which, after being
puddled, gave
forty-two ounces of
retorted gold and
some five ounces of
very rich specimens
from the stamper
boxes.

Now money is your
only friend, / So if
you want some tin to
spend, / To paddocks
rich your footsteps
bend, / And your
time there well
employ; / When no
one's looking fill
your dish, /And you
may wash out what
you wish, / Puddling
mullock's knocked
into a `mish,' /
Hard work will but
annoy.

Source: History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago
Author: PYKE
Quote:
There was nothing to
`puddle' - anything
like the stiff-clays
of Bendigo being
non-existent.

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
The Chinese swarm
around, my boys, /
Puddling every bit
of ground.

Author: CONNELL & HADFIELD
Quote:
On the more gently
sloping land,
especially where it
is cultivated,
puddle erosion, the
loss of fine
particles in muddy
water run-off, and
rilling, small
gullies in
cultivated
hillsides, also
occur.

[Chief Ranger
speaks] Instead of a
new chev. truck we
found we had an old
chev. puddle-jumper
- a Second World War
puddle-jumper - and
if any of you have
ever driven a
puddle-jumper ...
Notes: 9.00 am (Spectrum Documentary about Tongariro National Park)

Quote:
With a little
training, the
average Joe can get
in one of these
puddle-jumpers and
have some fun.

Author: BLYTH
Quote: Puddlers: Circular machines used for washing paydirt.

The puddler they
found in capital
condition, and a
very good asset to
the company.

The advocates for
sluicing believe
that this is the
only way that
anything can be made
out of the ground,
while the puddler
thinks if he can
make, as a few are
now doing, GBP8 or
GBP10 a week ...
[From the Otago Daily Times] Next came the puddler, with his puddling machine, making fortunes of quite handsome dimensions, digging further still into the hill and reducing its bulk.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
I may mention, in
proof of the
permanent character
of the gold-field,
that Major Croker
has had numerous
applications for
permission to erect
puddling machines.
.. I find that the
applicants are for
the most part old
Bendigo puddlers,
who, no doubt,
remember well the
extraordinary
success that waited
on the efforts of
those who first
established this
method of extracting
the gold from the
soil in Victoria.

The Greytown correspondent of the Heathcote Advertiser states that a miner in that town, named John Duvain, has come into the possession of GBP450,000. There are also two brothers, puddlers, of the same place, who have lately received the intelligence from America of a third brother having made provision for the annuity of GBP250 per annum for each of them for life.

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
A day with a
prospecting dish is
real good fun, and
will often give the
novice puddler
visions of gold that
will put to shame
the [21] goose that
laid the golden
eggs.

Author: MAY
Quote:
PUDDLING: separating
gold from clay.
[From the Otago Daily Times] Next came the puddler, with his puddling machine, making fortunes of quite handsome dimensions, digging still further into the hill and reducing its bulk.

The discoverers are
also the proprietors
of the first
puddling machine
erected on these
diggings ...

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
I may mention, in
proof of the
permanent character
of the gold-field,
that Major Croker
has had numerous
applications for
permission to erect
puddling machines.
.. I find that the
applicants are for
the most part old
Bendigo puddlers,
who, no doubt,
remember well the
extraordinary
success that waited
on the efforts of
those who first

Author: WEKEY
Quote: (quoting Otago Gfds Regs) Claims shall be classified thus;- 1. Ordinary Claims, i.e., alluvial claims worked without the aid of sluices or machines. 2. Sluice and machine claims, i.e., alluvial claims worked with the aid of sluices or puddling machines. 3. Wet Claims, i.e.., alluvial claims in flooded ground ... 4. Creek or river claims, i.e., alluvial claims in the bed of creeks or rivers. 5. Quartz claims.

Mr. Wilson tried
hard to make money;
he even made a
"corner" in puddling
machines, but just
when he had got his
plans perfected a
change in the
process was made,
and so the "corner"
collapsed, leaving
Mr. Wilson very much
the poorer for his
enterprise.

Author: MONEY
Quote:
For three days I
`did duty' on a
puddling machine
until the `gaffer',
finding me not equal
to the others, who
were all old hands,
gave me the sack.

The puddling machine
interest is stronger
here than in other
parts of the
Province, but the
results ... offer no
very cheering
assurance of its
adaptability to
these gold fields.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ORTYGOMETRA TABUENSIS. (SWAMP-RAIL.) ... Native names..- Pueto and Putoto.

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
...thus they sat/ to
make some puff-cakes
boiled in fat.
Puff-pipe- An anti-siphonage pipe from a single waste water fixture carried up on the outside of a building and terminating at least 150 mm above the overflow level of the fixture.

Source: Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author: CROWE
Quote:
Both the giant and
common puffball are
recommended as being
amongst the best of
the puffballs, so
long as they are
solid and white
inside.

Source: Field Guide to Native Edible Plants of NZ
Author: CROWE
Quote:
The Maori ate young
puffballs.. after
steaming.

Author: BROOKER et al.
Quote: Calvatia caelata (Bull.) Morg. Common name: Puffball Maori name: Pukurau. In Hooker's `Handbook ...', the name `pukurau' or `pukuvau' is applied to Lycoperdon fontanesei ... which is now known as Calvatia caelata. In Williams ... the name `pukurau' is identified as Clathrus cibarium ... a net-like fungus ... [C. caelata is found in Europe ...as well as NZ.]

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Tank Tarrant once
led his gang across
the paddocks ...,
kicking the
puffballs and the
sheep turds,
throwing the dry cow
pats at any tarts he
met. Chanting the
gang haka.

The common puffball
is also finely
flavoured. This is
nearer a golfball
size than a
softball, and it has
a stem.

The giant puffball
grows in any soil
with high organic
matter, often on
bare earth and on
back lawns,
including my own.

I well remember the
strict warnings
never to pick the
puffball, and it was
always a source of
great satisfaction
to trample the
puffballs that had
gone brown and watch
the evil yellow
cloud of spores
spurt forth.

Author: MARSHALL
Quote:
Arthur picked up a
large puff-ball and
punted it high into
the air. "One for
the forwards," he
cried, and laughed
as the khaki dust
drifted in the sky
and the broken
fungus dropped back
to the ground.

Author: MORELAND
Quote: GLOBEFISH [Spheroides jaculiferus] ... Puffer, toado, common toado, are alternative names sometimes heard here.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: GLOBEFISH ... Other names: Spheroides richei; puffer, common toado, sand toado.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
puffer 2354-73
PUFFERFISHES 2353-83

Council staff sprang
into action
yesterday morning
when more than 250
puffer fish were
found scattered over
two kilometres
between Karaka Bay
and Fort Dorset...
National Institute
of Water and
Atmosphere spokesman
Malcolm Francis said
quick action was
necessary as the
fish were extremely
toxic... Puffer fish
were common in New
Zealand waters, but
they rarely washed
up on the beaches.

Author: AYLING
Quote: GLOBEFISH (Pufferfish, prickly toadfish) Contusus richei (Sphoeroides richei) ... The globefish is a round bodied puffer ... [317] They prefer shallow coastal waters and are found in large numbers just off sandy beaches.

Author: PARROTT
Quote:
Flathead
Kathetostoma
giganteum
Puffer-fish

Author: PAUL
Quote: Pufferfish Contusus richei Alternatively globefish, or toadfish. Also present in southern Australia.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] pufferfish .. [scientific name] Sphoeroides sp. .. [other name(s)] --

Author: PAUL
Quote: Clown toado Canthigaster callisternus Alternatively sharpnosed pufferfish. Present off south-east Australia, regularly seen around north-eastern New Zealand.

Author: AYLING
Quote: CLOWN TOAD (Sharpnosed pufferfish) Canthigaster callisternus ...The clown toado is a small puffer ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: There is also a sort of Puffin or pelicanoides, commonly called the mutton-bird, which the natives take in large quantities by lighting fires on the seaward face of the hills near the coast, into which these birds, called titi by the natives, fly, and are killed.
As we hear the short-tailed puffin at night flying overhead, I count it also as one of our Tutira birds. It is called by the bushmen the `mutton-bird,' but can be only ... Puffinus caudus.

Fishermen have
nicknamed
Hector'sdolphins
"puffing pigs."

Author: FUTTER
Quote: PUFTALOONS ... Flour ... Butter ... Baking Powder ... Milk. Salt ... roll out lightly as thin as a wafer, cut in rounds ... fry a golden brown ... Serve very hot ... eaten with golden syrup.

Author: McKAY
Quote: PUFFTALOONS Drain on ... paper, serve at once with jam, or honey.
pufftaloons, pufftaloonies ...n. pl. hot fried cakes spread with jam, sugar, or honey.

An undetermined kaolinic product - the `pug' of the miners - is fairly abundant in the reefs. Ibid. 113 (Coromandel) The actual vein-walls are frequently smooth and slickensided, being separated from the wass-rock by a narrow selvage of plaster finely comminated rock (locally termed `pug') Ibid 114 They are in almost all cases fissures filled, as the result of rock-movement and decomposition processes, with clayey material (`pug')

The more steeply
dipping contacts
between these
andesites and the
older land-surface
... are usually
marked by a heavy of
band slickensided
pug.

... there was merely
a narrow vein of
pug, showing no
scheelite, but a
little gold.

This silica settled
in pockets, forming
the siliceous `pug'
common in the
workings of the New
Zealand quick-silver
mines ...

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
The house itself was
built of pug, that
mixture of clay and
tussock which makes
the most comfortable
of all dwellings,
cool in summer and
warm in winter. ..
The chimneys were
huge, each one four
feet of solid pug
all round.

The nature of the
sinking is 40ft
through pug.

On my return on
Friday I found the
party labouring in
soft blue pug which
behaved like quick
sand.

The present face is
showing quartz grit
mixed up in pug
seams.

Source: Maori and Pakeha in North Otago
Author: STEVENSON
Quote:
The blue pug in
which they [bones]
are usually found ..
is impervious to
both air and water.

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol III
Author: TAIT
Quote:
A hard clay pug
subsoil has required
heavy draining.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
Suddenly the blue
pug released its
grip on all four
legs and, spraying a
bow wave of mud, the
cow shot across the
top of the bog like
a speed boat..

Author: STACEY
Quote:
It is backed by a
large hill of
unstable blue and
white pug which in
the wet season,
becomes like a mass
of soft putty.

There are certain
paddocks that pug
badly in winter ...

Wintering is in two
mobs, and care is
needed to avoid
pugging the pakihi.

If they're pugging
the verge, get them
off as you could be
responsible for any
damage to the
District Council.

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
Some of the lads
made their
[sun-dried] bricks
in what they called
a pug ring, formed
by driving the
horses round in a
circle as with the
old-time
chaffcutter, but
Cecil made his on
what they called a
straight. A strip of
ground about 30
yards long by four
or five wide was
scooped free of top
soil, which was
dumped on the garden
nearby. It was then
ploughed about ten
inches deep, or
according to the
number of bricks
required, and very
well watered, which
was usually done
with a shovel from a
tank on a sledge for
even distribution,
and left to soak all
night. A good layer
of chopped-up
tussocks was then
evenly spread over
the top. After more
watering a six-horse
team was driven up
and down the strip
until the pug was
well mixed.

.. if the pigs have
a fairly large run
and the shelter is
shifted about as
soon as the ground
in front shows signs
of 'pugging up'...

Wet land is not
pugged up in the
winter months.

If you abuse your
pastures by allowing
them to pug up
excessively, you
will have a bumper
crop of buttercup
and pennyroyal ...

Author: SINCLAIR & TROTTER
Quote:
I put on a lot of
lime in the early
days. I might have
overdone some of the
paddocks, it made
them very free on
top, in the winter
they used to pug up.
2.

By July the weather
is getting wetter
and the cows will
pug up the breaks
they graze on rainy
days.

Author: STRONACH
Quote:
Nails would stick in
those brittle pug
walls.

Author: McKEON
Quote:
One day [ca1905]
after school hours I
was engaged in the
forbidden sport of
`pug-heaving', which
consisted of rolling
small balls of clay,
impaling them on a
whippy stick and
letting fly at some
convenient object,
the fun being to
watch the clay balls
flatten on impact.

In season pugged
areas become a sea
of yellow buttercup.

Author: CONNELL & HADFIELD
Quote:
On heavy soils in
wet weather,
however, soil
compaction is
undesirable because
the soil structure
is broken down, or
'pugged', reducing
water penetration
and aeration.

Even though stock
concentrations
reached more than
400 cows an acre,
only two areas were
pugged, amounting to
half an acre in all.

Low-lying portions
are liable to
"pugging" if stocked
to any extent in the
winter.

Author: CONNELL & HADFIELD
Quote:
.. sod-seeding may
be practised with
advantages not only
of .. but also ..
less pugging of the
soil during the
first winter
grazing.

Care has been
essential to avoid
serious pugging, but
now it could be
worse.

.. the swear word on
Taranaki farms at
this time of the
year is pugging.

Author: SALMOND
Quote: Pugmill. a mechanical device used to break clay down in preparation for brickmaking.

Author: HILLIARD
Quote: [Maori speaks] Don't ask me. I suppose they frightened we eat them with pork and puha, eh? Ibid. 220 `you never see watercress here, eh? And puha, with a bit of brisket or pork-bones'.
puha n -s [Maori] New Zealand : a sow thistle (Sonchus oleraceus) that is commonly used as a potherb <~ turned up with practically everything, corned beef, boiled bacon, baked rabbit - Ruth Park>

Author: JOHNSTON
Quote: On making New Zealand, Cook was pleased to find wild celery growing in profusion as well as `scurvy grass' of the cress family and the native sowthistle, puwha.

A WEED that was
ruthlessly removed
by hand from corn
crops in the
Gisborne area has
now become a crop
itself with a market
that covers the East
Coast and Rotorua
districts. This is
the sow thistle,
better known as
`rauriki' in the
Wellington district,
which, marketed as
`puha,' finds a
ready sale at 1/- a
bundle. There are
two varieties, puha
tiotio or
prickly-leaved, and
puha pororua, or
smooth - leaved. [So
Williams Dict 318]

Author: McCALLUM
Quote: As easy as pulling puha out of wet ground. Ibid. 98 Puha: Maori cabbage.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Sea-eggs, puha,
pork, and kumara:/
The Maori owned the
land. I have a
camera.

For example, puha -
a plant still
commonly eaten by
Maori - had more
than three times the
level of
antioxidants than
blueberries.

local version of
puha, found growing

Appian [sic] Way -

a par with the Kiwi

Author: BURNS
Quote: A sow thistle Poowha

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: When I reproved a chief for not compelling his children to attend school, his excuse was, that as soon as they arose in the morning, they went and gathered little bundles of Puwha, sow thistles or sticks, which they carried to the town and sold, either for a few pence or a little food, saying, they were like the fowls which went scratching about for food.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Puwha, Col[enso]. Sonchus oleraceus.

Author: TREGEAR

PUHA OR SOW THISTLE ...throw out stalks and branches, clea ean thoroughly ... squeezing out the bitter milky juice, cook with dripping and meat ... When puha becomes popular, it will be like the once despised potato, a national boon.

Whaariki/ - to help

Author: HILGENDORF

This is very similar to the former [S.oleraceus, sowthistle] in all respects, except that the margins of the leaves are much more prickly, ... This form seems scarcely as common as the former, though it was found in New Zealand when Cook arrived here.
puwha [=] prickly sow thistle: sow thistle [s]

Quote:
I took her advice
and every day
gathered half a
sugarbag full of
puha (sow thistle)
and korau, the wild
turnip.

Amongst [the weeds]
were very large
quantities of sow
thistle (puha),
large quantities of
which we boiled.

A Maori woman is
raffling a parcel of
puha, a tray of eggs
and a meat pack, but
there are few
takers.

Whether it's an
Irish stew, a
delicious French
pot-au-feu, or an
old-fashioned Kiwi
pork and puha, a
boil-up will satisfy
winter appetites.

Author: PARK
Quote:
I took her advice
and every day
gathered half a
sugarbag full of

and korau, the wild
turnip.

For vegetables there

the Maori turnip,
and puwha (rauriki)

Basic English is as
.. useless.. as the
recent report to the
Son of Heaven on
"The Immediate
Practicality of
Supplementing the

Rice and More Rice
with Pouha (sic)

We'd go each weekend
to gather pipis and
pick watercress and
puha in Howick and
that would last us
till pay day.

As you rightly point
out, the different
types of puha or sow
thistles are
ubiquitous
throughout the
world. From Gisborne
I went to live in
Greece, where
picking "horta"
(puha) is akin to a
national pastime.

[Caption] Sonchus
oleraceus, pororua
or common puha; S.
kirkii, raurorua or
NZ native puha.
Ibid. The original
Maori puha was
rauroroa or S.
kirkii - a ntive
which has a whitish
bloom on the leaf
surfaces and is
usually found near
the coast... Puha
leaves were put on
cuts and wounds to
prevent infection,
and waipuha, or
water in which puha
had been boiled, was
drunk to cure
stomach complains
and loss of
appetite.

Spread an old
newspaper on the
floor andon it place
a steaming pot of
puha,kamo-kamo,
riwai,
brisket-on-the-bone
anddumplings what we
call: doughboys.

We became great
mates. We'd stop in
thestreet for a
yack- how's it going
andwhatever - and
they'd bring me in
feedsof puha.

Get your
puha-picking hands
off our man!
Puwha is a popular green vegetable and can also be used to treat warts by slapping it onto the skin.

Cooked like this,
puha tastes a little
like cooked lettuce,
and unlike the usual
slow-boiled version.

Puwha tiotio (Sonchus asper), the prickly leaf sow thistle and Puwha pororua (Sonchus oleraceus), the smooth leaf sow thistle are actually not natives but were probably brought here by early Maori. The Maori name is often spelt as puha.

For vegetables [in
early Banks
Peninsula] there was
plenty of pora, the
Maori turnip, and
puwha (rauriki) or
sowthistle ...

The Puwha, or [31] Milk-thistle (Sonchus oleraceus), the large-leaved variety was common, though not (it is reasonably suspected) too plentiful; and this was abandoned for the smaller-leaved European kind (after its introduction) as being less bitter and more palatable.
The next is the puwha, or comon sow-thistle (Sonchus oleraceus, var., or two varieties, exclusive of the later introduced British one).

The Rev. W. Colenso
... considers this
var. [Sonchus
oleraceus L. asper
... leaves clasping,
sharply toothed] to
be the puwha of the
Maoris, who formerly
used it for food,
but abandoned it for
the introduced
European plant,
which is less
bitter.

and puha on the

Quote: One of these [curious plants of Stewart Island] is the puharitaiko (senecio rotundifolius) with large glossy-green leathery leaves, on which messages can be written in ink. These leaves could be stamped and sent through the post-office a few years ago, but the practice is now interdicted.

Author: KEENE
Quote: puhau: raft made of raupo and dried flax-seed stems.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Puheritaiko, Lyall. Senecio rotundifolius.

The traveller who visits Stewart Island in December or January will have his attention arrested by the blaze of crimson presented by the rata (Metrosideros lucida), often flecked with the pale racemes of the kamahi (Weinmannia racemosa), the deep green leaves of the puheretaiko and the tupari (Senecio rotundifolius and Olearia colensoi), and the grass-like leaves of the inaka (Drachophyllum longifolium), all of which form a fringe of greater or less breadth at the water's edge, and (except the puheretaiko) often expand into large masses ascending to the crests of the hills.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: Where the coastal scrub of Stewart Island is densest, it has received the name of `mutton-bird scrub'. This consists largely of the puheritaiko, a very fine shrubby groundsel (Senecio rotundifolius) ...

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: ... they creep over the thinly scatterd flat, fresh fallen Puheretaiko leaves [on the Snares island].

Author: HOWARD
Quote: Along the coastal fringes [of Stewart Island] it consists of a characteristic scrub known locally as `Mutton-bird scrub', the principal constituents ... being Puheretaiko (Senecio Rotundifolius), Tete-a-weka (Olearia Angustifolia) and Daisy Tree (Olearia Colensoi).

Author: WILSON
Quote: Senecio reinoldii MUTTONBIRD SCRUB ... Puuheretaaiko ... Muttonwood ... Shrub or small tree. Leaves leathery ...

f.
Puheritaiko (Senecio rotundifolius) and S. eloaeagnifolius, are very ornamental shrub-trees, having large leathery leaves, covered on the back with white wool.

In the birch bush

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote: [From the Auckland Provincial Gazette.] .. The principal "puia" at Tokanu is called Pirori, an intermittent fountain, whose column of boiling water, of two feet in diameter, sometimes reaches a height of more than 40 feet.

Author: BULLER
Quote: Hochstetter divides the steam jets into three kinds: 1. Puias, which are geysers, continuously or intermittently active. 2. Ngawas, which are inactive Puias - emitting steam, but not throwing up columns of water. 3. Waiarikis, which mean any sort of cistern of hot water suitable for bathing.

The word Puia is
especially used in
the Taupo country,
to designate the
intermittent,
geyser-like
fountains of Tokanu
... and of
Whakarewarewa on
Lake Rotorua. Puia
has ... the more
general meaning of
crater or volcano,
and is applied to
active as well as
extinct volcanoes.
... Ngawhas [is] a
term specially used
for non-intermittent
springs, for the
solfataras and
sulphurous
hot-springs on the
Rotomahana, Rotorua,
and Rotoiti.
Finally, the springs
suited to bathing
purposes, the water
of which never
reaches the boiling
point, and all
naturally warm baths
are called
`Waiariki,'
corresponding to the
Laugar of Iceland.

In her passage
underground she set
fire to the world
below, hence the hot
springs, puias,
fumaroles ... in the
line of route.

... strange to say,
several large masses
of waterworn gravel
cemented by
puia-deposit into a
compact rock are to
be seen a short
distance below the
bridge at Taupo.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
About three miles

An account of the PUKA (Meryta Sinclairii, Seem.) By T. KIRK.

Pú.ka (pú.k&adot.), n. [Maori.] 1. (Bot.) A New Zealand tree (Meryta Sinclairii), of the order Araliaceae; - called also broadleaf. [Local, North Island of N. Z.] 2. (Bot.) Either of two species of New Zealand trees Griselina lucida and G. littoralis) of the order Corneae. G. littoralis is usually called broadleaf by the settlers. [Local, N. Z.]
