Author: LEDYARD
Quote:
... they add what
they call the
Bugabuga or the
Toga, and sometimes
both. The Bugabuga
is a very coarse
covering made with
little trouble, and
affords a good
shelter from cold or
wet weather : The
Toga is different
and is equally
calculated for use
and elegance : The
Bugabuga is formed
round and converging
to the top where
there is an
apperture just
sufficient to admit
the head to pass
through, and when
on, covers the body
as low as the hip :
If it storms, or
they have occasion
to stop where they
have no other
shelter they squat
down upon their
hams, and then the
bottom of the
Bugabuga reaching
the ground, forms a
shelter to the whole
body (the head
excepted) which
looks in that
situation as if it
had been severed
from a human form,
and fixed upon a
hay-cock.

{Hdg] New wheels for
Pukaha team. The
team of five
undertaking
predator-control in
the Mount Bruce
pukaha forest have
the use of a new
quad bike...

The lake floor is
formed of a species
of pukahu, similar
to that found in
kauri forests, and
termed "bukau" by
bushmen.

... the floor of the kauri bush is covered with a thick coating of vegetable humus (pukahu), which is rendered highly inflammable by a mixture of dead leaves, particles of gum, and scales dropped from the resinous bark. Ibid. 493 Wherever the kauri-trees grow ... the ground is covered with a thick [493] layer of humus (pukahau), composed of vegetable fibre intemingled with fallen leaves, particles of gum, and scales from the resinous bark, the latter helping to form a solid bank, sometimes several feet in height, round the base of the trees.

Author: LEVY
Quote: Really hot, white-ash burns of the felled forest were rarely secured, [15] which meant that large numbers of the felled trees did not burn, much raw pukahu was left merely blackened, ... Ibid. 94 In high humidity forests, ... pukahu - undecomposed dead forest litter - may accumulate on the forest floor, feet in depth.

Author: REED
Quote: In early days the volume of the timber would not have warranted the time and expense involved clearing away the accumulated debris, known as pukahu (Maori: masses of rootlets), and usually referred to by the bushmen as `bookau'. Ibid. 208 The platform enabled a man to go from side to side, in order to pour pukahu down the face of the dam as a preventive of leaks in the planking. This pukahu (bookau to the bushman) was the matted, fibrous material which gathered at the foot of large Kauris.
PUKAU Short for pukahukau. The mound at the base of mature kauri trees. syn. CONE

Stumps can vary in
height up to 3.2
metres above ground
level ... When the
stumps are covered
by a pukahu - a
mound of shed bark
and other
forestlitter - it is
necessary to dig
down to find the
stump height.

Author: REED
Quote:
Some of the men were
sent to pukahu it
[the dam].

Author: REED
Quote:
`I have known these
bookau fires to stay
alight through
fairly heavy falls
of rain, and after a
few fine days to get
going again'.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
Good burns were hard
to obtain and most
burns were not hot
enough to consume
all timber, so that
much pukahu was left
on the forest floor.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote: They dwelt in whares [11] (huts) built in the traditional shape of an inverted V, roofed with grass, and lined inside with the reeds of the toetoe or New Zealand pampas grass. The orthodox Maori name for these reeds is pukakaho, but the white men called them `bukaka'. Ibid. 44 A potato was hollowed and a bukaka stem was inserted and the [pipe] owner puffed away. Ibid. 139-140 One spot was marked by a lot of bukakas [140] (toitois) and when they drained it they found the skeleton of a saddled horse.

The total bag
consists of 54 grey
ducks, seven
puk[a]ki and two
swans.

"Thanks, sonny, but
I'll push on to my
lonely cot by the
mossy rill and Dan's
stewed pukaki."

Mrs M'Killop had
already received so
many compliments and
remmembrances from
him, varying from
recipes for potting
pukaki to panaceas
for rheumatism, that
her faithful Celtic
heart was almost
resigned to the
probable loss of her
mistress and
nursling.

Everyone was

Thompson allegedly

performed a pukana -
the part of the haka
that involves
rolling of the eyes,
poking of the
tongue, and
thrusting the upper
body towards an
opponent.

[Noel Harris] was so
chuffed at having
won the race for the
first time in his 35
years in the saddle
that he let rip the
Maori pukana which
only last month

Michael Walker in

As for her reaction

means instead of

clever enough to do

The women are
smiling and doing

fierce.

While the
controversial
22-year-old did not
deliver a pukana
(poking out tongue
and rolling eyes) at

meeting, he said he
would carry on but
"only at the big
races". ... Victory:
Michael Walker
celebrates his

earned a warning

Sizeranne to victory

Stoney Bridge Stakes

Are not Wellington's

over-correctness in

Michael Walker for
delivering a pukana
as he passed the
post first at a
recent meeting?

Walker's pukana
(poking out his
tongue and rolling
his eyes) is exactly
the sort of colour
the sport needs as
it seeks to attract
people back to the
nation's
racecourses.

"It wasn't until I

Tara do the pukana
with ther eyes -
then, straight away,
I saw behind her an
old woman.. doing
the same thing."

Mr Harawira said he

pukana-style when he

Pukanui, Meryta
Snclairii[sic]
(Paddle leaf)was

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: MERYTA SINCLAIRII, puka, pukanui. Meryta is a genus of the south Pacific. Its southernmost occurrence is in New Zealand, where its natural distribution is limited to two groups of islands, the Hen and Chickens, and the Three Kings. ... [M.sinclairii] is widely cultivated as an ornamental tree ...in warmer parts of the country.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: Pukanui (Meryta sinclairii): a small tree with very large simple leaves which is also found on the Hen and Chicken Islands off the Northland east coast.

Another to protect
from the family
florist is the
huge-leafed Meryta
sinclairii, Pukanui.

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: PISONIA BRUNONIANA. Parapara is a small tree of quick, rather soft growth carrying leaves up to 40cm long, of dark glossy green ... Nodular ridges down the length of the `fruit' ... secrete a glutinous substance ... Most spectacular is the ability of this tarry substance to hold small birds. ... anyone who has seen a waxeye struggling to free itself from amongst a cluster of these fruits can easily understand why parapara has earned the name `bird-catching tree'. ... Where it grows with pukanui (Meryta sinclairii) two of our largest-leaved trees come together.

There are [sic] a

does. [pungapunga]

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Pukapuka - the word applied either to paper or books - at first sight appears to be derived from our English word book; it is not so, but from the large white leaf of the Pukapuka Rangiora (Brachyglottis repanda), to which the natives likened paper when they first saw it. They said, `He rau pukapuka tenei!' `Oh! this is a leaf of the Pukapuka.' The Greeks derived their [biblos] book, and the Latins their Liber, book, in a similar way, from the inner bark of the Linden or Teil tree, and the Egyptians theirs from the leaf of the Papyrus, whence comes our word paper.

You may recall the
recent TV commercial
featuring a boy
floating pukapuka
leaves down a river.

Even in the North

The pukatea is

tree above the
ground. Its leaves
are thick, serrated,
and of a glossy
green; the wood is
said to be
close-grained, and
to resemble a pine.

Notes: It is considered a good sign in this province if fuschia, whitewood, and pukatea (often called buckateer) abound.

But here, a little

pukeko: swamp hen.

Of the boys' funny
sayings [in the
1930s] two live on
in my memory. ...
And if he was asked
where he was going,
he would answer: `Up
the boo-ai in a
matchbox hunting
pukakers [pukekos]
with a long-handled
shovel.'

The swamp hen, or
pukaki, has been
noticed by some of
your writers.

Farmers left only
small pockets of
manuka and kanuka,
some up to 12 metres
tall, and a narrow
band of broad-leaved
trees - karaka, two
large-leaved trees,
one kohekohe and one
wharangi - in the
steep Forest Valley
on the island's east
side.

In a quaint
old-world lagoonThe
wild pukaki breeds.

The road winds into
the countryside past
mailboxes, barking
dogs, slack-uddered
cows, milking sheds,
pukeko stalking
through long wet
grass, beige cows
chewing contentedly,
kids on sweating
ponies, haybarns and
still more cows
until finally there
it is.
He also sees pukekos. What a brilliant bird! Porphyrio porphyrio melanotus, otherwise known as the purple swamp-hen.

We tried using
pukekos as surrogate
mothers for them,
but, as they grew
up, they thought
they were pukekos
and ran away from
other takahe.

There are a few art
enthusiasts here and
there amongst us,
but.. their voices
have been as the
voice of the pukako
crying in the
wilderness.

That handsome bird,
the pukeko, with its
brilliant purple
neck and breast and
crimson beak, is
often seen.

Before Messrs Thomas
Bamber and Morton
Jones, J.P.'s, this
morning R. E. M.
Campbell pleaded
guilty to a charge
of killing a pukeka
out of season.

Next to the plant is
a paddock, puggy now
in mid-winter, four
pukeko pecking
desultorily, empty
save for the birds.

Stewed Pukaki. Hang
for some time, then
skin like a rabbit
or hare, and stew or
jug like wild duck
or hare.

The raupo spread of

kakapo or bo-kaker

Besides themselves

save only the
sprightly pukaki of

We awoke to four
plump pukeko
preening in a line
outside the window.

This verdant fringe
of reed and rush is
the home of the
porphyrio melanotus,
or pukeko.

The pakeha boat..
gliding across
raupo-fringed lakes,
where the wild duck
and pukaki, the
black swan and the
red bill muster in
countless mobs.

...at least I had a

You know, you buy

Mr. E. Tregear, in his Maori Polynesian Dictionary, and the Rev. H. W. Williams in the Polynesian Journal, give "Pukunui" as the Maori name of the dotterel.

Has anybody ever seen the bird Pukunui ("Big Stomach")? It was once supposed to exist in the North Island, but no European has reported it to science, and its existence has now become very problematical and perhaps mythical.

Author: YATE
Quote: Pukunui - A bird so called from the largeness and rotundity of its breast, about the size of the crow, and remarkable for the deep red with which the feathers are tinged upon the back and under the wings. (Williams 309 2.n) Pluvialis obscurus, dotterel : see TURIWHATI

Several fungi were also eaten ... such as the two large terrestrial species called pukurau (Lycoperdon fontanesei and L. giganteum); the harore (Agaricus adiposus); the hakekakeka (Hirneola auricula judae); and the paruwhatitiri (Ileodictyon cibarium).

[Also eaten were] several Fungi [especially] ... four ... which grow on trees, - the Harori (Agaricus adiposus), the Hakeke, and the Popoiahakeke (Polyporus species, and the Pekepekekiore (Hydnum clathroides); also, three terrestrial ones, - the Paruwhatitiri (Ileodictyon cibarium), the Pukurau (Lycoperdon Fontainesii), ... Ibid. 57 ... for severe burns ... [Maoris] applied ... the fine reddish dust of the large decaying fungus pukirau (Lycoperdon fontainesii).

Author: BROOKER et al.

In Hooker's `Handbook ...', the name `pukurau' or `pukuvau' is applied to Lycoperdon fontanesei ... which is now known as Calvatia caelata. In Williams ... the name `pukurau' is identified as Clathrus cibarium ... a net-like fungus ... [C. caelata is found in Europe ...as well as NZ.]

Author: MILLS ET AL
Quote:
Any rash tactic
likely to upset the
sheep can be fatal,
not only to a good
'pull' but also for
later work at hand.
Although it isn't
always possible, try
to avoid a jerky,
stop-and-start kind
of pull.

Pull - when a
heading dog brings -
pulls - sheep to the
shepherd. Should be
as straight as
possible and at
walking pace.

There is a
background of
gorse-flecked hills,
a good pull, a nice
flat for yarding,
and a natural
terrace affords an
excellent vantage
ground for
spectators.

It was considered by
many to be about the
longest run-out in
the country, and the
pull also is far
from easy.

The pull was a bit
loose although the
dog was in
reasonable control
and held a good
line. His sheep
refused to settle
and, with a loose
pull across the
flat, they entered
the ring moving too
freely and the dog
had some difficulty
in getting his hold.

Source: Constitution of NZ Dog Trial Assoc
Quote:
The pull is
completed when the
sheep enter the
ring.

Author: McLEOD
Quote: Heading dog: On which casts wide to reach the `head' of sheep, and brings them back. Their work divides into the `head' and the `pull'.
Pull: Action of dog bringing sheep directly to its handler.
Pull.- (1) A dog pulls sheep when he brings them towards his master. (C.) (2) Hard walk, a long climb. (C.)

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Carpodetus serratus (The Serrate Carpodetus)... The native name Puta-puta-weta signifies full of weta holes. In the North Island trees of this species are rarely cut down unperforated by longitudinal insect galleries. Another name by which it is known is Puna-weta. In the Urewera country it is called Kai-weta (i.e., weta food). [That ugly innocent the weta (Deinacrida) has thus been accused of perforating the tree; but as a matter of fact though often used as convenient residences [195] by the weta, the holes are made by the caterpillar of the large moth Hepialus virescens ...]

horns are visible,
there is no danger."

Mr. Editor, the late
Judge Gillies was at
one time a bullock
puncher, his
education soon made
him leave it.

.. for, although a gentleman armed with a stout walking stick and backed up by one assistant armed with a dumpy level and a second with a painted staff, may get round a sharp corner on the side of a steep hill, it in no way necessarily follows that Long Jem the bull puncher can accomplish the same feat with five or six yoke of bullocks and the dray load of stores ...

Author: McNAUGHTON
Quote:
It was a slow
process, getting
those sheep down.
The hillside was
benchy and rough.
But once they were
started on the
downward journey,
the danger of a
breakaway was past,
and all that
remained was hard
punching to keep
them together.

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
There were no tracks
- just hard punching
all the way, with a
fair number of sheep
dying from tutu
poisoning.

Author: NELSON
Quote:
punching: setting
the dog to drive the
mob along.
vine, puncture [s] Tribulus terrestris L.

Author: HARVEY
Quote:
We tried to find
some water somewhere
to fix the pung, ...
so we settled for
the lavatory bowl.
We soon found out
where the bubbles
were coming from and
fixed the thing up
so's Nuts could put
his wheel back on.

.. by the felling
and uprooting of a
punga tree, they
accidentally came
across the leader
referred to.

The first thing that
called my attention
was a punga which
fell near me.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
It was now that I
heard the popping of
corks ..., and when
we arrived at a
punga summerhouse
..., Betty herself
reached beneath the
seat and placed on
the table a tiny
bottle of cherry
brandy ... .

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
They would.. uncrown
the graceful punga,
or "bungy", as it is
called in local
parlance.

A crumbling chimney,
the uprights of a
boat landing and the
moss-encrusted punga
of a temporary
bird-holding pen are
all that's left of
Henry's residence.

Naturally, clients
who actually leave
messages don't need
you urgently, or
they would have
spoken to someone
else in your office
by now - someone who
wasn't up a punga at
Anakiwa or
empathising on a
marae.

In Karamea the
locals decorated the
beautiful wooden
hall with punga.

In the North Island,
it is better known
by its Maori name,
ponga, sometimes
corrupted into
punga.

He says the most
interesting
inhabitants were the
"spooky but friendly
punga people". The
who? "They're carved
into punga logs with
paua shell eyes.
They live in the
forest,"...

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
We crossed the flat
and entered a narrow
path where high
grasses brushed
against our knees as
we rode past, and
every few yards
streams ran across
it in inverted
culverts of punga
logs.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote:
They would first rig
up a platform.. and
on top of it they
put trunks of punga
fern, because they
gave grip to the
feet.

Author: CHUDLEIGH
Quote:
Made a cow bale in
the morning, worked
at the punga fence
in the afternoon.

Author: LANGDALE-HUNT
Quote:
It was only a punga
house with a
corrugated iron
roof, but
beautifully kept
inside and the
cooking was done
with a colonial
oven.

(The Coroner took
down that the
footprints led from
the direction of the
punga house, the
nearest point in the
direction
indicated.)

Author: MORELAND
Quote:
We drove to the
little
accommodation-house
at the edge of the
bush - a punga
house, i.e. built of
fern logs on end,
filled in with moss
and grass.

A few trees were
left standing about
the tents for shade,
but since the
felling had been
finished to some
distance from the
camps, I have
advised the men to
build for themselves
rough punga huts,
not that I thought
they were in any
danger where they
were, but that I
thought they would
be more comfortable,
and be nearer their
work if they made
huts further up the
road.

Mr. F. A. Bremer
said he had known
Mr. Pearce in the
days when the latter
lived in a tent and
a punga whare.

This is a sure sign
that the district is
emerging from what
may be called the
packhorse and punga
whare stage.

First a punga whare
would be erected, to
be replaced later by
a two-roomed house..
from pit-sawn
timber.

In early 1853 the
Taita settlement was
a sporadic
settlement of punga
whares amongst thick
forest and man-made
clearings.

It was an ordinary
punga whare.

For the first year
or two he is
compelled to live in
a punga whare or a
tent.

Author: Reischek
Quote:
The first night in
this bush I camped
under a punga-punga
(fern-tree).

Source: Holiday Trip to the Catlins District, A
Author: HOLDEN & FENWICK
Quote:
We made our way ....
over the well made
track of
punga-pungas (or in
the vernacular of
the camp `bungies'.)
The pollen also of the flowers of the large Bulrush (Typha angustifolia) was ... collected ... by the Southern tribes, and made into large gingerbread like cakes, called Pungapunga.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Pungapunga, Geolog. Surv. Pollen of Typha angustifolia.

Author: HAY
Quote:
The root of the
raupo ..., the
swamp-grass of which
the Maori construct
their
whare[e-grave], is
edible ...
Punga-punga, the
pollen of the raupo,
used to be made into
bread.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Punga-punga, n. Maori name for the pollen of the raupo (q.v.).
~ n. the pollen of a plant used by the Maoris for making a kind of cake; the cake so made. [Maori]

Source: Two Hundred Years of NZ Food & Cookery
Author: BURTON
Quote: The inner parts and roots of the raupo (Typha orientalis) provided a meagre amount of food, but the seed heads were prized for their bright yellow pollen which was made into loaves known as pungapunga.

Another highly curious article of vegetable food was the pungapunga, the yellow pollen of the raupo flowers- the common bulrush, or cat's reed mace (Typha augustifolia... To use it as food it is mixed up with water into cakes and baked. It is sweetish and light, and reminds one strongly of London gingerbread.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Polystichum vestitum PRICKLY SHIELD FERN ... Puuniu ...Large spreading crowns of long, harsh-textured, glossy dark green fronds, a metre or more long on the largest plants ...

It is a good plan to
put some wood or
coal ashes in the
pig pen every week,
for the hogs to root
over and eat, or
throw in some chunks
of charcoal and punk
or rotten wood for
them to gnaw at
pleasure.

A lecturer aptly
demonstrates the
theory that heat
generates motion by
pointing to a boy
who accidentally sat
down on a piece of
lighted punk.

Author: MACKIE
Quote:
We had no lucifer
matches but my
friend had some

which is very
inflammable and
shooting this from a
pistol it ignited.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
[W.H.S. Roberts

that grew on the

punk, or by the

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
`Punk' [a fungus]
taken from the trees
was at hand
everywhere in the
bush, and was used
for a [home-made
cricket] ball. Large
pieces of punk two
or three pounds in

three balls. ...
[Carterton,
Wairarapa, 1880]

Author: FULLER
Quote: ... a dried bracket fungus - Polyporus hasularis, called punk by the European settlers and bushmen, was collected and prized for its slow-burning properties.

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Little has been recorded of the bracket fungus [Polyporus] and its importance in the generation of fire. ... Dr G.B. Cone has spoken to an old Pakeha bushman who has used it in the Thames district where it was known as `punk' to the early settlers, who learned of its use from the Maoris. Punk burns very slowly and persistently. It can be put out only when smothered. ... Punk has now been recognised as the dried flesh of the Polyporus hosularus which may be found in many parts of the North Island.

Author: MATTHEWS
Quote:
As many as twenty
punnets of fruit
have been picked
from a single
[boysenberry] vine.

Author: HALL
Quote: Square basket in which strawberries are sold. In Dunedin they are `pottles', in Christchurch `punnets', and in the North Island `chips'.
Notes: ca1951 May Letter Miss G Hall

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: The words pottle, punnet and chip are all used for a container for strawberries and investigation of the regional distribution of these words might be of interest....

Author: LELAND
Quote: punnet: The North Island term for a SMALL BOX OF BERRIES, e.g. strawberries (see: pottle, chip)

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote: punnet
punnet n. Chiefly Brit. a small basket for fruit.

Author: BIRKENHEAD CITY COUNCIL

Later they switched
to a cardboard
punnet [for
strawberries] and I
think it's still a
cardboard punnet. A
punnet held
approximately a
pound.

There was an
instance where
customers told a
retailer they didn't
like buying
strawberries in
punnets because they
couldn't tell if the
ones at the bottom
were squishy or not.

My sister took a
punt by asking me,
and I think I
surprised a lot of
people that day,
including myself.

Author: MARSDEN
Quote:
On the following day
(August 21st) all
our works went on
well, and every
preparation was made
for completing the
punt with all
possible dispatch,
in order that the
stores might be
landed and the
settlements formed
at Kiddee Kiddee and
Manowowra.

... the other is
crossed by a

Source: Story of a NZ River, The
Author: MANDER
Quote:
Bruce had stopped
punt building on the
beach, ..

This vessel, the

New Zealand,' was a

Author: MUNDY
Quote:
... Mr Jim Ryan, who

The[??] deciding

Punt him out. [sc. a

Quote: [Our Underworld slang includes] punter, an assistant of a pickpocket who diverts the victim's attention while robbery is committed.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
That pickpocket's

Slang, 1941. Ex the

punter n. now, one who backs racehorses; once, pickpocket's assistant who diverted one's attention.

Author: BULLER
Quote: LARUS DOMINICANUS. (SOUTHERN BLACK-BACKED GULL.) ... Native names. Karoro; the young bird distinguished as Ngoiro, {Koiro, and Punua}. [271] This fine Gull, which ranges over the whole Southern Hemisphere, is extremely plentiful.

The punui [on the Snares] is a strong growing herb, which resembles ... the punui of Stewart's island. Ibid. 1/163 The most striking herbaceous plant is ... the punui, Aralia Lyallii T. Kirk, var. robusta, the large orbicular leaves of which are sometimes two feet in diameter.
For the sake of conciseness, in the following paragraphs the native name punui will be restricted to the Stewart Island plant; the generic name Stilbocarpa to that from the Auckland Islands.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Stilbocarpa polaris (The Polar Stilbocarpa) ... Auckland, Antipodes, Macquarie, and Campbell Islands. ... Maori name Punui.

Author: WODZICKI
Quote: Goats have also been placed...on small mutton bird islands in order to destroy punui (Stilbocarpa lyallii) and thus improve the islands as mutton bird grounds (R. Trail, in litt., 1947)

Author: MARTIN
Quote: The PUNUI (Stilbocarpa), an araliad with circular leaves measuring on occasion two feet across, ... occupies [the Auckland and Campbell Islands] as well as the coast of Stewart Island ... .

Author: DEMPSEY
Quote:
A deft shake ... and
the [muttonbird]
bodies were ...
neatly packed into
casks lined with the
large leaves of the
punui, a plant which
grew near the hut.

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: Stilbocarpa lyallii, the punui of Stewart Island, has less hairy leaves and reddish-purple flowers. On the mutton-bird islands where there is low Olearia forest, these plants can form a dense undergrowth ...

Author: WILSON
Quote: Stilbocarpa lyalli PUUNUI ...Robust herb forming large clumps up to 1 m or more tall.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Stilbocarpa lyalli PUUNUI ...Robust herb forming large clumps up to 1 m or more tall.

Source: In the Grip of an Island
Author: SANSOM
Quote:
Herekopare and
Woman's Island are
the only two
beneficiary
muttonbird islands.
All the rest are
Crown lands. ... I
know ... that the
fierce nettle also
grows on Herekopare.
Other lovely ...
plants are there too
- the Stewart Island
yellow senecio,
teteaweka of course,
... Cook's
health-giving scurvy
grass, soft native
tatahi grass and
punui, the
giant-leafed
umbrella-like
araliad.

While my punui (Stilbocarpa lyallii) is out of its comfort zone, it had grown well for three years since it arrived as a seed from Putauhinu, one of the most southern titi (muttonbird) islands. Back on the mainland, my punui was growing well under the cover of a sinuous brachyglottis - until the heat of our La Nina summer overwhelmed it.

The punui of the
Auckland Islands,
with leaves
sometimes 12 in.
broad, and
purple-eyed flowers,
and its near
relation on Stewart
Island, are
important members of
this family.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: The second species [of Dicksonia] known as the PUNUI or WHEKI-PONGA (D. fibrosa?) ...

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Cyathea Cunninghamii, Hook.fil. Nat. name, `Punui', Col.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Punui, Col[enso]. Cyathea Cunninghamii.

A machine under the

pup: a miniature of

Sheaves,

What could not be

Pupu - the shellfish
periwinkle (turbo
granosus).

White seashore

...

his every kina, even

The rich marine life

196 Pupu = edible

We get sea-foods:

Shell fish, such as

three days.

Quote:
You learn it from

bubu, cat gets gull.

There was a mussel
bed there, too, just
near the Kakaho
Stream, but we
mainly went after

We used to rake them

In between the

array of

Author: COLLINS

Author: LEE & KENDALL
TAYLOR
Quote: The common name for all fish is ika, or ngohengohe; of all univalve shells, pupu; and of bivalves, pipi and anga, which includes both kinds.

The younger

She'd have admired
his every kina, even

Broadfoot wanted to

with complete

[heading] Didymo

Author: POWELL
Quote: PUPUHARAKEKE or FLAX SNAIL (Placostylus hongii). ... reddish-brown coloured snail about 3 inches in height. These snails are vegetarian and feed largely upon fallen karaka leaves. They are found hidden under leaves and around sedges, but only in flax when there is no other cover.

The flax snail,
pupuharakeke, a
species endemic to
the Te Paki region.

Unuwhao has its own unique fauna. Best known are the large land snails: two sub-species of pupuharakeke ( Placostylus ambagiosus ) survive only there, along with pupurangi ( Paryphanta busbyi watti ).

FOR SALE At the
Stores of the
Undersigned, a few
good specimens of
the New Zealand
Pupurangi Shell.

Sir, - I am informed
that there exists in
New Zealand a
whistling snail,
called by the Maoris
a pupurangi. .. I am
told this snail is a
tree-climber, and
that the natives
procure them by
posting themselves
below the trees in
which the pupurangi
are located, and
that on their
whistling to them
the snails fall to
the ground, and are
then greedily
devoured by their
captors, as their
flavour is said to
be curiously
delicious.

Author: POWELL
Quote: PUPURANGI or KAURI SNAIL (Paryphanta busbyi). A North Auckland representative of a group of large carnivorous snails found only in New Zealand. The shell is a flattened spiral of dark greenish colour, about 2 1/2 to 3 inches in diameter.

For the benefit of
the inquirer, I may
state that the
pupurangi of the
Maoris is Helix
busber, and the
largest land-snail
in New Zealand. I
have three
specimens, and am
willing to sell one
or two at the price
of GBP1 5s. each,
having refused GBP1
1s. repeatedly.

CONGIOPODUS LEUCOPAECILUS (Richardson). Pigfish; Puramorua. Large numbers commonly sold throughout the year in Christchurch under the name of `silver trumpeter.' Rarely seen in Dunedin markets unless other fish are scarce. ... Distribution: South Island and southern coasts of North Island.
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote:
The Maoris call it
pupurangi, snail of
the skies - I
suppose because the
shell is sky-blue
inside or because
they found it up in
the trees.

Author: MORELAND
Quote: PIGFISH [Congiopodus leucopaecilus ] ... The Maori name puramorua is not now heard.

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Congiopodus leucopaecilus (Richardson). PIGFISH; PURAMORUA.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: PIGFISH (PURAMORUA)Congiopodus leucopaecilus (Richardson) ...

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: PIGFISH ... Other names: Congiopodus leucopaecilus; puramorua (Maori).
On asking a Maori of North Auckland if the great purangi, our largest land-shell (Paryphanta busbyi), was edible, the answer was a decided negative ...

Between the karetao
are paintings
drawing on classic
tukutuku forms like
the ascending steps
of poutama, which
stand for
advancement and
education, or
purupuru whetu, the
stars in the sky.

This fish
[scorpion-fish
Scorpaena cruenta]
is the common
scarpee of Cook
Strait and the
cobbler of Napier.
Wellington Maoris
call it ngutoro or
puraruraru ... The
cobbler differs from
the sea-perch in
having more
pronounced ridges on
the head ...

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Purau was once
plentiful in

Notes: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 65

But the memory will
be far more

Quote:
The distribution of

described by

A pure form of
methamphetamine
popular at the

It is more than

has not a good

Japan last week...
They were grown in

Nursery and include

Piously Pulverise
Purge-Purveying
Publicans.
Plenty of Purge [Title of a report of slygrogging at Ashburton].

Josephine was only
too willing to sell
to the stage navvy,
and there were in

time three other men
under the influence

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
`Come on now, force
that purge down ya
gullet and have a
man's drink with
me.'

Author: SLATTER
Quote: Great drop of purge this ... . Down the hatch. Ibid. 173 Green Band, Red Band, Gold Top, Double Brown, Nut Brown, ... all the colours of purge. Karitane yellow. What was he babysitting for on Friday night ...?

Author: GIFFORD
Quote:
As many a joker
sufferin' a return
trip lunch ... will
tell you, the old
purge will put you
flat on your back

Author: YATE
Quote: Puriri (Vitex littoralis) - This tree, from its hardness and durability, has been denominated the New-Zealand Oak; and indeed it seems to answer all the purposes of that prince of trees. ... On first examining a Puriri log, you would be inclined to reject it, on account of the many large holes that at once present themselves to notice, ...

Many other trees abounded in Pamaki [a's-acute], such as the kaikatea [a2-acute], towai, rewa-rewa, totara [a's-acute], puriri, rata [a's-acute], kahika [a2-acute], tipow, tanikaha [a2-acute], rimu, and various kinds of akkas, all of which will be found described in the Appendix (Note 7). Ibid. 2/393 The Puriri (Metrocideros florida or quercus Australis), is a wood whose durability equals any of the timbers in the country; it is very tough and close grained, and has been termed the Oak of the Pacific; but the Teak would be more appropriate, ...

By the natives the
spike was, Dr Newman
explained, called an
ahao or purupuru.

[The Maori
implement's]
genuineness has been
questioned, one
sceptic asserting
that it was neither
more nor less than a
British marlinspike;
but the carving was

portion, instead of

was also
characteristically
Maori in type ...
The late Archdeacon
Williams had told

ahao, and he found

recently, through

exactly resembling

Europeans.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Push, n. gang. The word is of late, very common in Australia. It was once a prison term. Barrere and Leland quote from M. Davitt's `Leaves from a Prison Diary,' `the upper ten push.' In thieves' English it is (I) a crowd; (2) an association for a particular robbery. In Australia, its use began with the larrikins (q.v.), and spread, until now it often means clique, set, party, and even jocularly so far as `the Government House Push.' [1890]

I used to pack the

`Perseverance Push',
...

`Diehards,' the

`Skull-Draggers,'
faced the music
before the beak.

Quote: HARESFOOT TREFOIL (Trifolium arvense), also occasionally called stone clover and pussy tail, is a weed of light dry gravelly soils and roadsides over both islands. It is an annual with greyish, downy, very inconspicuous leaves, ... and the hairy flower heads, feeling something like a hare's foot, are very characteristic.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
She threw herself
down.. trying to
believe that
pussy-grass and
paraha were growing
through her.

`Tongue-murdering'
appears to be a new
term applied to
slandering a man, or
`putting his pot on'
with intent to do
him harm.

The first [indecent
post-] card was
enough to put his
pot on.

Walsh was abusing
Mrs. Kerr, the
landlady, when she
said she would `put
his pot on' with the
police. The term is
familiar, but is
believed to have a
highly respectable
origin, `Put his pot
on!' being the death
warrant uttered by
the chief when the
early cannibals
proposed having
boiled missionary
for dinner.

Author: REES
Quote:
You ought to put the
Liquor Party's pot
on.

Squarehead and Co.
had a try to rope in
Tom Wilford to put
our pot on. Tom W.
smelt a rat and
wasn't to be had
that way.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
Next time I saw him
with a girl I was
... not to come
deliberately and
`put his pot on'

Author: SMYTH
Quote:
Dalton has put your
pot on. [i.e., told
the boss]

Author: BURTON
Quote:
... I played one of
my [prison] pals for
the life of a girl
`who had done him
wrong' or, even in
more classical
language, had `put
his pot on with the
police'.

`I been there about
the same time as you
... and I haven't
had a rise yet.
Wonder if Myers put
my pot on.'

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote: Reliable news is the dinkum oil, to inform on a person is to put his pot on, ...

`If Mrs Moore and
her child are living
in the gully no one
would put her pot
on. They would just
accept it and say
nothing about it,'
she said.

Author: MARSH
Quote:
`Reckonin' she'll
put my pot on with
the boss.'

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use
Quote:
put his pot on with
the boss
pot ... put a person's pot on NZ & Austral. sl. inform on him.

Author: MITCALFE
Quote:
The cheek of them! I
didn't `put their
pot on', ...

Author: HISLOP
Quote:
It also shows how a
smart Alec, by
saying too much, can
put his own pot on
if he is not
careful. [He lost a
sale.]

Author: Grace
Quote:
...the falling-down
house in the trees
that Rua was giving
up for the Friday

could arrange a
meeting that would
put her husband's
pot on, and, she
hoped, teach the
no-good crook a

Got the pricker with

weights up - A

that Tank - Woppit
Upper -
weight ... 3. put person's weights up NZ colloq. inform on (someone).

Quote:
...they'd been given

husband's weights

Give me three bob.
I'll put you crook

beauty.

Of a wrong answer

We'll follow the

Quote:
`I might of known

put us crook. ...
That's not Gum Bay.'

you crook don't
blame you for
packing a sad..."

Tarakahi are on the
popular possies and
it seems I may have
put you crook with

inshore and behind
White Island. The
correct ones are
37-51.981S
176-58.678E.

I'm, afraid, Mr
Browne, that your
friend has put you
crook. I think. As
yet, no decision has
been made that might
remove the use of
rainwater tanks and
force Auckland
residents to use the
reticulated water,
at a cost, of
course.

Quote:
I had shaken him off

because, when he

likely to put a man
in crook with the
provosts.

I've got no monkey

Quote:
Got a snitch on me
and put me in crook

Quote:
To refer to a

.in 4;`You'd made it

with Val while she
was away. You silly

put me in crook with

Notes: (1962-63)1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 895

Quote:
He's me cobber, and

crook with his

on account of him
being too lenient on
the after-hours
liquor trade round
here.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Tried to put me in
crook with the
missus - I'm awake
up to that one -

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
I had shaken him off
as soon as we
arrived in London on
the U.K. leave
scheme from Italy
because, when he

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
No learner has ever
been put off the
board because he has
shorn sheep well,
but many have lost
their run through
over-fast, hurried,
slip-shod, and rough
shearing.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote: This is one of the reasons that informal social control mechanisms at Paremoremo are so strong. Anybody who deviates from the required standard of thought or behaviour - the criminal standard - is quickly observed and `put on the coat' by the rest of the community. At Paremoremo you have to learn quickly to conform to criminal norms or live the life of a pariah. Ibid. 130 A lot of my old mates ... disapproved totally of what was happening and put me on the coat. We remained on speaking terms, but it wasn't the same as it had been before. . Ibid. 246 Coat (n) Put on the Coat. Ostracise, excommunicate. In the sense of reprimand, British prison slang early in this century. See also JACKET.

Author: McALPINE
Quote:
There are so many
writers trying to
get in [sc. to Mills
and Boon
publications], but
with a number of
people you can put a
ring around it: they
write what they want
and it's not what
the publishers want.

Author: KEINZLY
Quote:
`There's still a
couple of hundred
that haven't told me
yet - but they will
tonight. You can put
a ring around it!'

Author: SLATTER
Quote: Up there will be all those Wairarapa supporters with drooling green ribbons, coming down to see their team win the Ranfurly Shield. You can put a ring around that one they kept on saying in the saloon bar last night. Ibid. 60 Gotta get a good possie on the bank and see the boys win. Ya can put a ring around that one. Ibid.... if it had been she'd have had kids all right. You can put a ring around that one.

Source: Boy, The Bridge, The River, The

Quote:
`It had better be
good weather then,'
Latty said. `You can
put a ring round
that,' Len said.

'.. Made recently by

can put the ring
aroud that.' ... .
`I beg your pardon.'
... ` `Put the ring
aroud that' ? ` /
`Only that I agree
with you ... Like,
you hit the nail on

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
George pulled a wry

ring around that,
matey!' [agreeing
that the pig
couldn't be
transported]

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
But we'll nail the
bastard [sc a rogue

ring around that!

If I kept a diary,

Not because it's

you can put a ring

[Hdg] You can put a

Author: McGILL
Quote: put a shit on to denigrate or deceive; eg `Look, Pat's a past master at this, he really put a shit on you, no sweat.' NZA.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Put across a beauty. To execute a smart move: coll., mostly New Zealanders': from ca. 1911.

Author: SARGESON
Quote: put: put me right off the tucker, completely deterred me from eating the food; put nasty ones across him, score unfair points off him.

To be a dag at,' `to
put across a beaut,'
`to jerry to,' ...
need no explanation.

I put a beaut [sc.
trick] across him.
Notes: also 1950 Gaskell in 1984 Some Other Country 97

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Anyhow, to give you
the fair dinkum guts
I put across a
beauty when I found
the double-headed
penny in the ring,
and that's how I won
200 francs.

Author: McGILL
Quote: put across a beauty make a smart or tricky move; eg `Sims put across a beauty with that double dummy.' c.1910. Mostly NZ.

Source: In the Grip of an Island

Quote:
My cousin's husband

The Neck at the

memories that are

Neither is there any
putting butter on
the bacon with him.

put down your own

putangitangi : paradise duck.

Kane and his mates

seventy three bales.

Source: From the Toss of a Coin

Quote:

and he soon got the
knack of putting
down a good paddock.

Author: McGILL
Quote: put in to betray or propose; eg `He put in word that Perkins had been seen twice in the pub during office hours.'/`He put in Perkins for the thankless job of secretary.' NZA.
put in ... 6. N.Z. (tr.) to establish or appoint, esp. in relation to a farm: he put in a manager.

Quote:
neutral, to put in:
to castrate. The

operating on and
then releasing with
a view to catching
up again later in
the year.

To castrate stock:
to put into neutral.

Dry humour runs
through this
collection .. to put
into neutral - to
castrate male lambs
or calves.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
To request a loan of

regular.'

To castrate stock:
to put into neutral.

Dry humour runs
through this
collection .. to put
into neutral - to
castrate male lambs
or calves .. .

Quote:
We observed that the
natives mode of
salutation was by
putting their noses
together.

If put on hard feed,
these teeth easily
come out and leave
the animals
'gummies' in the
course of a few
weeks.

Sheep and cattle
should now be put on
their winter blocks,
keeping any animals
not up to standard
in a separate
paddock.

Mares in foal should
be put on flat
paddocks with no
drains or creeks ...

The young stock is
put on to paddocks
that become
available as the
lambs get away fat.

The hoggets have to
be drenched and
crutched before they
are put on hill
blocks.

lime in the early
days.

have put on a feed
in the woolshed.

Quote:
You get it, sonny
Jim, cripple boy,
hundreds. ... I'm
putting on the acid,
get it, should've
done it ages ago.

The Lyttelton
Stevedores' Union
seems a pretty
strong joint. When a
member of the Union
is suspended or `put

...

I did not intend to
be caught with

Kapua ... had been
put on the heavy
jacket by the Maoris
in the can, and was
sitting at a table

During the month of
April dipping should
be concluded in the
South Island, and
the rams should be
put out.

Rams are put out
towards the end of
April ...

The rams are put out
to ensure lambing
from the middle of

Source: From the Top of a Hill
Author: GASCOIGNE
Quote:
If too many rams are
put out and the ewes
are not coming into
'season' in numbers
then the males fight
amongst themselves
and there is a waste
of their powers.

Putting the rams out
used to be a fairly
simple art. If you
put your rams out
around March 10, you
could expect to get
lambs from around
August 6 on. You may
be like one of our
friends up the coast
who was asked when
he put his rams out.

Have you decided
what date you are
going to put the
rams out?

We used to put the
rams out on April 10
but we put it back a
week this year
because September's
still our pinch
period for feed.

Author: SINCLAIR & TROTTER
Quote:
One of the farmers
said to me 'I
suppose you'll soon
be thinking of
putting your rams
out. '

He began by putting
Cheviot rams over
his Romneys and then
introduced Perendale
rams to the
crossbreds to cement
in the genetic
changes.

Coopworths cut 4lb
of wool off (the
fleece weights of
progeny of) any
Romney they're put
over and endanger
meat production by
encouraging Omega
grade lambs.

A Charolais bull is
put over the cows
and the calves are
sold at the
Culverden calf
sales.

Churchill is a
beefy-type Dexter
and putting him over
our Dexter/Jersey
cross heifers will
breed some of the
characteristics out
of their offspring.

Put the Acid On
[title of a story of
fake gold jewelry
with a pun on
testing it with acid
aqua fortis, and
puttingthe pressure
on buyers with
high-pressure sales
tactics]

Gibson replied that

Goram were putting
the acid on to a
drunk, or a
half-drunk, in the
bar, other-wise
`telling him a
tale.'

Got up and shouted :
`Bosh!...'
Notes: NZ Watersider (`The Mixer')[also c1926 Transport Workers' Song Book 141]

Quote:

To put `the nips in'

put the acid on,

But although you had

Author: VIRTUE
Quote:
You get it, sonny

Quote:
But although you had
tickets and no
mistake on Ju. at

Quote:
put the back up: to

Quote:
'I'm as good as
broke and I'd just
come all the way
back from England;
and what's the first
thing that happens?'
my father says to me
years later. 'A
homey comes up and
puts the bite on
me.'

Lola comes up and

bite on me because I
am a stranger.

the bite on
housewives.

Quote:
Tony would have the
kale. But he did not
like putting the
bite on Tony.

`You'd have more
show trying to put
the bite on the
Pope.'

He's come down to
put the bite on me
for a few thousand.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
[a down-and-out
speaks] Who's going
to put the bite on -
who'll ...

From him I learned
... that it was
smart to drop your
swag in small towns
and put the bite on
the butcher, baker
and grocer.

They have no notion
of what is called
British fair play,
but like many
Britons of similar
disposition, such as
Lancashire miners
and Australian
larrikins, the
moment a man is down
they put the boot
into him and so
doing willingly
incur the risk of
committing brutal
murder.

A youth named Albert
Beaumont was charged
with inciting
Helmling to resist
the arresting
copper. According to
McCowan and
Detective Osborn, he
remarked, with
vehemence, `Put in
the boot low down;
don't go any
further.'

Raymond attacked him
`putting the boot
in'.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
`Sonny's dead for
ages. Flashing his
roll after the
shearing season. At
a party or
something. Some
pakehas got him
outside and into him
with the boot.'

Author: CRUMP
Quote:
And then he dropped
two of the blokes
who butted in to
stop him putting the
boot into Ted while
he was on the
ground.
to put the boot in: to play rough or unfairly (rugby)

Author: McGILL
Quote: boot in phrs. put in the boot/put the boot in to kick brutally, literally or metaphorically; eg `He put the boot into Happy's chances of becoming matron by spreading the old rumour about her youthful experimant with dope.' Mostly NZA.

His helmet was off,
his baton had been
taken from him, and
the crowd was in the
mood to put the boot
in.

Author: CRANE
Quote:
The police had found
him sleeping out in
one of the city
gardens and had `put
the boot in'.

All of them keeping
the worker down, by
putting in the boot.

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
... she had done him
dirty. She had `put
in the boot.'

Author: part
Quote: [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... put the boot in, to take an unfair advantage; Ibid. 287 In London, for preference; there I can have a mag to a tabby, or if any of you fellows put the boot into me in any way, I'll parade sick and join Colonel Peerless's Light Infantry at the base.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
... all the half-pie
pannikin bosses
ordering me about
because there's
no-one like the
working man for
putting the boot
into the working
man.

Author: LELAND
Quote: boot: can be used for the things you hike in, and there is an expression `to put the boot in' which means metaphorically to kick someone, as `then he really put the boot in and sent him down the road' (fired him); or gave him the boot. How ever, the commonest use of boot refers to what you would call the TRUNK of your car.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
To aim a blow at the
morale or the
material position of
him who is already
at a loss. .in
4;`He's dropped the
ball. The mug! Oh
the useless bleedin'
mug! They'd be
better off without
him.' `Well, he's
not going too good
today, but there's
no need to stick in
the boot. You didn't
say that last
Saturday when he
went like a train.'
-->to PUT THE BOOT
IN means the same
thing.
Notes: (1962-63) 1974 Syder and Hodgetts Aust and NZ English [TS] 90 [987]

Quote:
Lois puts boot into
Union [heading]
Rugby enthusiast
Lois Henare is
claiming foul play
by one of the
country's leading
unions for selling
expensive match
tickets.

In full evangelistic
cry Marcus is likely
to shout
`hallelujah', and
urge his audience to
sink the boot into
Satan.

Mac's insinuation
put the `capper' on
it and fetched them
inside.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
To put the fangs
into. To request a
loan of money or a
donation. i .in
4;`Don't give him
anything. He's
always putting the
fangs into someone.'

Author: DEVANNY
Quote:
.. he thinks she is
putting the `hard
word' on him

Author: PARK
Quote:
[in a context of an
assumed US accent]
... a cinch to get
into the big-time.
But what I calculate
you oughta do, bo,
is to see this
Thrush of Erin when
he drops into this
burg, and put the
hard word on him [to
help you]. Yeah, bo.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote:
A request for a loan
of money. .in 4;`So
I said to him,
`Well, what you want
is enough cashto pay
the deposit, and
you'd be right from
there on. Why don't
you put the hard
word on your
father-on-law? I
think he'd lend you
that much without a
murmur.'

(phrase) put the
hard word on, to
touch for a loan or
favour.
hard word n. firm request, demand; specific amatory proposal. Ibid. 16 put theacid on, hard word on, the nips in (Sl Phr.) ask for a loan or favour.

I put the hard word
on the man I
believed to be the
father and he
arranged to get some
stuff to take.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
`Difficulty was
finding somewhere to
live ... When he got
back, he put the
hard word on Siggy.
Fixed that, too.'

Author: LELAND
Quote:
hard word, put the:
see PUT THE. . . put
the hard word on: To
INSIST that a
difficult DECISION
be MADE. Usually
used in the context
of pressuring
someone to grant
sexual favours or,
`put their money
where their mouth
is' in the case of a
business deal or an
offer of marriage.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
So Morrie put the
hard word on Hank [
...who] hadn't the
heart to refuse. -

Ormsby spotted them
as he headed back to
Turangi after
helping one of nine

get underway. ... He
gave the driver the
hard word and told
him to head back to
Rangipo, and take
State Highway 4,
which was still
open.

put the hard word on
NZ & Austral. ask
(person) for loan or
(woman) for sexual
favours.
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 225

Quote:
I hummed and haa-ed
for a couple of
weeks [about having
a cancer operation],
then I really got
the hard word [from
the doctor].

Author: McGILL
Quote:
hard word, the
demand, often for
sex, often phr. put
the hard word on; eg
`Jimmy had been
putting the hard
word on Helen for
years, but she
wouldn't come
across. It wasn't as
if she had them
queuing up outside
her door, but she
had her standards.'

Author: Owen Marshall
Quote:
Michael told Rik
that he'd thought
he'd take in mainly
women as flatmates,
because if they got
a bit behind in
payments then he
could put the hard
word on them.

When one of our
clients puts the
needle in we have to
do his job before
outside work.
Notes: H.S. Gajadhar quoting a Hutt Timber and Hardware Co. contract builder

Quote:
I put the nips into
one the other night
'n he come to light
with a couple o'
dener

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
I put the nips into
the fellow in charge
for a feed
Notes: A.E. Strong WW1 scene in Partridge SlangToday

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Nips in(to), put
the. To ask a loan
(from a person):
Australian and New
Zealand: from ca.
1908. Cf. sting,
q.v., and put the
hard word on.

To put `the nips in'
and `the acid on'
are clear enough.

Put the acid on,
hard word on, the
nips in (Sl Phr.)
ask for a loan or
favour.

nip ... 11. put the
nips in (to).
Austral. & N.Z. sl.
to try to borrow
money (from).

Author: McGILL
Quote:
put the nips
in/squeeze on seek
or extract money or
a favour; eg `Watch
out, lads, Badger's
doing the rounds
again putting the
nips in/squeeze on.'
NZA.

And it's anybody's
guess what Japanese
tourists make of
such Kiwisms [sic]
as `She's apples
`put the nips in'
`feeling crook' or
`give him some
curry'.

Author: MCLEOD
Quote:
I've heard a head
shepherd say to a
man "go down to the
shed and put the red
collar on those two
dog tuckers in the
yard." He meant the
man to cut the
throats of the sheep
and skin them for
the dogs.

Author: COTTLE
Quote:
It took the parson
to `put the set on
him'

Head Word: put the wood in the hole
Quote: to put the wood in the hole: to shut the door
Notes: to put the wood in the hole: to shut the door

Quote:
Mr Linn expects to
put through a herd
of 100 Jersey cows
in ninety minutes.

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
Being but an
indifferent milker
it used to take me
quite three hours
... to put my herd
through.

Former top telly
cop, Don Selwyn, has
been adjudged
bankrupt over an
alleged $8000
maintenance bill.
The actor who
starred in
Mortimer's Patch as
the popular Sergeant
Bob Storey was `put
through' on July 2
on an application by
Auckland lawyer,
Pauline Kingi.

The number of sheep
and lambs put
through the Waingawa
freezing works for
the past year was
260,957, which was
an increase of about
6000 on the previous
year.

[Photo caption]
Interior of the
Slaughterhouse, In
which 1000 sheep a
day is often put
through.

The Undersigned
having enlarged and
improved his Plant
for "Boiling Down,"
begs to intimate to
Sheepowners that he
is now a PURCHASER
OF FAT OR LEAN SHEEP
FOR BOILING DOWN
PURPOSES, or will
"put through" Sheep
for the owners on
terms which may be
ascertained on
application.

Principally hoggets
have been put
through the sheds,
but in a couple of
weeks shearing will
be general
throughout the
district.

Put about 5000 sheep
through the yards of
which nearly 3000
must have been ewes.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
They got a good
muster of cattle,
took them to the
yards, put them
through, kept those
that were to be
tamed in the
paddock, and let the
rest out in a mob,
each to find its way
to its own beat.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
He had been overseas
and he had been up
and down the island
picking up jobs ...
Crayfishing and
scrubcutting.
Contract fencing.
Poisoning rabbits.
Even collecting
agar. On the chain
at Whakatu [166]
when they put
through 13,000 lambs
a day. Share-milking
for a while.

An effective remedy
that is being used
by some farmers is a
bath of sheep dip.
After being put
through this, the
sheep are run into a
pen that has been
well sprinkled with
dry unslaked lime,
the mosture [sic] on
the sheep's feet
causing it to
slacken and effect a
cure in conjunction
with the dip.

Author: PEAT
Quote:
.. he is putting
sheep through every
bit as quick as the
others ...

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
One cross of Lincoln
has been put through
the ewe flock.

Head Word: put to bed with a shovel
Source: In the Grip of an Island
Author: SANSOM
Quote:
I can hear my
grandfather saying;
`Do something. Don't
give in or the next
thing you know we'll
be putting him to
bed with a shovel.'

Author: HOSKEN
Quote:
No-one had mentioned
lunches to me and I
had none put up.

Author: SPENCER
Quote:
Eva, Nancy and Jean
decided to accompany
Alick and put up
lunch to enjoy a
picnic at some
chosen place.
[?1951 ECR OEDS] Put up a smoke.- To light a snowgrass bush, etc., as a signal when mustering.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
put up smoke:
musterer's means of
signalling his
whereabouts. For
example, the
top-beat man would
set light to a
tussock to indicate
that he was in
position and the
muster could begin.

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
Young Bradshaw's the
boy who is flying
this plane,/ She is
as full as a tick
and it's pouring
with rain./ Things
are not going good -
his donk's on the
blink* -/ Then he
puts up a blue and
she dives in the
drink./ [fn] *his
donk's on the blink:
his engine is giving
trouble (airman's
slang) [Charles had
served in the RNZAF
in WW2]

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Rock had put up a
run in which he
fairly excelled
himself ...

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
At Lake Coleridge
also I witnessed the
most extraordinary
run I have known a
dog to put up.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
During that trip
Flirt put up a run
that was the equal
of any head I have
seen.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
But for the fact
that his out-run was
excessively wide he
put up a good run
...

Author: BURGESS
Quote:
While we were at the
township [in Otago,
c1862 March], one of
our acquaintances
came to me and told
me there was a man
in a disreputable
shanty, that had
plenty of money and
would I come and put
him up? Now the
Wetherstone diggings
were very quiet, so
that I objected to
men being put up and
let go to alarm the
place - for I
anticipated robbing
this banker sooner
or later, and that
would do me.
Sullivan [the bushranger] said, `Here's a young fellow and a woman carrying a swag; I'll put them up.' Ibid. 18 `I'll put them [the victims] up and you give me your gun while you tie them.'

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
He's been sacked and
put up for it.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
Anyhow he'd been
sacked and put up
for it, and he'd
only got six months
probation, but
there'd been a bit
in the newspaper.

With a few eager
multisporters and
newer paddlers keen
to experience some
grade 2-3
whitewater, we
thought that a
weekend at the
Raukawa Adventure
Centre (RAC) would
be ideal. Most of us
headed up on Friday
night for an early
start on Saturday.
So, by about 9 am
our team was
assembling at the
middle put-in for
the Whangaehu River.
Notes: http://www.huttkayakers.org.nz/tripIndex.php*Accessed 17/04/2006. No date for site construction or posting.

Quote:
Craig figured that
we should try a new
put-in, on the
little known
Makotuku River...
Notes: http://www.huttkayakers.org.nz/tripIndex.php *Accessed 17/04/06. No date for site construction or posting.

Author: BULLER
Quote: SPATULA {RHYNCAPSIS} VARIEGATA. (NEW-ZEALAND SHOVELLER.) ... Native name. Tete, {Pateke,} Putaitai, Kuriwhengi, {Kuruwhengu, Papaungungu,} Kahoho, and Wetawetangu; `Spoon-bill Duck' of the colonists.

Author: HAY
Quote: The species we have identified in the Kaipara and Hokianga are - the Putangi, or `paradise-duck' (Casarca variegata); the grey duck, or Parera (Anas superciliosa); the brown duck, an allied species or variety of the last; the Papanga, or `teal,' or `widgeon' (Fuligula N.Z.), and some other varieties that may be imported birds, or crosses, or other native species.

Both sanctuaries in
the Botanical
andWoodhaugh Gardens
are live
withwaterfowl, the
grey duck (parera)
beingespecially
numerous though
there are alsothe
Paradise Duck
(Putangitangi).

There are many of
the duck tribe, and
amongst them the
paradise duck
(putangitangi) is
particularly
abundant.

I was bathing the
other morning in a
small river when a
brood of young
putangitangi rushed
impetuously from the
thick toitoi bushes
on the water margin
and splashed in
close beside me.

Henry left at 6.0 in
his yacht, the
Putangi.

The hunters caught
poaka (wild pigs),
parera (grey duck),
putakitaki (paradise
duck), kereru or
kuku (pigeon), and
hurepo (bittern).

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: 59. Casarca variegata. ... Pooa dugghie dugghie of the natives of Dusky Bay. Forst. Putangi tangi of the natives of Cook's Strait; Paradise Duck of the settlers. Dieffenbach.
Notes: 1842 Gray's Fauna in 1843 Dieffenbach Travels in NZ 2/198

Author: SELWYN
Vol / Page: NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 12
Quote:
Walked along shingly
beach ... to a large
pool by the side of
the sea, in which
were swimming a
number of
Putangitangi, or
Paradise Ducks, ...
this being the
season of their
moulting.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
Putangitangi -
Paradise duck

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote:
In the afternoon, we
... were fortunate
enough to shoot some
`putangitangi' for
supper. This bird
has obtained the
name of paradise
duck, from the
beauty of its
plumage: ...

Author: WAKEFIELD
Notes: [take in quot p. 340 under Paradise duck]

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: ... the paradise duck, or Pu-tangi-tangi, (Caesarea variegata,) is remarkable for its size, for the beauty of its plumage, and the delicacy of its flesh.

Author: McLEAN
Quote: We caught some young putangitangi or Paradise ducks.
Notes: 1850 Dec 6 Mclean Diary in 1940 Cowan Sir Donald Maclean 59

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: PUTAKITAKI (carsarca variegata),;a duck with beautiful plumage, rather larger than the common grey variety. It is very common in the south of New Zealand, and is generally known as the paradise duck.

CASARCA VARIEGATA,
Gml. Putangitangi.
Paradise Duck.

Author: BULLER
Quote: CASARCA VARIEGATA. (NEW ZEALAND SHELDRAKE.) ... Native names. Putangitangi; Putakitaki in the South Island; `Paradise Duck' of the colonists.

Putakitaki - the
celebrated paradise
duck, once abundant.
Notes: c1880 South Island Maori Lists `Wahi Mahika Kai' in 1945 Beattie Maori Place-names of Canterbury 64

Quote: Casarca variegata. - Putangitangi, Paradise Duck. Both Islands.

Author: WILSON
Quote: ... her precious Paradise ducks [fn Maori Putangi tangi] had discovered that their wings ... were now strong enough for flight ...
Notes: 1891 Mar 9 in 1894 Wilson Land of the Tui 176

Author: TREGEAR
Quote: The paradise duck (putangi-tangi: Casarca variegata) a bird of beautiful plumage, but not of such flavour as the grey duck or teal, was considered a prize.

Author: COWAN
Quote: The town [Nelson] itself is sweet ...; there is a pretty park ... with a ... lakelet alive with swan and putangitangi or paradise duck; ...
putangitangi a bird (Casarca variegata), a goose but called the paradise-duck; always found in pairs.

Author: POWELL
Quote: PARADISE DUCK (Casarca variegate), Putangitangi of the Maoris, is a handsome bird variously mottled, freckled and lined with brown and white on a brownish to black ground.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: PARADISE DUCK Tadorna variegata Other names: Putangitangi, Rangitata Goose. Description: 25' Of intermediate size between the ducks and the larger species (Canada Goose and swans).

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Paradise Shelduck Tadorna variegata (GMELIN, 1789) ... OTHER NAMES: Paradise duck, pari, putangitangi.

Author: MIKAERE
Quote:
There were
putakitaki (paradise
ducks), parera (grey
ducks), tataa (brown
ducks) and whio
(blue ducks). ...
The pukeko
(swamphen) were
caught only as a
last resort, because
their flesh was
stringy and tough.

The native name of
this duck,
"putangitangi," is
said to have
reference to the
call, which is
likened to a lament.

Author: HULME & MORRISON
Quote:
hear the tolling of
putangitangiatoa the
paradise shelduck
trumpeting to its
ever-faithful mate

The native name [sc.
of the paradise
duck] is
Putangi-tangi, which
means the waterfowl
that makes a great
funeral crying - and
this she does to
perfection with her
loud clarionet
vocal.

Author: FEATON
Quote:
Piripiriwhata [Maori
name] .. Puta-puta
[Settlers' name] ..
Carpodetus serratus
.. Shrub

[Native name]
Putaputa-weta ..
[Family] Saxifrageae
Notes: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122

Author: FEATON
Quote: CARPODETUS SERRATUS (|Forst.) ... The `PUTA-PUTA-WETA'.- This graceful looking shrub, or sometimes small tree, is found in both the Northern and Middle Islands.

Putaputa-weta
(piripiriwhata) ..
Carpodetus serratus
.. Timber white and
open of grain; ...

Author: CHEESEMAN
Quote: C[arpodetus] serratus, Forst. ... Piripiriwhata; Putaputawheta.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Carpodetus serratus (The Serrate Carpodetus)... The native name Puta-puta-weta signifies full of weta holes. In the North Island trees of this species are rarely cut down unperforated by longitudinal insect galleries. Another name by which it is known is Puna-weta. In the Urewera country it is called Kai-weta (i.e., weta food). [That ugly innocent the weta (Deinacrida) has thus been accused of perforating the tree; but as a matter of fact though often used as convenient residences [195] by the weta, the holes are made by the caterpillar of the large moth Hepialus virescens... ].

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: The putaputaweta (Carpodetus serratus) is a rival of the English may.

Source: Field Guide to Common NZ Trees & Shrubs
Quote: PUTAPUTAWETA/ (Marble Leaf)/ Carpodetus serratus/ ... Leaves have a marbled effect.

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: CARPODETUS SERRATUS, putaputaweta, marble-leaf. ... It is one of the species grouped by foresters under the slightly opprobrious term `scrub hardwoods'.

352 Lithograph of
putaputaweta
(piripiriwhata)
foliage.

...the drive back to
our base at Okuru is
made more pleasant
by avenues of
flowering kamahi and
the occasional
sweet-smelling
putaputaweta.

PUTAPUTAWTA or
marble leaf
(carpodetus
serratus) is a
handsome small tree
with fabulous
floiage and
fragreant flowers.
Much of it's beauty
is in the mottled
appearance of its
leaves, the veins of
which are a darker
green than the leaf
blade, hence the
English common name
of marble leaf.

In exchange they
were give [sic] a
choice of native
plants such as
tarata, karamu,
totara, kohuhu,
broadleaf,
mingimingi,
putaputaweta,
harakeke (flax) and
cabbage tree.
putara: trumpet.

From his office, Dr
Pita Sharples,
63-year-old Hoani
Waititi Chairman,
kapa haka king,
tikanga Maori
champion, recently
retired professor of
education and
co-leader of the new
Maori Party, can see
the children play
and hear the
putatara
(traditional pipe)
calling them to
lessons.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
[W.H.S. Roberts
writes] we also
carried
`touch-paper' ...,
as well as a fungus
that grew on the
black birch called
punk, or by the
Maoris putawa.

Author: HOOKER
Quote: Putawa, [Colenso]. Boletus.

...he and his
colleagues began the
process of reading
aloud the names of
the claimants, and
delivering to them
the putea, each copy
of their report in a
simple flax kete.

The trust had made a
great deal of money
out of the levies it
put on the
operational grants
sent to the kohanga,
and from the
property putea, the
fund built up from
property loans to
kohanga.

ANAS CHLOROTIS,
Gray. Puteke. Teal.

In recent months I
have drawn two
arrows, as it were
from my own Maori
lexicon. I used the
word tangata whenua
to describe locals.
I used the word
putiputi to describe
freeloaders. This
last word is not to
be found in any
standard Maori
dictionary but was
in common usage a
good while ago.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
The Putiritiri, of
the same order [as
Karamu, coprosma
sp.], is a beautiful
tree with a small
leaf, and also the
Taupata, which
having a fine bright
leaf is a very
ornamental tree; ...

Author: HOLMES
Quote: Cyathodes robusta (Putiritiri but known as Mingimingi in the mainland) ...

fingers playing the
putorino on
keyboards / of
coroporate hardware
- / - there is not
an adze in sight

Mr Taylor will
incorporate music
from the guitar and
the putorino, a
Maori flute, into
his performances.

On Sunday, he will
play the koauau - an
end-blown flute -
the putorino - an
instrument that is
both flute and
trumpet at the same
time - the pukaea -
a "lusty and
spectacular"
six-foot long
trumpet - and the
nguru - a tiny
wooden flute played
with the nose.

Nunns played a
Putatara, a shell
trumpet; a
Pumotomoto, a wooden
flute and a
Putorino, both a
trumpet and a flute.

Source: Grammar & Vocabulary of the Language of NZ

Author: BULLER
Quote: ORTYGOMETRA TABUENSIS. (SWAMP-RAIL.) ... Native names.- Pueto and Putoto.
Ortygometra tabuensis. - Putoto, Swamp Crake. Both Islands; Australia, Tasmania, Polynesia. Sparingly dispersed throughout New Zealand.

Author: HAY
Quote: The Putoto (Ortygometra Tabuensis) is a crake, often confounded by settlers with the patatai. It is a smaller bird altogether, having partridge tints on the back, and a grey breast. It chiefly inhabits raupo swamps.

Quote:
Not on the job - I
had this old
puttabomb of a car,
and anyway the cops
pulled it over,
found all this
property in it. So I
went to jail.
Notes: 'The Feijoa is Brother to the Guava', David Eggleton, 2007

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Quote:
A fortnight before
its sittings, Mr.
Peter Proudfoot,
Chief Commissioner
of Lands, died, and
the Superintendent
appointed his own
son-in-law, Mr.
Cutten, to the
vacant post, which
was in the gift of
the Executive and
should have been
filled by them. In
his opening speech
to the Council he
justified this
action, or rather
rode roughshod over
any objections to
it. `Now,' he said,
`I would have Mr.
Cutten and all
others to know that
I am in no degree to
be swayed from doing
what I have a right
to do - to put the
right man into the
right place -
whether that man
happens to be my
son-in-law or any
one else' - a mode
of speech now known
amongst politicians
as `putting on
hobnailed boots.'

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
... chalking the
curved E on the
empty waggons, the
railwayman's
shorthand like PDK
for paddock, the
wide Waltham Yards
outside, and PUTTY
SHOP for the
Addington Workshops.

They consist of a
cluster of Erina
Autumnalis and rata
blossoms, shown in

Industrial
Exhibition;
flowering manuka- a

Arts Exhibition ; a
bunch of Alpine
daisies, and a group
of Clematis
indivita, the native
name for which is
Puawhananga.

The large white
Clematis indivisa is
called by the
natives Puawhananga.

Puwhananga. Clematis
indivisa, Willd.

Author: BULLER
Quote: The puwharawhara (Astelia cunninghamii) is a parasitical plant, with short, thickly set flag-leaves, radiating upwards from a clump of roots by which it adheres firmly to the parent tree.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ... the Weka has placed her nest under the shelter, forming it of dry flags of the puwharawhara (Astelia Cunninghamii) loosely arranged.

Speaking of the
Treaty we were very
nearly breaking one
of its provisions,
that which related
to parumoana or mud
flats, ... It arose
out of a proposal of
the Unemployment
Board, backed by
P.W.D., Lands and
Marine, to reclaim
mudflats at
Hokianga, Whangarei
and Whangaroa.

Author: BAILEY & ROTH
Quote:
I recall the lone
days in the ranges,/
In camps of the
P.W.D.
Notes: 1962 Aug Fernfire No 9 in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 137

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: ... I told my little friend that I was going to a job in the Public Works Department (PWD) in Southland ... . He then told me of a [3] few PWD paymasters. Ibid. 95 In the PWD there was a sprinkling of what were known as `compo kings'. These were men who always seemed to be on compo [either by bad luck, accident prone-ness, or malingering].

Author: GRADY
Quote:
In a rather
roundabout way, it
was the PWD who were
instrumental in
bringing Trevor back
to harpooning duties
in war-time.

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
I'll see that P.W.D.
joker next week.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
Juvenile
delinquency. What
about us? ... [10]
... Bowling the
P.W.D. wheelbarrows
over the bank and
down the hill.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
For a number of
married men there
were transfers to
other P.W.D. jobs.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
So too were some of
the tougher elements
of the PWD (Public
Works Department)
men, who took two
years to build the
Whekenui gun
emplacement [in
1943].

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
The men lived in the
Public Works
Department (P.W.D.)
tents which were
supplied with a
wooden floor and tin
fireplace.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Cosmos the comforter
of a thousand raw
huts in raw clay in
raw seacoast or raw
inland valley on
godforsaken PWD and
Railway and Hydro
projects.

Author: DEMPSEY
Quote:
And she took me to
meetings of the
P.W.M.U. and the
Women's Institute
...

We have been aiming
for heavy lean lambs
in the YX and PX
grades by rearing
Suffolk cross ram
lambs. Now, with the
new schedule prices,
we have to be wary
of falling into the
fatter PX grade
where an 18kg PX
lamb now has the
same value as a 14
kg YM lamb.

Author: JACKSON
Quote:
`You fight Nazis,
too, eh Hori?' `Py
corrie, yes.'
Notes: This needs checking to see if correctly under gorry or mis-copied.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Pycroft's Petrel Pterodroma pycrofti FALLA, 1933 ... Endangered species; world population less than 500 pairs. Breeds off the east coast of northern New Zealand ...

Indeed, rare species
such as Pycroft's
petrel, Duvaucel's
gecko and the New
Zealand native
cucumber are all
showing signs of
regaining their
foothold on these
islands.

Rare and endangered
species which stand
to benefit from the
work include..
Pycroft's petrel,
the little spotted
kiwi, takahe and
possibly the North
Island kaka and
kokako.

New Zealand's wet
alpine areas are
home to what is
thought to be the
world's smallest
conifer, the pygmy
pine, Lepidothamnus
laxifolius. This
"pine" doesn't even
make it as a shrub,
let alone a forest
specimen, but
spreads in a
cushion.
Dacrydium laxifolium pigmy pine
Notes: (And) Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of the Tongariro National Park

Quote: Dacrydium laxifolium pigmy pine
Notes: Cockayne Report on a Botanical Survey of Stewart Island (And)

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Dacrydium laxifolium (The Loose-leaved Dacrydium). ... Pigmy pine.

Author: HUNT
Quote: It (New Zealand) has the largest tree in the world in the Kauri ... and the smallest pine in the world, the Pygmy Pine (Dacrydium laxifolium ), of sub-alpine areas, the height of which is normally about twelve inches ...

Author: MARTIN
Quote: To this genus belong the PYGMY PINE (D[acrydium] laxifolium), the smallest conifer in the world.

Author: MARK & ADAMS
Quote: Small trailing shrubs - the pygmy pine (Dacrydium laxifolium ), creeping heath plants -dracophyllums (D. prostratum, D. politum), Pentachondra pumila, Cyathodes pumila and C. empetrifolia, also Coprosma pumila are typical of peat bogs.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Dacrydium laxifolium PYGMY PINE ...Sprawling shrub with long, flexible branches. ...

Author: DAWSON
Quote: The pigmy pine (Lepidothamnus laxifolius), sometimes called the smallest conifer in the world, forms even lower mat-like patches in poorly drained sites ...

The "pygmy sleeper"
- or Thalasseleotris
iota - grows to just
39.4mm in length.

The New Zealand
pygmy weed, taken to
Britain as an
aquarium plant, has
recently been
discovered invading
waterways there.

And dogs, madam,
